Stenciler: One who paints or colors in figures by means of stencil.
Semiquadrate: An aspect of the planets when distant from each other the half of a quadrant, or forty-five degrees, or one sign and a half.
Supratemporal: Situated above the temporal bone or temporal fossa.
Spathal: Furnished with a spathe; as, spathal flowers.
Saltcellar: Formerly a large vessel, now a small vessel of glass or other material, used for holding salt on the table.
Self-communion: Communion with one's self; thoughts about one's self.
Sternothyroid: Of or pertaining to the sternum and the thyroid cartilage.
Sensate: Felt or apprehended through a sense, or the senses.
Scythewhet: Wilson's thrush; -- so called from its note.
Shoading: The tracing of veins of metal by shoads.
Samoan: Of or pertaining to the Samoan Islands (formerly called Navigators' Islands) in the South Pacific Ocean, or their inhabitants.
&Verbar;Sostenuto: Sustained; -- applied to a movement or passage the sounds of which are to sustained to the utmost of the nominal value of the time; also, to a passage the tones of which are to be somewhat prolonged or protacted.
Successor: One who succeeds or follows; one who takes the place which another has left, and sustains the like part or character; -- correlative to predecessor; as, the successor of a deceased king.
Slopshop: A shop where slops. or ready-made clothes, are sold.
Secularism: The state or quality of being secular; a secular spirit; secularity.
Shucker: One who shucks oysters or clams
Secularist: One who theoretically rejects every form of religious faith, and every kind of religious worship, and accepts only the facts and influences which are derived from the present life; also, one who believes that education and other matters of civil policy should be managed without the introduction of a religious element.
Spurt: To make a sudden and violent exertion, as in an emergency.
Sugar: To impregnate, season, cover, or sprinkle with sugar; to mix sugar with.
Sneezeweed: A yellow-flowered composite plant (Helenium autumnale) the odor of which is said to cause sneezing.
Sergeanty: Tenure of lands of the crown by an honorary kind of service not due to any lord, but to the king only.
Sack: To plunder or pillage, as a town or city; to devastate; to ravage.
Scandalously: In a manner to give offense; shamefully.
Stipule: An appendage at the base of petioles or leaves, usually somewhat resembling a small leaf in texture and appearance.
Sacs: A tribe of Indians, which, together with the Foxes, formerly occupied the region about Green Bay, Wisconsin.
Superstratum: A stratum, or layer, above another.
Serrulate: Finely serrate; having very minute teeth.
Sandy: Consisting of, abounding with, or resembling, sand; full of sand; covered or sprinkled with sand; as, a sandy desert, road, or soil.
Screw: To use violent mans in making exactions; to be oppressive or exacting.
Sensitometer: An instrument or apparatus for comparing and grading the sensitiveness of plates, films, etc., as a screen divided into squares of different shades or colors, from which a picture is made on the plate to be tested.
Strewing: The act of scattering or spreading.
Sea purse: The horny egg case of a skate, and of certain sharks.
Scree: A pebble; a stone; also, a heap of stones or rocky débris.
Satiate: To satisfy the appetite or desire of; to feed to the full; to furnish enjoyment to, to the extent of desire; to sate; as, to satiate appetite or sense.
Superable: Capable of being overcome or conquered; surmountable.
Sapient: Wise; sage; discerning; -- often in irony or contempt.
Standard-wing: A curious paradise bird (Semioptera Wallacii) which has two long special feathers standing erect on each wing.
Sub-bass: The deepest pedal stop, or the lowest tones of an organ; the fundamental or ground bass.
Slide rule: a thin, flat calculating device consisting of a fixed outer piece and a movable middle piece.  Both pieces are graduated in such a way (as, by a logarithmic scale) that multiplication, division, and other mathematical functions of an input variable may be rapidly determined by movement of the middle pieces to a location on one scale corresponding to the input value, and reading off the result on another scale.  A movable window with a hairline assists in alignment of the scales.  This device has been largely superseded by the electronic calculator, which has a greater precision than the slide rule.  Also called colloquially slipstick.
Sub-base: The lowest member of a base when divided horizontally, or of a baseboard, pedestal, or the like.
Southpaw: A pitcher who pitches with the left hand.
Synonym: One of two or more words (commonly words of the same language) which are equivalents of each other; one of two or more words which have very nearly the same signification, and therefore may often be used interchangeably. See under Synonymous.
Sioux: A nation of American Indians; see Dakotas.
&Verbar;Spirituelle: Of the nature, or having the appearance, of a spirit; pure; refined; ethereal.
Swindler: One who swindles, or defrauds grossly; one who makes a practice of defrauding others by imposition or deliberate artifice; a cheat.
Self-evolution: Evolution of one's self; development by inherent quality or power.
Shoplifting: Larceny committed in a shop; the stealing of anything from a shop.
Sutural: Of or pertaining to a suture, or seam.
&Verbar;Septarium: A flattened concretionary nodule, usually of limestone, intersected within by cracks which are often filled with calcite, barite, or other minerals.
Stanhope: A light two-wheeled, or sometimes four-wheeled, carriage, without a top; -- so called from Lord Stanhope, for whom it was contrived.
Spectrograph: An apparatus for photographing or mapping a spectrum.
Secretive: Tending to secrete, or to keep secret or private; as, a secretive disposition.
Stereochromy: A style of painting on plastered walls or stone, in which the colors are rendered permanent by sprinklings of water, in which is mixed a proportion of soluble glass (a silicate of soda).
Surloin: A loin of beef, or the upper part of the loin. See Sirloin, the more usual, but not etymologically preferable, orthography.
&Verbar;Saraswati: The sakti or wife of Brahma; the Hindoo goddess of learning, music, and poetry.
Septangle: A figure which has seven angles; a heptagon.
Sphagnicolous: Growing in moss of the genus Sphagnum.
Swingle: A wooden instrument like a large knife, about two feet long, with one thin edge, used for beating and cleaning flax; a scutcher; -- called also swingling knife, swingling staff, and swingling wand.
Subovate: Nearly in the form of an egg, or of the section of an egg, but having the inferior extremity broadest; nearly ovate.
Sasse: A sluice or lock, as in a river, to make it more navigable.
Slate: To set a dog upon; to bait; to slat. See 2d Slat, 3.
&Verbar;Steatopyga: A remarkable accretion of fat upon the buttocks of Africans of certain tribes, especially of Hottentot (Khoikhoi) women.
Slaty: Resembling slate; having the nature, appearance, or properties, of slate; composed of thin parallel plates, capable of being separated by splitting; as, a slaty color or texture.
Salework: Work or things made for sale; hence, work done carelessly or slightingly.
Slatt: A slab of stone used as a veneer for coarse masonry.
Stonechat: A small, active, and very common European singing bird (Pratincola rubicola); -- called also chickstone, stonechacker, stonechatter, stoneclink, stonesmith.
&Verbar;Soulili: A long-tailed, crested Javan monkey (Semnopithecus mitratus).  The head, the crest, and the upper surface of the tail, are black.
Snapshot: A quick offhand shot, made without deliberately taking aim over the sights.
Scroll: A roll of paper or parchment; a writing formed into a roll; a schedule; a list.
Spear: To shoot into a long stem, as some plants. See Spire.
Saliretin: A yellow amorphous resinoid substance obtained by the action of dilute acids on saligenin.
Skelter: To run off helter-skelter; to hurry; to scurry; -- with away or off.
Scaramouch: A personage in the old Italian comedy (derived from Spain) characterized by great boastfulness and poltroonery; hence, a person of like characteristics; a buffoon.
Sanderling: A small gray and brown sandpiper (Calidris arenaria) very common on sandy beaches in America, Europe, and Asia. Called also curwillet, sand lark, stint, and ruddy plover.
&Verbar;Saucisson: A long and slender pipe or bag, made of cloth well pitched, or of leather, filled with powder, and used to communicate fire to mines, caissons, bomb chests, etc.
&Verbar;Schesis: General state or disposition of the body or mind, or of one thing with regard to other things; habitude.
Spermologist: One who treats of, or collects, seeds.
Soldierwood: A showy leguminous plant (Calliandra purpurea) of the West Indies. The flowers have long tassels of purple stamens.
&Verbar;Salvia: A genus of plants including the sage. See Sage.
Skean: A knife or short dagger, esp. that in use among the Highlanders of Scotland. [Variously spelt.]
Specimen: A part, or small portion, of anything, or one of a number of things, intended to exhibit the kind and quality of the whole, or of what is not exhibited; a sample; as, a specimen of a man's handwriting; a specimen of a person's blood; a specimen of painting; aspecimen of one's art.
Somnambulistic: Of or pertaining to a somnambulist or somnambulism; affected by somnambulism; appropriate to the state of a somnambulist.
Subcontractor: One who takes a portion of a contract, as for work, from the principal contractor.
Savingly: In a saving manner; with frugality or parsimony.
Stipuled: Furnished with stipules, or leafy appendages.
Sambur: An East Indian deer (Rusa Aristotelis) having a mane on its neck. Its antlers have but three prongs. Called also gerow. The name is applied to other species of the genus Rusa, as the Bornean sambur (R. equina).
Sterhydraulic: Pertaining to, or designating, a kind of hydraulic press; resembling such a press in action or principle.
Slumgum: The impure residue, consisting of cocoons, propolis, etc., remaining after the wax is extracted from honeycombs.
Sloughy: Resembling, or of the nature of, a slough, or the dead matter which separates from living flesh.
Suzerainty: The dominion or authority of a suzerain; paramount authority.
Stagirite: A native of, or resident in, Stagira, in ancient Macedonia; especially, Aristotle.
Sorrel: One of various plants having a sour juice; especially, a plant of the genus Rumex, as Rumex Acetosa, Rumex Acetosella, etc.
Surplice: A white garment worn over another dress by the clergy of the Roman Catholic, Episcopal, and certain other churches, in some of their ministrations.
San Jos\u00e9 scale: A very destructive scale insect (Aspidiotus perniciosus) that infests the apple, pear, and other fruit trees. So called because first introduced into the United States at San José, California.
Swordsmanship: The state of being a swordsman; skill in the use of the sword.
Synteretics: That department of medicine which relates to the preservation of health; prophylaxis.
Semilogical: Half logical; partly logical; said of fallacies.
Sciomachy: A fighting with a shadow; a mock contest; an imaginary or futile combat.
Slatternly: Resembling a slattern; sluttish; negligent; dirty.
Sumptuary: Relating to expense; regulating expense or expenditure.
Speechmaker: One who makes speeches; one accustomed to speak in a public assembly.
Semiligneous: Half or partially ligneous, as a stem partly woody and partly herbaceous.
Solicitude: The state of being solicitous; uneasiness of mind occasioned by fear of evil or desire good; anxiety.
Sea leopard: Any one of several species of spotted seals, especially Ogmorhinus leptonyx, and Leptonychotes Weddelli, of the Antarctic Ocean. The North Pacific sea leopard is the harbor seal.
Sideration: The state of being siderated, or planet-struck; esp., blast in plants; also, a sudden and apparently causeless stroke of disease, as in apoplexy or paralysis.
Synthesis: Composition, or the putting of two or more things together, as in compounding medicines.
Smithy: The workshop of a smith, esp. a blacksmith; a smithery; a stithy.
Synchoresis: A concession made for the purpose of retorting with greater force.
Splinter: A thin piece split or rent off lengthwise, as from wood, bone, or other solid substance; a thin piece; a sliver; as, splinters of a ship's mast rent off by a shot.
Short-wited: Having little wit; not wise; having scanty intellect or judgment.
Superficialize: To attend to, or to treat, superficially, or in a shallow or slighting way.
Spangler: One who, or that which, spangles.
Subhornblendic: Containing hornblende in a scattered state; of or relating to rocks containing disseminated hornblende.
Smarten: To make smart or spruce; -- usually with up.
Synallaxine: Having the outer and middle toes partially united; -- said of certain birds related to the creepers.
Sizy: Sizelike; viscous; glutinous; as, sizy blood.
Subspherical: Nearly spherical; having a figure resembling that of a sphere.
Steeply: In a steep manner; with steepness; with precipitous declivity.
Seth: An evil beast-headed god with high square ears and a long snout; his was the brother and murderer of Osiris.  Called also Set
Sojourn: A temporary residence, as that of a traveler in a foreign land.
Skeletogenous: Forming or producing parts of the skeleton.
Sea wall: A wall, or embankment, to resist encroachments of the sea.
Sarcocele: Any solid tumor of the testicle.
&Verbar;Serai: A palace; a seraglio; also, in the East, a place for the accommodation of travelers; a caravansary, or rest house.
Sarcophagus: A species of limestone used among the Greeks for making coffins, which was so called because it consumed within a few weeks the flesh of bodies deposited in it. It is otherwise called lapis Assius, or Assian stone, and is said to have been found at Assos, a city of Lycia.
Shield: To cover with, or as with, a shield; to cover from danger; to defend; to protect from assault or injury.
Start: A tail, or anything projecting like a tail.
Suba\u00ebrial: Beneath the sky; in the open air; specifically (Geol.), taking place on the earth's surface, as opposed to subaqueous.
Shame: To be ashamed; to feel shame.
&Verbar;Sycosis: A pustular eruption upon the scalp, or the beared part of the face, whether due to ringworm, acne, or impetigo.
Story-writer: One who writes short stories, as for magazines.
Shyly: In a shy or timid manner; not familiarly; with reserve.
Solitary: One who lives alone, or in solitude; an anchoret; a hermit; a recluse.
Shunt valve: A valve permitting a fluid under pressure an easier avenue of escape than normally; specif., a valve, actuated by the governor, used in one system of marine-engine governing to connect both ends of the low-pressure cylinder as a supplementary control.
&Verbar;Schindylesis: A form of articulation in which one bone is received into a groove or slit in another.
Sublingual: Situated under the tongue; as, the sublingual gland.
Sea holly: An evergeen seashore plant (Eryngium maritimum). See Eryngium.
Subalpine: Inhabiting the somewhat high slopes and summits of mountains, but considerably below the snow line.
Scalar: In the quaternion analysis, a quantity that has magnitude, but not direction; -- distinguished from a vector, which has both magnitude and direction.
Similor: An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, but of a golden color.
Septinsular: Consisting of seven islands; as, the septinsular republic of the Ionian Isles.
Shotgun: A light, smooth-bored gun, often double-barreled, especially designed for firing small shot at short range, and killing small game.
Swiftness: The quality or state of being swift; speed; quickness; celerity; velocity; rapidity; as, the swiftness of a bird; the swiftness of a stream; swiftness of descent in a falling body; swiftness of thought, etc.
Serially: In a series, or regular order; in a serial manner; as, arranged serially; published serially.
Soak: To lie steeping in water or other liquid; to become sturated; as, let the cloth lie and soak.
Super: A contraction of Supernumerary, in sense  2.
Shredcook: The fieldfare; -- so called from its harsh cry before rain.
Syrtic: Of or pertaining to a syrt; resembling syrt, or quicksand.
Sinistral: Of or pertaining to the left, inclining to the left; sinistrous; -- opposed to dextral.
Seedsman: A sower; one who sows or scatters seed.
&Verbar;Salisburia: The ginkgo tree (Ginkgo biloba, or Salisburia adiantifolia).
Scantiness: Quality or condition of being scanty.
&Verbar;Sulcus: A furrow; a groove; a fissure.
Strombuliform: Formed or shaped like a top.
Soft: Be quiet; hold; stop; not so fast.
Shroffage: A money dealer's commission; also, more commonly, the examination of coins, and the separation of the good from the debased.
Skyey: Like the sky; ethereal; being in the sky.
Speciality: A particular or peculiar case; a particularity.
Serpentinous: Relating to, or like, serpentine; as, a rock serpentinous in character.
Sea fern: Any gorgonian which branches like a fern.
Schooling: Collecting or running in schools or shoals.
Schwanns white substance: The substance of the medullary sheath.
Sea gull: Any gull living on the seacoast.
Seaweed: Popularly, any plant or plants growing in the sea.
Spectroheliogram: A photograph of the sun made by monochromatic light, usually of the calcium line (k), and showing the sun's faculæ and prominences.
Sententiosity: The quality or state of being sententious.
Saymaster: A master of assay; one who tries or proves.
&Verbar;Sciuromorpha: A tribe of rodents containing the squirrels and allied animals, such as the gophers, woodchucks, beavers, and others.
String: To form into a string or strings, as a substance which is stretched, or people who are moving along, etc.
Sinewless: Having no sinews; hence, having no strength or vigor.
Stringer: One who strings; one who makes or provides strings, especially for bows.
&Verbar;Stela: A small column or pillar, used as a monument, milestone, etc.
Staith: A landing place; an elevated staging upon a wharf for discharging coal, etc., as from railway cars, into vessels.
Sensorium: The seat of sensation; the nervous center or centers to which impressions from the external world must be conveyed before they can be perceived; the place where external impressions are localized, and transformed into sensations, prior to being reflected to other parts of the organism; hence, the whole nervous system, when animated, so far as it is susceptible of common or special sensations.
Sisyphean: Relating to Sisyphus; incessantly recurring; as, Sisyphean labors.
Sorely: In a sore manner; grievously; painfully; as, to be sorely afflicted.
Self-repetition: Repetition of one's self or of one's acts; the saying or doing what one has already said or done.
Straightener: One who, or that which, straightens.
Shaman: A priest of Shamanism; a wizard among the Shamanists.
Santonin: A white crystalline substance having a bitter taste, extracted from the buds of levant wormseed and used as an anthelmintic. It occassions a peculiar temporary color blindness, causing objects to appear as if seen through a yellow glass.
suricat: A South African mongooselike viverrine (Suricata suricatta or Suricata tetradactyla) having a lemurlike face and only four toes; called also mierkat, yellow mongoose and zenick.
Santonic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid (distinct from santoninic acid) obtained from santonin as a white crystalline substance.
Stratonic: Of or pertaining to an army.
Starriness: The quality or state of being starry; as, the starriness of the heavens.
Superficiary: Of or pertaining to the superficies, or surface; superficial.
Seraph: One of an order of celestial beings, each having three pairs of wings. In ecclesiastical art and in poetry, a seraph is represented as one of a class of angels.
Scattering: Act of strewing about; something scattered.
Salicylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid formerly obtained by fusing salicin with potassium hydroxide, and now made in large quantities from phenol (carbolic acid) by the action of carbon dioxide on heated sodium phenolate. It is a white crystalline substance. It is used as an antiseptic, and in its salts in the treatment of rheumatism. Called also hydroxybenzoic acid.
Soricine: Of or pertaining to the Shrew family (Soricidæ); like a shrew in form or habits; as, the soricine bat (Glossophaga soricina).
Stroboscope: An instrument for studying or observing the successive phases of a periodic or varying motion by means of light which is periodically interrupted.
Sneezewort: A European herbaceous plant (Achillea Ptarmica) allied to the yarrow, having a strong, pungent smell.
Singingly: With sounds like singing; with a kind of tune; in a singing tone.
Self-degradation: The act of degrading one's self, or the state of being so degraded.
Stoke: To poke or stir up a fire; hence, to tend the fires of furnaces, steamers, etc.
Stanchion: A prop or support; a piece of timber in the form of a stake or post, used for a support or stay.
Scagliola: An imitation of any veined and ornamental stone, as marble, formed by a substratum of finely ground gypsum mixed with glue, the surface of which, while soft, is variegated with splinters of marble, spar, granite, etc., and subsequently colored and polished.
&Verbar;Sistrum: An instrument consisting of a thin metal frame, through which passed a number of metal rods, and furnished with a handle by which it was shaken and made to rattle. It was peculiarly Egyptian, and used especially in the worship of Isis. It is still used in Nubia.
Self-neglecting: A neglecting of one's self, or of one's own interests.
Seid: A descendant of Mohammed through his daughter Fatima and nephew Ali.
Sigmodont: Any one of a tribe (Sigmodontes) of rodents which includes all the indigenous rats and mice of America. So called from the form of the ridges of enamel on the crowns of the worn molars. Also used adjectively.
Sealskin: The skin of a seal; the pelt of a seal prepared for use, esp. of the fur seal; also, a garment made of this material.
Still water: a section of a stream that is flat and moves slowly.
Sanguinolency: The state of being sanguinolent, or bloody.
Suppuration: The act or process of suppurating.
Sexto: A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into six leaves.
Sweaty: Moist with sweat; as, a sweaty skin; a sweaty garment.
Soapwort: A common plant (Saponaria officinalis) of the Pink family; -- so called because its bruised leaves, when agitated in water, produce a lather like that from soap. Called also Bouncing Bet.
Slab-sided: Having flat sides; hence, tall, or long and lank.
Shallowness: Quality or state of being shallow.
Supererogatory: Performed to an extent not enjoined, or not required, by duty or necessity; as, supererogatory services.
Sweet-breasted: Having a sweet, musical voice, as the nightingale.  Cf. Breast, n., 6.
Sorner: One who obtrudes himself on another for bed and board.
Stripe: To make stripes upon; to form with lines of different colors or textures; to variegate with stripes.
Steepness: Quality or state of being steep; precipitous declivity; as, the steepnessof a hill or a roof.
Solenodon: Either one of two species of singular West Indian insectivores, allied to the tenrec. One species (Solendon paradoxus), native of St. Domingo, is called also agouta; the other (S. Cubanus), found in Cuba, is called almique.
Sea apple: The fruit of a West Indian palm (Manicaria Plukenetii), often found floating in the sea.
Spadille: The ace of spades in omber and quadrille.
Safe-keeping: The act of keeping or preserving in safety from injury or from escape; care; custody.
Synonymic: Of or pertaining to synonyms, or synonymic; synonymous.
Spavin: A disease of horses characterized by a bony swelling developed on the hock as the result of inflammation of the bones; also, the swelling itself. The resulting lameness is due to the inflammation, and not the bony tumor as popularly supposed.
Sapidity: The quality or state of being sapid; taste; savor; savoriness.
Sea otter: An aquatic carnivore (Enhydris lutris syn. Enhydris marina) found in the North Pacific Ocean.   Its fur is highly valued, especially by the Chinese.  It is allied to the common otter, but is larger, with feet more decidedly webbed.
Sacrificial: Of or pertaining to sacrifice or sacrifices; consisting in sacrifice; performing sacrifice.
Shipmate: One who serves on board of the same ship with another; a fellow sailor.
Sweepings: Things collected by sweeping; rubbish; as, the sweepings of a street.
Sutler: A person who follows an army, and sells to the troops provisions, liquors, and the like.
Stipulation: The situation, arrangement, and structure of the stipules.
Satin weave: A style of weaving producing smooth-faced fabric in which the warp interlaces with the filling at points distributed over the surface.
-scope: A combining form usually signifying an instrument for viewing (with the eye) or observing (in any way); as in microscope, telescope, altoscope, anemoscope.
&Verbar;Seborrhea: A morbidly increased discharge of sebaceous matter upon the skin; stearrhea.
Schematize: To form a scheme or schemes.
Sizarship: The position or standing of a sizar.
Self-imposture: Imposture practiced on one's self; self-deceit.
Snowplow: An implement operating like a plow, but on a larger scale, for clearing away the snow from roads, railways, etc.
Setireme: A swimming leg (of an insect) having a fringe of hairs on the margin.
Surfel: To wash, as the face, with a cosmetic water, said by some to be prepared from the sulphur.
Spermist: A believer in the doctrine, formerly current, of encasement in the male (see Encasement), in which the seminal thread, or spermatozoid, was considered as the real animal germ, the head being the true animal head and the tail the body.
Sheafy: Pertaining to, or consisting of, a sheaf or sheaves; resembling a sheaf.
Spermism: The theory, formerly held by many, that the sperm or spermatozoön contains the germ of the future embryo; animalculism.
Significative: Betokening or representing by an external sign.
Snowberry: A name of several shrubs with white berries; as, the Symphoricarpus racemosus of the Northern United States, and the Chiococca racemosa of Florida and tropical America.
-ster: A suffix denoting the agent (originally a woman), especially a person who does something with skill or as an occupation; as in spinster (originally, a woman who spins), songster, baxter (= bakester), youngster.
Sparterie: Articles made of the blades or fiber of the Lygeum Spartum and Stipa tenacissima (syn. Macrochloa tenacissima), kinds of grass used in Spain and other countries for making ropes, mats, baskets, nets, and mattresses.
Starling: Any passerine bird belonging to Sturnus and allied genera. The European starling (Sturnus vulgaris) is dark brown or greenish black, with a metallic gloss, and spotted with yellowish white. It is a sociable bird, and builds about houses, old towers, etc. Called also stare, and starred. The pied starling of India is Sternopastor contra.
&Verbar;Soredium: A patch of granular bodies on the surface of the thallus of lichens.
Senatorship: The office or dignity of a senator.
Shrillness: The quality or state of being shrill.
Synastry: Concurrence of starry position or influence; hence, similarity of condition, fortune, etc., as prefigured by astrological calculation.
Senescence: The state of growing old; decay by time.
Sled: To convey or transport on a sled; as, to sled wood or timber.
Sybaritic: Of or pertaining to the Sybarites; resembling the Sybarites; luxurious; wanton; effeminate.
Sley: To separate or part the threads of, and arrange them in a reed; -- a term used by weavers. See Sleave, and Sleid.
Sea laces: A kind of seaweed (Chorda Filum) having blackish cordlike fronds, often many feet long.
Synthermal: Having the same degree of heat.
Self-renunciation: The act of renouncing, or setting aside, one's own wishes, claims, etc.; self-sacrifice.
Slew: A wet place; a river inlet.
Suckler: An animal that suckles its young; a mammal.
Solanoid: Resembling a potato; -- said of a kind of cancer.
Spongin: The chemical basis of sponge tissue, a nitrogenous, hornlike substance which on decomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and glycocoll.
Stag-evil: A kind of palsy affecting the jaw of a horse.
Self-contained Underwater Breathing Appa: A portable device to allow divers to breathe while under water, consisting of one or two tanks of compressed air which are strapped onto the back of the diver, and are connected by tubing to a mouthpiece through which the diver receives the air from the tanks at rate adjustable by a valve; -- called also SCUBA, SCUBA gear, or SCUBA apparatus.
Sorry: Grieved for the loss of some good; pained for some evil; feeling regret; -- now generally used to express light grief or affliction, but formerly often used to express deeper feeling.
Saddlecloth: A cloth under a saddle, and extending out behind; a housing.
Sittine: Of or pertaining to the family Sittidæ, or nuthatches.
Sitting: The state or act of one who sits; the posture of one who occupies a seat.
Straggler: One who straggles, or departs from the direct or proper course, or from the company to which he belongs; one who falls behind the rest; one who rambles without any settled direction.
Spermoderm: The covering of a seed; -- sometimes limited to the outer coat or testa.
Setiferous: Producing, or having one or more, bristles.
Sky pilot: A person licensed as a pilot.
Strongyloid: Like, or pertaining to, Strongylus, a genus of parasitic nematode worms of which many species infest domestic animals. Some of the species, especially those living in the kidneys, lungs, and bronchial tubes, are often very injurious.
Subsoil: To turn up the subsoil of.
Seven-up: The game of cards called also all fours, and old sledge.
Self-imparting: Imparting by one's own, or by its own, powers and will.
&Verbar;Saiga: An antelope (Saiga Tartarica) native of the plains of Siberia and Eastern Russia. The male has erect annulated horns, and tufts of long hair beneath the eyes and ears.
Spiricle: One of certain minute coiled threads in the coating of some seeds. When moistened these threads protrude in great numbers.
Surreption: The act or process of getting in a surreptitious manner, or by craft or stealth.
Salvific: Tending to save or secure safety.
Salver-shaped: Tubular, with a spreading border. See Hypocraterimorphous.
Scrimshaw: A shell, a whale's tooth, or the like, that is scrimshawed.
Sienna: Clay that is colored red or brown by the oxides of iron or manganese, and used as a pigment. It is used either in the raw state or burnt.
Stercorianism: The doctrine or belief of the Stercoranists.
Subpulmonary: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the lungs.
&Verbar;Sanies: A thin, serous fluid commonly discharged from ulcers or foul wounds.
&Verbar;Strepitores: A division of birds, including the clamatorial and picarian birds, which do not have well developed singing organs.
Sitten: p. p. of Sit, for sat.
Scapula: The principal bone of the shoulder girdle in mammals; the shoulder blade.
Sitter: One who sits; esp., one who sits for a portrait or a bust.
Sword: An offensive weapon, having a long and usually sharp-pointed blade with a cutting edge or edges. It is the general term, including the small sword, rapier, saber, scimiter, and many other varieties.
Submersion: The act of submerging, or putting under water or other fluid, or of causing to be overflowed; the act of plunging under water, or of drowning.
&Verbar;Steatoma: A cyst containing matter like suet.
Stinkpot: An earthen jar charged with powder, grenades, and other materials of an offensive and suffocating smell, -- sometimes used in boarding an enemy's vessel.
Spherograph: An instrument for facilitating the practical use of spherics in navigation and astronomy, being constructed of two cardboards containing various circles, and turning upon each other in such a manner that any possible spherical triangle may be readily found, and the measures of the parts read off by inspection.
Sesquipedal: Measuring or containing a foot and a half; as, a sesquipedalian pygmy; -- sometimes humorously applied to long words.
Stall-feed: To feed and fatten in a stall or on dry fodder; as, to stall-feed an ox.
Space age: the time during which humans engaged in space exploration; -- generally considered as beginning on October 4, 1957 when the Soviet Union placed the first artificial satellite into orbit around the earth.
Sheeling: A hut or small cottage in an exposed or a retired place (as on a mountain or at the seaside) such as is used by shepherds, fishermen, sportsmen, etc.; a summer cottage; also, a shed.
Stannous: Pertaining to, or containing, tin; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with stannic compounds.
Sizing: The act of sorting with respect to size.
Successional: Of or pertaining to a succession; existing in a regular order; consecutive.
Salicylide: A white crystalline substance obtained by dehydration of salicylic acid.
Stunning: Overpowering consciousness; overpowering the senses; especially, overpowering the sense of hearing; confounding with noise.
Saccharin: A bitter white crystalline substance obtained from the saccharinates and regarded as the lactone of saccharinic acid; -- so called because formerly supposed to be isomeric with cane sugar (saccharose).
Saccharic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, saccharine substances; specifically, designating an acid obtained, as a white amorphous gummy mass, by the oxidation of mannite, glucose, sucrose, etc.
Skilligalee: A kind of thin, weak broth or oatmeal porridge, served out to prisoners and paupers in England; also, a drink made of oatmeal, sugar, and water, sometimes used in the English navy or army.
Sensuality: The quality or state of being sensual; devotedness to the gratification of the bodily appetites; free indulgence in carnal or sensual pleasures; luxuriousness; voluptuousness; lewdness.
Sulphovinic: Of, pertaining to, and formerly designating, ethylsulphuric acid.
Slang-whanger: One who uses abusive slang; a ranting partisan.
Sonderclass: A special class of small yachts developed in Germany under the patronage of  Emperor William and Prince Henry of Prussia, and so called because these yachts do not conform to the restrictions for the regular classes established by the rules of the International Yacht Racing Union. In yachts of the sonderclass, as prescribed for the season of 1911, the  aggregate of the length on water line, extreme beam, and  extreme draft must be not more than 32 feet; the weight, not less than 4,035 pounds (without crew); the sail area, not more than 550 square yards; and the cost of construction (for American boats) not more than $2400. The crew must be amateurs and citizens of the country in which the yacht was built.
Strapple: To hold or bind with, or as with, a strap; to entangle.
&Verbar;Shereef: A member of an Arab princely family descended from Mohammed through his son-in-law Ali and daughter Fatima. The Grand Shereef is the governor of Mecca.
&Verbar;Scalaria: Any one of numerous species of marine gastropods of the genus Scalaria, or family Scalaridæ, having elongated spiral turreted shells, with rounded whorls, usually crossed by ribs or varices. The color is generally white or pale. Called also ladder shell, and wentletrap. See Ptenoglossa, and Wentletrap.
Subsequent: Following in time; coming or being after something else at any time, indefinitely; as, subsequent events; subsequent ages or years; a period long subsequent to the foundation of Rome.
Saltire: A St. Andrew's cross, or cross in the form of an X, -- one of the honorable ordinaries.
Sciurine: Of or pertaining to the Squirrel family.
Speechless: Destitute or deprived of the faculty of speech.
Supplely: In a supple manner; softly; pliantly; mildly.
Snakeroot: Any one of several plants of different genera and species, most of which are (or were formerly) reputed to be efficacious as remedies for the bites of serpents; also, the roots of any of these.
shtetl: A village or small town; -- usually referring to Jewish towns in Eastern Europe.
Sportsmanship: The practice of sportsmen; skill in field sports.
Sniggle: To catch, as an eel, by sniggling; hence, to hook; to insnare.
Surely: In a sure or certain manner; certainly; infallibly; undoubtedly; assuredly.
Sessile: Attached without any sensible projecting support.
Scragginess: The quality or state of being scraggy; scraggedness.
Sword-shaped: Shaped like a sword; ensiform, as the long, flat leaves of the Iris, cattail, and the like.
Shill-I-shall-I: In an irresolute, undecided, or hesitating manner.
Spence: A place where provisions are kept; a buttery; a larder; a pantry.
Stereotypography: The act or art of printing from stereotype plates.
Sphyr\u00e6noid: Of or pertaining to the Sphyrænidæ, a family of marine fishes including the barracudas.
Spitter: One who puts meat on a spit.
Spectrology: The science of spectrum analysis in any or all of its relations and applications.
Self-communicative: Imparting or communicating by its own powers.
Saponite: A hydrous silicate of magnesia and alumina. It occurs in soft, soapy, amorphous masses, filling veins in serpentine and cavities in trap rock.
Spitted: p. p. of Spit, v. i., to eject, to spit.
Suitable: Capable of suiting; fitting; accordant; proper; becoming; agreeable; adapted; as, ornaments suitable to one's station; language suitable for the subject.
Sodomitical: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, sodomy.
Scirrhosity: A morbid induration, as of a gland; state of being scirrhous.
Shrove: To join in the festivities of Shrovetide; hence, to make merry.
Sentinel: To watch over like a sentinel.
spinach beet: a beet lacking a swollen root; it is grown as a vegetable for its edible leaves and stalks.
Shepherdess: A woman who tends sheep; hence, a rural lass.
Smelt: To melt or fuse, as, ore, for the purpose of separating and refining the metal; hence, to reduce; to refine; to flux or scorify; as, to smelt tin.
Split stuff: Timber sawn into lengths and then split.
Suspect: To imagine guilt; to have a suspicion or suspicions; to be suspicious.
Smell: The sense or faculty by which certain qualities of bodies are perceived through the instrumentally of the olfactory nerves. See Sense.
Sexlocular: Having six cells for seeds; six-celled; as, a sexlocular pericarp.
Sneezewood: The wood of a South African tree. See Neishout.
Suncup: A yellow flowered evening primrose (Taraxia ovata, syn. Œnothera ovata) native of California.
Separative: Causing, or being to cause, separation.
Subintestinal: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the intestine.
Seediness: The quality or state of being seedy, shabby, or worn out; a state of wretchedness or exhaustion.
Susceptibility: The state or quality of being susceptible; the capability of receiving impressions, or of being affected.
Scilicet: To wit; namely; videlicet; -- often abbreviated to sc., or ss.
Splanchnopleure: The inner, or visceral, one of the two lamellæ into which the vertebrate blastoderm divides on either side of the notochord, and from which the walls of the enteric canal and the umbilical vesicle are developed. See Somatopleure.
Scraping: Resembling the act of, or the effect produced by, one who, or that which, scrapes; as, a scraping noise; a scraping miser.
Sorehon: Formerly, in Ireland, a kind of servile tenure which subjected the tenant to maintain his chieftain gratuitously whenever he wished to indulge in a revel.
Souterrain: A grotto or cavern under ground.
&Verbar;Symbranchii: An order of slender eel-like fishes having the gill openings confluent beneath the neck. The pectoral arch is generally attached to the skull, and the entire margin of the upper jaw is formed by the premaxillary. Called also Symbranchia.
Supervision: The act of overseeing; inspection; superintendence; oversight.
Suckling: A young child or animal nursed at the breast.
Stretcher: One who, or that which, stretches.
Scincoid: Of or pertaining to the family Scincidæ, or skinks.
Shaky: Shaking or trembling; as, a shaky spot in a marsh; a shaky hand.
Scyllarian: One of a family (Scyllaridæ) of macruran Crustacea, remarkable for the depressed form of the body, and the broad, flat antennæ. Also used adjectively.
Subjunctive: The subjunctive mood; also, a verb in the subjunctive mood.
Skyish: Like the sky, or approaching the sky; lofty; ethereal.
Static: Resting; acting by mere weight without motion; as, statical pressure; static objects.
Scission: The act of dividing with an instrument having a sharp edge.
Spalpeen: A scamp; an Irish term for a good-for-nothing fellow; -- often used in good-humored contempt or ridicule.
Shake: The act or result of shaking; a vacillating or wavering motion; a rapid motion one way and other; a trembling, quaking, or shivering; agitation.
Sylleptic: Of or pertaining to a syllepsis; containing syllepsis.
Shako: A kind of military cap or headdress.
Shopkeeper: A trader who sells goods in a shop, or by retail; -- in distinction from one who sells by wholesale.
Sea goddess: A goddess supposed to live in or reign over the sea, or some part of the sea.
Sanatory: Conducive to health; tending to cure; healing; curative; sanative.
Solemnness: The state or quality of being solemn; solemnity; impressiveness; gravity; as, the solemnness of public worship.
Suffocation: The act of suffocating, or the state of being suffocated; death caused by smothering or choking.
Saw-wort: Any plant of the composite genus Serratula; -- so named from the serrated leaves of most of the species.
Spicosity: The state of having, or being full of, ears like corn.
Slipcoat cheese: A rich variety of new cheese, resembling butter, but white.
Sweat: The fluid which is excreted from the skin of an animal; the fluid secreted by the sudoriferous glands; a transparent, colorless, acid liquid with a peculiar odor, containing some fatty acids and mineral matter; perspiration. See Perspiration.
Subglottic: Situated below the glottis; -- applied to that part of the cavity of the larynx below the true vocal cords.
Surround: A method of hunting some animals, as the buffalo, by surrounding a herd, and driving them over a precipice, into a ravine, etc.
Sifac: The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the natives as sacred.
Sniveler: One who snivels, esp. one who snivels habitually.
Supermundane: Being above the world; -- opposed to inframundane.
&Verbar;Soubise: A sauce made of white onions and melted butter mixed with velouté sauce.
Self-conceited: Having an overweening opinion of one's own powers, attainments; vain; conceited.
Suppository: A pill or bolus for introduction into the rectum; esp., a cylinder or cone of medicated cacao butter.
Stromeyerite: A steel-gray mineral of metallic luster. It is a sulphide of silver and copper.
Semeiotic: Relating to signs or indications; pertaining to the language of signs, or to language generally as indicating thought.
Sterned: Having a stern of a particular shape; -- used in composition; as, square-sterned.
Seeing: In view of the fact (that); considering; taking into account (that); insmuch as; since; because; -- followed by a dependent clause; as, he did well, seeing that he was so young.
Saccholactate: A salt of saccholactic acid; -- formerly called also saccholate.
Scrolled: Formed like a scroll; contained in a scroll; adorned with scrolls; as, scrolled work.
Scupper: An opening cut through the waterway and bulwarks of a ship, so that water falling on deck may flow overboard; -- called also scupper hole.
Self-opinion: Opinion, especially high opinion, of one's self; an overweening estimate of one's self or of one's own opinion.
Stemmer: One who, or that which, stems (in any of the senses of the verbs).
Sentiment: A thought prompted by passion or feeling; a state of mind in view of some subject; feeling toward or respecting some person or thing; disposition prompting to action or expression.
Sit: To sit upon; to keep one's seat upon; as, he sits a horse well.
Spuller: One employed to inspect yarn, to see that it is well spun, and fit for the loom.
Six: The number greater by a unit than five; the sum of three and three; six units or objects.
Sea mouse: A dorsibranchiate annelid, belonging to Aphrodite and allied genera, having long, slender, hairlike setæ on the sides.
Squab: To fall plump; to strike at one dash, or with a heavy stroke.
Schematic: Of or pertaining to a scheme or a schema.
Secundo-geniture: A right of inheritance belonging to a second son; a property or possession so inherited.
Squam: An oilskin hat or southwester; -- a fisherman's name.
Sin: To depart voluntarily from the path of duty prescribed by God to man; to violate the divine law in any particular, by actual transgression or by the neglect or nonobservance of its injunctions; to violate any known rule of duty; -- often followed by against.
Sloppiness: The quality or state of being sloppy; muddiness.
Subduple: Indicating one part of two; in the ratio of one to two.
Speckled: Marked or variegated with small spots of a different color from that of the rest of the surface.
Stick-seed: A plant (Echinospermum Lappula) of the Borage family, with small blue flowers and prickly nutlets.
Santees: One of the seven confederated tribes of Indians belonging to the Sioux, or Dakotas.
Sparge: To sprinkle; to moisten by sprinkling; as, to sparge paper.
&Verbar;Streptobacteria: A so-called variety of bacterium, consisting in reality of several bacteria linked together in the form of a chain.
Strath: A valley of considerable size, through which a river runs; a valley bottom; -- often used in composition with the name of the river; as, Strath Spey, Strathdon, Strathmore.
Subordinative: Tending to subordinate; expressing subordination; used to introduce a subordinate sentence; as, a subordinative conjunction.
Summon: To call, bid, or cite; to notify to come to appear; -- often with up.
Stowboard: A place into which rubbish is put.
Stirring: Putting in motion, or being in motion; active; active in business; habitually employed in some kind of business; accustomed to a busy life.
Styrolene: An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C8H8, obtained by the distillation of storax, by the decomposition of cinnamic acid, and by the condensation of acetylene, as a fragrant, aromatic, mobile liquid; -- called also phenyl ethylene, vinyl benzene, styrol, styrene, and cinnamene.
Surrenderor: One who makes a surrender, as of an estate.
Supravaginal: Situated above or outside a sheath or vaginal membrane.
Samara: A dry, indehiscent, usually one-seeded, winged fruit, as that of the ash, maple, and elm; a key or key fruit.
Skate: Any one of numerous species of large, flat elasmobranch fishes of the genus Raia, having a long, slender tail, terminated by a small caudal fin. The pectoral fins, which are large and broad and united to the sides of the body and head, give a somewhat rhombic form to these fishes. The skin is more or less spinose.
Seethe: To be a state of ebullition or violent commotion; to be hot; to boil.
Salutation: The act of saluting, or paying respect or reverence, by the customary words or actions; the act of greeting, or expressing good will or courtesy; also, that which is uttered or done in saluting or greeting.
Sufficient: Equal to the end proposed; adequate to wants; enough; ample; competent; as, provision sufficient for the family; an army sufficient to defend the country.
Salimetry: The art or process of measuring the amount of salt in a substance.
Silver State: Nevada; -- a nickname alluding to its silver mines.
Saturnalia: The festival of Saturn, celebrated in December, originally during one day, but afterward during seven days, as a period of unrestrained license and merriment for all classes, extending even to the slaves.
Staging: A structure of posts and boards for supporting workmen, etc., as in building.
Spicate: Having the form of a spike, or ear; arranged in a spike or spikes.
Sanguine: To stain with blood; to impart the color of blood to; to ensanguine.
Sinuous: Bending in and out; of a serpentine or undulating form; winding; crooked.
Spermatozoid: The male germ cell in animals and plants, the essential element in fertilization; a microscopic animalcule-like particle, usually provided with one or more cilia by which it is capable of active motion. In animals, the familiar type is that of a small, more or less ovoid head, with a delicate threadlike cilium, or tail. Called also spermatozoön. In plants the more usual term is antherozoid.
Sluggish: Habitually idle and lazy; slothful; dull; inactive; as, a sluggish man.
Supparasitation: The act of flattering to gain favor; servile approbation.
Siziness: The quality or state of being sizy; viscousness.
Semiflosculous: Having all the florets ligulate, as in the dandelion.
Sodium bicarbonate: a white crystalline substance, HNaCO3, with a slight alkaline taste resembling that of sodium carbonate. It is found in many mineral springs and also produced artificially,. It is used in cookery, in baking powders, and as a source of carbonic acid gas (carbon dioxide) for soda water. Called also baking soda, cooking soda, bicarbonate of soda, bicarb, saleratus, and technically, acid sodium carbonate, sodium acid carbonate, primary sodium carbonate, sodium dicarbonate, etc.
Substratum: That which is laid or spread under; that which underlies something, as a layer of earth lying under another; specifically (Agric.), the subsoil.
Struggle: A violent effort or efforts with contortions of the body; agony; distress.
&Verbar;Sedilia: Seats in the chancel of a church near the altar for the officiating clergy during intervals of service.
Solar myth: A myth which essentially consists of allegory based upon ideas as to the sun's course, motion, influence, or the like.
Sixpenny: Of the value of, or costing, sixpence; as, a sixpenny loaf.
Suboccipital: Situated under, or posterior to, the occiput; as, the suboccipital, or first cervical, nerve.
Sollar: To cover, or provide with, a sollar.
Superiority: The quality, state, or condition of being superior; as, superiority of rank; superiority in merit.
Syndyasmian: Pertaining to the state of pairing together sexually; -- said of animals during periods of procreation and while rearing their offspring.
Spadix: A fleshy spike of flowers, usually inclosed in a leaf called a spathe.
Sterve: To die, or cause to die; to perish. See Starve.
Self-created: Created by one's self; not formed or constituted by another.
Saunter: A sauntering, or a sauntering place.
Stereographic: Made or done according to the rules of stereography; delineated on a plane; as, a stereographic chart of the earth.
Skirling: A small trout or salmon; -- a name used loosely.
&Verbar;Sideroxylon: A genus of tropical sapotaceous trees noted for their very hard wood; ironwood.
Spellbound: Bound by, or as by, a spell.
Stalk-eyed: Having the eyes raised on a stalk, or peduncle; -- opposed to sessile-eyed. Said especially of podophthalmous crustaceans.
Salubrity: The quality of being salubrious; favorableness to the preservation of health; salubriousness; wholesomeness; healthfulness; as, the salubrity of the air, of a country, or a climate.
Swaddler: A term of contempt for an Irish Methodist.
Synclastic: Curved toward the same side in all directions; -- said of surfaces which in all directions around any point bend away from a tangent plane toward the same side, as the surface of a sphere; -- opposed to anticlastic.
Siphorhinal: Having tubular nostrils, as the petrels.
Songster: One who sings; one skilled in singing; -- not often applied to human beings.
Sunniness: The quality or state of being sunny.
Substituted: Exchanged; put in the place of another.
Scuttle: To cut a hole or holes through the bottom, deck, or sides of (as of a ship), for any purpose.
Sacro-: A combining form denoting connection with, or relation to, the sacrum, as in sacro-coccygeal, sacro-iliac, sacrosciatic.
Southwest: Pertaining to, or in the direction of, the southwest; proceeding toward the southwest; coming from the southwest; as, a southwest wind.
Scylla: A dangerous rock on the Italian coast opposite the whirpool Charybdis on the coast of Sicily, -- both personified in classical literature as ravenous monsters. The passage between them was formerly considered perilous; hence, the saying “Between Scylla and Charybdis,” signifying a great peril on either hand.
Sluggardy: The state of being a sluggard; sluggishness; sloth.
Streamful: Abounding in streams, or in water.
Styrone: A white crystalline substance having a sweet taste and a hyacinthlike odor, obtained by the decomposition of styracin; -- properly called cinnamic alcohol or styryl alcohol.
Splining: Of or pertaining to a spline.
Scapulo-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the scapula or the shoulder; as, the scapulo-clavicular articulation, the articulation between the scapula and clavicle.
Salivation: The act or process of salivating; an excessive secretion of saliva, often accompanied with soreness of the mouth and gums; ptyalism.
Scrapple: An article of food made by boiling together bits or scraps of meat, usually pork, and flour or Indian meal.
Spearman: One who is armed with a spear.
spottiness: The state or quality of being spotty.
&Verbar;Spermoplasma: The protoplasm of the sperm cell.
Soberness: The quality or state of being sober.
Spit-venom: Poison spittle; poison ejected from the mouth.
Sea clam: Any one of the large bivalve mollusks found on the open seacoast, especially those of the family Mactridæ, as the common American species. (Mactra solidissima or Spisula solidissima); -- called also beach clam, and surf clam.
Spheral: Of or pertaining to a sphere or the spheres.
Slugger: One who strikes heavy blows; hence, a boxer; a prize fighter.
Stealing: The act of taking feloniously the personal property of another without his consent and knowledge; theft; larceny.
Spoffish: Earnest and active in matters of no moment; bustling.
Sci-Fi: Science fiction; -- a common shortened form for the name of the literaray genre.  See science fiction.
Scriber: A sharp-pointed tool, used by joiners for drawing lines on stuff; a marking awl.
Semicolumn: A half column; a column bisected longitudinally, or along its axis.
Spectrometry: Art or process of using a spectrometer, of any type; -- when used alone, it usually refers to the use of a spectrometer using light in the visible, infrared, or ultraviolet region.
Sentient: One who has the faculty of perception; a sentient being.
Sodium sulphate: A salt well known as a catharic under the name of Glauber's salt, which term is properly applied to the hydrate, Na2SO4.10H2O.
Sexradiate: Having six rays; -- said of certain sponge spicules. See Illust. of Spicule.
Solar: Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from the sun; as, the solar system; solar light; solar rays; solar influence. See Solar system, below.
Swarmspore: One of innumerable minute, motile, reproductive bodies, produced asexually by certain algæ and fungi; a zoöspore.
Should: Used as an auxiliary verb, to express a conditional or contingent act or state, or as a supposition of an actual fact; also, to express moral obligation (see Shall); e. g.: they should have come last week; if I should go; I should think you could go.
&Verbar;Sondeli: The musk shrew. See under Musk.
Space walk: any activity by a human outside of the protective environment of a spacecraft while it is in outer space, requiring a space suit to protect the person from the vacuum and other hazards of space.
Splendent: Shining; glossy; beaming with light; lustrous; as, splendent planets; splendent metals. See the Note under 3d Luster, 4.
Synodically: In a synodical manner; in a synod; by the authority of a synod.
Siderolite: A kind of meteorite. See under Meteorite.
Sooty: To black or foul with soot.
Sago: A dry granulated starch imported from the East Indies, much used for making puddings and as an article of diet for the sick; also, as starch, for stiffening textile fabrics. It is prepared from the stems of several East Indian and Malayan palm trees, but chiefly from the Metroxylon Sagu; also from several cycadaceous plants (Cycas revoluta, Zamia integrifolia, etc.).
Saga: A Scandinavian legend, or heroic or mythic tradition, among the Norsemen and kindred people; a northern European popular historical or religious tale of olden time.
Selachian: One of the Selachii. See Illustration in Appendix.
Sage: A wise man; a man of gravity and wisdom; especially, a man venerable for years, and of sound judgment and prudence; a grave philosopher.
Seraskier: A general or commander of land forces in the Turkish empire; especially, the commander-in-chief of minister of war.
Sagy: Full of sage; seasoned with sage.
Satiric: Of or pertaining to satire; of the nature of satire; as, a satiric style.
Showery: Raining in showers; abounding with frequent showers of rain.
Siling: a. & n. from Sile to strain.
Stemmery: A large building in which tobacco is stemmed.
Swallow-tailed: Having a tail like that of a swallow; hence, like a swallow's tail in form; having narrow and tapering or pointed skirts; as, a swallow-tailed coat.
Stage-struck: Fascinated by the stage; seized by a passionate desire to become an actor.
Scrap: Something scraped off; hence, a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
Swizzle: Ale and beer mixed; also, drink generally.
&Verbar;Septuagesima: The third Sunday before Lent; -- so called because it is about seventy days before Easter.
Scram: the rapid shut down of a nuclear reactor, as in an emergency.
Seriality: The quality or state of succession in a series; sequence.
Scrag: To seize, pull, or twist the neck of; specif., to hang by the neck; to kill by hanging.
Snaphance: A spring lock for discharging a firearm; also, the firearm to which it is attached.
&Verbar;Sexagesima: The second Sunday before Lent; -- so called as being about the sixtieth day before Easter.
Sea bream: Any one of several species of sparoid fishes, especially the common European species (Pagellus centrodontus), the Spanish (P. Oweni), and the black sea bream (Cantharus lineatus); -- called also old wife.
Significant: That which has significance; a sign; a token; a symbol.
Subinfeudation: The granting of lands by inferior lords to their dependents, to be held by themselves by feudal tenure.
Strabismus: An affection of one or both eyes, in which the optic axes can not be directed to the same object, -- a defect due either to undue contraction or to undue relaxation of one or more of the muscles which move the eyeball; squinting; cross-eye.
Seminarian: A member of, or one educated in, a seminary; specifically, an ecclesiastic educated for the priesthood in a seminary.
Spermophile: Any ground squirrel of the genus Spermophilus; a gopher. See Illust. under Gopher.
Splanchnology: That part of anatomy which treats of the viscera; also, a treatise on the viscera.
Sabulosity: The quality of being sabulous; sandiness; grittiness.
Softness: The quality or state of being soft; -- opposed to hardness, and used in the various specific senses of the adjective.
Sea salt: Common salt, obtained from sea water by evaporation.
Scramble: The act of scrambling, climbing on all fours, or clambering.
supersonic: Moving at a speed greater than the speed of sound in air; -- this speed varies with altitude, since the speed of sound varies with altitude, as well as with temperature and humidity, being approximately 1129 feet per second at sea level and 984 feet per second at 16 miles altitude.
Self-begotten: Begotten by one's self, or one's own powers.
Spathed: Having a spathe or calyx like a sheath.
Sherbet: A refreshing drink, common in the East, made of the juice of some fruit, diluted, sweetened, and flavored in various ways; as, orange sherbet; lemon sherbet; raspberry sherbet, etc.
Swelt: To overpower, as with heat; to cause to faint; to swelter.
Sitfast: A callosity with inflamed edges, on the back of a horse, under the saddle.
Stereotypy: The art or process of making stereotype plates.
Slaughterhouse: A house where beasts are butchered for the market.
Swarthiness: The quality or state of being swarthy; a dusky or dark complexion; tawniness.
Sternal: Of or pertaining to the sternum; in the region of the sternum.
Sharpshooting: A shooting with great precision and effect; hence, a keen contest of wit or argument.
Sea rover: One that cruises or roves the sea for plunder; a sea robber; a pirate; also, a piratical vessel.
Scripturalism: The quality or state of being scriptural; literal adherence to the Scriptures.
Soorma: A preparation of antimony with which Mohammedan men anoint their eyelids.
Showbread: Bread of exhibition; loaves to set before God; -- the term used in translating the various phrases used in the Hebrew and Greek to designate the loaves of bread which the priest of the week placed before the Lord on the golden table in the sanctuary. They were made of fine flour unleavened, and were changed every Sabbath. The loaves, twelve in number, represented the twelve tribes of Israel. They were to be eaten by the priests only, and in the Holy Place.
Semi-Pelagian: Of or pertaining to the Semi-Pelagians, or their tenets.
Scripturalist: One who adheres literally to the Scriptures.
Sanguification: The production of blood; the conversion of the products of digestion into blood; hematosis.
Sparerib: A piece of pork, consisting or ribs with little flesh on them.
Shrive: To receive confessions, as a priest; to administer confession and absolution.
Semantics: the study of the meanings of words and of the sense development of words; -- formerly called semasiology.
Sonoran: Pertaining to or designating the arid division of the Austral zone, including the warmer parts of the western United States and central Mexico. It is divided into the Upper Sonoran, which lies next to the Transition zone, and the Lower Sonoran, next to the Tropical.
Sister: To be sister to; to resemble closely.
Socialist: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, socialism.
&Verbar;Syngnathi: A suborder of lophobranch fishes which have an elongated snout and lack the ventral and first dorsal fins.  The pipefishes and sea horses are examples.
Socialism: A theory or system of social reform which contemplates a complete reconstruction of society, with a more just and equitable distribution of property and labor. In popular usage, the term is often employed to indicate any lawless, revolutionary social scheme. See Communism, Fourierism, Saint-Simonianism, forms of socialism.
Steganography: The art of writing in cipher, or in characters which are not intelligible except to persons who have the key; cryptography.
Saintism: The character or quality of saints; also, hypocritical pretense of holiness.
Soapfish: Any serranoid fish of the genus Rhypticus; -- so called from the soapy feeling of its skin.
Statistic: Of or pertaining to statistics; as, statistical knowledge; statistical tabulation.
Sneaking: Marked by cowardly concealment; deficient in openness and courage; underhand; mean; crouching.
Spiciness: The quality or state of being spicy.
Seignioral: Of or pertaining to a seignior; seigneurial.
Straiten: To make strait; to make narrow; hence, to contract; to confine.
Stating: The act of one who states anything; statement; as, the statingof one's opinions.
Smithsonite: Native zinc carbonate. It generally occurs in stalactitic, reniform, or botryoidal shapes, of a white to gray, green, or brown color. See Note under Calamine.
Scraper: An instrument with which anything is scraped.
Scuddle: To run hastily; to hurry; to scuttle.
&Verbar;Swietenia: A genus of meliaceous trees consisting of one species (Sweitenia Mahogoni), the mahogany tree.
Stimulant: That which stimulates, provokes, or excites.
Shepherd: To tend as a shepherd; to guard, herd, lead, or drive, as a shepherd.
Satellite: Situated near; accompanying; as, the satellite veins, those which accompany the arteries.
Slopseller: One who sells slops, or ready-made clothes. See 4th Slop, 3.
Skeet: A scoop with a long handle, used to wash the sides of a vessel, and formerly to wet the sails or deck.
Semele: A daughter of Cadmus, and by Zeus mother of Bacchus.
Suppress: To overpower and crush; to subdue; to put down; to quell.
Shorthead: A sucking whale less than one year old; -- so called by sailors.
Sachem: A chief of a tribe of the American Indians; a sagamore.
Sea fan: Any gorgonian which branches in a fanlike form, especially Gorgonia flabellum of Florida and the West Indies.
Seismic: Of or pertaining to an earthquake; caused by an earthquake.
Saturn: One of the elder and principal deities, the son of Cœlus and Terra (Heaven and Earth), and the father of Jupiter. The corresponding Greek divinity was Kro`nos, later CHro`nos, Time.
Skeel: A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream.
Stander-by: One who stands near; one who is present; a bystander.
Stream wheel: A wheel used for measuring, by its motion when submerged, the velocity of flowing water; a current wheel.
Squaloid: Like or pertaining to a shark or sharks.
Sesquitone: A minor third, or interval of three semitones.
Sinewy: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, a sinew or sinews.
Stenodermine: Of or pertaining to the genus Stenoderma, which includes several West Indian and South American nose-leaf bats.
Saccade: A sudden, violent check of a horse by drawing or twitching the reins on a sudden and with one pull.
Seesaw: Moving up and down, or to and fro; having a reciprocating motion.
Sterculiaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order (Sterculiaceæ) of polypetalous exogenous plants, mostly tropical. The cacao (Theobroma Cacao) is the most useful plant of the order.
Spine-finned: Having fine supported by spinous fin rays; -- said of certain fishes.
Smallpox: A contagious, constitutional, febrile disease characterized by a peculiar eruption; variola. The cutaneous eruption is at first a collection of papules which become vesicles (first flat, subsequently umbilicated) and then pustules, and finally thick crusts which slough after a certain time, often leaving a pit, or scar.
Succinamic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid amide derivative of succinic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, and forming a series of salts.
Synthetic: Of or pertaining to synthesis; consisting in synthesis or composition; as, the synthetic method of reasoning, as opposed to analytical.
Startlish: Easily startled; apt to start; startish; skittish; -- said especially of a horse.
Saxifragous: Dissolving stone, especially dissolving stone in the bladder.
Shieling: A hut or shelter for shepherds of fishers. See Sheeling.
Shoring: The act of supporting or strengthening with a prop or shore.
Seedlip: A vessel in which a sower carries the seed to be scattered.
Suffuse: To overspread, as with a fluid or tincture; to fill or cover, as with something fluid; as, eyes suffused with tears; cheeks suffused with blushes.
Spooler: One who, or that which, spools.
&Verbar;Stapelia: An extensive and curious genus of African plants of the natural order Asclepiadaceæ (Milkweed family). They are succulent plants without leaves, frequently covered with dark tubercles giving them a very grotesque appearance. The odor of the blossoms is like that of carrion.
Sclerotome: One of the bony, cartilaginous, or membranous partitions which separate the myotomes.
Servantry: A body of servants; servants, collectively.
Schizopod: Of or pertaining to a schizopod, or the Schizopoda.
Suction: The act or process of sucking; the act of drawing, as fluids, by exhausting the air.
Scabling: A fragment or chip of stone.
Shipboard: A ship's side; hence, by extension, a ship; -- found chiefly in adverbial phrases; as, on shipboard; a shipboard.
Swankie: An active and clever young fellow.
Solpugid: Of or pertaining to the Solifugæ.
Slate-gray: Of a dark gray, like slate.
Seamanship: The skill of a good seaman; the art, or skill in the art, of working a ship.
&Verbar;Simulacrum: A likeness; a semblance; a mock appearance; a sham; -- now usually in a derogatory sense.
Silica: Silicon dioxide, SiO&unr_;. It constitutes ordinary quartz (also opal and tridymite), and is artifically prepared as a very fine, white, tasteless, inodorous powder.
Sept: A clan, tribe, or family, proceeding from a common progenitor; -- used especially of the ancient clans in Ireland.
Sea risk: Risk of injury, destruction, or loss by the sea, or while at sea.
Spawn: The ova, or eggs, of fishes, oysters, and other aquatic animals.
Solstice: A stopping or standing still of the sun.
Seven: The number greater by one than six; seven units or objects.
Sensation: An impression, or the consciousness of an impression, made upon the central nervous organ, through the medium of a sensory or afferent nerve or one of the organs of sense; a feeling, or state of consciousness, whether agreeable or disagreeable, produced either by an external object (stimulus), or by some change in the internal state of the body.
&Verbar;Sanga: The Abyssinian ox (Bos Africanus syn. Bibos Africanus), noted for the great length of its horns. It has a hump on its back.
Supraspinate: Situated above a spine or spines; especially, situated above, or on the dorsal side of, the neural spines of the vertebral column, or above, or in front of, the spine of the scapula.
&Verbar;Sicca: A seal; a coining die; -- used adjectively to designate the silver currency of the Mogul emperors, or the Indian rupee of 192 grains.
Sever: To suffer disjunction; to be parted, or rent asunder; to be separated; to part; to separate.
Servomechanism: an electronically controlled mechanical or hydraulic device permitting a large action or strong forces to be controlled by a small electrical signal.
Submit: To yield one's person to the power of another; to give up resistance; to surrender.
Semiaxis: One half of the axis of an &unr_;llipse or other figure.
Spindleworm: The larva of a noctuid mmoth (Achatodes zeæ) which feeds inside the stalks of corn (maize), sometimes causing much damage. It is smooth, with a black head and tail and a row of black dots across each segment.
School-teacher: One who teaches or instructs a school.
Scapegoat: A goat upon whose head were symbolically placed the sins of the people, after which he was suffered to escape into the wilderness.
Sarcoderm: A fleshy covering of a seed, lying between the external and internal integuments.
Skirlcock: The missel thrush; -- so called from its harsh alarm note.
&Verbar;Sudarium: The handkerchief upon which the Savior is said to have impressed his own portrait miraculously, when wiping his face with it, as he passed to the crucifixion.
Swabber: One who swabs a floor or desk.
Suscitation: The act of raising or exciting.
Settler: One who settles, becomes fixed, established, etc.
Sycamore: A large tree (Ficus Sycomorus) allied to the common fig.  It is found in Egypt and Syria, and is the sycamore, or sycamine, of Scripture.
Straight-pight: Straight in form or upright in position; erect.
Slideway: A way along which something slides.
Stream line: The path of a constituent particle of a flowing fluid undisturbed by eddies or the like.
Subhumerate: To place the shoulders under; to bear.
&Verbar;Sporades: Stars not included in any constellation; -- called also informed, or unformed, stars.
Syphilization: Inoculation with the syphilitic virus, especially when employed as a preventive measure, like vaccination.
Soja: An Asiatic leguminous herb (Glycine max, formerly Glycine Soja) the seeds of which (called soy beans) are used in preparing the sauce called soy.  Called also soya.
Sarcosin: A crystalline nitrogenous substance, formed in the decomposition of creatin (one of the constituents of muscle tissue). Chemically, it is methyl glycocoll.
Successionist: A person who insists on the importance of a regular succession of events, offices, etc.; especially (Eccl.), one who insists that apostolic succession alone is valid.
Strid: A narrow passage between precipitous rocks or banks, which looks as if it might be crossed at a stride.
Sheldrake: Any one of several species of large Old World ducks of the genus Tadorna and allied genera, especially the European and Asiatic species. (Tadorna cornuta syn. Tadorna tadorna), which somewhat resembles a goose in form and habit, but breeds in burrows.
Scattered: Dispersed; dissipated; sprinkled, or loosely spread.
Subinvolution: Partial or incomplete involution; as, subinvolution of the uterus.
Strip: A narrow piece, or one comparatively long; as, a strip of cloth; a strip of land.
Sucrate: A compound of sucrose (or of some related carbohydrate) with some base, after the analogy of a salt; as, sodium sucrate.
Schilling: Any one of several small German and Dutch coins, worth from about one and a half cents to about five cents.
Substitute: To put in the place of another person or thing; to exchange.
Strix: One of the flutings of a column.
Souffle: A murmuring or blowing sound; as, the uterine souffle heard over the pregnant uterus.
Somnambulism: A condition of the nervous system in which an individual during sleep performs actions appropriate to the waking state; a state of sleep in which some of the senses and voluntary powers are partially awake; noctambulism.
Siskin: A small green and yellow European finch (Spinus spinus, or Carduelis spinus); -- called also aberdevine.
&Verbar;Sphagnum: A genus of mosses having white leaves slightly tinged with red or green and found growing in marshy places; bog moss; peat moss.
Sky: To hang (a picture on exhibition) near the top of a wall, where it can not be well seen.
Sheth: The part of a plow which projects downward beneath the beam, for holding the share and other working parts; -- also called standard, or post.
Sea pass: A document carried by neutral merchant vessels in time of war, to show their nationality; a sea letter or passport. See Passport.
Subsidiarily: In a subsidiary manner; so as to assist.
Somnambulist: A person who is subject to somnambulism; one who walks in his sleep; a sleepwalker; a noctambulist.
Somniloquist: One who talks in his sleep.
Ski: A long, flat, narrow runner made of wood, plastic or metal, curved upwards in front, having a fitting allowing it to be attached to the foot, and used for gliding or sliding over snow.  Commonly used in the plural, to designate the pair.
Summist: One who sums up; one who forms an abridgment or summary.
Stromboid: Of, pertaining to, or like, Strombus.
Shamer: One who, or that which, disgraces, or makes ashamed.
Sarcotic: Producing or promoting the growth of flesh.
States-general: In France, before the Revolution, the assembly of the three orders of the kingdom, namely, the clergy, the nobility, and the third estate, or commonalty.
Surrogate mother: a person or who serves in place of the biological mother for child, as for caring or nurturing.
sloo: A slough; a run or wet place. See 2d Slough, 2.
Step-: A prefix used before father, mother, brother, sister, son, daughter, child, etc., to indicate that the person thus spoken of is not a blood relative, but is a relative by the marriage of a parent; as, a stepmother to X is the wife of the father of X, married by him after the death of the mother of X. See Stepchild, Stepdaughter, Stepson, etc.
Swashbuckler: A bully or braggadocio; a swaggering, boastful fellow; a swaggerer.
Surprising: Exciting surprise; extraordinary; of a nature to excite wonder and astonishment; as, surprising bravery; a surprising escape from danger.
Supracostal: Situated above, or on the outside of, the ribs.
Seaside: The land bordering on, or adjacent to, the sea; the seashore. Also used adjectively.
Sepaline: Relating to, or having the nature of, sepals.
Speedy: Not dilatory or slow; quick; swift; nimble; hasty; rapid in motion or performance; as, a speedy flight; on speedy foot.
Supplicate: To make petition with earnestness and submission; to implore.
Sikhs: A religious sect noted for warlike traits, founded in the Punjab at the end of the 15th century.
Seagoing: Going upon the sea; especially, sailing upon the deep sea; -- used in distinction from coasting or river, as applied to vessels.
Shotten: Having ejected the spawn; as, a shotten herring.
Speciosity: The quality or state of being specious; speciousness.
Spillway: A sluiceway or passage for superfluous water in a reservoir, to prevent too great pressure on the dam.
Scrupulous: Full of scruples; inclined to scruple; nicely doubtful; hesitating to determine or to act, from a fear of offending or of doing wrong.
Simious: Of or pertaining to the Simiæ; monkeylike.
space bar: A bar or key, in a typewriter, typesetting machine, or other keyboard (as a computer keyboard), used to insert a space between letters.
Synthesize: To combine by synthesis; to unite.
Surliness: The quality or state of being surly.
Ship railway: An inclined railway running into the water with a cradelike car on which a vessel may be drawn out on land, as for repairs.
Selfishness: The quality or state of being selfish; exclusive regard to one's own interest or happiness; that supreme self-love or self-preference which leads a person to direct his purposes to the advancement of his own interest, power, or happiness, without regarding those of others.
Serosity: The quality or state of being serous.
Subbrachial: Of or pertaining to the subbrachians.
Speckle: To mark with small spots of a different color from that of the rest of the surface; to variegate with spots of a different color from the ground or surface.
Standish: A stand, or case, for pen and ink.
Stool: A single seat with three or four legs and without a back, made in various forms for various uses.
Souffl\u00e9: A side dish served hot from the oven at dinner, made of eggs, milk, and flour or other farinaceous substance, beaten till very light, and flavored with fruits, liquors, or essence.
Stoop: The act of stooping, or bending the body forward; inclination forward; also, an habitual bend of the back and shoulders.
Screechers: The picarian birds, as distinguished from the singing birds.
Superciliary: Of or pertaining to the eyebrows; supraorbital.
Statehood: The condition of being a State; as, a territory seeking Statehood.
Shoder: A package of gold beater's skins in which gold is subjected to the second process of beating.
Suffocative: Tending or able to choke or stifle.
Sapper: One who saps; specifically (Mil.), one who is employed in working at saps, building and repairing fortifications, and the like.
Slanderous: Given or disposed to slander; uttering slander.
Sacrificator: A sacrificer; one who offers a sacrifice.
Sabellian: A follower of Sabellius, a presbyter of Ptolemais in the third century, who maintained that there is but one person in the Godhead, and that the Son and Holy Spirit are only different powers, operations, or offices of the one God the Father.
Sadducee: One of a sect among the ancient Jews, who denied the resurrection, a future state, and the existence of angels.
Step-up: Transforming or converting a low-voltage current into one of high voltage; as, a step-up transformer.
Shaving: The act of one who, or that which, shaves; specifically, the act of cutting off the beard with a razor.
Seriation: Arrangement or position in a series.
Semipellucid: Half clear, or imperfectly transparent; as, a semipellucid gem.
Sunnud: A charter or warrant; also, a deed of gift.
