Service uniform: The uniform prescribed in regulations for active or routine service, in distinction from dress, full dress, etc. In the United States army it is of olive-drab woolen or khaki-colored cotton, with all metal attachments of dull-finish bronze, with the exceptional of insignia of rank, which are of gold or silver finish.
Storeroom: Room in a storehouse or repository; a room in which articles are stored.
Snow-blind: Affected with blindness by the brilliancy of snow.
&Verbar;Schizomycetes: An order of Schizophyta, including the so-called fission fungi, or bacteria. See Schizophyta, in the Supplement.
Spearfish: A large and powerful fish (Tetrapturus albidus) related to the swordfish, but having scales and ventral fins. It is found on the American coast and the Mediterranean.
Sarculation: A weeding, as with a hoe or a rake.
Subderivative: A word derived from a derivative, and not directly from the root; as, “friendliness” is a subderivative, being derived from “friendly”, which is in turn a derivative from “friend.”
Self-possessed: Composed or tranquil in mind, manner, etc.; undisturbed.
Sniffle: To snuffle, as one does with a catarrh.
Snast: The snuff, or burnt wick, of a candle.
Spider: Any one of numerous species of arachnids comprising the order Araneina. Spiders have the mandibles converted into poison fangs, or falcers. The abdomen is large and not segmented, with two or three pairs of spinnerets near the end, by means of which they spin threads of silk to form cocoons, or nests, to protect their eggs and young. Many species spin also complex webs to entrap the insects upon which they prey. The eyes are usually eight in number (rarely six), and are situated on the back of the cephalothorax. See Illust. under Araneina.
Stability: The state or quality of being stable, or firm; steadiness; stableness; firmness; strength to stand without being moved or overthrown; as, the stability of a structure; the stability of a throne or a constitution.
Sheepshank: A hitch by which a rope may be temporarily shortened.
Sexually: In a sexual manner or relation.
Sprawl: To spread and stretch the body or limbs carelessly in a horizontal position; to lie with the limbs stretched out ungracefully.
Steenkirk: A kind of neckcloth worn in a loose and disorderly fashion.
Septuagenary: Consisting of seventy; also, seventy years old.
Skied: imp. & p. p. of Ski, v. i.
Soaker: One who, or that which, soaks.
Scummer: An instrument for taking off scum; a skimmer.
Shaftman: A measure of about six inches.
Sea peach: A beautiful American ascidian (Cynthia pyriformis syn. Halocynthia pyriformis) having the size, form, velvety surface, and color of a ripe peach.
Sagger: A pot or case of fire clay, in which fine stoneware is inclosed while baking in the kiln; a seggar.
Sportule: A charitable gift or contribution; a gift; an alms; a dole; a largess; a sportula.
Sarcolactic: Relating to muscle and milk; as, sarcolactic acid. See Lactic acid, under Lactic.
Skullfish: A whaler's name for a whale more than two years old.
Socratist: A disciple or follower of Socrates.
Spoor: To follow a spoor or trail.
&Verbar;Sindi: A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.
Shorthand: A compendious and rapid method or writing by substituting characters, abbreviations, or symbols, for letters, words, etc.; short writing; stenography. See Illust. under Phonography.
Socratism: The philosophy or the method of Socrates.
&Verbar;Sierra: A ridge of mountain and craggy rocks, with a serrated or irregular outline; as, the Sierra Nevada.
Spiritual: A spiritual function, office, or affair. See Spirituality, 2.
Sectant: One of the portions of space bounded by the three coordinate planes. Specif. (Crystallog.), one of the parts of a crystal into which it is divided by the axial planes.
Stirpiculture: The breeding of special stocks or races.
Steerer: One who steers; as, a boat steerer.
Syllabication: The act of forming syllables; the act or method of dividing words into syllables. See Guide to Pron., §275.
Spherulitic: Of or pertaining to a spherulite; characterized by the presence of spherulites.
Snobbishness: Vulgar affectation or ostentation; mean admiration of mean things; conduct or manners of a snob.
Self-reliant: Reliant upon one's self; trusting to one's own powers or judgment.
Size: To take greater size; to increase in size.
Sennit: A braided cord or fabric formed by plaiting together rope yarns or other small stuff.
Sward-cutter: A plow for turning up grass land.
Spirituality: The quality or state of being spiritual; incorporeality; heavenly-mindedness.
Salvor: One who assists in saving a ship or goods at sea, without being under special obligation to do so.
&Verbar;Sem\u00e6ostomata: A division of Discophora having large free mouth lobes. It includes Aurelia, and Pelagia. Called also Semeostoma. See Illustr. under Discophora, and Medusa.
Sublet: To underlet; to lease, as when a lessee leases to another person.
Safe-conduct: To conduct safely; to give safe-conduct to.
Serfage: The state or condition of a serf.
Suitor: One who sues, petitions, or entreats; a petitioner; an applicant.
Sickerness: The quality or state of being sicker, or certain.
Spoutshell: Any marine gastropod shell of the genus Apporhais having an elongated siphon. See Illust. under Rostrifera.
Subtriple: Containing a third, or one part to three.
Syndical: Consisting of, or pert. to, a syndic.
Sagamore: The head of a tribe among the American Indians; a chief; -- generally used as synonymous with sachem, but some writters distinguished between them, making the sachem a chief of the first rank, and a sagamore one of the second rank.
Set chisel: A kind of chisel or punch, variously shaped, with a broad flat end, used for stripping off rivet heads, etc.
Slay: To put to death with a weapon, or by violence; hence, to kill; to put an end to; to destroy.
Slav: One of a race of people occupying a large part of Eastern and Northern Europe, including the Russians, Bulgarians, Roumanians, Servo-Croats, Slovenes, Poles, Czechs, Wends or Sorbs, Slovaks, etc.
Slaw: p. p. of Slee, to slay.
Slat: To slap; to strike; to beat; to throw down violently.
Skilled: Having familiar knowledge united with readiness and dexterity in its application; familiarly acquainted with; expert; skillful; -- often followed by in; as, a person skilled in drawing or geometry.
Slap: With a sudden and violent blow; hence, quickly; instantly; directly.
Slimy: Of or pertaining to slime; resembling slime; of the nature of slime; viscous; glutinous; also, covered or daubed with slime; yielding, or abounding in, slime.
Slam: The act of one who, or that which, slams.
Strengthener: One who, or that which, gives or adds strength.
Slag: To form, or form into, a slag; to agglomerate when heated below the fusion point.
Skillet: A small vessel of iron, copper, or other metal, with a handle, used for culinary purpose, as for stewing meat.
Slab: That which is slimy or viscous; moist earth; mud; also, a puddle.
Solitaire: A person who lives in solitude; a recluse; a hermit.
&Verbar;Synarthrosis: Immovable articulation by close union, as in sutures. It sometimes includes symphysial articulations also. See the Note under Articulation, n., 1.
Spermatism: The emission of sperm, or semen.
Seignioralty: The territory or authority of a seignior, or lord.
Semeiotics: The study of signs as an element of communication; the analysis of systems of communication; -- also called semiology.
Salmonoid: Like, or pertaining to, the Salmonidæ, a family of fishes including the trout and salmon.
Subnuvolar: Under the clouds; attended or partly covered or obscured by clouds; somewhat cloudy.
Separation: The act of separating, or the state of being separated, or separate.
Subsphenoidal: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the body of the sphenoid bone.
Sea turtle: Any one of several very large species of chelonians having the feet converted into paddles, as the green turtle, hawkbill, loggerhead, and leatherback. They inhabit all warm seas.
Snakewood: An East Indian climbing plant (Strychnos colubrina) having a bitter taste, and supposed to be a remedy for the bite of the hooded serpent.
Self-view: A view of one's self; specifically, carefulness or regard for one's own interests.
Sea pork: An American compound ascidian (Amorœcium stellatum) which forms large whitish masses resembling salt pork.
Subcranial: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the cranium; facial.
Shark: To play the petty thief; to practice fraud or trickery; to swindle.
Sea duck: Any one of numerous species of ducks which frequent the seacoasts and feed mainly on fishes and mollusks. The scoters, eiders, old squaw, and ruddy duck are examples. They may be distinguished by the lobate hind toe.
Seamark: Any elevated object on land which serves as a guide to mariners; a beacon; a landmark visible from the sea, as a hill, a tree, a steeple, or the like.
&Verbar;Strisores: A division of passerine birds including the humming birds, swifts, and goatsuckers. It is now generally considered an artificial group.
Share: To have part; to receive a portion; to partake, enjoy, or suffer with others.
Shard: A piece or fragment of an earthen vessel, or a like brittle substance, as the shell of an egg or snail.
Sharp: To play tricks in bargaining; to act the sharper.
Syphering: The lapping of chamfered edges of planks to make a smooth surface, as for a bulkhead.
Secularness: The quality or state of being secular; worldliness; worldly-mindedness.
Skew: To shape or form in an oblique way; to cause to take an oblique position.
Superiorly: In a superior position or manner.
Skee: A long strip of wood, curved upwards in front, used on the foot for sliding; now usually spelled ski.
Sower: One who, or that which, sows.
Staggerbush: An American shrub (Andromeda Mariana) having clusters of nodding white flowers. It grows in low, sandy places, and is said to poison lambs and calves.
Skatol: A constituent of human fæces formed in the small intestines as a product of the putrefaction of albuminous matter. It is also found in reduced indigo.  Chemically it is methyl indol, C9H9N.
Sleetch: Mud or slime, such as that at the bottom of rivers.
Superfetate: To conceive after a prior conception, but before the birth of the offspring.
Sympathy: Feeling corresponding to that which another feels; the quality of being affected by the affection of another, with feelings correspondent in kind, if not in degree; fellow-feeling.
Slant: Inclined from a direct line, whether horizontal or perpendicular; sloping; oblique.
soul kiss: A kiss in which both parties have their mouths open and pressed together, and the tongue of one or both is maneuvered within the mouth of the other.
Stirrage: The act of stirring; stir; commotion.
&Verbar;Saree: The principal garment of a Hindoo woman. It consists of a long piece of cloth, which is wrapped round the middle of the body, a portion being arranged to hang down in front, and the remainder passed across the bosom over the left shoulder.
Slang: To address with slang or ribaldry; to insult with vulgar language.
Sterno-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the sternum; as, sternocostal, sternoscapular.
Self-suspended: Suspended by one's self or by itself; balanced.
Sack-winged: Having a peculiar pouch developed near the front edge of the wing; -- said of certain bats of the genus Saccopteryx.
Scabbed: Abounding with scabs; diseased with scabs.
Serge: A large wax candle used in the ceremonies of various churches.
Stalked: Having a stalk or stem; borne upon a stem.
Sumatra leaf: A thin, elastic, uniformly light-colored tobacco leaf, raised in Sumatra and extensively used for cigar wrappers.
Sheath-winged: Having elytra, or wing cases, as a beetle.
Stunner: One who, or that which, stuns.
Scrawl: Unskillful or inelegant writing; that which is unskillfully or inelegantly written.
Scientist: One learned in science; a scientific investigator; one devoted to scientific study; a savant.
Spring steel: A variety of steel, elastic, strong, and tough, rolled for springs, etc.
Supraprotest: An acceptance of a bill by a third person after protest for nonacceptance by the drawee.
Summoner: One who summons; one who cites by authority; specifically, a petty officer formerly employed to summon persons to appear in court; an apparitor.
Supersede: To come, or be placed, in the room of; to replace.
&Verbar;Synapta: A genus of slender, transparent holothurians which have delicate calcareous anchors attached to the dermal plates. See Illustration in Appendix.
Subreption: The act of obtaining a favor by surprise, or by unfair representation through suppression or fraudulent concealment of facts.
Satyr: A sylvan deity or demigod, represented as part man and part goat, and characterized by riotous merriment and lasciviousness.
Sea hare: Any tectibranchiate mollusk of the genus Aplysia. See Aplysia.
Supertuberation: The production of young tubers, as potatoes, from the old while still growing.
Subsacral: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the sacrum.
Screw-driver: A tool for turning screws so as to drive them into their place. It has a thin end which enters the nick in the head of the screw.
Smalt: A deep blue pigment or coloring material used in various arts. It is a vitreous substance made of cobalt, potash, and calcined quartz fused, and reduced to a powder.
Sphinx: In Egyptian art, an image of granite or porphyry, having a human head, or the head of a ram or of a hawk, upon the wingless body of a lion.
Setbolt: An iron pin, or bolt, for fitting planks closely together.
Slacken: A spongy, semivitrifled substance which miners or smelters mix with the ores of metals to prevent their fusion.
Synonymize: To express by a synonym or synonyms; to give the synonym or synonyms corresponding to.
Sanguinariness: The quality or state of being sanguinary.
Shorling: The skin of a sheen after the fleece is shorn off, as distinct from the morling, or skin taken from the dead sheep; also, a sheep of the first year's shearing.
Sovereignly: In a sovereign manner; in the highest degree; supremely.
Serpentiform: Having the form of a serpent.
space-time: the four-dimensional coordinate system in which all physical objects of the known universe are located, and in which all physical events occur; it consists of three spatial dimensions and one time dimension; -- also called the space-time continuum.
Shea tree: An African sapotaceous tree (Bassia Parkii syn. Butyrospermum Parkii), from the seeds of which a substance resembling butter is obtained; the African butter tree.
Self-satisfied: Satisfied with one's self or one's actions; self-complacent.
S\u00e8vres ware: Porcelain manufactured at Sèvres, France, ecpecially in the national factory situated there.
&Verbar;Situs: The method in which the parts of a plant are arranged; also, the position of the parts.
Surmount: To rise above; to be higher than; to overtop.
Spiroylic: Pertaining to, or designating, a substance now called salicylal.
Seditious: Of or pertaining to sedition; partaking of the nature of, or tending to excite, sedition; as, seditious behavior; seditious strife; seditious words.
Sirenize: To use the enticements of a siren; to act as a siren; to fascinate.
Shackle: To tie or confine the limbs of, so as to prevent free motion; to bind with shackles; to fetter; to chain.
Sultanate: The rule or dominion of a sultan; sultanship.
Semispheric: Having the figure of a half sphere.
Self-reliance: Reliance on one's own powers or judgment; self-trust.
Spectrophone: An instrument constructed on the principle of the photophone and used in spectrum analysis as an adjunct to the spectroscope.
Swim: To be dizzy; to have an unsteady or reeling sensation; as, the head swims.
Salmagundi: A mixture of chopped meat and pickled herring, with oil, vinegar, pepper, and onions.
Swig: To castrate, as a ram, by binding the testicles tightly with a string, so that they mortify and slough off.
Salamander: Any one of numerous species of Urodela, belonging to Salamandra, Amblystoma, Plethodon, and various allied genera, especially those that are more or less terrestrial in their habits.
Self-convicted: Convicted by one's own consciousness, knowledge, avowal, or acts.
Subulipalp: One of a group of carabid beetles having slender palpi.
Savior: One who saves, preserves, or delivers from destruction or danger.
Slabberer: One who slabbers, or drools; hence, an idiot.
Sibyl: A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
&Verbar;Spongilla: A genus of siliceous sponges found in fresh water.
Serf: A servant or slave employed in husbandry, and in some countries attached to the soil and transferred with it, as formerly in Russia.
Sotted: a. & p. p. of Sot. Befooled; deluded; besotted.
Scratchback: A toy which imitates the sound of tearing cloth, -- used by drawing it across the back of unsuspecting persons.
Sorriness: The quality or state of being sorry.
Suttle: To act as sutler; to supply provisions and other articles to troops.
Sermocinator: One who makes sermons or speeches.
Streel: To trail along; to saunter or be drawn along, carelessly, swaying in a kind of zigzag motion.
Streek: To stretch; also, to lay out, as a dead body. See Streak.
Street: Originally, a paved way or road; a public highway; now commonly, a thoroughfare in a city or village, bordered by dwellings or business houses.
Spumescence: The state of being foamy; frothiness.
&Verbar;Signor: Sir; Mr.; -- a title of address or respect among the Italians. Before a noun the form is Signor.
Schizognathous: Having the maxillo-palatine bones separate from each other and from the vomer, which is pointed in front, as in the gulls, snipes, grouse, and many other birds.
Sapogenin: A white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of saponin.
Sandemanian: A follower of Robert Sandeman, a Scotch sectary of the eighteenth century. See Glassite.
Spetches: Parings and refuse of hides, skins, etc., from which glue is made.
Sycee: Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used as currency. The most common weight is about one pound troy.
Sorcerer: A conjurer; an enchanter; a magician.
Shapeless: Destitute of shape or regular form; wanting symmetry of dimensions; misshapen; -- opposed to shapely.
Swash: Impulse of water flowing with violence; a dashing or splashing of water.
Strictness: Quality or state of being strict.
Sacristy: An apartment in a church where the sacred utensils, vestments, etc., are kept; a vestry.
Sea fight: An engagement between ships at sea; a naval battle.
Servite: One of the order of the Religious Servants of the Holy Virgin, founded in Florence in 1223.
Sastrugi: Incorrect, but common, var. of Zastrugi.
Spalting knife: A knife used in splitting codfish.
Subprior: The vicegerent of a prior; a claustral officer who assists the prior.
Soho: Ho; -- a word used in calling from a distant place; a sportsman's halloo.
Sursolid: The fifth power of a number; as, a&unr_; is the sursolid of a, or 32 that of 2.
Spree: A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic; a carousal.
Stockjobbing: The act or art of dealing in stocks; the business of a stockjobber.
Stathmograph: A contrivance for recording the speed of a railway train.
Soldiery: A body of soldiers; soldiers, collectivelly; the military.
Spilter: Any one of the small branches on a stag's head.
Shibboleth: A word which was made the criterion by which to distinguish the Ephraimites from the Gileadites. The Ephraimites, not being able to pronounce sh, called the word sibboleth. See Judges xii.
Spitz dog: A breed of dogs having erect ears and long silky hair, usually white; -- called also Pomeranian dog, and louploup.
&Verbar;Seriema: either of two large South American birds related to the cranes, the cariama of Southern Brazil (Cariama cristata, formerly Dicholophus cristata) or the Chunga burmeisteri of Argentina. They have an erectile crest and a short, broad bill.  They are often domesticated.
Severance: The act of severing, or the state of being severed; partition; separation.
Sedulity: The quality or state of being sedulous; diligent and assiduous application; constant attention; unremitting industry; sedulousness.
Slangy: Of or pertaining to slang; of the nature of slang; disposed to use slang.
Sextoness: A female sexton; a sexton's wife.
Spoliate: To plunder; to pillage; to despoil; to rob.
Sportsman: One who pursues the sports of the field; one who hunts, fishes, etc.
Sylvic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pine or its products; specifically, designating an acid called also abeitic acid, which is the chief ingredient of common resin (obtained from Pinus sylvestris, and other species).
Starnose: A curious American mole (Condylura cristata) having the nose expanded at the end into a stellate disk; -- called also star-nosed mole.
Sultan: A ruler, or sovereign, of a Mohammedan state; specifically, the ruler of the Turks; the Padishah, or Grand Seignior; -- officially so called.
Stopcock: A bib, faucet, or short pipe, fitted with a turning stopper or plug for permitting or restraining the flow of a liquid or gas; a cock or valve for checking or regulating the flow of water, gas, etc., through or from a pipe, etc.
Sight-seer: One given to seeing sights or noted things, or eager for novelties or curiosities.
Sofa: A long seat, usually with a cushioned bottom, back, and ends; -- much used as a comfortable piece of furniture.
Sassorol: The rock pigeon. See under Pigeon.
Self-reproached: Reproached by one's own conscience or judgment.
Symbological: Pertaining to a symbology; versed in, or characterized by, symbology.
Sludge acid: Impure dark-colored sulphuric acid that has been used in the refining of petroleum.
Scoffery: The act of scoffing; scoffing conduct; mockery.
Sternutative: Having the quality of provoking to sneeze.
Singult: A sigh or sobbing; also, a hiccough.
Sporogony: The growth or development of an animal or a zooid from a nonsexual germ.
Sea willow: A gorgonian coral with long flexible branches.
Scowl: The wrinkling of the brows or face in frowing; the expression of displeasure, sullenness, or discontent in the countenance; an angry frown.
Spencer: A fore-and-aft sail, abaft the foremast or the mainmast, hoisted upon a small supplementary mast and set with a gaff and no boom; a trysail carried at the foremast or mainmast; -- named after its inventor, Knight Spencer, of England [1802].
Silence: To compel to silence; to cause to be still; to still; to hush.
Selflessness: Quality or state of being selfless.
Subeditor: An assistant editor, as of a periodical or journal.
skyrocket: To rise rapidly; -- usually used figuratively, as of prices.
Sorosis: A woman's club; an association of women.
&Verbar;Scrobicula: One of the smooth areas surrounding the tubercles of a sea urchin.
Smote: imp. (and rare p. p.) of Smite.
&Verbar;Sors: A lot; also, a kind of divination by means of lots.
Strained: Subjected to great or excessive tension; wrenched; weakened; as, strained relations between old friends.
Scarceness: The quality or condition of being scarce; smallness of quantity in proportion to the wants or demands; deficiency; lack of plenty; short supply; penury; as, a scarcity of grain; a great scarcity of beauties.
Surbed: To set edgewise, as a stone; that is, to set it in a position different from that which it had in the quarry.
Spectrogram: A photograph, map, or diagram of a spectrum.
Saki: The alcoholic drink of Japan. It is made from rice; it is usually spelled sake.
Stoat: The ermine in its summer pelage, when it is reddish brown, but with a black tip to the tail. The name is sometimes applied also to other brown weasels.
Subaxillary: Situated under the axilla, or armpit.
Shiite: A member of that branch of the Mohammedans to which the Persians belong. They reject the first three caliphs, and consider Ali as being the first and only rightful successor of Mohammed. They do not acknowledge the Sunna, or body of traditions respecting Mohammed, as any part of the law, and on these accounts are treated as heretics by the Sunnites, or orthodox Mohammedans.
Sirocco: An oppressive, relaxing wind from the Libyan deserts, chiefly experienced in Italy, Malta, and Sicily.
Silversmith: One whose occupation is to manufacture utensils, ornaments, etc., of silver; a worker in silver.
Stultiloquent: Given to, or characterized by, silly talk; babbling.
Spherulate: Covered or set with spherules; having one or more rows of spherules, or minute tubercles.
Subfamily: One of the subdivisions, of more importance than genus, into which certain families are divided.
Scruple: To regard with suspicion; to hesitate at; to question.
&Verbar;Smorzando: Growing gradually fainter and softer; dying away; morendo.
Statism: The art of governing a state; statecraft; policy.
Supersalt: An acid salt. See Acid salt (a), under Salt, n.
Speechifying: The act of making a speech or speeches.
Spotlight: The projected spot or circle of light used to illuminate brilliantly a single person or object or group on the stage, leaving the rest of the stage more or less unilluminated.
Strobilaceous: Of or pertaining to a strobile or cone.
Supplantation: The act of supplanting or displacing.
Sloe: A small, bitter, wild European plum, the fruit of the blackthorn (Prunus spinosa); also, the tree itself.
Stake-driver: The common American bittern (Botaurus lentiginosus); -- so called because one of its notes resembles the sound made in driving a stake into the mud.  Called also meadow hen, and Indian hen.
Spermophyte: Any plant which produces true seeds; -- a term recently proposed to replace phænogam.
Sorcering: Act or practice of using sorcery.
Sheet anchor: A large anchor stowed on shores outside the waist of a vessel; -- called also waist anchor. See the Note under Anchor.
Shortener: One who, or that which, shortens.
Surcharge: An overcharge; an excessive load or burden; a load greater than can well be borne.
Slype: A narrow passage between two buildings, as between the transept and chapter house of a monastery.
Sextain: A stanza of six lines; a sestine.
Somali: A Hamitic people of East Central Africa.
Saddlebags: Bags, usually of leather, united by straps or a band, formerly much used by horseback riders to carry small articles, one bag hanging on each side.
Stylite: One of a sect of anchorites in the early church, who lived on the tops of pillars for the exercise of their patience; -- called also pillarist and pillar saint.
Salpicon: Chopped meat, bread, etc., used to stuff legs of veal or other joints; stuffing; farce.
&Verbar;Satyrion: Any one of several kinds of orchids.
Succeed: To come in the place of another person, thing, or event; to come next in the usual, natural, or prescribed course of things; to follow; hence, to come next in the possession of anything; -- often with to.
Simulate: To assume the mere appearance of, without the reality; to assume the signs or indications of, falsely; to counterfeit; to feign.
Swish: A sound of quick movement, as of something whirled through the air.
&Verbar;Soldo: A small Italian coin worth a sou or a cent; the twentieth part of a lira.
&Verbar;Sambucus: A genus of shrubs and trees; the elder.
Somatic: Of or pertaining to the body as a whole; corporeal; as, somatic death; somatic changes.
Speedwell: Any plant of the genus Veronica, mostly low herbs with pale blue corollas, which quickly fall off.
Superabundant: Abounding to excess; being more than is sufficient; redundant; as, superabundant zeal.
&Verbar;Seiches: Local oscillations in level observed in the case of some lakes, as Lake Geneva.
Sea dove: The little auk, or rotche. See Illust. of Rotche.
Sealing wax: A compound of the resinous materials, pigments, etc., used as a material for seals, as for letters, documents, etc.
Sauroid: Like or pertaining to the saurians.
Suroxidate: To combine with oxygen so as to form a suroxide or peroxide.
Septentrionate: To tend or point toward the north; to north.
Snugness: The quality or state of being snug.
Skittles: An English game resembling ninepins, but played by throwing wooden disks, instead of rolling balls, at the pins.
Succedaneum: One who, or that which, succeeds to the place of another; that which is used for something else; a substitute;
&Verbar;Soutache: A kind of narrow braid, usually of silk; -- also known as Russian braid.
Shipment: The act or process of shipping; as, he was engaged in the shipment of coal for London; an active shipment of wheat from the West.
Stormglass: A glass vessel, usually cylindrical, filled with a solution which is sensitive to atmospheric changes, indicating by a clouded appearance, rain, snow, etc., and by clearness, fair weather.
Symbologist: One who practices, or who is versed in, symbology.
Steelyard: A form of balance in which the body to be weighed is suspended from the shorter arm of a lever, which turns on a fulcrum, and a counterpoise is caused to slide upon the longer arm to produce equilibrium, its place upon this arm (which is notched or graduated) indicating the weight; a Roman balance; -- very commonly used also in the plural form, steelyards.
Sorghum: A genus of grasses, properly limited to two species, Sorghum Halepense, the Arabian millet, or Johnson grass (see Johnson grass), and S. vulgare, the Indian millet (see Indian millet, under Indian).
Submediant: The sixth tone of the scale; the under mediant, or third below the keynote; the superdominant.
Screenings: The refuse left after screening sand, coal, ashes, etc.
Stringed: Having strings; as, a stringed instrument.
Subgroup: A subdivision of a group, as of animals.
Sound: To cause to make a noise; to play on; as, to sound a trumpet or a horn; to sound an alarm.
Synepy: The interjunction, or joining, of words in uttering the clauses of sentences.
Santalic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sandalwood (Santalum); -- used specifically to designate an acid obtained as a resinous or red crystalline dyestuff, which is called also santalin.
Suppositional: Resting on supposition; hypothetical; conjectural; supposed.
Sackage: The act of taking by storm and pillaging; sack.
Sewellel: A peculiar gregarious burrowing rodent (Haplodon rufus), native of the coast region of the Northwestern United States. It somewhat resembles a muskrat or marmot, but has only a rudimentary tail. Its head is broad, its eyes are small and its fur is brownish above, gray beneath. It constitutes the family Haplodontidæ.  Called also boomer, showt'l, and mountain beaver.
Sea chart: A chart or map on which the lines of the shore, islands, shoals, harbors, etc., are delineated.
Savagism: The state of being savage; the state of rude, uncivilized men, or of men in their native wildness and rudeness.
Shafiite: A member of one of the four sects of the Sunnites, or Orthodox Mohammedans; -- so called from its founder, Mohammed al-Shafeï.
Skag: An additional piece fastened to the keel of a boat to prevent lateral motion. See Skeg.
Sea ginger: A hydroid coral of the genus Millepora, especially Millepora alcicornis, of the West Indies and Florida.  So called because it stings the tongue like ginger. See Illust. under Millepore.
Supraorbital: Situated above the orbit of the eye.
Substantively: In a substantive manner; in substance; essentially.
Slish: A cut; as, slish and slash.
Surmise: To imagine without certain knowledge; to infer on slight grounds; to suppose, conjecture, or suspect; to guess.
Soleplate: A bedplate; as, the soleplate of a steam engine.
Shadowing: Shade, or gradation of light and color; shading.
Scampish: Of or like a scamp; knavish; as, scampish conduct.
Sea adder: The European fifteen-spined stickleback (Gasterosteus spinachia); -- called also bismore.
Seal-brown: Of a rich dark brown color, like the fur of the fur seal after it is dyed.
Setting: The act of one who, or that which, sets; as, the setting of type, or of gems; the setting of the sun; the setting (hardening) of moist plaster of Paris; the setting (set) of a current.
Surface: To rise from the depths of a liquid to the surface; as, the submarine surfaced to recharge its batteries.
Stickle: A shallow rapid in a river; also, the current below a waterfall.
Sunblink: A glimpse or flash of the sun.
Ship-rigged: Rigged like a ship, that is, having three masts, each with square sails.
Swaggerer: One who swaggers; a blusterer; a bully; a boastful, noisy fellow.
Saxicoline: Stone-inhabiting; pertaining to, or having the characteristics of, the stonechats.
Self-deceit: The act of deceiving one's self, or the state of being self-deceived; self-deception.
Starthroat: Any humming bird of the genus Heliomaster.  The feathers of the throat have a brilliant metallic luster.
Sunburn: The burning or discoloration produced on the skin by the heat of the sun; tan.
Separability: Quality of being separable or divisible; divisibility; separableness.
Simplist: One skilled in simples, or medicinal plants; a simpler.
Sanguiferous: Conveying blood; as, sanguiferous vessels, i. e., the arteries, veins, capillaries.
Superstructure: Any material structure or edifice built on something else; that which is raised on a foundation or basis
Sessile-eyed: Having eyes which are not elevated on a stalk; -- opposed to stalk-eyed.
Stringy: Consisting of strings, or small threads; fibrous; filamentous; as, a stringy root.
Serious: Grave in manner or disposition; earnest; thoughtful; solemn; not light, gay, or volatile.
Shortcake: An unsweetened breakfast cake shortened with butter or lard, rolled thin, and baked.
Sinapine: An alkaloid occuring in the seeds of mustard. It is extracted, in combination with sulphocyanic acid, as a white crystalline substance, having a hot, bitter taste.  When sinapine is isolated it is unstable and undergoes decomposition.
strongbox: A box of rigid and durable construction fitted with a lock, used for the purpose of protecting valuable items, such as jewelry or money.
Scraffle: To scramble or struggle; to wrangle; also, to be industrious.
Spank: To move with a quick, lively step between a trot and gallop; to move quickly.
Shape: Character or construction of a thing as determining its external appearance; outward aspect; make; figure; form; guise; as, the shape of a tree; the shape of the head; an elegant shape.
Sawder: A corrupt spelling and pronunciation of solder.
Sandemanianism: The faith or system of the Sandemanians.
&Verbar;Soutane: A close garnment with straight sleeves, and skirts reaching to the ankles, and buttoned in front from top to bottom; especially, the black garment of this shape worn by the clergy in France and Italy as their daily dress; a cassock.
Skeletonize: To prepare a skeleton of; also, to reduce, as a leaf, to its skeleton.
Sunnite: One of the orthodox Mohammedans who receive the Sunna as of equal importance with the Koran.
Subclavian: Situated under the clavicle, or collar bone; as, the subclavian arteries.
Spermosphere: A mass or ball of cells formed by the repeated division of a male germinal cell (spermospore), each constituent cell (spermoblast) of which is converted into a spermatozoid; a spermatogemma.
Syllabary: A table of syllables; more especially, a table of the indivisible syllabic symbols used in certain languages, as the Japanese and Cherokee, instead of letters.
Sleevehand: The part of a sleeve nearest the hand; a cuff or wristband.
Swimmeret: One of a series of flat, fringed, and usually bilobed, appendages, of which several pairs occur on the abdominal somites of many crustaceans. They are used as fins in swimming.
Shinney: The game of hockey; -- so called because of the liability of the players to receive blows on the shin.
Sibilant: Making a hissing sound; uttered with a hissing sound; hissing; as, s, z, sh, and zh, are sibilant elementary sounds.
Slock: To quench; to allay; to slake. See Slake.
Subhepatic: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the liver; -- applied to the interlobular branches of the portal vein.
Sprinkle: A small quantity scattered, or sparsely distributed; a sprinkling.
Scissible: Capable of being cut or divided by a sharp instrument.
&Verbar;Sextans: A Roman coin, the sixth part of an as.
&Verbar;Sargo: Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging to Sargus, Pomadasys, and related genera; -- called also sar, and saragu.
Starter: One who, or that which, starts; as, a starter on a journey; the starter of a race.
Scurrility: The quality or state of being scurrile or scurrilous; mean, vile, or obscene jocularity.
Shaveling: A man shaved; hence, a monk, or other religious; -- used in contempt.
Septi-: A combining form meaning seven; as, septifolious, seven-leaved; septi-lateral, seven-sided.
Slayer: One who slays; a killer; a murderer; a destroyer of life.
Serenity: The quality or state of being serene; clearness and calmness; quietness; stillness; peace.
Skinny: Consisting, or chiefly consisting, of skin; wanting flesh.
Scyllite: A white crystalline substance of a sweetish taste, resembling inosite and metameric with dextrose. It is extracted from the kidney of the dogfish (of the genus Scyllium), the shark, and the skate.
Selenious: Of, pertaining to, or containing, selenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with selenic compounds.
Schoolbook: A book used in schools for learning lessons.
Semeiological: Of or pertaining to the science of signs, or the systematic use of signs; as, a semeiological classification of the signs or symptoms of disease; a semeiological arrangement of signs used as signals.
Shrewish: having the qualities of a shrew; having a scolding disposition; froward; peevish.
Shoefly: A contrivance for throwing the track temporarily to one side for  convenience in filling washouts or effecting other repairs.
Scansion: The act of scanning; distinguishing the metrical feet of a verse by emphasis, pauses, or otherwise.
Scrippage: The contents of a scrip, or wallet.
Snoring: The act of respiring through the open mouth so that the currents of inspired and expired air cause a vibration of the uvula and soft palate, thus giving rise to a sound more or less harsh. It is usually unvoluntary, but may be produced voluntarily.
Stupefier: One who, or that which, stupefies; a stupefying agent.
Shiloh: A word used by Jacob on his deathbed, and interpreted variously, as “the Messiah,” or as the city “Shiloh,” or as “Rest.”
Sulu: A member of the most prominent tribe of the Moro tribes, occupying the Sulu Archipelago; also, their language.
Scrubby: Of the nature of scrub; small and mean; stunted in growth; as, a scrubby cur.
Succeeding: The act of one who, or that which, succeeds; also, that which succeeds, or follows after; consequence.
Sweeper: One who, or that which, sweeps, or cleans by sweeping; a sweep; as, a carpet sweeper.
Scopuliped: Any species of bee which has on the hind legs a brush of hairs used for collecting pollen, as the hive bees and bumblebees.
Subversion: The act of overturning, or the state of being overturned; entire overthrow; an overthrow from the foundation; utter ruin; destruction; as, the subversion of a government; the subversion of despotic power; the subversion of the constitution.
Sulphophosphorous: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical acid of phosphorus, analogous to phosphorous acid, and known in its salts.
Spectroelectric: Pert. to or designating any form of spark tube the electric discharge within which is used in spectroscopic observations.
&Verbar;Semuncia: A Roman coin equivalent to one twenty-fourth part of a Roman pound.
Scullery: A place where dishes, kettles, and culinary utensils, are cleaned and kept; also, a room attached to the kitchen, where the coarse work is done; a back kitchen.
Snuggle: To move one way and the other so as to get a close place; to lie close for comfort; to cuddle; to nestle.
&Verbar;Siphonophora: An order of pelagic Hydrozoa including species which form complex free-swimming communities composed of numerous zooids of various kinds, some of which act as floats or as swimming organs, others as feeding or nutritive zooids, and others as reproductive zooids. See Illust. under Physallia, and Porpita.
Sectionalize: To divide according to geographical sections or local interests.
Saturation: The act of saturating, or the state of being saturating; complete penetration or impregnation.
Service elevator: an elevator for carrying large or havy items, or for the use of service people.
Stipe: The stalk or petiole of a frond, as of a fern.
Sea snipe: A sandpiper, as the knot and dunlin.
Strelitz: A soldier of the ancient Muscovite guard or Russian standing army; also, the guard itself.
Self-command: Control over one's own feelings, temper, etc.; self-control.
Sea lettuce: The green papery fronds of several seaweeds of the genus Ulva, sometimes used as food.
Seemly: In a decent or suitable manner; becomingly.
Sarsen: One of the large sandstone blocks scattered over the English chalk downs; -- called also sarsen stone, and Druid stone.
Sea lion: Any one of several large species of seals of the family Otariidæ native of the Pacific Ocean, especially the southern sea lion (Otaria jubata) of the South American coast; the northern sea lion (Eumetopias Stelleri) found from California to Japan; and the black, or California, sea lion (Zalophus Californianus), which is common on the rocks near San Francisco.
singles: For unmarried persons, or catering especially to unmarried persons; as, a singles bar; a singles party.
Sulk: To be silently sullen; to be morose or obstinate.
Subtenant: One who rents a tenement, or land, etc., of one who is also a tenant; an undertenant.
Shortwing: Any one of several species of small wrenlike Asiatic birds having short wings and a short tail. They belong to Brachypterix, Callene, and allied genera.
Serrous: Like the teeth off a saw; jagged.
&Verbar;S\u00e9rac: A pinnacle of ice among the crevasses of a glacier; also, one of the blocks into which a glacier breaks on a steep grade.
Siphuncle: The tube which runs through the partitions of chambered cephalopod shells.
Sweetwater: A variety of white grape, having a sweet watery juice; -- also called white sweetwater, and white muscadine.
Sallowness: The quality or condition of being sallow.
Scorification: The act, process, or result of scorifying, or reducing to a slag; hence, the separation from earthy matter by means of a slag; as, the scorification of ores.
Subdepartment: A subordinate department; a bureau. See the Note under Bureau.
Solicitation: The act of soliciting; earnest request; persistent asking; importunity.
Supra-ethmoid: Above, or on the dorsal side of, the ethmoid bone or cartilage.
&Verbar;Soma: The whole axial portion of an animal, including the head, neck, trunk, and tail.
Shopwalker: One who walks about in a shop as an overseer and director.  Cf. Floorwalker.
Seagirt: Surrounded by the water of the sea or ocean; as, a seagirt isle.
Simplicity: The quality or state of being simple, unmixed, or uncompounded; as, the simplicity of metals or of earths.
Southerner: An inhabitant or native of the south, esp. of the Southern States of North America; opposed to Northerner.
Sharebeam: The part of the plow to which the share is attached.
Sexdigitist: One who has six fingers on a hand, or six toes on a foot.
Sothiac: Of or pertaining to Sothis, the Egyptian name for the Dog Star; taking its name from the Dog Star; canicular.
Squashiness: The quality or state of being squashy, or soft.
Self-delusion: The act of deluding one's self, or the state of being thus deluded.
&Verbar;Saltatoria: A division of Orthoptera including grasshoppers, locusts, and crickets.
Sarmatian: Of or pertaining to Sarmatia, or its inhabitants, the ancestors of the Russians and the Poles.
Sequoia: A genus of coniferous trees, consisting of two species, Sequoia Washingtoniana, syn. S. gigantea, the “big tree” of California, and S. sempervirens, the redwood, both of which attain an immense height.
Sexdigitism: The state of having six fingers on a hand, or six toes on a foot.
Subpubic: Situated under, or posterior to, the pubic bones.
Stickful: As much set type as fills a composing stick.
Scleroskeleton: That part of the skeleton which is developed in tendons, ligaments, and aponeuroses.
Screechy: Like a screech; shrill and harsh.
Subject-matter: The matter or thought presented for consideration in some statement or discussion; that which is made the object of thought or study.
Shallow-waisted: Having a flush deck, or with only a moderate depression amidships; -- said of a vessel.
Subordinacy: The quality or state of being subordinate, or subject to control; subordination, as, to bring the imagination to act in subordinacy to reason.
Surveying: That branch of applied mathematics which teaches the art of determining the area of any portion of the earth's surface, the length and directions of the bounding lines, the contour of the surface, etc., with an accurate delineation of the whole on paper; the act or occupation of making surveys.
Subsultory: Bounding; leaping; moving by sudden leaps or starts.
Squamose: Covered with, or consisting of, scales; resembling a scale; scaly; as, the squamose cones of the pine; squamous epithelial cells; the squamous portion of the temporal bone, which is so called from a fancied resemblance to a scale.
Spiralozooid: One of the special defensive zooids of certain hydroids. They have the form of long, slender tentacles, and bear lasso cells.
Scalenohedron: A pyramidal form under the rhombohedral system, inclosed by twelve faces, each a scalene triangle.
Snowflake: A flake, or small filmy mass, of snow.
Sinistrin: A mucilaginous carbohydrate, resembling achroödextrin, extracted from squill as a colorless amorphous substance; -- so called because it is levorotatory.
Spongiform: Resembling a sponge; soft and porous; porous.
Sitology: A treatise on the regulation of the diet; dietetics.
Song: That which is sung or uttered with musical modulations of the voice, whether of a human being or of a bird, insect, etc.
Shiver-spar: A variety of calcite, so called from its slaty structure; -- called also slate spar.
&Verbar;Scoliosis: A lateral curvature of the spine.
Sejunction: The act of disjoining, or the state of being disjoined.
Saltfoot: A large saltcellar formerly placed near the center of the table. The superior guests were seated above the saltfoot.
Self-acting: Acting of or by one's self or by itself; -- said especially of a machine or mechanism which is made to perform of or for itself what is usually done by human agency; automatic; as, a self-acting feed apparatus; a self-acting mule; a self-acting press.
Sanctified: Made holy; also, made to have the air of sanctity; sanctimonious.
Sewel: A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hung up to prevent deer from breaking into a place.
Sanctifier: One who sanctifies, or makes holy; specifically, the Holy Spirit.
Subsulphide: A nonacid compound consisting of one equivalent of sulphur and more than one equivalent of some other body, as a metal.
Sewer: Formerly, an upper servant, or household officer, who set on and removed the dishes at a feast, and who also brought water for the hands of the guests.
Superstitious: Of or pertaining to superstition; proceeding from, or manifesting, superstition; as, superstitious rites; superstitious observances.
Syntonic: Of or pert. to syntony; specif., designating, or pert. to, a system of wireless telegraphy in which the transmitting and receiving apparatus are in syntony with, and only with, one another.
Strophe: In Greek choruses and dances, the movement of the chorus while turning from the right to the left of the orchestra; hence, the strain, or part of the choral ode, sung during this movement. Also sometimes used of a stanza of modern verse. See the Note under Antistrophe.
Stripping: The act of one who strips.
Scholarship: The character and qualities of a scholar; attainments in science or literature; erudition; learning.
Systyle: Having a space equal to two diameters or four modules between two columns; -- said of a portico or building. See Intercolumniation.
Sagene: A Russian measure of length equal to about seven English feet.
Shuffle: The act of shuffling; a mixing confusedly; a slovenly, dragging motion.
Sanitarium: A health station or retreat; a sanatorium.
Shikaree: A sportsman; esp., a native hunter.
Statutable: Made or introduced by statute; proceeding from an act of the legistature; as, a statutable provision or remedy.
&Verbar;Sombrero: A kind of broad-brimmed hat, worn in Spain and in Spanish America.
Submaxillary: Situated under the maxilla, or lower jaw; inframaxillary; as, the submaxillary gland.
Sextile: The aspect or position of two planets when distant from each other sixty degrees, or two signs. This position is marked thus: ✶.
Strew: To scatter; to spread by scattering; to cast or to throw loosely apart; -- used of solids, separated or separable into parts or particles; as, to strew seed in beds; to strew sand on or over a floor; to strew flowers over a grave.
Scribable: Capable of being written, or of being written upon.
Self-love: The love of one's self; desire for personal happiness; tendency to seek one's own benefit or advantage.
Shamefaced: Easily confused or put out of countenance; diffident; bashful; modest.
Sensualization: The act of sensualizing, or the state of being sensualized.
&Verbar;Spirula: A genus of cephalopods having a multilocular, internal, siphunculated shell in the form of a flat spiral, the coils of which are not in contact.
Superhuman: Above or beyond what is human; sometimes, divine; as, superhuman strength; superhuman wisdom.
Stanchness: The quality or state of being stanch.
Spadefoot: Any species of burrowing toads of the genus Scaphiopus, esp. Scaphiopus Holbrookii, of the Eastern United States; -- called also spade toad.
Scrawler: One who scrawls; a hasty, awkward writer.
Salivate: To produce an abnormal flow of saliva in; to produce salivation or ptyalism in, as by the use of mercury.
Sheepberry: The edible fruit of a small North American tree of the genus Viburnum (V. Lentago), having white flowers in flat cymes; also, the tree itself. Called also nannyberry.
Seership: The office or quality of a seer.
Shellac: Lac which has been reduced to a thin crust.  See the Note under 2d Lac.
Superfine: Very fine, or most fine; being of surpassing fineness; of extra nice or fine quality; as, superfine cloth.
Swingebuckler: A swashbuckler; a bully; a roisterer.
Sternson: The end of a ship's keelson, to which the sternpost is bolted; -- called also stern knee.
Subdeaconry: The order or office of subdeacon.
&Verbar;Struthio: A genus of birds including the African ostriches.
Scout: To go on the business of scouting, or watching the motions of an enemy; to act as a scout.
&Verbar;Stemma: One of the ocelli of an insect. See Ocellus.
Spicknel: An umbelliferous herb (Meum Athamanticum) having finely divided leaves, common in Europe; -- called also baldmoney, mew, and bearwort.
Symbology: The art of expressing by symbols.
Scath: Harm; damage; injury; hurt; waste; misfortune.
Shelly: Abounding with shells; consisting of shells, or of a shell.
Scorpene: A marine food fish of the genus Scorpæna, as the European hogfish (S. scrofa), and the California species (S. guttata).
Steganopodous: Having all four toes webbed together.
Splintery: Consisting of splinters; resembling splinters; as, the splintery fracture of a mineral.
Souple: That part of a flail which strikes the grain.
Sumpter: Carrying pack or burdens on the back; as, a sumpter horse; a sumpter mule.
Subsulphate: A sulphate with an excess of the base.
Swiftlet: Any one of numerous species of small East Indian and Asiatic swifts of the genus Collocalia. Some of the species are noted for furnishing the edible bird's nest. See Illust. under Edible.
Syncarpous: Composed of several carpels consolidated into one ovary.
Sergeancy: The office of a sergeant; sergeantship.
Sectary: A sectarian; a member or adherent of a sect; a follower or disciple of some particular teacher in philosophy or religion; one who separates from an established church; a dissenter.
Savable: Capable of, or admitting of, being saved.
Splashy: Full of dirty water; wet and muddy, so as be easily splashed about; slushy.
Starvedly: In the condition of one starved or starving; parsimoniously.
Spoiler: One who spoils; a plunderer; a pillager; a robber; a despoiler.
Subquadruple: Containing one part of four; in the ratio of one to four; as, subquadruple proportion.
&Verbar;Serpentarius: A constellation on the equator, lying between Scorpio and Hercules; -- called also Ophiuchus.
Strategy: The science of military command, or the science of projecting campaigns and directing great military movements; generalship.
Silicle: A seed vessel resembling a silique, but about as broad as it is long. See Silique.
&Verbar;Scopula: A peculiar brushlike organ found on the foot of spiders and used in the construction of the web.
Swelldom: People of rank and fashion; the class of swells, collectively.
Stock: Used or employed for constant service or application, as if constituting a portion of a stock or supply; standard; permanent; standing; as, a stock actor; a stock play; a stock phrase; a stock response; a stock sermon.
Self-heal: A blue-flowered labiate plant (Brunella vulgaris); the healall.
Self-born: Born or produced by one's self.
Spiracular: Of or pertaining to a spiracle.
Scurviness: The quality or state of being scurvy; vileness; meanness.
Satanic: Of or pertaining to Satan; having the qualities of Satan; resembling Satan; extremely malicious or wicked; devilish; infernal.
Stoichiometric: Of or pertaining to stoichiometry; employed in, or obtained by, stoichiometry.
Stearyl: The hypothetical radical characteristic of stearic acid.
Swingling: a. & n. from Swingle, v. t.
Spawling: That which is spawled, or spit out.
Stemson: A piece of curved timber bolted to the stem, keelson, and apron in a ship's frame near the bow.
Subtangent: The part of the axis contained between the ordinate and tangent drawn to the same point in a curve.
Saliva: The secretion from the salivary glands.
Superpolitic: More than politic; above or exceeding policy.
Secretitious: Parted by animal secretion; as, secretitious humors.
Sinewed: Furnished with sinews; as, a strong-sinewed youth.
Spoon-meat: Food that is, or must be, taken with a spoon; liquid food.
Starvation: The act of starving, or the state of being starved.
Self-conscious: Conscious of one's acts or state as belonging to, or originating in, one's self.
&Verbar;Scombriformes: A division of fishes including the mackerels, tunnies, and allied fishes.
Soc: The lord's power or privilege of holding a court in a district, as in manor or lordship; jurisdiction of causes, and the limits of that jurisdiction.
Sob: The act of sobbing; a convulsive sigh, or inspiration of the breath, as in sorrow.
Soe: A large wooden vessel for holding water; a cowl.
Sod: To cover with sod; to turf.
Suctorian: A cartilaginous fish with a mouth adapted for suction, as the lampery.
Sol: A fluid mixture of a colloid and a liquid; a liquid colloidal solution or suspension.
Son: A male child; the male issue, or offspring, of a parent, father or mother.
Slatter: To be careless, negligent, or aswkward, esp. with regard to dress and neatness; to be wasteful.
Sou: An old French copper coin, equivalent in value to, and now displaced by, the five-centime piece (1/20 of a franc), which is popularly called a sou.
Sectarianism: The quality or character of a sectarian; devotion to the interests of a party; excess of partisan or denominational zeal; adherence to a separate church organization.
Sow: To scatter seed for growth and the production of a crop; -- literally or figuratively.
Soy: A Chinese and Japanese liquid sauce for fish, etc., made by subjecting boiled beans (esp. soybeans), or beans and meal, to long fermentation and then long digestion in salt and water.
Sophistry: The art or process of reasoning; logic.
Seminist: A believer in the old theory that the newly created being is formed by the admixture of the seed of the male with the supposed seed of the female.
Shindle: To cover or roof with shindles.
Smelter: One who, or that which, smelts.
Spheno-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the sphenoid bone; as in sphenomaxillary, sphenopalatine.
Saw-whet: A small North American owl (Nyctale Acadica), destitute of ear tufts and having feathered toes; -- called also Acadian owl.
Self-luminous: Possessing in itself the property of emitting light.
Seconder: One who seconds{3} or supports what another attempts, affirms, moves, or proposes; as, the seconder of an enterprise or of a motion.
Saintship: The character or qualities of a saint.
Straw: A stalk or stem of certain species of grain, pulse, etc., especially of wheat, rye, oats, barley, more rarely of buckwheat, beans, and pease.
Selters water: A mineral water from Sellers, in the district of Nassan, Germany, containing much free carbonic acid.
Staidness: The quality or state of being staid; seriousness; steadiness; sedateness; regularity; -- the opposite of wildness, or levity.
Sphagnous: Pertaining to moss of the genus Sphagnum, or bog moss; abounding in peat or bog moss.
Superfete: To conceive (another fetus) after a former conception.
Seducer: One who, or that which, seduces.  For a female seducer, the term seductress is also used
Shop: To visit shops for the purpose of purchasing goods.
Supernumerary: A person or thing beyond the number stated.
Sea partridge: The gilthead (Crenilabrus melops), a fish of the British coasts.
set-in sleeve: A sleeve joined to the body of a garment by a seam starting at the edge of the shoulder and continuing around the armhole.  Contrasted to a raglan sleeve.
Strangle hold: a hold by which one's opponent is choked. It is usually not allowed.
Six-shooter: A pistol or other firearm which can be fired six times without reloading especially, a six-chambered revolver.
Stereoplasm: The solid or insoluble portion of the cell protoplasm. See Hygroplasm.
Sharpsaw: The great titmouse; -- so called from its harsh call notes.
Senonian: In european geology, a name given to the middle division of the Upper Cretaceous formation.
Splint: To split into splints, or thin, slender pieces; to splinter; to shiver.
Straitly: In a strait manner; narrowly; strictly; rigorously.
Stolon: A trailing branch which is disposed to take root at the end or at the joints; a stole.
Sight: To take aim by a sight.
Supra-axillary: Growing above the axil; inserted above the axil, as a peduncle. See Suprafoliaceous.
Spline: A rectangular piece fitting grooves like key seats in a hub and a shaft, so that while the one may slide endwise on the other, both must revolve together; a feather; also, sometimes, a groove to receive such a rectangular piece.
Silent: That which is silent; a time of silence.
Summery: Of or pertaining to summer; like summer; as, a summery day.
Sandstone: A rock made of sand more or less firmly united. Common or siliceous sandstone consists mainly of quartz sand.
Scot: A portion of money assessed or paid; a tax or contribution; a mulct; a fine; a shot.
Silene: A genus of caryophyllaceous plants, usually covered with a viscid secretion by which insects are caught; catchfly.
Switchel: A beverage of molasses and water, seasoned with vinegar and ginger.
Sashoon: A kind of pad worn on the leg under the boot.
Sobriety: Habitual soberness or temperance as to the use of spirituous liquors; as, a man of sobriety.
Sloppy: Wet, so as to spatter easily; wet, as with something slopped over; muddy; plashy; as, a sloppy place, walk, road.
Sarco-: A combining form from Gr. sa`rx, sa`rkos, flesh; as, sarcophagous, flesh-eating; sarcology.
Satsuma ware: A kind of ornamental hard-glazed pottery made at Satsuma in Kiushu, one of the Japanese islands.
Set-stitched: Stitched according to a formal pattern.
Shot samples: Samples taken for assay from  a molten metallic mass pouring a portion into water, to granulate it.
Shoe: To furnish with a shoe or shoes; to put a shoe or shoes on; as, to shoe a horse, a sled, an anchor.
Sculler: A boat rowed by one man with two sculls, or short oars.
&Verbar;Stenosis: A narrowing of the opening or hollow of any passage, tube, or orifice; as, stenosis of the pylorus. It differs from stricture in being applied especially to diffused rather than localized contractions, and in always indicating an origin organic and not spasmodic.
Sniff: The act of sniffing; perception by sniffing; that which is taken by sniffing; as, a sniff of air.
Self-conceit: Conceit of one's self; an overweening opinion of one's powers or endowments.
Slender: Small or narrow in proportion to the length or the height; not thick; slim; as, a slender stem or stalk of a plant.
Subindex: A number or mark placed opposite the lower part of a letter or symbol to distinguish the symbol; thus, a0, b1, c2, xn, have 0, 1, 2, and n as subindices.
&Verbar;Sekes: A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deities were inclosed.
Sulphostannic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphacid of tin (more exactly called metasulphostannic acid), which is obtained as a dark brown amorphous substance, H&unr_;SnS&unr_;, forming a well-known series of salts.
Sugary: Resembling or containing sugar; tasting of sugar; sweet.
Somnipathist: A person in a state of somniapathy.
Scuff: To walk without lifting the feet; to proceed with a scraping or dragging movement; to shuffle.
Scandalous: Giving offense to the conscience or moral feelings; exciting reprobation; calling out condemnation.
Sea snake: Any one of many species of venomous aquatic snakes of the family Hydrophidæ, having a flattened tail and living entirely in the sea, especially in the warmer parts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. They feed upon fishes, and are mostly of moderate size, but some species become eight or ten feet long and four inches broad.
Soft-spoken: Speaking softly; having a mild or gentle voice; hence, mild; affable.
Staymaker: One whose occupation is to make stays.
Safranin: An orange-red dyestuff extracted from the saffron.
Shaw: A thicket; a small wood or grove.
Starproof: Impervious to the light of the stars; as, a starproof elm.
Shag: To make hairy or shaggy; hence, to make rough.
Shad: Any one of several species of food fishes of the Herring family. The American species (Alosa sapidissima formerly Clupea sapidissima), which is abundant on the Atlantic coast and ascends the larger rivers in spring to spawn, is an important market fish. The European allice shad, or alose (Alosa alosa  formerly Clupea alosa), and the twaite shad (Alosa finta  formerly Clupea finta), are less important species.
Shah: A former title of the supreme ruler in certain Eastern countries, especially Persia and Iran.
Sham: To make false pretenses; to deceive; to feign; to impose.
Superexcination: Excessive, or more than normal, excitation.
spar: An old name for a nonmetallic mineral, usually cleavable and somewhat lustrous; as, calc spar, or calcite, fluor spar, etc.  It was especially used in the case of the gangue minerals of a metalliferous vein.
Sturionian: One of the family of fishes of which the sturgeon is the type.
Stargazer: One who gazes at the stars; an astrologer; sometimes, in derision or contempt, an astronomer.
Statue: To place, as a statue; to form a statue of; to make into a statue.
&Verbar;Span\u00e6mia: A condition of impoverishment of the blood; a morbid state in which the red corpuscles, or other important elements of the blood, are deficient.
Surreptitious: Done or made by stealth, or without proper authority; made or introduced fraudulently; clandestine; stealthy; as, a surreptitious passage in an old manuscript; a surreptitious removal of goods.
Steady: To become steady; to regain a steady position or state; to move steadily.
Slickensides: The smooth, striated, or partially polished surfaces of a fissure or seam, supposed to have been produced by the sliding of one surface on another.
Solstitial: Of or pertaining to a solstice.
Siphonostome: Any parasitic entomostracan of the tribe Siphonostomata.
Sleepful: Strongly inclined to sleep; very sleepy.
Scapolite: A grayish white mineral occuring in tetragonal crystals and in cleavable masses. It is essentially a silicate of alumina and soda.
Salivous: Pertaining to saliva; of the nature of saliva.
Spinnaker: A large triangular sail set upon a boom, -- used when running before the wind.
Spale: A lath; a shaving or chip, as of wood or stone.
Sartorial: Of or pertaining to a tailor or his work.
Spall: To give off spalls, or wedge-shaped chips; -- said of stone, as when badly set, with the weight thrown too much on the outer surface.
&Verbar;Shippo: Cloisonné enamel on a background of metal or porcelain; -- also called shippo yaki.
Springiness: The state or quality of being springy.
Sectional: Of or pertaining to a section or distinct part of larger body or territory; local.
Scotchman: A native or inhabitant of Scotland; a Scot; a Scotsman.
Seckel: A small reddish brown sweet and juicy pear. It originated on a farm near Philadelphia, afterwards owned by a Mr. Seckel.
Siderostat: An apparatus consisting essentially of a mirror moved by clockwork so as to throw the rays of the sun or a star in a fixed direction; -- a more general term for heliostat.
Splash: Water, or water and dirt, thrown upon anything, or thrown from a puddle or the like; also, a spot or daub, as of matter which wets or disfigures.
Syngenesis: A theory of generation in which each germ is supposed to contain the germs of all subsequent generations; -- the opposite of epigenesis.
Sirrah: A term of address implying inferiority and used in anger, contempt, reproach, or disrespectful familiarity, addressed to a man or boy, but sometimes to a woman. In sililoquies often preceded by ah. Not used in the plural.
Salacity: Strong propensity to venery; lust; lecherousness.
Suiogoths: The Scandinavian Goths. See the Note under Goths.
Supercharge: A bearing charged upon another bearing.
Saccharize: To convert into, or to impregnate with, sugar.
Solenacean: Any species of marine bivalve shells belonging to the family Solenidæ.
Saponaceous: Resembling soap; having the qualities of soap; soapy.
Sandish: Approaching the nature of sand; loose; not compact.
Stroll: A wandering on foot; an idle and leisurely walk; a ramble.
Streamer: An ensign, flag, or pennant, which floats in the wind; specifically, a long, narrow, ribbonlike flag.
Saint-Simonism: A system of socialism in which the state owns all the property and the laborer is entitled to share according to the quality and  amount of his work, founded by Saint Simon (1760-1825); -- called also Saint- Simonianism.
Serpentize: To turn or bend like a serpent, first in one direction and then in the opposite; to meander; to wind; to serpentine.
Soreness: The quality or state of being sore; tenderness; painfull; as, the soreness of a wound; the soreness of an affliction.
Schizocarp: A dry fruit which splits at maturity into several closed one-seeded portions.
Summary: A general or comprehensive statement; an abridged account; an abstract, abridgment, or compendium, containing the sum or substance of a fuller account.
Self-justifier: One who excuses or justifies himself.
Stulm: A shaft or gallery to drain a mine.
Southcottian: A follower of Joanna Southcott (1750-1814), an Englishwoman who, professing to have received a miraculous calling, preached and prophesied, and committed many impious absurdities.
Sciuroid: Resembling the tail of a squirrel; -- generally said of branches which are close and dense, or of spikes of grass like barley.
&Verbar;Suctoria: An order of Infusoria having the body armed with somewhat stiff, tubular processes which they use as suckers in obtaining their food. They are usually stalked.
Stilar: Of or pertaining to the style of a dial.
Subjectist: One skilled in subjective philosophy; a subjectivist.
Scrod: A young codfish, especially when cut open on the back and dressed.
Scrog: A stunted shrub, bush, or branch.
&Verbar;Stegocephala: An extinct order of amphibians found fossil in the Mesozoic rocks; called also Stegocephali, and Labyrinthodonta.
Straticulate: Characterized by the presence of thin parallel strata, or layers, as in an agate.
&Verbar;Synecphonesis: A contraction of two syllables into one; synizesis.
Soddy: Consisting of sod; covered with sod; turfy.
Surrebound: To give back echoes; to reëcho.
Scutch grass: A kind of pasture grass (Cynodon Dactylon). See Bermuda grass: also Illustration in Appendix.
&Verbar;Satyriasis: Immoderate venereal appetite in the male.
Shabbiness: The quality or state of being sghabby.
&Verbar;Squilla: Any one of numerous stomapod crustaceans of the genus Squilla and allied genera.  They make burrows in mud or beneath stones on the seashore.  Called also mantis shrimp. See Illust. under Stomapoda.
Silicified: Combined or impregnated with silicon or silica, especially the latter; as, silicified wood.
Strangulated: Having the circulation stopped by compression; attended with arrest or obstruction of circulation, caused by constriction or compression; as, a strangulated hernia.
Stem: To move forward against an obstacle, as a vessel against a current.
Step: An advance or movement made by one removal of the foot; a pace.
Stive: The floating dust in flour mills caused by the operation or grinding.
Stew: A place of stewing or seething; a place where hot bathes are furnished; a hothouse.
Sarplier: A coarse cloth made of hemp, and used for packing goods, etc.
Sanatorium: An establishment for the treatment of the sick; a resort for invalids. See Sanitarium.
Salaam: To make or perform a salam.
Saturnist: A person of a dull, grave, gloomy temperament.
Squawroot: A scaly parasitic plant (Conopholis Americana) found in oak woods in the United States; -- called also cancer root.
Spicule: A minute, slender granule, or point.
Spiritless: Destitute of spirit; wanting animation; wanting cheerfulness; dejected; depressed.
Snider rifle: A breech-loading rifle formerly used in the British service; -- so called from the inventor.
Scratch coat: The first coat in plastering; -- called also scratchwork. See Pricking-up.
&Verbar;Souffl\u00e9: Decorated with very small drops or sprinkles of color, as if blown from a bellows.
Screamer: Any one of three species of South American birds constituting the family Anhimidæ, and the suborder Palamedeæ. They have two spines on each wing, and the head is either crested or horned. They are easily tamed, and then serve as guardians for other poultry. The crested screamers, or chajas, belong to the genus Chauna. The horned screamer, or kamichi, is Palamedea cornuta.
Stereograph: Any picture, or pair of pictures, prepared for exhibition in the stereoscope. Stereographs are now commonly made by means of photography.
&Verbar;Sieur: Sir; -- a title of respect used by the French.
Sabbath: A season or day of rest; one day in seven appointed for rest or worship, the observance of which was enjoined upon the Jews in the Decalogue, and has been continued by the Christian church with a transference of the day observed from the last to the first day of the week, which is called also Lord's Day.
Supererogate: To do more than duty requires; to perform works of supererogation; to atone (for a dificiency in another) by means of a surplus action or quality.
Semined: Thickly covered or sown, as with seeds.
Skat: A three-handed card game played with 32 cards, of which  two constitute the skat (sense 2), or widow. The players bid for the privilege of attempting any of several games or tasks, in most of which the player undertaking the game must take tricks counting in aggregate at least 61 (the counting cards being ace 11, ten 10, king 4, queen 3, jack 2). The four jacks are the best trumps, ranking club, spade, heart, diamond, and ten outranks king or queen (but when the player undertakes to lose all the tricks, the cards rank as in whist). The value of hands depends upon the game played, trump suit, points taken, and number of matadores.
Squirehood: The rank or state of a squire; squireship.
Scatter-brain: A giddy or thoughtless person; one incapable of concentration or attention.
Sodium: A common metallic element of the alkali group, in nature always occuring combined, as in common salt, in albite, etc. It is isolated as a soft, waxy, white, unstable metal, so highly reactive that it combines violently with water, and to be preserved must be kept under petroleum or some similar liquid. Sodium is used combined in many salts, in the free state as a reducer, and as a means of obtaining other metals (as magnesium and aluminium) is an important commercial product. Symbol Na (Natrium). Atomic weight 22.990.  Specific gravity 0.97.
Smoother: One who, or that which, smooths.
Sorbition: The act of drinking or sipping.
Scaleboard: A thin slip of wood used to justify a page.
Stonehenge: An assemblage of upright stones with others placed horizontally on their tops, on Salisbury Plain, England, -- generally supposed to be the remains of an ancient Druidical temple.
Self-considering: Considering in one's own mind; deliberating.
Signaturist: One who holds to the doctrine of signatures impressed upon objects, indicative of character or qualities.
Serricorn: Any one of a numerous tribe of beetles (Serricornia). The joints of the antennæ are prominent, thus producing a serrate appearance. See Illust. under Antenna.
Shepherdly: Resembling, or becoming to, a shepherd; pastoral; rustic.
Sincipital: Of or pertaining to the sinciput; being in the region of the sinciput.
Self-sufficing: Sufficing for one's self or for itself, without needing external aid; self-sufficient.
Soapiness: Quality or state of being soapy.
Sooterkin: A kind of false birth, fabled to be produced by Dutch women from sitting over their stoves; also, an abortion, in a figurative sense; an abortive scheme.
Slipslop: Weak, poor, or flat liquor; weak, profitless discourse or writing.
Southwester: A storm, gale, or strong wind from the southwest.
Seabeach: A beach lying along the sea.
Spectator: One who on; one who sees or beholds; a beholder; one who is personally present at, and sees, any exhibition; as, the spectators at a show.
Semidetached: Half detached; partly distinct or separate.
Stratify: To form or deposit in strata, or layers, as substances in the earth; to arrange in strata.
Streak: To form streaks or stripes in or on; to stripe; to variegate with lines of a different color, or of different colors.
&Verbar;Spermatheca: A small sac connected with the female reproductive organs of insects and many other invertebrates, serving to receive and retain the spermatozoa.
Stream: To send forth in a current or stream; to cause to flow; to pour; as, his eyes streamed tears.
Sufflation: The act of blowing up or inflating.
Sylphid: A little sylph; a young or diminutive sylph.
Stewardly: In a manner, or with the care, of a steward.
Steeplechasing: The act of riding steeple chases.
Snub-nosed: Having a short, flat nose, slightly turned up; as, the snub-nosed eel.
Sardonic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a kind of linen made at Colchis.
Semi pupa: The young of an insect in a stage between the larva and pupa.
Spooney: A weak-minded or silly person; one who is foolishly fond.
Stoneweed: Any plant of the genus Lithospermum, herbs having a fruit composed of four stony nutlets.
Staff: Plaster combined with fibrous and other materials so as to be suitable for sculpture in relief or in the round, or for forming flat plates or boards of considerable size which can be nailed to framework to make the exterior of a larger structure, forming joints which may afterward be repaired and concealed with fresh plaster.
Skinch: To give scant measure; to squeeze or pinch in order to effect a saving.
salsuginous: Growing in brackish places or in salt marshes.
Submultiple: Of or pertaining to a submultiple; being a submultiple; as, a submultiple number; submultiple ratio.
Simpleton: A person of weak intellect; a silly person.
Sexagenary: Something composed of sixty parts or divisions.
Scalenohedral: Of or pertaining to a scalenohedron.
Solo: Performing, or performed, alone; uncombined, except with subordinate parts, voices, or instruments; not concerted.
Sapid: Having the power of affecting the organs of taste; possessing savor, or flavor.
Skysail: The sail set next above the royal. See Illust. under Sail.
Scandalize: To offend the feelings or the conscience of (a person) by some action which is considered immoral or criminal; to bring shame, disgrace, or reproach upon.
Sola: A leguminous plant (Æschynomene aspera) growing in moist places in Southern India and the East Indies. Its pithlike stem is used for making hats, swimming-jackets, etc.
Sulphocarbonate: A salt of sulphocarbonic acid; a thiocarbonate.
Second-rate: Of the second size, rank, quality, or value; as, a second-rate ship; second-rate cloth; a second-rate champion.
Squirm: To twist about briskly with contortions like an eel or a worm; to wriggle; to writhe.
&Verbar;Scleroderma: A disease of adults, characterized by a diffuse rigidity and hardness of the skin.
Systematology: The doctrine of, or a treatise upon, systems.
Stillicide: A continual falling or succession of drops; rain water falling from the eaves.
&Verbar;Schlich: The finer portion of a crushed ore, as of gold, lead, or tin, separated by the water in certain wet processes.
Subtly: In a subtle manner; slyly; artfully; cunningly.
Safe-pledge: A surety for the appearance of a person at a given time.
Sulphantimonic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid of antimony (called also thioantimonic acid) analogous to sulpharsenic acid.
Subtle: Sly in design; artful; cunning; insinuating; subtile; -- applied to persons; as, a subtle foe.
Snow-bound: Enveloped in, or confined by, snow.
&Verbar;Sankha: A chank shell (Turbinella pyrum); also, a shell bracelet or necklace made in India from the chank shell.
Squamosal: Scalelike; squamous; as, the squamosal bone.
Saturnicentric: Appearing as if seen from the center of the planet Saturn; relating or referred to Saturn as a center.
Syderolite: A kind of Bohemian earthenware resembling the Wedgwood ware.
Sponsional: Of or pertaining to a pledge or agreement; responsible.
&Verbar;Stichidium: A special podlike or fusiform branch containing tetraspores. It is found in certain red algæ.
Several: Each particular taken singly; an item; a detail; an individual.
Spongoblast: One of the cells which, in sponges, secrete the spongin, or the material of the horny fibers.
Star stereogram: A view of the universe of brighter stars as it would appear to an observer transported into space outside or beyond our universe of stars.
Sooner: In the western United States, one who settles on government land before it is legally open to settlement in order to gain the prior claim that the law gives to the first settler when the land is opened to settlement; hence, any one who does a thing prematurely or anticipates another in acting in order to gain an unfair advantage.
Strontium: A metallic element of the calcium group, always naturally occurring combined, as in the minerals strontianite, celestite, etc. It is isolated as a yellowish metal, somewhat malleable but harder than calcium. It is chiefly employed (as in the nitrate) to color pyrotechnic flames red. Symbol Sr. Atomic weight 87.3.
Sheathbill: Either one of two species of birds composing the genus Chionis, and family Chionidæ, native of the islands of the Antarctic seas.
