Speechifier: One who makes a speech or speeches; an orator; a declaimer.
Septet: A set of seven persons or objects; as, a septet of singers.
Sayette: A mixed stuff, called also sagathy. See Sagathy.
Surinam toad: A species of toad native of Surinam. See Pipa.
Sweetmeat: Fruit preserved with sugar, as peaches, pears, melons, nuts, orange peel, etc.; -- usually in the plural; a confect; a confection.
Sufflaminate: To retard the motion of, as a carriage, by preventing one or more of its wheels from revolving, either by means of a chain or otherwise.
Sedate: Undisturbed by passion or caprice; calm; tranquil; serene; not passionate or giddy; composed; staid; as, a sedate soul, mind, or temper.
Syncretist: One who attempts to unite principles or parties which are irreconcilably at variance;
Stinkwood: A name given to several kinds of wood with an unpleasant smell, as that of the Fœtidia Mauritiana of the Mauritius, and that of the South African Ocotea bullata.
Sumpitan: A kind of blowgun for discharging arrows, -- used by the savages of Borneo and adjacent islands.
Skitter: To pass or glide lightly or with quick touches at intervals; to skip; to skim.
Stereometry: The art of measuring and computing the cubical contents of bodies and figures; -- distinguished from planimetry.
&Verbar;Serpette: A pruning knife with a curved blade.
Subchanter: An underchanter; a precentor's deputy in a cathedral; a succentor.
Span\u00e6mic: Of or pertaining to spanæmia; having impoverished blood.
Schoolhouse: A house appropriated for the use of a school or schools, or for instruction.
Supinator: A muscle which produces the motion of supination.
Semivitrification: The quality or state of being semivitrified.
Sesquiplicate: Subduplicate of the triplicate; -- a term applied to ratios; thus, a and a' are in the sesquiplicate ratio of b and b', when a is to a' as the square root of the cube of b is to the square root of the cube of b', or a:a'::√b3:√b'3.
Scientific: Of or pertaining to science; used in science; as, scientific principles; scientific apparatus; scientific observations.
Secretariat: The office of a secretary; the place where a secretary transacts business, keeps records, etc.
Semiditone: A lesser third, having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone.
Squawweed: The golden ragwort. See under Ragwort.
Slugworm: Any caterpillar which has the general appearance of a slug, as do those of certain moths belonging to Limacodes and allied genera, and those of certain sawflies.
Sentine: A place for dregs and dirt; a sink; a sewer.
Saccharoid: Resembling sugar, as in taste, appearance, consistency, or composition; as, saccharoidal limestone.
Succedaneous: Pertaining to, or acting as, a succedaneum; supplying the place of something else; being, or employed as, a substitute for another.
Shindy: An uproar or disturbance; a spree; a row; a riot.
Secretarial: Of or pertaining to a secretary; befitting a secretary.
Solid: A substance that is held in a fixed form by cohesion among its particles; a substance not fluid.
Salite: A massive lamellar variety of pyroxene, of a dingy green color.
Semidiameter: Half of a diameter; a right line, or the length of a right line, drawn from the center of a circle, a sphere, or other curved figure, to its circumference or periphery; a radius.
Sphenography: The art of writing in cuneiform characters, or of deciphering inscriptions made in such characters.
Self-denying: Refusing to gratify one's self; self-sacrificing.
Salad days: a period when a person is young and inexperienced.
Sensuosity: The quality or state of being sensuous; sensuousness.
Swelling: The act of that which swells; as, the swelling of rivers in spring; the swelling of the breast with pride.
Sporting: Of, pertaining to, or engaging in, sport or sports; exhibiting the character or conduct of one who, or that which, sports.
Self-ignorance: Ignorance of one's own character, powers, and limitations.
Sag: State of sinking or bending; sagging.
&Verbar;Scenario: A preliminary sketch of the plot, or main incidents, of an opera.
Selenic: Of or pertaining to selenium; derived from, or containing, selenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with selenious compounds.
Shoaliness: The quality or state of being shoaly; little depth of water; shallowness.
Squamiform: Having the shape of a scale.
Salivary: Of or pertaining to saliva; producing or carrying saliva; as, the salivary ferment; the salivary glands; the salivary ducts, etc.
Sap: A narrow ditch or trench made from the foremost parallel toward the glacis or covert way of a besieged place by digging under cover of gabions, etc.
Saw: To use a saw; to practice sawing; as, a man saws well.
Squir: To throw with a jerk; to throw edge foremost.
Safeness: The quality or state of being safe; freedom from hazard, danger, harm, or loss; safety; security; as the safeness of an experiment, of a journey, or of a possession.
Saxon: Of or pertaining to the Saxons, their country, or their language.
Saddleback: Anything saddle-backed; esp., a hill or ridge having a concave outline at the top.
Selfhood: Existence as a separate self, or independent person; conscious personality; individuality.
Supersensible: Beyond the reach of the senses; above the natural powers of perception.
Schizo-: A combining form denoting division or cleavage; as, schizogenesis, reproduction by fission or cell division.
Sea bear: Any fur seal. See under Fur.
Stomatic: A medicine for diseases of the mouth.
Scolopendrine: Like or pertaining to the Scolopendra.
Sesquitertian: Having the ratio of one and one third to one (as 4 : 3).
Semiformed: Half formed; imperfectly formed; as, semiformed crystals.
Shawnees: A tribe of North American Indians who occupied Western New York and part of Ohio, but were driven away and widely dispersed by the Iroquois.
Supereminent: Eminent in a superior degree; surpassing others in excellence; as, a supereminent divine; the supereminent glory of Christ.
Stubbedness: The quality or state of being stubbed.
Statesman: A man versed in public affairs and in the principles and art of government; especially, one eminent for political abilities.
Shortly: In a short or brief time or manner; soon; quickly.
Surrogate: To put in the place of another; to substitute.
Sadducaic: Pertaining to, or like, the Sadducees; as, Sadducaic reasonings.
Saphead: A weak-minded, stupid fellow; a milksop.
Spent: Exhausted; worn out; having lost energy or motive force.
Schmelze: A kind of glass of a red or ruby color, made in Bohemia.
Self-reproach: The act of reproaching one's self; censure by one's own conscience.
Smilingness: Quality or state of being smiling.
Spiked: Furnished or set with spikes, as corn; fastened with spikes; stopped with spikes.
Spend: To expend money or any other possession; to consume, use, waste, or part with, anything; as, he who gets easily spends freely.
Suzerain: A superior lord, to whom fealty is due; a feudal lord; a lord paramount.
Surmisable: Capable of being surmised; as, a surmisable result.
slip stitch: loose stitch catching only a thread or two of fabric, designed to be invisible from the right side.
Smokeless powder: A high-explosive gunpowder whose explosion produces little, if any, smoke.  It is usually based on guncotton.
&Verbar;Sacrarium: A sort of family chapel in the houses of the Romans, devoted to a special divinity.
Shearing: The act or operation of clipping with shears or a shearing machine, as the wool from sheep, or the nap from cloth.
Star drift: Similar and probably related motion of the stars of an asterism, as distinguished from apparent change of place due to solar motion.-- ##?? = star streaming? --
Subterfuge: That to which one resorts for escape or concealment; an artifice employed to escape censure or the force of an argument, or to justify opinions or conduct; a shift; an evasion.
Shallow-bodied: Having a moderate depth of hold; -- said of a vessel.
Suleah fish: A coarse fish of India, used in making a breakfast relish called burtah.
Scrobiculate: Having numerous small, shallow depressions or hollows; pitted.
Shipowner: Owner of a ship or ships.
Scrobicular: Pertaining to, or surrounding, scrobiculæ; as, scrobicular tubercles.
&Verbar;Sadr: A plant of the genus Ziziphus (Z. lotus); -- so called by the Arabs of Barbary, who use its berries for food. See Lotus (b).
Spray paint: paint packaged in a spray can.
Strobile: A scaly multiple fruit resulting from the ripening of an ament in certain plants, as the hop or pine; a cone. See Cone, n., 3.
Smash: A breaking or dashing to pieces; utter destruction; wreck.
Sidereal: Relating to the stars; starry; astral; as, sidereal astronomy.
Sugaring: The act of covering or sweetening with sugar; also, the sugar thus used.
Switchman: One who tends a switch on a railway.
Spectatorial: Of or pertaining to a spectator.
Sector: A part of a circle comprehended between two radii and the included arc.
Sea snail: A small fish of the genus Liparis, having a ventral sucker. It lives among stones and seaweeds.
Sea flower: A sea anemone, or any related anthozoan.
science fiction: A genre of fiction in which scientific and technological issues feature prominently, especially including scenarios in which speculative but unproven scientific advances are accepted as fact, and usually set at some time in the future, or in some distant region of the universe.
Saltern: A building or place where salt is made by boiling or by evaporation; salt works.
Souther: A strong wind, gale, or storm from the south.
Sisal grass: The prepared fiber of the Agave Americana, or American aloe, used for cordage; -- so called from Sisal, a port in Yucatan. See Sisal hemp, under Hemp.
Sentience: The quality or state of being sentient; esp., the quality or state of having sensation.
Syenitic: Relating to Syene; as, Syenitic inscriptions.
Sea chickweed: A fleshy plant (Arenaria peploides) growing in large tufts in the sands of the northern Atlantic seacoast; -- called also sea sandwort, and sea purslane.
Sycophancy: The character or characteristic of a sycophant.
Scutibranchiate: Having the gills protected by a shieldlike shell; of or pertaining to the Scutibranchiata.
Sphygmograph: An instrument which, when applied over an artery, indicates graphically the movements or character of the pulse. See Sphygmogram.
Self-educated: Educated by one's own efforts, without instruction, or without pecuniary assistance from others.
Sundry: Several; divers; more than one or two; various.
Surbase: A cornice, or series of moldings, on the top of the base of a pedestal, podium, etc. See Illust. of Column.
&Verbar;Spermatophyta: A phylum embracing the highest plants, or those that produce seeds; the  seed plants, or flowering plants. They form the most numerous group, including over 120,000 species. In general, the group is characterized by the marked development of the sporophyte, with great differentiation of its parts (root, stem, leaves, flowers, etc.); by the extreme reduction of the gametophyte; and by the development of seeds. All the Spermatophyta are heterosporous; fertilization of the egg cell is either through a pollen tube emitted by the microspore or (in a few gymnosperms) by spermatozoids.
Stele: A stale, or handle; a stalk.
Shredless: Having no shreds; without a shred.
&Verbar;Sorex: A genus of small Insectivora, including the common shrews.
Self-moved: Moved by inherent power., without the aid of external impulse.
Samaritan: Of or pertaining to Samaria, in Palestine.
Subjectivism: Any philosophical doctrine which refers all knowledge to, and founds it upon, any subjective states; egoism.
Stiffness: The quality or state of being stiff; as, the stiffness of cloth or of paste; stiffness of manner; stiffness of character.
Supersaturate: To add to beyond saturation; as, to supersaturate a solution.
Squarrose: Ragged or full of loose scales or projecting parts; rough; jagged
Sudd: A tangled mass of floating vegetal matter obstructing navigation.
Self-abasement: Degradation of one's self by one's own act.
Scrappy: Consisting of scraps; fragmentary; lacking unity or consistency; as, a scrappy lecture.
&Verbar;Serpigo: A dry, scaly eruption on the skin; especially, a ringworm.
Segregate: To separate from a mass, and collect together about centers or along lines of fracture, as in the process of crystallization or solidification.
Scallop: To mark or cut the edge or border of into segments of circles, like the edge or surface of a scallop shell. See Scallop, n., 2.
Suds: Water impregnated with soap, esp. when worked up into bubbles and froth.
Sluttery: The qualities and practices of a slut; sluttishness; slatternlines.
Slumming: Visiting slums.  Sometimes used humorously, in reference to the appearance of a dignified person in a situation generally thought of as low-class.
Severity: The quality or state of being severe.
Seduce: To draw aside from the path of rectitude and duty in any manner; to entice to evil; to lead astray; to tempt and lead to iniquity; to corrupt.
Shrine: To enshrine; to place reverently, as in a shrine.
Sixscore: Six times twenty; one hundred and twenty.
&Verbar;Samshoo: A spirituous liquor distilled by the Chinese from the yeasty liquor in which boiled rice has fermented under pressure.
Sibbens: A contagious disease, endemic in Scotland, resembling the yaws. It is marked by ulceration of the throat and nose and by pustules and soft fungous excrescences upon the surface of the body. In the Orkneys the name is applied to the itch.
Shrink: The act shrinking; shrinkage; contraction; also, recoil; withdrawal.
Studbook: A genealogical register of a particular breed or stud of horses, esp. thoroughbreds.
&Verbar;Sarcoptes: A genus of parasitic mites including the itch mites.
Synovial: Of or pertaining to synovia; secreting synovia.
Sorcery: Divination by the assistance, or supposed assistance, of evil spirits, or the power of commanding evil spirits; magic; necromancy; witchcraft; enchantment.
&Verbar;Santalum: A genus of trees with entire opposite leaves and small apetalous flowers. There are less than a dozen species, occurring from India to Australia and the Pacific Islands. See Sandalwood.
Serin: A European finch (Serinus hortulanus) closely related to the canary.
Strong: Having active physical power, or great physical power to act; having a power of exerting great bodily force; vigorous.
Systematize: To reduce to system or regular method; to arrange methodically; to methodize; as, to systematize a collection of plants or minerals; to systematize one's work; to systematize one's ideas.
Stanno-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting relating to tin, or connected with tin, or indicating containing tin as an ingredient.
Sea level: The level of the surface of the sea; any surface on the same level with the sea.
Sensualize: To make sensual; to subject to the love of sensual pleasure; to debase by carnal gratifications; to carnalize; as, sensualized by pleasure.
Sonship: The state of being a son, or of bearing the relation of a son; filiation.
Stony: Of or pertaining to stone, consisting of, or abounding in, stone or stones; resembling stone; hard; as, a stony tower; a stony cave; stony ground; a stony crust.
Seaworthy: Fit for a voyage; worthy of being trusted to transport a cargo with safety; as, a seaworthy ship.
Scrabbed eggs: A Lenten dish, composed of eggs boiled hard, chopped, and seasoned with butter, salt, and pepper.
Saprophytic: Feeding or growing upon decaying animal or vegetable matter; pertaining to a saprophyte or the saprophytes.
Superlation: Exaltation of anything beyond truth or propriety.
Sickler: One who uses a sickle; a sickleman; a reaper.
Scrid: A screed; a shred; a fragment.
Sinologist: A student of China and the Chinese; one versed in the Chinese language, literature, history, politics and culture.  Same as sinologue.
Scrim: A kind of light cotton or linen fabric, often woven in openwork patterns, -- used for curtains, etc,; -- called also India scrim.
Singlestick: In England and Scotland, a cudgel used in fencing or fighting; a backsword.
Source: The act of rising; a rise; an ascent.
Songstress: A woman who sings; also, a female singing bird.
Sisterhood: The state or relation of being a sister; the office or duty of a sister.
Sea fir: A sertularian hydroid, especially Sertularia abietina, which branches like a miniature fir tree.
&Verbar;Scarus: A Mediterranean food fish (Sparisoma scarus) of excellent quality and highly valued by the Romans; -- called also parrot fish.
Surmullet: Any one of various species of mullets of the family Millidæ, esp. the European species (Millus surmulletus), which is highly prized as a food fish. See Mullet.
Silversides: Any one of several species of small fishes of the family Atherinidæ, having a silvery stripe along each side of the body. The common species of the American coast (Menidia notata) is very abundant. Called also silverside, sand smelt, friar, tailor, and tinker.
Sapphirine: Resembling sapphire; made of sapphire; having the color, or any quality of sapphire.
Stinkhorn: A kind of fungus of the genus Phallus, which emits a fetid odor.
&Verbar;Symbiosis: The living together in more or less imitative association or even close union of two dissimilar organisms. In a broad sense the term includes parasitism, or antagonistic symbiosis or antipathetic symbiosis, in which the association is disadvantageous or destructive to one of the organisms, but ordinarily it is used of cases where the association is advantageous, or often necessary, to one or both, and not harmful to either. When there is bodily union (in extreme cases so close that the two form practically a single body, as in the union of algæ and fungi to form lichens, and in the inclusion of algæ in radiolarians) it is called conjunctive symbiosis; if there is no actual union of the organisms (as in the association of ants with myrmecophytes), disjunctive symbiosis.
Surmountable: Capable of being surmounted or overcome; superable.
Subduction: The act of subducting or taking away.
Sundries: Many different or small things; sundry things.
Self-originating: Beginning with, or springing from, one's self.
Seacoast: The shore or border of the land adjacent to the sea or ocean. Also used adjectively.
Self-affrighted: Frightened at or by one's self.
Sequin: An old gold coin of Italy and Turkey. It was first struck at Venice about the end of the 13th century, and afterward in the other Italian cities, and by the Levant trade was introduced into Turkey. It is worth about 9s. 3d. sterling, or about $2.25. The different kinds vary somewhat in value.
slitter: One who, or that which, slits.
&Verbar;Sporidium: A secondary spore, or a filament produced from a spore, in certain kinds of minute fungi.
Suradanni: A valuable kind of wood obtained on the shores of the Demerara River in South America, much used for timbers, rails, naves and fellies of wheels, and the like.
Scopiform: Having the form of a broom or besom.
Spinaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant spinach, or the family of plants to which it belongs.
Superadvenient: Coming upon; coming in addition to, or in assistance of, something.
Springtail: Any one of numerous species of small apterous insects belonging to the order Thysanura. They have two elastic caudal stylets which can be bent under the abdomen and then suddenly extended like a spring, thus enabling them to leap to a considerable distance. See Collembola, and Podura.
Sialogogue: An agent which promotes the flow of saliva.
Stayed: Staid; fixed; settled; sober; -- now written staid. See Staid.
Suspicious: Inclined to suspect; given or prone to suspicion; apt to imagine without proof.
Siderography: The art or practice of steel engraving; especially, the process, invented by Perkins, of multiplying facsimiles of an engraved steel plate by first rolling over it, when hardened, a soft steel cylinder, and then rolling the cylinder, when hardened, over a soft steel plate, which thus becomes a facsimile of the original. The process has been superseded by electrotypy.
Somniatory: Pertaining to sleep or dreams; somnial.
Stayer: One who upholds or supports that which props; one who, or that which, stays, stops, or restrains; also, colloquially, a horse, man, etc., that has endurance, as in a race.
Sure-footed: Not liable to stumble or fall; as, a sure-footed horse.
Slapdash: To apply, or apply something to, in a hasty, careless, or rough manner; to roughcast; as, to slapdash mortar or paint on a wall, or to slapdash a wall.
Spongiole: A supposed spongelike expansion of the tip of a rootlet for absorbing water; -- called also spongelet.
Sowbane: The red goosefoot (Chenopodium rubrum), -- said to be fatal to swine.
Soprano: The treble; the highest vocal register; the highest kind of female or boy's voice; the upper part in harmony for mixed voices.
Sext: The office for the sixth canonical hour, being a part of the Breviary.
Sinigrin: A glucoside found in the seeds of black mustard (Brassica nigra, formerly Sinapis nigra) It resembles sinalbin, and consists of a potassium salt of myronic acid.
Squarely: In a square form or manner.
Squabbler: One who squabbles; a contentious person; a brawler.
Stigmatic: Marked with a stigma, or with something reproachful to character.
Sphygmogram: A tracing, called a pulse tracing, consisting of a series of curves corresponding with the beats of the heart, obtained by the application of the sphygmograph.
Squaw: A female; a woman, especially a married woman; a wife; -- in the language of Indian tribes of the Algonquin family, correlative of sannup.
Sufferable: Able to suffer or endure; patient.
Smilax: A genus of perennial climbing plants, usually with a prickly woody stem; green brier, or cat brier. The rootstocks of certain species are the source of the medicine called sarsaparilla.
Self-moving: Moving by inherent power, without the aid of external impulse.
Sarment: A prostrate filiform stem or runner, as of the strawberry. See Runner.
Slipknot: knot which slips along the rope or line around which it is made.
Suraddition: Something added or appended, as to a name.
Sblood: An abbreviation of God's blood; -- used as an oath.
Searchlight: An apparatus for projecting a powerful beam of light of approximately parallel rays, usually devised so that it can be swiveled about.
Sex-: A combining form meaning six; as, sexdigitism; sexennial.
Setdown: The humbling of a person by act or words, especially by a disparaging remark, a retort or a reproof; the retort or the reproof which has such effect.  Also called put-down.
Secretaryship: The office, or the term of office, of a secretary.
Stirabout: A dish formed of oatmeal boiled in water to a certain consistency and frequently stirred, or of oatmeal and dripping mixed together and stirred about in a pan; a hasty pudding.
Surfeit-water: Water for the cure of surfeits.
Seniority: The quality or state of being senior.
Synaptase: A ferment resembling diastase, found in bitter almonds.  Cf. Amygdalin, and Emulsin.
Strop: A piece of rope spliced into a circular wreath, and put round a block for hanging it.
Slaggy: Of or pertaining to slag; resembling slag; as, slaggy cobalt.
Sclerogen: The thickening matter of woody cells; lignin.
Sinistrously: In a sinistrous manner; perversely; wrongly; unluckily.
Squat: The posture of one that sits on his heels or hams, or close to the ground.
Smatterer: One who has only a slight, superficial knowledge; a sciolist.
Self-elective: Having the right of electing one's self, or, as a body, of electing its own members.
Solvent: A substance (usually liquid) suitable for, or employed in, solution, or in dissolving something; as, water is the appropriate solvent of most salts, alcohol of resins, ether of fats, and mercury or acids of metals, etc.
Serval: An African wild cat (Felis serval) of moderate size; -- called also serval cat. It has rather long legs and a tail of moderate length. Its color is tawny, with black spots on the body and rings of black on the tail.
Silverweed: A perennial rosaceous herb (Potentilla Anserina) having the leaves silvery white beneath.
Sinecural: Of or pertaining to a sinecure; being in the nature of a sinecure.
Sora: A North American rail (Porzana Carolina) common in the Eastern United States. Its back is golden brown, varied with black and white, the front of the head and throat black, the breast and sides of the head and neck slate-colored. Called also American rail, Carolina rail, Carolina crake, common rail, sora rail, soree, meadow chicken, and orto.
Sorb: The wild service tree (Pyrus torminalis) of Europe; also, the rowan tree.
Saw-set: An instrument used to set or turn the teeth of a saw a little sidewise, that they may make a kerf somewhat wider than the thickness of the blade, to prevent friction; -- called also saw-wrest.
Sigaultian: Pertaining to Sigault, a French physician. See Symphyseotomy.
&Verbar;Spiodea: An extensive division of marine Annelida, including those that are without oral tentacles or cirri, and have the gills, when present, mostly arranged along the sides of the body. They generally live in burrows or tubes.
Scrutineer: A scrutinizer; specifically, an examiner of votes, as at an election.
Self-mettle: Inborn mettle or courage; one's own temper.
slip of the tongue: an unintentional utterance; a mistake in speaking.
Stover: Fodder for cattle, especially straw or coarse hay.
Spicewood: An American shrub (Lindera Benzoin), the bark of which has a spicy taste and odor; -- called also Benjamin, wild allspice, and fever bush.
Solidly: In a solid manner; densely; compactly; firmly; truly.
&Verbar;Sarcobasis: A fruit consisting of many dry indehiscent cells, which contain but few seeds and cohere about a common style, as in the mallows.
Stray: Any domestic animal that has an inclosure, or its proper place and company, and wanders at large, or is lost; an estray.  Used also figuratively.
Sea robin: See under Robin, and Illustration in Appendix.
Sphygmophone: An electrical instrument for determining by the ear the rhythm of the pulse of a person at a distance.
Sister-in-law: The sister of one's husband or wife; also, the wife of one's brother; sometimes, the wife of one's husband's or wife's brother.
Sociability: The quality of being sociable; sociableness.
Sontag: A knitted worsted jacket, worn over the waist of a woman's dress.
Seductress: A woman who seduces; a female seducer.
Sillon: A work raised in the middle of a wide ditch, to defend it.
Self-confidence: The quality or state of being self-confident; self-reliance.
Storekeeper: A man in charge of stores or goods of any kind; as, a naval storekeeper.
Superficial: Of or pertaining to the superficies, or surface; lying on the surface; shallow; not deep; as, a superficial color; a superficial covering; superficial measure or contents; superficial tillage.
Sandfish: A small marine fish of the Pacific coast of North America (Trichodon trichodon) which buries itself in the sand.
Sump: A round pit of stone, lined with clay, for receiving the metal on its first fusion.
Smeared: Having the color mark ings ill defined, as if rubbed; as, the smeared dagger moth (Apatela oblinita).
Segmentation: The act or process of dividing into segments; specifically (Biol.), a self-division into segments as a result of growth; cell cleavage; cell multiplication; endogenous cell formation.
Sea hen: The common guillemot; -- applied also to various other sea birds.
Slatting: The violent shaking or flapping of anything hanging loose in the wind, as of a sail, when being hauled down.
&Verbar;Synosteosis: Union by means of bone; the complete closing up and obliteration of sutures.
Scroggy: Abounding in scrog; also, twisted; stunted.
Stethoscopic: Of or pertaining to a stethoscope; obtained or made by means of a stethoscope.
Selfless: Having no regard to self; unselfish.
Scorbutic: Of or pertaining to scurvy; of the nature of, or resembling, scurvy; diseased with scurvy; as, a scorbutic person; scorbutic complaints or symptoms.
Sycoceric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the oxidation of sycoceryl alcohol.
Scold: One who scolds, or makes a practice of scolding; esp., a rude, clamorous woman; a shrew.
Superlunar: Being above the moon; not belonging to this world; -- opposed to sublunary.
Smartness: The quality or state of being smart.
Shipping: The act of one who, or of that which, ships; as, the shipping of flour to Liverpool.
Semiliquidity: The quality or state of being semiliquid; partial liquidity.
Saddlebow: The bow or arch in the front part of a saddle, or the pieces which form the front.
Sweetweed: A name for two tropical American weeds (Capraria biflora, and Scoparia dulcis) of the Figwort family.
Seating: The act of providing with a seat or seats; as, the seating of an audience.
Symphyseal: Of or pertaining to to symphysis.
Slouch: To cause to hang down; to depress at the side; as, to slouth the hat.
Spur-royal: A gold coin, first made in the reign of Edward IV., having a star on the reverse resembling the rowel of a spur. In the reigns of Elizabeth and of James I., its value was fifteen shillings.
&Verbar;Siciliano: A Sicilian dance, resembling the pastorale, set to a rather slow and graceful melody in 12-8 or 6-8 measure; also, the music to the dance.
Stogy: A stout, coarse boot or shoe; a brogan.
Squid: Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having a long, tapered body, and a caudal fin on each side; especially, any species of Loligo, Ommastrephes, and related genera. See Calamary, Decacerata, Dibranchiata.
&Verbar;Septic\u00e6mia: A poisoned condition of the blood produced by the absorption into it of septic or putrescent material; blood poisoning.  It is marked by chills, fever, prostration, and inflammation of the different serous membranes and of the lungs, kidneys, and other organs.
Surface tension: That property, due to molecular forces, which exists in the surface film of all liquids and tends to bring the contained volume into a form having the least superficial area. The thickness of this film, amounting to less than a thousandth of a millimeter, is considered to equal the radius of the sphere of molecular action, that is, the greatest distance at which there is cohesion between two particles. Particles lying below this film, being equally acted on from all sides, are in equilibrium as to forces of cohesion, but those in the film are on the whole attracted inward, and tension results.
Satire: A composition, generally poetical, holding up vice or folly to reprobation; a keen or severe exposure of what in public or private morals deserves rebuke; an invective poem; as, the Satires of Juvenal.
Squib: To throw squibs; to utter sarcastic or severe reflections; to contend in petty dispute; as, to squib a little in debate.
Stereotypery: The art, process, or employment of making stereotype plates.
Streaminess: The state of being streamy; a trailing.
Sonties: Probably from “saintes” saints, or from sanctities; -- used as an oath.
Stinker: One who, or that which, stinks.
Self-opinioned: Having a high opinion of one's self; opinionated; conceited.
Spin: The act of spinning; as, the spin of a top; a spin a bicycle.
Serbonian: Relating to the lake of Serbonis in Egypt, which by reason of the sand blowing into it had a deceptive appearance of being solid land, but was a bog.
Scaphocephalic: Of, pertaining to, or affected with, scaphocephaly.
Solon: A celebrated Athenian lawmaker, born about 638 b. c.; hence, a legislator; a publicist; -- often used ironically.
Sureness: The state of being sure; certainty.
Subglacial: Pertaining or belonging to the under side of a glacier; being beneath a glacier; as, subglacial streams.
Shoulder-shotten: Sprained in the shoulder, as a horse.
Stripling: A youth in the state of adolescence, or just passing from boyhood to manhood; a lad.
Sulphite: A salt of sulphurous acid; -- called also sulfite.
Syndesmography: A description of the ligaments; syndesmology.
Sea mud: A rich slimy deposit in salt marshes and along the seashore, sometimes used as a manure; -- called also sea ooze.
Sheller: One who, or that which, shells; as, an oyster sheller; a corn sheller.
Stalwart: Brave; bold; strong; redoubted; daring; vehement; violent.
Sericeous: Of or pertaining to silk; consisting of silk; silky.
Spiderwort: An American endogenous plant (Tradescantia Virginica), with long linear leaves and ephemeral blue flowers. The name is sometimes extended to other species of the same genus.
Superadd: To add over and above; to add to what has been added; to annex, as something extrinsic.
Snoff: A short candle end used for igniting a fuse.
Somewhere: In some place unknown or not specified; in one place or another.
Subastral: Beneath the stars or heavens; terrestrial.
Secant: A line that cuts another; especially, a straight line cutting a curve in two or more points.
Self-consciousness: The quality or state of being self-conscious.
Scopeloid: Like or pertaining to fishes of the genus Scopelus, or family Scopelodæ, which includes many small oceanic fishes, most of which are phosphorescent.
Smokestack: A chimney; esp., a pipe serving as a chimney, as the pipe which carries off the smoke of a locomotive, the funnel of a steam vessel, etc.
Sickness: The quality or state of being sick or diseased; illness; sisease or malady.
Sea poppy: The horn poppy. See under Horn.
Straightedge: A board, or piece of wood or metal, having one edge perfectly straight, -- used to ascertain whether a line is straight or a surface even, and for drawing straight lines.
Spell: To form words with letters, esp. with the proper letters, either orally or in writing.
Spelk: A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.
Synaxis: A congregation; also, formerly, the Lord's Supper.
Spelt: To split; to break; to spalt.
Superinstitution: One institution upon another, as when A is instituted and admitted to a benefice upon a title, and B instituted and admitted upon the presentation of another.
Specify: To mention or name, as a particular thing; to designate in words so as to distinguish from other things; as, to specify the uses of a plant; to specify articles purchased.
Scrotal: Of or pertaining to the scrotum; as, scrotal hernia.
Sanitation: The act of rendering sanitary; the science of sanitary conditions; the preservation of health; the use of sanitary measures; hygiene.
&Verbar;Solfeggio: The system of arranging the scale by the names do, re, mi, fa, sol, la, si, by which singing is taught; a singing exercise upon these syllables.
Stingbull: The European greater weever fish (Trachinus draco), which is capable of inflicting severe wounds with the spinous rays of its dorsal fin. See Weever.
Sinuosity: Quality or state of being sinuous.
Succor: Aid; help; assistance; esp., assistance that relieves and delivers from difficulty, want, or distress.
Saxicavid: Of or pertaining to the saxicavas.
Scatter: To be dispersed or dissipated; to disperse or separate; as, clouds scatter after a storm.
Shortsighted: Not able to see far; nearsighted; myopic. See Myopic, and Myopia.
Surplus: Being or constituting a surplus; more than sufficient; as, surplus revenues; surplus population; surplus words.
Staminal: Of or pertaining to stamens or stamina; consisting in stamens.
Subnormal: That part of the axis of a curved line which is intercepted between the ordinate and the normal.
Scintillant: Emitting sparks, or fine igneous particles; sparkling.
Scaphocephaly: A deformed condition of the skull, in which the vault is narrow, elongated, and more or less boat-shaped.
Stratarithmetry: The art of drawing up an army, or any given number of men, in any geometrical figure, or of estimating or expressing the number of men in such a figure.
Substantially: In a substantial manner; in substance; essentially.
&Verbar;Spiculispongi\u00e6: A division of sponges including those which have independent siliceous spicules.
Slyboots: A humerous appellation for a sly, cunning, or waggish person.
Subversive: Tending to subvert; having a tendency to overthrow and ruin.
Sandal: A kind of shoe consisting of a sole strapped to the foot; a protection for the foot, covering its lower surface, but not its upper.
Selenio-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of selenium or its compounds; as, selenio-phosphate, a phosphate having selenium in place of all, or a part, of the oxygen.
Self-exposure: The act of exposing one's self; the state of being so exposed.
sibling: of or pertaining to a sibling, n.; as, sibling rivalry: the common rivalry between siblings.
Spiring: Shooting up in a spire or spires.
Schoolroom: A room in which pupils are taught.
Self-centered: Centered in itself, or in one's self.
Subarration: The ancient custom of betrothing by the bestowal, on the part of the man, of marriage gifts or tokens, as money, rings, or other presents, upon the woman.
Succumb: To yield; to submit; to give up unresistingly; as, to succumb under calamities; to succumb to disease.
Self-kindled: Kindled of itself, or without extraneous aid or power.
Sulphureity: The quality or state of being sulphureous.
Structure: The act of building; the practice of erecting buildings; construction.
Syrphus fly: Any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the genus Syrphus and allied genera. They are usually bright-colored, with yellow bands, and hover around plants. The larvæ feed upon plant lice, and are, therefore, very beneficial to agriculture.
Stadia hairs: In a theodolite, etc., horizontal cross wires or hairs equidistant from the central horizontal cross wire.
Self-perplexed: Perplexed by doubts originating in one's own mind.
Short circuit: A circuit formed or closed by a conductor of relatively low resistance because shorter or of relatively great conductivity.
Shoshones: A linguistic family or stock of North American Indians, comprising many tribes, which extends from Montana and Idaho into Mexico. In a restricted sense the name is applied especially to the Snakes, the most northern of the tribes.
Scyphus: A kind of large drinking cup, -- used by Greeks and Romans, esp. by poor folk.
Seamster: One who sews well, or whose occupation is to sew.
Sageness: The quality or state of being sage; wisdom; sagacity; prudence; gravity.
Scapulet: A secondary mouth fold developed at the base of each of the armlike lobes of the manubrium of many rhizostome medusæ. See Illustration in Appendix.
Symmetrize: To make proportional in its parts; to reduce to symmetry.
Splanchno-skeleton: That part of the skeleton connected with the sense organs and the viscera.
Subsolary: Being under the sun; hence, terrestrial; earthly; mundane.
Stomachic: A medicine that strengthens the stomach and excites its action.
Socage: A tenure of lands and tenements by a certain or determinate service; a tenure distinct from chivalry or knight's service, in which the obligations were uncertain. The service must be certain, in order to be denominated socage, as to hold by fealty and twenty shillings rent.
Seventy-four: A naval vessel carrying seventy-four guns.
Setiform: Having the form or structure of setæ.
Statesmanship: The qualifications, duties, or employments of a statesman.
Silicicalcareous: Consisting of silica and calcareous matter.
Superregal: More than regal; worthy of one greater than a king.
Saucepan: A small pan with a handle, in which sauce is prepared over a fire; a stewpan.
Subapennine: Under, or at the foot of, the Apennine mountains; -- applied, in geology, to a series of Tertiary strata of the older Pliocene period.
Stilly: In a still manner; quietly; silently; softly.
Salifiable: Capable of neutralizing an acid to form a salt; -- said of bases; thus, ammonia is salifiable.
&Verbar;Status in quo: The state in which anything is already.  The phrase is also used retrospectively, as when, on a treaty of peace, matters return to the status quo ante bellum, or are left in statu quo ante bellum, i.e., the state (or, in the state) before the war.  The form status quo is in most common use.
Sledge: A large, heavy hammer, usually wielded with both hands; -- called also sledge hammer.
Secundine: The second coat, or integument, of an ovule, lying within the primine.
Stationer: A bookseller or publisher; -- formerly so called from his occupying a stand, or station, in the market place or elsewhere.
Synthetize: To combine; to unite in regular structure.
Safranine: An orange-red nitrogenous dyestuff produced artificially by oxidizing certain aniline derivatives, and used in dyeing silk and wool; also, any one of the series of which safranine proper is the type.
Semidome: A roof or ceiling covering a semicircular room or recess, or one of nearly that shape, as the apse of a church, a niche, or the like. It is approximately the quarter of a hollow sphere.
Sublimeness: The quality or state of being sublime; sublimity.
&Verbar;Stasimon: In the Greek tragedy, a song of the chorus, continued without the interruption of dialogue or anapæstics.
space heater: a portable heating device used for warming the air of a single room; -- it may be electrical or use a combustible fuel.
Self-interested: Particularly concerned for one's own interest or happiness.
Spoliation: The act of plundering; robbery; deprivation; despoliation.
Suberone: The hypothetical ketone of suberic acid.
Skeletonizer: Any small moth whose larva eats the parenchyma of leaves, leaving the skeleton; as, the apple-leaf skeletonizer.
Sufi: One of a certain order of religious men in Persia.
Swingel: The swinging part of a flail which falls on the grain in thrashing; the swiple.
Shortcoming: The act of falling, or coming short
Subcarbureted: United with, or containing, carbon in less than the normal proportion.
Sermon: To discourse to or of, as in a sermon.
Swallet: Water breaking in upon the miners at their work; -- so called among tin miners.
Snakebird: Any one of four species of aquatic birds of the genus Anhinga or Plotus.  They are allied to the gannets and cormorants, but have very long, slender, flexible necks, and sharp bills.
Slipshod: Wearing shoes or slippers down at the heel.
Sesterce: A Roman coin or denomination of money, in value the fourth part of a denarius, and originally containing two asses and a half, afterward four asses, -- equal to about two pence sterling, or four cents.
Synantherous: Having the stamens united by their anthers; as, synantherous flowers.
Sinopia: A red pigment made from sinopite.
Stallon: A slip from a plant; a scion; a cutting.
Stationery: Belonging to, or sold by, a stationer.
Spagyrist: A chemist, esp. one devoted to alchemistic pursuits.
Shrill: To utter or express in a shrill tone; to cause to make a shrill sound.
Sensibly: In a sensible manner; so as to be perceptible to the senses or to the mind; appreciably; with perception; susceptibly; sensitively.
Spud: A sharp, narrow spade, usually with a long handle, used by farmers for digging up large-rooted weeds; a similarly shaped implement used for various purposes.
Superincumbence: The quality or state of being superincumbent.
Sonata: An extended composition for one or two instruments, consisting usually of three or four movements; as, Beethoven's sonatas for the piano, for the violin and piano, etc.
Sedan: A portable chair or covered vehicle for carrying a single person, -- usually borne on poles by two men. Called also sedan chair.
Sput: An annular reënforce, to strengthen a place where a hole is made.
Sally: A leaping forth; a darting; a spring.
Saddle-backed: Having the outline of the upper part concave like the seat of a saddle.
&Verbar;Staphyloma: A protrusion of any part of the globe of the eye; as, a staphyloma of the cornea.
Segmental: Relating to, or being, a segment.
Spleenless: Having no spleen; hence, kind; gentle; mild.
Starboard: To put to the right, or starboard, side of a vessel; as, to starboard the helm.
Subpodophyllous: Situated under the podophyllous tissue of the horse's foot.
Squireen: One who is half squire and half farmer; -- used humorously.
Shed: A parting; a separation; a division.
Statuette: A small statue; -- usually applied to a figure much less than life size, especially when of marble or bronze, or of plaster or clay as a preparation for the marble or bronze, as distinguished from a figure in terra cotta or the like.  Cf. Figurine.
Sepalous: Having, or relating to, sepals; -- used mostly in composition. See under Sepal.
&Verbar;Sankhya: A Hindu system of philosophy which refers all things to soul and a rootless germ called prakriti, consisting of three elements, goodness, passion, and darkness.
Split key: A key split at one end like a split pin, for the same purpose.
Salutatory: A place for saluting or greeting; a vestibule; a porch.
Scholastic: One who adheres to the method or subtilties of the schools.
Salability: The quality or condition of being salable; salableness.
Spruce: To dress one's self with affected neatness; as, to spruce up.
&Verbar;Strelitzia: A genus of plants related to the banana, found at the Cape of Good Hope. They have rigid glaucous distichous leaves, and peculiar richly colored flowers.
Sameness: The state of being the same; identity; absence of difference; near resemblance; correspondence; similarity; as, a sameness of person, of manner, of sound, of appearance, and the like.
Self-culture: Culture, training, or education of one's self by one's own efforts.
Self-adjusting: Capable of assuming a desired position or condition with relation to other parts, under varying circumstances, without requiring to be adjusted by hand; -- said of a piece in machinery.
Stratus: A form of clouds in which they are arranged in a horizontal band or layer. See Cloud.
Sheaf: To collect and bind cut grain, or the like; to make sheaves.
&Verbar;Sagus: A genus of palms from which sago is obtained.
Storminess: The state of being stormy; tempestuousness; biosteruousness; impetuousness.
Satan: The grand adversary of man; the Devil, or Prince of darkness; the chief of the fallen angels; the archfiend.
&Verbar;Sagum: The military cloak of the Roman soldiers.
Sardachate: A variety of agate containing sard.
Sporophoric: Having the nature of a sporophore.
Staw: To be fixed or set; to stay.
Schiller: The peculiar bronzelike luster observed in certain minerals, as hypersthene, schiller spar, etc. It is due to the presence of minute inclusions in parallel position, and is sometimes of secondary origin.
Spirituous: Having the quality of spirit; tenuous in substance, and having active powers or properties; ethereal; immaterial; spiritual; pure.
Stay: That which serves as a prop; a support.
Stag: To watch; to dog, or keep track of.
Structural formula: a symbolic representation of the structure of one molecule of a chemical compound, showing the attachments of the atoms to each other, and representing their arrangement in space; the spatial representation is symbolic and approximate, and it may or may not depict the stereochemical relations of the bonds.  Distinguished from empirical formula. See also Rational formula, under Formula.
Stab: The thrust of a pointed weapon.
Skilder: To beg; to pilfer; to skelder.
Selenology: That branch of astronomy which treats of the moon.
Scurrile: Such as befits a buffoon or vulgar jester; grossly opprobrious or loudly jocose in language; scurrilous; as, scurrile taunts.
Scapple: To work roughly, or shape without finishing, as stone before leaving the quarry.
Stereography: The art of delineating the forms of solid bodies on a plane; a branch of solid geometry which shows the construction of all solids which are regularly defined.
Shading: Act or process of making a shade.
Severally: Separately; distinctly; apart from others; individually.
Structural shape: The shape of a member especially adapted to structural purposes, esp. in giving the greatest strength with the least material.
Self-possession: The possession of one's powers; calmness; self-command; presence of mind; composure.
Scoley: To go to school; to study.
Self-reverence: A reverent respect for one's self.
Substantial: Belonging to substance; actually existing; real; as, substantial life.
Strigil: An instrument of metal, ivory, etc., used for scraping the skin at the bath.
Stereo-chemic: Pertaining to, or illustrating, the hypothetical space relations of atoms in the molecule; as, a stereo-chemic formula.
&Verbar;Strophanthus: A genus of tropical apocynaceous shrubs having singularly twisted flowers. One species (Strophanthus hispidus) is used medicinally as a cardiac sedative and stimulant.
Sealer: A mariner or a vessel engaged in the business of capturing seals.
Swad: A cod, or pod, as of beans or pease.
Swab: A kind of mop for cleaning floors, the desks of vessels, etc., esp. one made of rope-yarns or threads.
Salable: Capable of being sold; fit to be sold; finding a ready market.
Sarmentose: Long and filiform, and almost naked, or having only leaves at the joints where it strikes root; as, a sarmentose stem.
Swat: a former state in Northwest India, now a part of Pakistan.  It was ruled by a prince called a Wali.
Selfsame: Precisely the same; the very same; identical.
Stonework: Work or wall consisting of stone; mason's work of stone.
&Verbar;Shahin: A large and swift Asiatic falcon (Falco pregrinator) highly valued in falconry.
Supposal: The act of supposing; also, that which is supposed; supposition; opinion.
Syrinx: A wind instrument made of reeds tied together; -- called also pandean pipes.
&Verbar;Segno: A sign. See Al segno, and Dal segno.
Superfluitant: Floating above or on the surface.
Scatch: A kind of bit for the bridle of a horse; -- called also scatchmouth.
Scrotocele: A rupture or hernia in the scrotum; scrotal hernia.
Segment: To divide or separate into parts in growth; to undergo segmentation, or cleavage, as in the segmentation of the ovum.
Scholasticism: The method or subtilties of the schools of philosophy; scholastic formality; scholastic doctrines or philosophy.
Self-evidence: The quality or state of being self-evident.
Sexed: Belonging to sex; having sex; distinctively male of female; as, the sexed condition.
Synalepha: A contraction of syllables by suppressing some vowel or diphthong at the end of a word, before another vowel or diphthong; as, th' army, for the army.
&Verbar;Scolithus: A tubular structure found in Potsdam sandstone, and believed to be the fossil burrow of a marine worm.
&Verbar;Synchysis: A derangement or confusion of any kind, as of words in a sentence, or of humors in the eye.
Sprengel pump: A form of air pump in which exhaustion is produced by a stream of mercury running down a narrow tube, in the manner of an aspirator; -- named from the inventor.
Selion: A short piece of land in arable ridges and furrows, of uncertain quantity; also, a ridge of land lying between two furrows.
Stolid: Hopelessly insensible or stupid; not easily aroused or excited; dull; impassive; foolish.
Sluice: To emit by, or as by, flood gates.
Sexual: Of or pertaining to sex, or the sexes; distinguishing sex; peculiar to the distinction and office of male or female; relating to the distinctive genital organs of the sexes; proceeding from, or based upon, sex; as, sexual characteristics; sexual intercourse, connection, or commerce; sexual desire; sexual diseases; sexual generation.
Septemvirate: The office of septemvir; a government by septimvirs.
Supercelestial: Situated above the firmament, or great vault of heaven.
Suggillation: A livid, or black and blue, mark; a blow; a bruise.
Stenostome: Having a small or narrow mouth; -- said of certain small ground snakes (Opoterodonta), which are unable to dilate their jaws.
Sentimentalism: The quality of being sentimental; the character or behavior of a sentimentalist; sentimentality.
Siphonal: Of or pertaining to a siphon; resembling a siphon.
Sea perch: The European bass (Roccus lupus syn. Labrax lupus); -- called also sea dace.
Serine: one of the natural L-amino acids, obtainable as a white crystalline nitrogenous substance by the action of dilute sulphuric acid on silk gelatin.  It is found in many proteins, and, having a free primary hydroxyl group on the side chain, is involved in the catalytic action at the active site of some enzymes, such as proteases.  The IUPAC abbreviation for serine in protein sequences is Ser.  Chemically it is 2-amino-3-hydroxy-propanoic acid (C3H7NO3), HO.CH2.CH(NH2).COOH.
Strickle: An instrument to strike grain to a level with the measure; a strike.
Syllable: To pronounce the syllables of; to utter; to articulate.
Speechful: Full of speech or words; voluble; loquacious.
Subjoin: To add after something else has been said or written; to ANNEX; as, to subjoin an argument or reason.
Scorodite: A leek-green or brownish mineral occurring in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous arseniate of iron.
Siderite: Carbonate of iron, an important ore of iron occuring generally in cleavable masses, but also in rhombohedral crystals. It is of a light yellowish brown color. Called also sparry iron, spathic iron.
Stiffen: To become stiff or stiffer, in any sense of the adjective.
Service cap: A cap or hat worn by officers or enlisted men when full-dress uniform, or dress uniform, is not worn.
Snowslip: A large mass or avalanche of snow which slips down the side of a mountain, etc.
Self-affairs: One's own affairs; one's private business.
Sancho pedro: A variety of auction pitch in which the nine (sancho) and five (pedro) of trumps are added as counting cards at their pip value, and the ten of trumps counts game.
Sabbat: In mediæval demonology, the nocturnal assembly in which demons and sorcerers were thought to celebrate their orgies.
Saponifiable: Capable of conversion into soap; as, a saponifiable substance.
&Verbar;Siphonostomata: A tribe of parasitic copepod Crustacea including a large number of species that are parasites of fishes, as the lerneans. They have a mouth adapted to suck blood.
Self-existent: Existing of or by himself, independent of any other being or cause; -- as, God is the only self-existent being.
&Verbar;Suji: Indian wheat, granulated but not pulverized; a kind of semolina.
Siphuncular: Of or pertaining to the siphuncle.
Substantivize: To convert into a substantive; as, to substantivize an adjective.
Sororize: To associate, or hold fellowship, as sisters; to have sisterly feelings; -- analogous to fraternize.
Skitty: A rail; as, the water rail (called also skitty cock, and skitty coot); the spotted crake (Porzana maruetta), and the moor hen.
Storify: To form or tell stories of; to narrate or describe in a story.
Shrieval: Of or pertaining to a sheriff.
Siccation: The act or process of drying.
Subsist: To support with provisions; to feed; to maintain; as, to subsist one's family.
Sanguivorous: Subsisting upon blood; -- said of certain blood-sucking bats and other animals. See Vampire.
Sphygmic: Of or pertaining to the pulse.
Swinish: Of or pertaining to swine; befitting swine; like swine; hoggish; gross; beasty; as, a swinish drunkard or sot.
Spatulate: Shaped like spatula, or like a battledoor, being roundish, with a long, narrow, linear base.
Shuck: To deprive of the shucks or husks; as, to shuck walnuts, Indian corn, oysters, etc.
Scarp: To cut down perpendicularly, or nearly so; as, to scarp the face of a ditch or a rock.
Symposiast: One engaged with others at a banquet or merrymaking.
Sclerometer: An instrument for determining with accuracy the degree of hardness of a mineral.
Scare: Fright; esp., sudden fright produced by a trifling cause, or originating in mistake.
Scarf: In a piece which is to be united to another by a scarf joint, the part of the end or edge that is tapered off, rabbeted, or notched so as to be thinner than the rest of the piece.
Syndication: Act or process of syndicating or forming a syndicate.
Sketch: To make sketches, as of landscapes.
September: The ninth month of the year, containing thurty days.
Stipendiate: To provide with a stipend, or salary; to support; to pay.
Seiner: One who fishes with a seine.
Scalpriform: Shaped like a chisel; as, the scalpriform incisors of rodents.
Shoddyism: The quality or state of being shoddy.
Susceptible: Capable of admitting anything additional, or any change, affection, or influence; readily acted upon; as, a body susceptible of color or of alteration.
Shopwoman: A woman employed in a shop.
Smolt: A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired its silvery color.
Subgeneric: Of or pertaining to a subgenus.
Squeezing: The act of pressing; compression; oppression.
Synanthrose: A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose, found in the tubers of the Jerusalem artichoke (Helianthus tuberosus), in the dahlia, and other Compositæ.
Sorrow: To feel pain of mind in consequence of evil experienced, feared, or done; to grieve; to be sad; to be sorry.
Syndactylous: Having the toes firmly united together for some distance, and without an intermediate web, as the kingfishers; gressorial.
Simplify: To make simple; to make less complex; to make clear by giving the explanation for; to show an easier or shorter process for doing or making.
Suprasternal: Situated above, or anterior to, the sternum.
Sentimental: Having, expressing, or containing a sentiment or sentiments; abounding with moral reflections; containing a moral reflection; didactic.
Staurolite: A mineral of a brown to black color occurring in prismatic crystals, often twinned so as to form groups resembling a cross.  It is a silicate of alumina and iron, and is generally found imbedded in mica schist.  Called also granatite, and grenatite.
&Verbar;Solenostomi: A tribe of lophobranch fishes having a tubular snout. The female carries the eggs in a ventral pouch.
Subsalt: A basic salt. See the Note under Salt.
&Verbar;Sciurus: A genus of rodents comprising the common squirrels.
Sendal: A light thin stuff of silk.
Spherometer: An instrument for measuring the curvature of spherical surface, as of lenses for telescope, etc.
Sew: To drain, as a pond, for taking the fish.
&Verbar;Scleroma: Induration of the tissues. See Sclerema, Scleroderma, and Sclerosis.
Stradometrical: Of, or relating to, the measuring of streets or roads.
Settee: A vessel with a very long, sharp prow, carrying two or three masts with lateen sails, -- used in the Mediterranean.
Subtlety: The quality or state of being subtle, or sly; cunning; craftiness; artfulness.
Stearolic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the acetylene series, isologous with stearic acid, and obtained, as a white crystalline substance, from oleïc acid.
Sey: imp. sing. & 2d pers. pl. of See.
Sex: The distinguishing peculiarity of male or female in both animals and plants; the physical difference between male and female; the assemblage of properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.
Sarcoid: Resembling flesh, or muscle; composed of sarcode.
Sunniah: One of the sect of Sunnites.
See: To have the power of sight, or of perceiving by the proper organs; to possess or employ the sense of vision; as, he sees distinctly.
Sea: One of the larger bodies of salt water, less than an ocean, found on the earth's surface; a body of salt water of second rank, generally forming part of, or connecting with, an ocean or a larger sea; as, the Mediterranean Sea; the Sea of Marmora; the North Sea; the Carribean Sea.
Surcingle: A belt, band, or girth which passes over a saddle, or over anything laid on a horse's back, to bind it fast.
Spikelet: A small or secondary spike; especially, one of the ultimate parts of the in florescence of grasses. See Illust. of Quaking grass.
Setter: To cut the dewlap (of a cow or an ox), and to insert a seton, so as to cause an issue.
&Verbar;Sgraffito: Scratched; -- said of decorative painting of a certain style, in which a white overland surface is cut or scratched through, so as to form the design from a dark ground underneath.
Superseminate: To sow, as seed, over something previously sown.
Sannup: A married male Indian; a brave; -- correlative of squaw.
Scutellation: The entire covering, or mode of arrangement, of scales, as on the legs and feet of a bird.
Slimly: In a state of slimness; in a slim manner; slenderly.
Steganographist: One skilled in steganography; a cryptographer.
Scutage: Shield money; commutation of service for a sum of money. See Escuage.
Stroud: A kind of coarse blanket or garment used by the North American Indians.
Sun-burner: A circle or cluster of gas-burners for lighting and ventilating public buildings.
Sullage: Drainage of filth; filth collected from the street or highway; sewage.
Strout: To cause to project or swell out; to enlarge affectedly; to strut.
Scunner: A feeling of disgust or loathing; a strong prejudice; abhorrence; as, to take a scunner against some one.
Stalder: A wooden frame to set casks on.
Stallman: One who keeps a stall for the sale of merchandise, especially books.
Side: To be or stand at the side of; to be on the side toward.
Subsensible: Deeper than the reach of the senses.
&Verbar;Seta: Any slender, more or less rigid, bristlelike organ or part; as the hairs of a caterpillar, the slender spines of a crustacean, the hairlike processes of a protozoan, the bristles or stiff hairs on the leaves of some plants, or the pedicel of the capsule of a moss.
Slovenliness: The quality or state of being slovenly.
Scene: To exhibit as a scene; to make a scene of; to display.
Self-contained: Having self-control; reserved; uncommunicative; wholly engrossed in one's self.
Symphytism: Coalescence; a growing into one with another word.
Sinciput: The fore part of the head.
Scent: That which, issuing from a body, affects the olfactory organs of animals; odor; smell; as, the scent of an orange, or of a rose; the scent of musk.
Stiffener: One who, or that which, stiffens anything, as a piece of stiff cloth in a cravat.
Short-lived: Not living or lasting long; being of short continuance; as, a short-lived race of beings; short-lived pleasure; short-lived passion.
Space travel: the process of travelling in or into outer space.
Sauroidichnite: The fossil track of a saurian.
&Verbar;Scaphopoda: A class of marine cephalate Mollusca having a tubular shell open at both ends, a pointed or spadelike foot for burrowing, and many long, slender, prehensile oral tentacles. It includes Dentalium, or the tooth shells, and other similar shells. Called also Prosopocephala, and Solenoconcha.
Sea feather: Any gorgonian which branches in a plumelike form.
Subereous: Of or pertaining to cork; of the nature of cork; suberose.
Stewardess: A female steward; specifically, a woman employed in passenger vessels to attend to the wants of female passengers.
Seeder: One who, or that which, sows or plants seed.
Sparteine: A narcotic alkaloid extracted from the tops of the common broom (Cytisus scoparius, formerly Spartium scoparium), as a colorless oily liquid of aniline-like odor and very bitter taste.
Speculate: To consider attentively; as, to speculate the nature of a thing.
Squalodon: A genus of fossil whales belonging to the Phocodontia; -- so called because their teeth are serrated, like a shark's.
Spearmint: A species of mint (Mentha viridis) growing in moist soil. It vields an aromatic oil. See Mint, and Mentha.
Stryphnic: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid, obtained by the action of acetic acid and potassium nitrite on uric acid, as a yellow crystalline substance, with a bitter, astringent taste.
Stylography: A mode of writing or tracing lines by means of a style on cards or tablets.
Sash: To furnish with a sash or sashes; as, to sash a door or a window.
Stackyard: A yard or inclosure for stacks of hay or grain.
Shapeliness: The quality or state of being shapely.
Scamblingly: In a scambling manner; with turbulence and noise; with bold intrusiveness.
Syntonize: To adjust or devise so as to emit or respond to electric oscillations of a certain wave length; to tune; specif., to put (two or more instruments or systems of wireless telegraphy) in syntony with each other.
Scissel: The clippings of metals made in various mechanical operations.
&Verbar;Sang-froid: Freedom from agitation or excitement of mind; coolness in trying circumstances; indifference; calmness.
Subdial: Of or pertaining to the open air; being under the open sky.
Sesquiduplicate: Twice and a half as great (as another thing); having the ratio of two and a half to one.
Shot-clog: A person tolerated only because he pays the shot, or reckoning, for the rest of the company, otherwise a mere clog on them.
Sebaceous: Pertaining to, or secreting, fat; composed of fat; having the appearance of fat; as, the sebaceous secretions of some plants, or the sebaceous humor of animals.
&Verbar;Sutra: A precept; an aphorism; a brief rule.
Strepsorhine: Having twisted nostrils; -- said of the lemurs.
Stibiconite: A native oxide of antimony occurring in masses of a yellow color.
Stillatory: An alembic; a vessel for distillation.
Syphilology: That branch of medicine which treats of syphilis.
Subsume: To take up into or under, as individual under species, species under genus, or particular under universal; to place (any one cognition) under another as belonging to it; to include under something else.
Spandogs: A pair of grappling dogs for hoisting logs and timber.
Serotinous: Appearing or blossoming later in the season than is customary with allied species.
seasonal affective disorder: A form of mild depression that occurs in winters, associated with reduction in the amount of sunlight.  It is characterized by oversleeping, irritability, and sometimes overeating.  It can be treated by light therapy and usually disappears with the arrival of spring.
Spissated: Rendered dense or compact, as by evaporation; inspissated; thickened.
Sinical: Of or pertaining to a sine; employing, or founded upon, sines; as, a sinical quadrant.
Subocular: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the eye.
Soulless: Being without a soul, or without greatness or nobleness of mind; mean; spiritless.
&Verbar;Salamandrina: A suborder of Urodela, comprising salamanders.
Shaper: One who shapes; as, the shaper of one's fortunes.
Sorrowful: Full of sorrow; exhibiting sorrow; sad; dejected; distressed.
Short-dated: Having little time to run from the date.
Stimulism: The theory of medical practice which regarded life as dependent upon stimulation, or excitation, and disease as caused by excess or deficiency in the amount of stimulation.
Studding sail: A light sail set at the side of a principal or square sail of a vessel in free winds, to increase her speed. Its head is bent to a small spar which is called the studding-sail boom. See Illust. of Sail.
Saurian: Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, the Sauria.
Subdue: To bring under; to conquer by force or the exertion of superior power, and bring into permanent subjection; to reduce under dominion; to vanquish.
Semi-: A prefix signifying half, and sometimes partly or imperfectly; as, semiannual, half yearly; semitransparent, imperfectly transparent.
Superangelic: Superior to the angels in nature or rank.
Salver: A tray or waiter on which anything is presented.
Solidist: An advocate of, or believer in, solidism.
Syringe: To inject by means of a syringe; as, to syringe warm water into a vein.
Sockdolager: That which finishes or ends a matter; a settler; a poser, as a heavy blow, a conclusive answer, and the like.
Syringa: A genus of plants; the lilac.
Sistine: Of or pertaining to Pope Sixtus.
Superreward: To reward to an excessive degree.
Sailboat: A boat propelled by a sail or sails.
&Verbar;Storge: Parental affection; the instinctive affection which animals have for their young.
Septal: Of or pertaining to a septum or septa, as of a coral or a shell.
Shout: A loud burst of voice or voices; a vehement and sudden outcry, especially of a multitudes expressing joy, triumph, exultation, or animated courage.
Souled: Furnished with a soul; possessing soul and feeling; -- used chiefly in composition; as, great-souled Hector.
Slade: A little dell or valley; a flat piece of low, moist ground.
Souvenir: That which serves as a reminder; a remembrancer; a memento; a keepsake.
Seemingly: In appearance; in show; in semblance; apparently; ostensibly.
Specificness: The quality or state of being specific.
Smegmatic: Being of the nature of soap; soapy; cleansing; detersive.
Staphyloraphy: The operation of uniting a cleft palate, consisting in paring and bringing together the edges of the cleft.
Siennese: Of or pertaining to Sienna, a city of Italy.
Sublimate: Brought into a state of vapor by heat, and again condensed as a solid.
Spurrier: One whose occupation is to make spurs.
Sphericity: The quality or state of being spherial; roundness; as, the sphericity of the planets, or of a drop of water.
Synod: An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.
Scaphognathite: A thin leafike appendage (the exopodite) of the second maxilla of decapod crustaceans. It serves as a pumping organ to draw the water through the gill cavity.
&Verbar;Sui generis: Of his or its own kind.
Surfeit: To feed so as to oppress the stomach and derange the function of the system; to overfeed, and produce satiety, sickness, or uneasiness; -- often reflexive; as, to surfeit one's self with sweets.
&Verbar;Sedum: A genus of plants, mostly perennial, having succulent leaves and cymose flowers; orpine; stonecrop.
Stopship: A remora. It was fabled to stop ships by attaching itself to them.
Scolopacine: Of or pertaining to the Scolopacidæ, or Snipe family.
Superreflection: The reflection of a reflected image or sound.
Skirret: An umbelliferous plant (Sium Sisarum syn. Pimpinella Sisarum).  It is a native of Asia, but has been long cultivated in Europe for its edible clustered tuberous roots, which are very sweet.
Sheathe: To put into a sheath, case, or scabbard; to inclose or cover with, or as with, a sheath or case.
somnolism: The somnolent state induced by animal magnetism (hypnotism); the hypnotic state.
Stellion: A lizard (Stellio vulgaris), common about the Eastern Mediterranean among ruins. In color it is olive-green, shaded with black, with small stellate spots. Called also hardim, and star lizard.
Sanability: The quality or state of being sanable; sanableness; curableness.
Scutch: A wooden instrument used in scutching flax and hemp.
Sequel: That which follows; a succeeding part; continuation; as, the sequel of a man's advantures or history.
Skidder: One that skids; one that uses a skid;
Semiweekly: Coming, or made, or done, once every half week; as, a semiweekly newspaper; a semiweekly trip.
Santal: A colorless crystalline substance, isomeric with piperonal, but having weak acid properties. It is extracted from sandalwood.
Scobs: Raspings of ivory, hartshorn, metals, or other hard substance.
Subtreasurer: The public officer who has charge of a subtreasury.
Scepter: To endow with the scepter, or emblem of authority; to invest with royal authority.
Scrine: A chest, bookcase, or other place, where writings or curiosities are deposited; a shrine.
Subatom: A hypothetical component of a chemical atom, on the theory that the elements themselves are complex substances; -- called also atomicule.
Skylarking: The act of running about the rigging of a vessel in sport; hence, frolicking; scuffing; sporting; carousing.
Self-reproving: Reproving one's self; reproving by consciousness of guilt.
Statable: That can be stated; as, a statable grievance; the question at issue is statable.
Salvation: The act of saving; preservation or deliverance from destruction, danger, or great calamity.
Sinistrous: Being on the left side; inclined to the left; sinistral.
Steapsin: An unorganized ferment or enzyme present in pancreatic juice.  It decomposes neutral fats into glycerin and fatty acids.
Specular: Having the qualities of a speculum, or mirror; having a smooth, reflecting surface; as, a specular metal; a specular surface.
Subcommittee: An under committee; a part or division of a committee.
Salineness: The quality or state of being salt; saltness.
Sparable: A kind of small nail used by shoemakers.
Shasta Sam: A game like California Jack, except that the pack drawn from is turned face down.
Shopboard: A bench or board on which work is performed; a workbench.
Stymie: To bring into the position of, or impede by, a stymie.
Scientifically: In a scientific manner; according to the rules or principles of science.
Superterrestrial: Being above the earth, or above what belongs to the earth.
Setiger: An annelid having setæ; a chætopod.
Saber: To strike, cut, or kill with a saber; to cut down, as with a saber.
Superheated: heated to a temperature above the boiling point at the ambient pressure; -- said of liquids.  In such an unstable condition, a small disturbance of the liquid can cause a rapid and sometimes violent ebullition of vapor.
Slyness: The quality or state of being sly.
Say: A speech; something said; an expression of opinion; a current story; a maxim or proverb.
Semioccasionally: Once in a while; on rare occasions.
Sempre: Always; throughout; as, sempre piano, always soft.
Superchemical: Above or beyond chemistry; inexplicable by chemical laws.
Sax: A kind of chopping instrument for trimming the edges of roofing slates.
Subquintuple: Having the ratio of one to five; as, subquintuple proportion.
&Verbar;Sub judice: Before the judge, or court; not yet decided; under judicial consideration.
Sternocoracoid: Of or pertaining to the sternum and the coracoid.
Sheetful: Enough to fill a sheet; as much as a sheet can hold.
Salicaceous: Belonging or relating to the willow.
Shafting: Shafts, collectivelly; a system of connected shafts for communicating motion.
Swollen: Enlarged by swelling; immoderately increased; as, swollen eyes; swollen streams.
Smokiness: The quality or state of being smoky.
Starkness: The quality or state of being stark.
Space flight: the process or event in which vehicles travel into outer space.
Seasoner: One who, or that which, seasons, or gives a relish; a seasoning.
Survenue: A sudden or unexpected coming or stepping on.
Stupration: Violation of chastity by force; rape.
&Verbar;Sagittarius: The ninth of the twelve signs of the zodiac, which the sun enters about November 22, marked thus [&sagittarius_;] in almanacs; the Archer.
Stably: In a stable manner; firmly; fixedly; steadily; as, a government stably settled.
Sunbird: Any one of numerous species of small brilliantly colored birds of the family Nectariniidæ, native of Africa, Southern Asia, the East Indies, and Australia. In external appearance and habits they somewhat resemble humming birds, but they are true singing birds (Oscines).
Stumpage: Timber in standing trees, -- often sold without the land at a fixed price per tree or per stump, the stumps being counted when the land is cleared.
Stilpnomelane: A black or greenish black mineral occurring in foliated flates, also in velvety bronze-colored incrustations. It is a hydrous silicate of iron and alumina.
Scroddled ware: Mottled pottery made from scraps of differently colored clays.
&Verbar;Succubus: A demon or fiend; especially, a lascivious spirit supposed to have sexual intercourse with the men by night; a succuba.  Cf. Incubus.
Stable: To dwell or lodge in a stable; to dwell in an inclosed place; to kennel.
Seafarer: One who follows the sea as a business; a mariner; a sailor.
Single-breasted: Lapping over the breast only far enough to permit of buttoning, and having buttons on one edge only; as, a single-breasted coast.
Shipload: The load, or cargo, of a ship.
Subcellar: A cellar beneath another story wholly or partly underground; usually, a cellar under a cellar.
Scion: A shoot or sprout of a plant; a sucker.
Seposit: To set aside; to give up.
Scaphander: The case, or impermeable apparel, in which a diver can work while under water.
&Verbar;Setula: A small, short hair or bristle; a small seta.
Saxicavous: Boring, or hollowing out, rocks; -- said of certain mollusks which live in holes which they burrow in rocks. See Illust. of Lithodomus.
Scytheman: One who uses a scythe; a mower.
Surangular: Above the angular bone; supra-angular; -- applied to a bone of the lower jaw in many reptiles and birds.
Superpose: To lay upon, as one kind of rock on another.
Salse: A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated with salts, whence the name.
Stageplayer: An actor on the stage; one whose occupation is to represent characters on the stage; as, Garrick was a celebrated stageplayer.
Sciot: Of or pertaining to the island Scio (Chio or Chios).
Sharking: Petty rapine; trick; also, seeking a livelihood by shifts and dishonest devices.
School: To train in an institution of learning; to educate at a school; to teach.
Subjectivist: One who holds to subjectivism; an egoist.
Savagery: The state of being savage; savageness; savagism.
Spout: That through which anything spouts; a discharging lip, pipe, or orifice; a tube, pipe, or conductor of any kind through which a liquid is poured, or by which it is conveyed in a stream from one place to another; as, the spout of a teapot; a spout for conducting water from the roof of a building.
Swedenborgian: Of or pertaining to Swedenborg or his views.
Scaphoid: Resembling a boat in form; boat-shaped.
Swine: Any animal of the hog kind, especially one of the domestical species. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat, which, when extracted, is known as lard. The male is specifically called boar, the female, sow, and the young, pig. See Hog.
Staphyloplasty: The operation for restoring or replacing the soft palate when it has been lost.
Seedy: Abounding with seeds; bearing seeds; having run to seeds.
Sleazy: Wanting firmness of texture or substance; thin; flimsy; as, sleazy silk or muslin.
Stoneroot: A North American plant (Collinsonia Canadensis) having a very hard root; horse balm. See Horse balm, under Horse.
Scorpioid: Having the inflorescence curved or circinate at the end, like a scorpion's tail.
Simous: Having a very flat or snub nose, with the end turned up.
Subaud: To understand or supply in an ellipsis.
Stairway: A flight of stairs or steps; a staircase.
Stole: A long, loose garment reaching to the feet.
&Verbar;Sarong: A sort of petticoat worn by both sexes in Java and the Malay Archipelago.
&Verbar;Stundist: One of a large sect of Russian dissenters founded, about 1860, in the village of Osnova, near Odessa, by a peasant, Onishchenko, who had apparently been influenced by a German sect settled near there. They zealously practice Bible reading and reject priestly dominion and all external rites of worship.
Self-approving: Approving one's own action or character by one's own judgment.
Stertorous: Characterized by a deep snoring, which accompanies inspiration in some diseases, especially apoplexy; hence, hoarsely breathing; snoring.
Sclaff: A slight blow; a slap; a soft fall; also, the accompanying noise.
Shamble: To walk awkwardly and unsteadily, as if the knees were weak; to shuffle along.
Strikeout: an out made by a batter against whom three strikes were called in a single at-bat; also, the same out as credited to the pitcher, in the scoring of the game.
Subsumptive: Relating to, or containing, a subsumption.
Syntony: State of being adjusted to a certain wave length; agreement or tuning between the time period of an apparatus emitting electric oscillations and that of a receiving apparatus, esp. in wireless telegraphy.
Stipulate: To make an agreement or covenant with any person or company to do or forbear anything; to bargain; to contract; to settle terms; as, certain princes stipulated to assist each other in resisting the armies of France.
Superstition: An excessive reverence for, or fear of, that which is unknown or mysterious.
