Semiopal: A variety of opal not possessing opalescence.
Salacious: Having a propensity to venery; lustful; lecherous.
Secreto-motory: Causing secretion; -- said of nerves which go to glands and influence secretion.
Saucily: In a saucy manner; impudently; with impertinent boldness.
Shopboy: A boy employed in a shop.
Sympiesometer: A sensitive kind of barometer, in which the pressure of the atmosphere, acting upon a liquid, as oil, in the lower portion of the instrument, compresses an elastic gas in the upper part.
Secund: Arranged on one side only, as flowers or leaves on a stalk.
Solemnizate: To solemnize; as, to solemnizate matrimony.
Schorlaceous: Partaking of the nature and character of schorl; resembling schorl.
Somaj: A society; a congregation, a worshiping assembly, or church, esp. of the Brahmo-somaj.
Slumber: Sleep; especially, light sleep; sleep that is not deep or sound; repose.
System: An assemblage of objects arranged in regular subordination, or after some distinct method, usually logical or scientific; a complete whole of objects related by some common law, principle, or end; a complete exhibition of essential principles or facts, arranged in a rational dependence or connection; a regular union of principles or parts forming one entire thing; as, a system of philosophy; a system of government; a system of divinity; a system of botany or chemistry; a military system; the solar system.
Saltly: With taste of salt; in a salt manner.
Swashy: Soft, like fruit that is too ripe; quashy; swash.
Subpetiolar: Concealed within the base of the petiole, as the leaf buds of the plane tree.
sloakan: A species of seaweed.  See 3d Laver.
Stahlian: A believer in, or advocate of, Stahlism.
Sterile: Producing little or no crop; barren; unfruitful; unproductive; not fertile; as, sterile land; a sterile desert; a sterile year.
Stomatopodous: Of or pertaining to the Stomatopoda.
Sardinian: Of or pertaining to the island, kingdom, or people of Sardinia.
Scurrilous: Using the low and indecent language of the meaner sort of people, or such as only the license of buffoons can warrant; as, a scurrilous fellow.
Splanchnic: Of or pertaining to the viscera; visceral.
Speakership: The office of speaker; as, the speakership of the House of Representatives.
Scenery: Assemblage of scenes; the paintings and hangings representing the scenes of a play; the disposition and arrangement of the scenes in which the action of a play, poem, etc., is laid; representation of place of action or occurence.
Superexcellent: Excellent in an uncommon degree; very excellent.
Sea thongs: A kind of blackish seaweed (Himanthalia lorea) found on the northern coasts of the Atlantic. It has a thonglike forking process rising from a top-shaped base.
Saraband: A slow Spanish dance of Saracenic origin, to an air in triple time; also, the air itself.
Siruped: Moistened, covered, or sweetened with sirup, or sweet juice.
Saccharose: Cane sugar; sucrose; also, in general, any one of the group of which saccharose, or sucrose proper, is the type. See Sucrose.
Shufflecap: A play performed by shaking money in a hat or cap.
Sportulary: Subsisting on alms or charitable contributions.
Shebander: A harbor master, or ruler of a port, in the East Indies.
Subacetate: An acetate containing an excess of the basic constituent.
Spindly: Long and slender, or disproportionately tall and slender; as, spindly legs..  Used in some cases to suggest weakness.
Styryl: A hypothetical radical found in certain derivatives of styrolene and cinnamic acid; -- called also cinnyl, or cinnamyl.
Sheathless: Without a sheath or case for covering; unsheathed.
Saturday: The seventh or last day of the week; the day following Friday and preceding Sunday.
Spindle: To shoot or grow into a long, slender stalk or body; to become disproportionately tall and slender.
Sandalwood: The highly perfumed yellowish heartwood of an East Indian and Polynesian tree (Santalum album), and of several other trees of the same genus, as the Hawaiian Santalum Freycinetianum and S. pyrularium, the Australian S. latifolium, etc. The name is extended to several other kinds of fragrant wood.
Scabious: Any plant of the genus Scabiosa, several of the species of which are common in Europe. They resemble the Compositæ, and have similar heads of flowers, but the anthers are not connected.
Sessional: Of or pertaining to a session or sessions.
Stoichiology: That part of the science of physiology which treats of the elements, or principles, composing animal tissues.
Sutlership: The condition or occupation of a sutler.
Syrphian: Of or pertaining to the syrphus flies.
Susurrous: Whispering; rustling; full of whispering sounds.
Subindication: The act of indicating by signs; a slight indication.
Sciolist: One who knows many things superficially; a pretender to science; a smatterer.
&Verbar;Stigmaria: The fossil root stem of a coal plant of the genus Sigillaria.
Serve: To be a servant or a slave; to be employed in labor or other business for another; to be in subjection or bondage; to render menial service.
Spoilfive: A certain game at cards in which, if no player wins three of the five tricks possible on any deal, the game is said to be spoiled.
Scoundrelism: The practices or conduct of a scoundrel; baseness; rascality.
Sternite: The sternum of an arthropod somite.
Sublease: A lease by a tenant or lessee to another person; an underlease.
Spinozism: The form of Pantheism taught by Benedict Spinoza, that there is but one substance, or infinite essence, in the universe, of which the so-called material and spiritual beings and phenomena are only modes, and that one this one substance is God.
Sciolism: The knowledge of a sciolist; superficial knowledge.
Showiness: The quality or state of being showy; pompousness; great parade; ostentation.
So-called: So named; called by such a name (but perhaps called thus with doubtful propriety).
Shoeblack: One who polishes shoes; same as bootblack.
Squally: Abounding with squalls; disturbed often with sudden and violent gusts of wind; gusty; as, squally weather.
Superlative: That which is highest or most eminent; the utmost degree.
Stultify: To make foolish; to make a fool of; as, to stultify one by imposition; to stultify one's self by silly reasoning or conduct.
Somberness: The quality or state of being somber; gloominess.
Scotch terrier: One of a breed of small terriers with long, rough hair.
Sheephook: A hook fastened to pole, by which shepherds lay hold on the legs or necks of their sheep; a shepherd's crook.
Septiferous: Conveying putrid poison; as, the virulence of septiferous matter.
Sopsavine: See Sops of wine, under Sop.
Stative: Of or pertaining to a fixed camp, or military posts or quarters.
Softling: A soft, effeminate person; a voluptuary.
Spherics: The doctrine of the sphere; the science of the properties and relations of the circles, figures, and other magnitudes of a sphere, produced by planes intersecting it; spherical geometry and trigonometry.
Survene: To supervene upon; to come as an addition to.
Sexenary: Proceeding by sixes; sextuple; -- applied especially to a system of arithmetical computation in which the base is six.
Slowly: In a slow manner; moderately; not rapidly; not early; not rashly; not readly; tardly.
Sanded: Covered or sprinkled with sand; sandy; barren.
&Verbar;Senhor: A Portuguese title of courtesy corresponding to the Spanish señor or the English Mr. or sir; also, a gentleman.
Smoke-dry: To dry by or in smoke.
Still wine: a table wine which is not effervescent; a non-sparkling wine.
Secularly: In a secular or worldly manner.
&Verbar;Sarcelle: The old squaw, or long-tailed duck.
Stime: A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse.
Setaceous: Set with, or consisting of, bristles; bristly; as, a stiff, setaceous tail.
Soldierly: Like or becoming a real soldier; brave; martial; heroic; honorable; soldierlike.
Semifable: That which is part fable and part truth; a mixture of truth and fable.
Sparage: Obs. or corrupt forms of Asparagus.
Serviceable: Doing service; promoting happiness, interest, advantage, or any good; useful to any end; adapted to any good end use; beneficial; advantageous.
Snell: A short line of horsehair, gut, etc., by which a fishhook is attached to a longer line.
Submissly: In a submissive manner; with a submission.
Semivocal: Of or pertaining to a semivowel; half cocal; imperfectly sounding.
Shocking: Causing to shake or tremble, as by a blow; especially, causing to recoil with horror or disgust; extremely offensive or disgusting.
Slope: To take an oblique direction; to be at an angle with the plane of the horizon; to incline; as, the ground slopes.
Scapular: A loose sleeveless vestment falling in front and behind, worn by certain religious orders and devout persons.
Stonebrash: A subsoil made up of small stones or finely-broken rock; brash.
Sceptral: Of or pertaining to a scepter; like a scepter.
&Verbar;Soiree: An evening party; -- distinguished from levee, and matinée.
Spite: To be angry at; to hate.
Syllidian: Any one of numerous species of marine annelids of the family Syllidæ.
Southness: A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point toward the south pole.
Semasiology: The science of meanings or sense development (of words); the explanation of the development and changes of the meanings of words; -- more commonly referred to as semantics.
Sketchily: In a sketchy or incomplete manner.
&Verbar;Sanguinaria: A genus of plants of the Poppy family.
Seminoles: A tribe of Indians who formerly occupied Florida, where some of them still remain. They belonged to the Creek Confideration.
Sulphury: Resembling, or partaking of the nature of, sulphur; having the qualities of sulphur.
Straightforward: Proceeding in a straight course or manner; not deviating; honest; frank.
Sublimed: Having been subjected to the process of sublimation; hence, also, purified.
Saleratus: Aërated salt; a white crystalline substance having an alkaline taste and reaction, consisting of sodium bicarbonate (see under Sodium.) It is largely used in cooking, with sour milk (lactic acid) or cream of tartar as a substitute for yeast. It is also an ingredient of most baking powders, and is used in the preparation of effervescing drinks.
Sprightful: Full of spirit or of life; spirited; earnest; vivacious; lively; brisk; nimble; gay.
Sarcastic: Expressing, or expressed by, sarcasm; characterized by, or of the nature of, sarcasm; given to the use of sarcasm; bitterly satirical; scornfully severe; taunting.
&Verbar;Sabicu: The very hard wood of a leguminous West Indian tree (Lysiloma Sabicu), valued for shipbuilding.
Synchronization: The act of synchronizing; concurrence of events in respect to time.
Sanctiloquent: Discoursing on heavenly or holy things, or in a holy manner.
Sturnoid: Like or pertaining to the starlings.
Sub-: A prefix signifying under, below, beneath, and hence often, in an inferior position or degree, in an imperfect or partial state, as in subscribe, substruct, subserve, subject, subordinate, subacid, subastringent, subgranular, suborn. Sub- in Latin compounds often becomes sum- before m, sur before r, and regularly becomes suc-, suf-, sug-, and sup- before c, f, g, and p respectively. Before c, p, and t it sometimes takes form sus- (by the dropping of b from a collateral form, subs-).
Succinimide: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, C2H4.(CO)2.NH, obtained by treating succinic anhydride with ammonia gas. It is a typical imido acid, and forms a series of salts. See Imido acid, under Imido.
Shaft: The slender, smooth stem of an arrow; hence, an arrow.
Secularization: The act of rendering secular, or the state of being rendered secular; conversion from regular or monastic to secular; conversion from religious to lay or secular possession and uses; as, the secularization of church property.
Solicitor-general: The second law officer in the government of Great Britain; also, a similar officer under the United States government, who is associated with the attorney-general; also, the chief law officer of some of the States.
SWAT team: a special group of police trained to deal with unusually dangerous or violent situations, and having special weapons, such as rifles more powerful than those carried by regular police officers.  They are employed, for example, in situations when hostages are being held, or heavily armed persons need to be captured.  Called also SWAT or S.W.A.T..
Sprout: The shoot of a plant; a shoot from the seed, from the stump, or from the root or tuber, of a plant or tree; more rarely, a shoot from the stem of a plant, or the end of a branch.
Subpolygonal: Approximately polygonal; somewhat or almost polygonal.
Schizophyte: One of a class of vegetable organisms, in the classification of Cohn, which includes all of the inferior forms that multiply by fission, whether they contain chlorophyll or not.
Semi-Diesel: Designating an internal-combustion engine of a type resembling the Diesel engine in using as fuel heavy oil which is injected in a spray just before the end of the compression stroke and is fired without electrical ignition. The fuel is sprayed into an iron box (called a hot bulb or hot pot) opening into the combustion chamber, and heated for ignition by a blast-lamp until the engine is running, when it is, ordinarily, kept red hot by the heat of combustion.
Scratch player: One that starts from the scratch; hence, one of first-rate ability.
Syphilide: A cutaneous eruption due to syphilis.
Salutiferous: Bringing health; healthy; salutary; beneficial; as, salutiferous air.
Seriatim: In regular order; one after the other; severally.
Sheave: To gather and bind into a sheaf or sheaves; hence, to collect.
Slavonian: A native or inhabitant of Slavonia; ethnologically, a Slav.
Supra: Over; above; before; also, beyond; besides; -- much used as a prefix.
Supratrochlear: Situated over or above a trochlea or trochlear surface; -- applied esp. to one of the subdivisions of the trigeminal nerve.
Stannic: Of or pertaining to tin; derived from or containing tin; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with stannous compounds.
&Verbar;Saibling: A European mountain trout (Salvelinus alpinus); -- called also Bavarian charr.
Serolin: A peculiar fatty substance found in the blood, probably a mixture of fats, cholesterin, etc.
Spit: To throw out saliva from the mouth.
Showily: In a showy manner; pompously; with parade.
Salicylite: A compound of salicylal; -- named after the analogy of a salt.
Semiplume: A feather which has a plumelike web, with the shaft of an ordinary feather.
Stallage: The right of erecting a stall or stalls in fairs; rent paid for a stall.
Starry: Abounding with stars; adorned with stars.
&Verbar;Spadassin: A bravo; a bully; a duelist.
Sclerenchymatous: Pertaining to, or composed of, sclerenchyma.
Sacrificable: Capable of being offered in sacrifice.
Solenoglyph: Pertaining to the Selenoglypha. See Ophidia.
Spiller: One who, or that which, spills.
Suspend: To cease from operation or activity; esp., to stop payment, or be unable to meet obligations or engagements (said of a commercial firm or a bank).
Shin: To climb (a pole, etc.) by shinning up.
Secretness: The state or quality of being secret, hid, or concealed.
&Verbar;Selachii: An order of elasmobranchs including the sharks and rays; the Plagiostomi. Called also Selacha, Selache, and Selachoidei.
Ship: To engage to serve on board of a vessel; as, to ship on a man-of-war.
Storier: A relater of stories; an historian.
Sheep: Any one of several species of ruminants of the genus Ovis, native of the higher mountains of both hemispheres, but most numerous in Asia.
&Verbar;Stomod\u00e6um: A part of the alimentary canal. See under Mesenteron.
Sheer: The longitudinal upward curvature of the deck, gunwale, and lines of a vessel, as when viewed from the side.
Sheet: To furnish with a sheet or sheets; to wrap in, or cover with, a sheet, or as with a sheet.
Semilor: A yellowish alloy of copper and zinc. See Simplor.
Solertiousness: The quality or state of being solert.
Stelography: The art of writing or inscribing characters on pillars.
Sparry: Resembling spar, or consisting of spar; abounding with spar; having a confused crystalline structure; spathose.
Sectionality: The state or quality of being sectional; sectionalism.
Sighted: Having sight, or seeing, in a particular manner; -- used in composition; as, long-sighted, short-sighted, quick-sighted, sharp-sighted, and the like.
Scimiter: A saber with a much curved blade having the edge on the convex side, -- in use among Mohammedans, esp., the Arabs and persians.
Scutal: Of or pertaining to a shield.
Semicolumnar: Like a semicolumn; flat on one side and round on the other; imperfectly columnar.
Styphnic: Pertaining to, or designating, a yellow crystalline astringent acid, (NO2)3.C6H.(OH)2, obtained by the action of nitric acid on resorcin. Styphnic acid resembles picric acid, but is not bitter. It acts like a strong dibasic acid, having a series of well defined salts.
Single-hearted: Having an honest heart; free from duplicity.
Semicircle: The half of a circle; the part of a circle bounded by its diameter and half of its circumference.
Snore: A harsh nasal noise made in sleep.
Sacristan: An officer of the church who has the care of the utensils or movables, and of the church in general; a sexton.
Supercrescent: Growing on some other growing thing.
Scrip: A small writing, certificate, or schedule; a piece of paper containing a writing.
Snort: To expel throught the nostrils with a snort; to utter with a snort.
Sacrist: A sacristan; also, a person retained in a cathedral to copy out music for the choir, and take care of the books.
Songless: Destitute of the power of song; without song; as, songless birds; songless woods.
Specially: In a special manner; particularly; especially.
Schneiderian: Discovered or described by C. V. Schneider, a German anatomist of the seventeenth century.
Silverly: Like silver in appearance or in sound.
Skit: A reflection; a jeer or gibe; a sally; a brief satire; a squib.
Stratigraphy: That branch of geology which treats of the arrangement and succession of strata.
Spiritualistic: Relating to, or connected with, spiritualism.
Skin: To become covered with skin; as, a wound skins over.
Sakti: The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma, Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
Saturnalian: Of or pertaining to the Saturnalia.
Skeptic: Of or pertaining to a sceptic or skepticism; characterized by skepticism; hesitating to admit the certainly of doctrines or principles; doubting of everything.
Supersacral: Situated over, or on the dorsal side of, the sacrum.
Steadiness: The quality or state of being steady.
Spirketing: The planking from the waterways up to the port sills.
Seemliness: The quality or state of being seemly: comeliness; propriety.
Septembrist: An agent in the massacres in Paris, committed in patriotic frenzy, on the 22d of September, 1792.
Sassenach: A Saxon; an Englishman; a Lowlander.
Stemple: A crossbar of wood in a shaft, serving as a step.
Snuffers: An instrument for cropping and holding the snuff of a candle.
Solidness: State or quality of being solid; firmness; compactness; solidity, as of material bodies.
Stakeholder: The holder of a stake; one with whom the bets are deposited when a wager is laid.
Supermaterial: Being above, or superior to, matter.
&Verbar;Stridor: A harsh, shrill, or creaking noise.
Stylomastoid: Of or pertaining to the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone.
Sybarite: A person devoted to luxury and pleasure; a voluptuary.
Stigmatist: One believed to be supernaturally impressed with the marks of Christ's wounds. See Stigma, 8.
Sleigh: A vehicle moved on runners, and used for transporting persons or goods on snow or ice; -- in England commonly called a sledge.
Stank: Water retained by an embankment; a pool of water.
Sidehill: The side or slope of a hill; sloping ground; a descent.
Supra-ilium: The cartilaginous cap at the sacral end of the ilium of some animals.
Sublition: The act or process of laying the ground in a painting.
Sarsaparilla: Any plant of several tropical American species of Smilax.
Shortclothes: Coverings for the legs of men or boys, consisting of trousers which reach only to the knees, -- worn with long stockings.
Sop: To steep or dip in any liquid.
Septemfluous: Flowing sevenfold; divided into seven streams or currents.
Savingness: The quality of being saving; carefulness not to expend money uselessly; frugality; parsimony.
Snow-capped: Having the top capped or covered with snow; as, snow-capped mountains.
Satinwood: The hard, lemon-colored, fragrant wood of an East Indian tree (Chloroxylon Swietenia). It takes a lustrous finish, and is used in cabinetwork. The name is also given to the wood of a species of prickly ash (Xanthoxylum Caribæum) growing in Florida and the West Indies.
Simian: Of or pertaining to the family Simiadæ, which, in its widest sense, includes all the Old World apes and monkeys; also, apelike.
&Verbar;Stoma: One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serous membranes.
Suspensation: The act of suspending, or the state of being suspended, especially for a short time; temporary suspension.
Saponacity: The quality or state of being saponaceous.
Self-destruction: The destruction of one's self; self-murder; suicide.
Suicide: The act of taking one's own life voluntary and intentionally; self-murder; specifically (Law), the felonious killing of one's self; the deliberate and intentional destruction of one's own life by a person of years of discretion and of sound mind.
Solanum: A genus of plants comprehending the potato (S. tuberosum), the eggplant (S. melongena, and several hundred other species; nightshade.
Smugness: The quality or state of being smug.
Simmer: To cause to boil gently; to cook in liquid heated almost or just to the boiling point.
Sputter: Moist matter thrown out in small detached particles; also, confused and hasty speech.
Staithman: A man employed in weighing and shipping at a staith.
&Verbar;Scutiger: Any species of chilopod myriapods of the genus Scutigera. They sometimes enter buildings and prey upon insects.
Slickens: The pulverized matter from a quartz mill, or the lighter soil of hydraulic mines.
Syncretic: Uniting and blending together different systems, as of philosophy, morals, or religion.
Stanielry: Hawking with staniels, or stannels, -- a base kind of falconry.
Separate: Divided from another or others; disjoined; disconnected; separated; -- said of things once connected.
Scirrhous: Proceeding from scirrhus; of the nature of scirrhus; indurated; knotty; as, scirrhous affections; scirrhous disease.
&Verbar;Stylus: An instrument for writing. See Style, n., 1.
Sarking: Thin boards for sheathing, as above the rafters, and under the shingles or slates, and for similar purposes.
Surcoat: A coat worn over the other garments; especially, the long and flowing garment of knights, worn over the armor, and frequently emblazoned with the arms of the wearer.
Sentimentality: The quality or state of being sentimental.
Scholar: One who attends a school; one who learns of a teacher; one under the tuition of a preceptor; a pupil; a disciple; a learner; a student.
Smallclothes: A man's garment for the hips and thighs; breeches. See Breeches.
Securiform: Having the form of an ax or hatchet.
Scutelliplantar: Having broad scutella on the front, and small scales on the posterior side, of the tarsus; -- said of certain birds.
Slouching: Hanging down at the side; limp; drooping; without firmness or shapeliness; moving in an ungainly manner.
Safety chain: A normally slack chain for preventing excessive movement between a truck and a car body in sluing.
Siderealize: To elevate to the stars, or to the region of the stars; to etherealize.
Self-devotion: The act of devoting one's self, or the state of being self-devoted; willingness to sacrifice one's own advantage or happiness for the sake of others; self-sacrifice.
Side-chain theory: A theory proposed by P. Ehrlich as a chemical explanation of immunity phenomena. In brief outline it is as follows: Animal cells and bacteria are complex aggregations of molecules, which are themselves complex. Complex molecules react with one another through certain of their side chains, but only when these side chains have a definite correspondence in structure (this accounts for the specific action of antitoxins).
Settlement: The act of setting, or the state of being settled.
Speculatory: Intended or adapted for viewing or espying; having oversight.
&Verbar;Semita: A fasciole of a spatangoid sea urchin.
Sulphinide: A white or yellowish crystalline substance, C6H4.(SO2.CO).NH, produced artificially by the oxidation of a sulphamic derivative of toluene. It is the sweetest substance known, having over two hundred times the sweetening power of sugar, and is known in commerce under the name of saccharine. It has acid properties and forms salts (which are inaccurately called saccharinates).
Saffron: To give color and flavor to, as by means of saffron; to spice.
Sabelloid: Like, or related to, the genus Sabella.
Subsistence Department: A staff department of the United States army charged, under the  supervision of the Chief of Staff, with the purchasing and issuing to the army of such supplies as make up the  ration. It also supplies, for authorized sales, certain articles of food and other minor stores. It is commanded by any officer of the rank of brigadier general, called commissary general, and the department is popularly called the Commissary Department.
Seynd: p. p. of Senge, to singe.
Saccholactic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid now called mucic acid; saccholic.
Sea room: Room or space at sea for a vessel to maneuver, drive, or scud, without peril of running ashore or aground.
Sizzle: A hissing sound, as of something frying over a fire.
Stateliness: The quality or state of being stately.
Sprite: A spirit; a soul; a shade; also, an apparition.  See Spright.
Scalariform: Resembling a ladder in form or appearance; having transverse bars or markings like the rounds of a ladder; as, the scalariform cells and scalariform pits in some plants.
Salification: The act, process, or result of salifying; the state of being salified.
Submerge: To plunge into water or other fluid; to be buried or covered, as by a fluid; to be merged; hence, to be completely included.
Subterranean: Being or lying under the surface of the earth; situated within the earth, or under ground; as, subterranean springs; a subterraneous passage.
Secularize: To convert from regular or monastic into secular; as, to secularize a priest or a monk.
Spheroid: A body or figure approaching to a sphere, but not perfectly spherical; esp., a solid generated by the revolution of an ellipse about one of its axes.
Selenite: A variety of gypsum, occuring in transparent crystals or crystalline masses.
Surgeoncy: The office or employment of a surgeon, as in the naval or military service.
&Verbar;Sequestrum: A portion of dead bone which becomes separated from the sound portion, as in necrosis.
Shovelboard: A board on which a game is played, by pushing or driving pieces of metal or money to reach certain marks; also, the game itself. Called also shuffleboard, shoveboard, shovegroat, shovelpenny.
Sluttish: Like a slut; untidy; indecently negligent of cleanliness; disorderly; as, a sluttish woman.
&Verbar;Sem\u00e9: Sprinkled or sown; -- said of field, or a charge, when strewed or covered with small charges.
Steamer: A vessel propelled by steam; a steamship or steamboat.
Scrabble: The act of scrabbling; a moving upon the hands and knees; a scramble; also, a scribble.
Sulphinate: A salt of a sulphinic acid.
Sycophantic: Of or pertaining to a sycophant; characteristic of a sycophant; meanly or obsequiously flattering; courting favor by mean adulation; parasitic.
Surtout: A man's coat to be worn over his other garments; an overcoat, especially when long, and fitting closely like a body coat.
Sharper: A person who bargains closely, especially, one who cheats in bargains; a swinder; also, a cheating gamester.
Snarer: One who lays snares, or entraps.
Smartweed: An acrid plant of the genus Polygonum (P. Hydropiper), which produces smarting if applied where the skin is tender.
Sesquipedality: The quality or condition of being sesquipedal.
Successiveness: The quality or state of being successive.
Sketchiness: The quality or state of being sketchy; lack of finish; incompleteness.
Seismographic: Of or pertaining to a seismograph; indicated by a seismograph.
Sleaved: Raw; not spun or wrought; as, sleaved thread or silk.
Snively: Running at the nose; sniveling pitiful; whining.
Substituent: Any atom, group, or radical substituted for another, or entering a molecule in place of some other part which is removed.
Subconscious: Occurring without the possibility or the fact of an attendant consciousness; -- said of states of the soul.
Sandpaper: To smooth or polish with sandpaper; as, to sandpaper a door.
&Verbar;Shabrack: The saddlecloth or housing of a cavalry horse.
Sulphureous: Consisting of sulphur; having the qualities of sulphur, or brimstone; impregnated with sulphur.
Split infinitive: A simple infinitive with to, having a modifier between the verb and the to; as in, to largely decrease. Called also cleft infinitive.
&Verbar;Scutibranchiata: An order of gastropod Mollusca having a heart with two auricles and one ventricle. The shell may be either spiral or shieldlike.
Sephen: A large sting ray of the genus Trygon, especially Trygon sephen of the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea. The skin is an article of commerce.
&Verbar;Scincoidea: A tribe of lizards including the skinks. See Skink.
Sixtieth: The quotient of a unit divided by sixty; one of sixty equal parts forming a whole.
Synoptic: One of the first three Gospels of the New Testament. See Synoptist.
Sirdar: A native chief in Hindostan; a headman.
&Verbar;Sotto voce: With a restrained voice or moderate force; in an undertone.
Scurf: Thin dry scales or scabs upon the body; especially, thin scales exfoliated from the cuticle, particularly of the scalp; dandruff.
Scribatious: Skillful in, or fond of, writing.
Sequestral: Of or pertaining to a sequestrum.
Sea arrow: A squid of the genus Ommastrephes. See Squid.
Self-indulgent: Indulging one's appetites, desires, etc., freely.
&Verbar;Solidago: A genus of yellow-flowered composite perennial herbs; golden-rod.
Sustentacular: Supporting; sustaining; as, a sustentacular tissue.
Spinetail: Any one or several species of swifts of the genus Acanthylis, or Chætura, and allied genera, in which the shafts of the tail feathers terminate in rigid spines.
Swingtree: The bar of a carriage to which the traces are fastened; the whiffletree.
Sneezing: The act of violently forcing air out through the nasal passages while the cavity of the mouth is shut off from the pharynx by the approximation of the soft palate and the base of the tongue.
Septifragal: Breaking from the partitions; -- said of a method of dehiscence in which the valves of a pod break away from the partitions, and these remain attached to the common axis.
Self-dependent: Dependent on one's self; self-depending; self-reliant.
Soutage: That in which anything is packed; bagging, as for hops.
Superstructive: Built or erected on something else.
Stackage: Hay, grain, or the like, in stacks; things stacked.
Spermatophyte: Any plant of the phylum Spermatophyta.
Sophistic: Of or pertaining to a sophist; embodying sophistry; fallaciously subtile; not sound.
&Verbar;Scomber: A genus of acanthopterygious fishes which includes the common mackerel.
Simon-pure: Genuine; true; real; authentic; -- a term alluding to the comedy character Simon Pure, who is impersonated by another and is obliged to prove himself to be the “real Simon Pure.”
Stereomonoscope: An instrument with two lenses, by which an image of a single picture projected upon a screen of ground glass is made to present an appearance of relief, and may be viewed by several persons at once.
Sulciform: Having the form of a sulcus; as, sulciform markings.
Stepsister: A daughter of one's stepfather or stepmother by a former marriage.
Sassafras: An American tree of the Laurel family (Sassafras officinale); also, the bark of the roots, which has an aromatic smell and taste.
Scenic: Of or pertaining to scenery; of the nature of scenery; theatrical.
Sickening: Causing sickness; specif., causing surfeit or disgust; nauseating.
Stentor: A herald, in the Iliad, who had a very loud voice; hence, any person having a powerful voice.
Sarcolemma: The very thin transparent and apparently homogeneous sheath which incloses a striated muscular fiber; the myolemma.
Skutterudite: A mineral of a bright metallic luster and tin-white to pale lead-gray color. It consists of arsenic and cobalt.
Squadron: Primarily, a square; hence, a square body of troops; a body of troops drawn up in a square.
&Verbar;Saltarello: A popular Italian dance in quick 3-4 or 6-8 time, running mostly in triplets, but with a hop step at the beginning of each measure. See Tarantella.
Snuffbox: A small box for carrying snuff about the person.
Sassolin: Native boric acid, found in saline incrustations on the borders of hot springs near Sasso, in the territory of Florence.
Suffer: To feel or undergo pain of body or mind; to bear what is inconvenient; as, we suffer from pain, sickness, or sorrow; we suffer with anxiety.
Sheathed: Povided with, or inclosed in, sheath.
Sulky: A light two-wheeled carriage for a single person.
Series winding: A winding in which the armature coil and the field-magnet coil are in series with the external circuits; -- opposed to shunt winding.
Supporter: One who, or that which, supports; as, oxygen is a supporter of life.
Spelding: A haddock or other small fish split open and dried in the sun; -- called also speldron.
Scamp: To perform in a hasty, neglectful, or imperfect manner; to do superficially.
Sportive: Tending to, engaged in, or provocative of, sport; gay; frolicsome; playful; merry.
Sir: A man of social authority and dignity; a lord; a master; a gentleman; -- in this sense usually spelled sire.
Syndicalist: One who advocates or practices syndicalism.
Syndicalism: The theory, plan, or practice of trade-union action (originally as advocated and practiced by the French Confédération Générale du Travail) which aims to abolish the present political and social system by means of the general strike (as distinguished from the local or sectional strike) and direct action of whatever kind (as distinguished from action which takes effect only through the medium of political action) -- direct action including any kind of action that is directly effective, whether it be a simple strike, a peaceful public demonstration, sabotage, or revolutionary violence. By the general strike and direct action syndicalism aims to establish a social system in which the means and processes of production are in the control of local organizations of workers, who are manage them for the common good.
Sip: The act of sipping; the taking of a liquid with the lips.
Syrianism: A Syrian idiom, or a peculiarity of the Syrian language; a Syriacism.
Spindling: Long and slender, or disproportionately tall and slender; as, a spindling tree; a spindling boy.
Simultaneity: The quality or state of being simultaneous; simultaneousness.
Sagging: A bending or sinking between the ends of a thing, in consequence of its own, or an imposed, weight; an arching downward in the middle, as of a ship after straining. Cf. Hogging.
Sappiness: The quality of being sappy; juiciness.
Shatter: A fragment of anything shattered; -- used chiefly or soley in the phrase into shatters; as, to break a glass into shatters.
&Verbar;Subsultus: A starting, twitching, or convulsive motion.
Stick: To adhere; as, glue sticks to the fingers; paste sticks to the wall.
Stich: A verse, of whatever measure or number of feet.
Sematrope: An instrument for signaling by reflecting the rays of the sun in different directions.
Superessential: Essential above others, or above the constitution of a thing.
Spillet fishing: A system or method of fishing by means of a number of hooks set on snoods all on one line; -- in North America, called trawl fishing, bultow, or bultow fishing, and long-line fishing.
Sleighing: The act of riding in a sleigh.
Self-life: Life for one's self; living solely or chiefly for one's own pleasure or good.
Spigurnel: Formerly the title of the sealer of writs in chancery.
Sublevation: The act of raising on high; elevation.
Subcompressed: Not fully compressed; partially or somewhat compressed.
Suffragator: One who assists or favors by his vote.
Scissorstail: A tyrant flycatcher (Milvulus forficatus) of the Southern United States and Mexico, which has a deeply forked tail.  It is light gray above, white beneath, salmon on the flanks, and fiery red at the base of the crown feathers.
Soliped: A mammal having a single hoof on each foot, as the horses and asses; a solidungulate.
Sackcloth: Linen or cotton cloth such as sacks are made of; coarse cloth; anciently, a cloth or garment worn in mourning, distress, mortification, or penitence.
Subscapular: Situated beneath the scapula; infrascapular; as, the subscapular muscle.
Stabiliment: The act of making firm; firm support; establishment.
Suggillate: To beat livid, or black and blue.
Supperless: Having no supper; deprived of supper; as, to go supperless to bed.
Sapotaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order (Sapotaceæ) of (mostly tropical) trees and shrubs, including the star apple, the Lucuma, or natural marmalade tree, the gutta-percha tree (Isonandra), and the India mahwa, as well as the sapodilla, or sapota, after which the order is named.
Sway bar: A bar attached to the hounds, in the rear of the front axle, so as to slide on the reach as the axle is swung in turning the vehicle.
Spire: A spiral; a curl; a whorl; a twist.
Spiry: Of or pertaining to a spire; like a spire, tall, slender, and tapering; abounding in spires; as, spiry turrets.
Sixth: The quotient of a unit divided by six; one of six equal parts which form a whole.
Stalagmite: A deposit more or less resembling an inverted stalactite, formed by calcareous water dropping on the floors of caverns; hence, a similar deposit of other material.
Scouse: A sailor's dish. Bread scouse contains no meat; lobscouse contains meat, etc. See Lobscouse.
&Verbar;Sobranje: The unicameral national assembly of Bulgaria, elected for a term of five years by universal suffrage of adult males.
Sixty: The sum of six times ten; sixty units or objects.
Smoothness: Quality or state of being smooth.
Sequoi\u00ebne: A hydrocarbon (C13H10) obtained in white fluorescent crystals, in the distillation products of the needles of the California “big tree” (Sequoia gigantea).
Shady: Abounding in shade or shades; overspread with shade; causing shade.
Shade: To undergo or exhibit minute difference or variation, as of color, meaning, expression, etc.; to pass by slight changes; -- used chiefly with a preposition, as into, away, off.
Shadd: Rounded stones containing tin ore, lying at the surface of the ground, and indicating a vein.
Stumbling-block: Any cause of stumbling, perplexity, or error.
Separable: Capable of being separated, disjoined, disunited, or divided; as, the separable parts of plants; qualities not separable from the substance in which they exist.
Sulphur-bottom: A very large whalebone whale of the genus Sibbaldius, having a yellowish belly; especially, S. sulfureus of the North Pacific, and S. borealis of the North Atlantic; -- called also sulphur whale.
Supplication: The act of supplicating; humble and earnest prayer, as in worship.
Subaquatic: Being under water, or beneath the surface of water; adapted for use under water; submarine; as, a subaqueous helmet.
Shopshift: The trick of a shopkeeper; deception.
&Verbar;Spermatogonium: A primitive seminal cell, occuring in masses in the seminal tubules. It divides into a mass (spermosphere) of small cells (spermoblast), which in turn give rise to spermatozoids.
Sedge: Any plant of the genus Carex, perennial, endogenous, innutritious herbs, often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangular jointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaves which are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are several hundred species.
Service: The act of serving; the occupation of a servant; the performance of labor for the benefit of another, or at another's command; attendance of an inferior, hired helper, slave, etc., on a superior, employer, master, or the like; also, spiritual obedience and love.
Stargazing: The act or practice of observing the stars with attention; contemplation of the stars as connected with astrology or astronomy.
Surrejoinder: The answer of a plaintiff to a defendant's rejoinder.
Subreligion: A secondary religion; a belief or principle held in a quasi religious veneration.
Sterling: Belonging to, or relating to, the standard British money of account, or the British coinage; as, a pound sterling; a shilling sterling; a penny sterling; -- now chiefly applied to the lawful money of England; but sterling cost, sterling value, are used.
Stonebow: A kind of crossbow formerly used for shooting stones.
Slam-bang: With great violence; with a slamming or banging noise.
Spot: Lit., being on the spot, or place;
Setness: The quality or state of being set; formality; obstinacy.
Storeship: A vessel used to carry naval stores for a fleet, garrison, or the like.
Shadowiness: The quality or state of being shadowy.
Segregation: The act of segregating, or the state of being segregated; separation from others; a parting.
Spitfire: A violent, irascible, or passionate person.
Shaggy: Rough with long hair or wool.
Shirred: Made or gathered into a shirr; as, a shirred bonnet.
Shot: To load with shot, as a gun.
Shrovetide: The days immediately preceding Ash Widnesday, especially the period between the evening before Quinguagesima Sunday and the morning of Ash Wednesday.
Show: The act of showing, or bringing to view; exposure to sight; exhibition.
Solvency: The quality or state of being solvent.
Spirituousness: The quality or state of being spirituous.
Shoo: Begone; away; -- an expression used in frightening away animals, especially fowls.
Simpleness: The quality or state of being simple; simplicity.
Sublate: To take or carry away; to remove.
Snet: The clear of mucus; to blow.
Sermocination: The making of speeches or sermons; sermonizing.
Straw-cutter: An instrument to cut straw for fodder.
&Verbar;Sigma: The Greek letter Σ, σ, or ς (English S, or s). It originally had the form of the English C.
Sneak-cup: One who sneaks from his cups; one who balks his glass.
Sherryvallies: Trousers or overalls of thick cloth or leather, buttoned on the outside of each leg, and generally worn to protect other trousers when riding on horseback.
Submissive: Inclined or ready to submit; acknowledging one's inferiority; yielding; obedient; humble.
Synonymist: One who collects or explains synonyms.
Scoff: To treat or address with derision; to assail scornfully; to mock at.
Southeast: Of or pertaining to the southeast; proceeding toward, or coming from, the southeast; as, a southeast course; a southeast wind.
Spottedness: State or quality of being spotted.
Sedition: The raising of commotion in a state, not amounting to insurrection; conduct tending to treason, but without an overt act; excitement of discontent against the government, or of resistance to lawful authority.
Sanctionary: Of, pertaining to, or giving, sanction.
Stoping: The act of excavating in the form of stopes.
Soaproot: A perennial herb (Gypsophila Struthium) the root of which is used in Spain as a substitute for soap.
Signature: To mark with, or as with, a signature or signatures.
&Verbar;Sinapis: A disused generic name for mustard; -- now called Brassica.
Skunkish: Like the skunk, especially in odor.
Succotash: Green maize and beans boiled together. The dish is borrowed from the native Indians.
Sloop: A vessel having one mast and fore-and-aft rig, consisting of a boom-and-gaff mainsail, jibs, staysail, and gaff topsail. The typical sloop has a fixed bowsprit, topmast, and standing rigging, while those of a cutter are capable of being readily shifted.  The sloop usually carries a centerboard, and depends for stability upon breadth of beam rather than depth of keel.  The two types have rapidly approximated since 1880.  One radical distinction is that a sloop may carry a centerboard. See Cutter, and Illustration in Appendix.
Subtreasury: A subordinate treasury, or place of deposit; as, the United States subtreasury at New York.
&Verbar;Stasis: A slackening or arrest of the blood current in the vessels, due not to a lessening of the heart's beat, but presumably to some abnormal resistance of the capillary walls.  It is one of the phenomena observed in the capillaries in inflammation.
Skimming: The act of one who skims.
&Verbar;Sigillaria: A genus of fossil trees principally found in the coal formation; -- so named from the seallike leaf scars in vertical rows on the surface.
Salesman: One who sells anything; one whose occupation is to sell goods or merchandise.
Story: To tell in historical relation; to make the subject of a story; to narrate or describe in story.
Salient: A salient angle or part; a projection.
Swart: To make swart or tawny; as, to swart a living part.
Sappho: Any one of several species of brilliant South American humming birds of the genus Sappho, having very bright-colored and deeply forked tails; -- called also firetail.
Stork: Any one of several species of large wading birds of the family Ciconidæ, having long legs and a long, pointed bill. They are found both in the Old World and in America, and belong to Ciconia and several allied genera. The European white stork (Ciconia alba) is the best known. It commonly makes its nests on the top of a building, a chimney, a church spire, or a pillar. The black stork (C. nigra) is native of Asia, Africa, and Europe.
Semivowel: A sound intermediate between a vowel and a consonant, or partaking of the nature of both, as in the English w and y.
Sward: To produce sward upon; to cover, or be covered, with sward.
Swarf: The grit worn away from grindstones in grinding cutlery wet.
Semination: The act of sowing or spreading.
Store: To collect as a reserved supply; to accumulate; to lay away.
stare: To look with fixed eyes wide open, as through fear, wonder, surprise, impudence, etc.; to fasten an earnest and prolonged gaze on some object.
Stomatode: Having a mouth; -- applied to certain Protozoa.
Saccharimetrical: Of or pertaining to saccharimetry; obtained by saccharimetry.
Slipes: Sledge runners on which a skip is dragged in a mine.
Silex: Silica, SiO2 as found in nature, constituting quarz, and most sands and sandstones. See Silica, and Silicic.
Sarcophagan: Any animal which eats flesh, especially any carnivorous marsupial.
Sabal: A genus of palm trees including the palmetto of the Southern United States.
&Verbar;Striges: The tribe of birds which comprises the owls.
Shifting: Changing in place, position, or direction; varying; variable; fickle; as, shifting winds; shifting opinions or principles.
&Verbar;Squali: The suborder of elasmobranch fishes which comprises the sharks.
Sternomastoid: Of or pertaining to the sternum and the mastoid process.
Stall: To live in, or as in, a stall; to dwell.
Stalk: A high, proud, stately step or walk.
Stale: Something set, or offered to view, as an allurement to draw others to any place or purpose; a decoy; a stool pigeon.
Stockinet: An elastic textile fabric imitating knitting, of which stockings, under-garments, etc., are made.
Septennate: A period of seven years; as, the septennate during which the President of the French Republic holds office.
&Verbar;Soup\u00e7on: A suspicion; a suggestion; hence, a very small portion; a taste; as, coffee with a soupçon of brandy; a soupçon of coquetry.
Symptom: Any affection which accompanies disease; a perceptible change in the body or its functions, which indicates disease, or the kind or phases of disease; as, the causes of disease often lie beyond our sight, but we learn their nature by the symptoms exhibited.
Sericite: A kind of muscovite occuring in silky scales having a fibrous structure. It is characteristic of sericite schist.
Syllogize: To reason by means of syllogisms.
Soft-shell: Having a soft or fragile shell.
Subapical: Being under the apex; of or pertaining to the part just below the apex.
Succory: A plant of the genus Cichorium. See Chicory.
Spiroscope: A wet meter used to determine the breathing capacity of the lungs.
Sinapic: Of or pertaining to sinapine; specifically, designating an acid (C11H12O5) related to gallic acid, and obtained by the decomposition of sinapine, as a white crystalline substance.
Self-preservation: The preservation of one's self from destruction or injury.
Scorp\u00e6noid: Of or pertaining to the family Scorpænidæ, which includes the scorpene, the rosefish, the California rockfishes, and many other food fishes. [Written also scorpænid.] See Illust. under Rockfish.
Separatory: An apparatus used in separating, as a separating funnel.
Semiquintile: An aspect of the planets when distant from each other half of the quintile, or thirty-six degrees.
Starchness: The quality or state of being starched or starchy{5}; stiffness of manner; preciseness.
Splaymouth: A wide mouth; a mouth stretched in derision.
Survival: A living or continuing longer than, or beyond the existence of, another person, thing, or event; an outliving.
Septilateral: Having seven sides; as, a septilateral figure.
Securipalp: One of a family of beetles having the maxillary palpi terminating in a hatchet-shaped joint.
Subservient: Fitted or disposed to subserve; useful in an inferior capacity; serving to promote some end; subordinate; hence, servile, truckling.
Selenograph: A picture or delineation of the moon's surface, or of any part of it.
Subsecute: To follow closely, or so as to overtake; to pursue.
&Verbar;Sarcina: A genus of bacteria found in various organic fluids, especially in those those of the stomach, associated with certain diseases. The individual organisms undergo division along two perpendicular partitions, so that multiplication takes place in two directions, giving groups of four cubical cells. Also used adjectively; as, a sarcina micrococcus; a sarcina group.
Smerk: Smart; jaunty; spruce. See Smirk, a.
Sentimentalize: To think or act in a sentimental manner, or like a sentimentalist; to affect exquisite sensibility.
Sleave: To separate, as threads; to divide, as a collection of threads; to sley; -- a weaver's term.
Sinker: One who, or that which, sinks.
Sultry: Very hot, burning, and oppressive; as, Libya's sultry deserts.
Southwesterly: To ward or from the southwest; as, a southwesterly course; a southwesterly wind.
Stuffing: That which is used for filling anything; as, the stuffing of a saddle or cushion.
Shagreen: Made or covered with the leather called shagreen.
Sequacity: Quality or state of being sequacious; sequaciousness.
Subbreed: A race or strain differing in certain characters from the parent breed; an incipient breed.
Synanthous: Having flowers and leaves which appear at the same time; -- said of certain plants.
Soybean: An Asiatic leguminous herb (Glycine max, formerly Glycine Soja) the seeds of which (also called soy beans) are used in preparing the sauce called soy.  Called also soya bean and soya.
Sarcocarp: The fleshy part of a stone fruit, situated between the skin, or epicarp, and the stone, or endocarp, as in a peach. See Illust. of Endocarp.
Sinologue: A student of China and the Chinese; one versed in the Chinese language, literature, history, politics and culture.
Surmounted: Having its vertical height greater than the half span; -- said of an arch.
Self-defense: The act of defending one's own person, property, or reputation.
Staktometer: A drop measurer; a glass tube tapering to a small orifice at the point, and having a bulb in the middle, used for finding the number of drops in equal quantities of different liquids. See Pipette.
Sulphurize: To combine or impregnate with sulphur or any of its compounds; as, to sulphurize caoutchouc in vulcanizing.
Sterrink: The crab-eating seal (Lobodon carcinophaga) of the Antarctic Ocean.
Sounding-board: A thin board which propagates the sound in a piano, in a violin, and in some other musical instruments.
Silver certificate: A certificate issued by a government that there has been deposited with it silver to a specified amount, payable to the bearer on demand. In the United States and its possessions, it is issued against the deposit of silver coin, and is not legal tender, but is receivable for customs, taxes, and all public dues. In the United States the redeemability in silver of silver certificates was discontinued in the 1970's; they are still (1997) accepted as money at the face dollar value, but cannot be redeemed in silver.
Scumming: The act of taking off scum.
&Verbar;Summum bonum: The supreme or highest good, -- referring to the object of human life.
Sensorial: Of or pertaining to the sensorium; as, sensorial faculties, motions, powers.
Surmounter: One who, or that which, surmounts.
&Verbar;Saccharomyces: A genus of budding fungi, the various species of which have the power, to a greater or less extent, or splitting up sugar into alcohol and carbonic acid. They are the active agents in producing fermentation of wine, beer, etc. Saccharomyces cerevisiæ is the yeast of sedimentary beer. Also called Torula.
Springy: Resembling, having the qualities of, or pertaining to, a spring; elastic; as, springy steel; a springy step.
Scantling: A fragment; a bit; a little piece.
Staphyline: Of or pertaining to the uvula or the palate.
Succula: A bare axis or cylinder with staves or levers in it to turn it round, but without any drum.
-s: The suffix used to form the plural of most words; as in roads, elfs, sides, accounts.
Speeching: The act of making a speech.
Sheeps-foot: A printer's tool consisting of a metal bar formed into a hammer head at one end and a claw at the other, -- used as a lever and hammer.
Surrebut: To reply, as a plaintiff to a defendant's rebutter.
Shovel-nosed: Having a broad, flat nose; as, the shovel-nosed duck, or shoveler.
Sporulation: The act or process of forming spores; spore formation. See Illust. of Bacillus, (b).
Sally Lunn: A tea cake slighty sweetened, and raised with yeast, baked in the form of biscuits or in a thin loaf, and eaten hot with butter.
Sale: The act of selling; the transfer of property, or a contract to transfer the ownership of property, from one person to another for a valuable consideration, or for a price in money.
Saurel: Any carangoid fish of the genus Trachurus, especially T. trachurus, or T. saurus, of Europe and America, and T. picturatus of California. Called also skipjack, and horse mackerel.
Salp: Any species of Salpa, or of the family Salpidæ.
Subprehensile: Somewhat prehensile; prehensile in an inferior degree.
Salt: The act of leaping or jumping; a leap.
Squint: The act or habit of squinting.
Seasonal: Of or pertaining to the seasons.
Skive: To pare or shave off the rough or thick parts of (hides or leather).
Scaphism: An ancient mode of punishing criminals among the Persians, by confining the victim in a trough, with his head and limbs smeared with honey or the like, and exposed to the sun and to insects until he died.
Syndetic: Connecting; conjunctive; as, syndetic words or connectives; syndetic references in a dictionary.
Syphilitically: In a syphilitic manner; with venereal disease.
Spheroidal: Having the form of a spheroid.
Sojournment: Temporary residence, as that of a stranger or a traveler.
&Verbar;Sagapenum: A fetid gum resin obtained from a species of Ferula. It has been used in hysteria, etc., but is now seldom met with.
Stearate: A salt of stearic acid; as, ordinary soap consists largely of sodium or potassium stearates.
Squasher: One who, or that which, squashes.
Sipid: Having a taste or flavorl savory; sapid.
Schooner: A large goblet or drinking glass, -- used for lager beer or ale.
&Verbar;Serpens: A constellation represented as a serpent held by Serpentarius.
Sun-struck: Overcome by, or affected with, sunstroke; as, sun-struck soldiers.
Shasta daisy: A large-flowered garden variety of the oxeye daisy.
Singlet: An unlined or undyed waistcoat; a single garment; -- opposed to doublet.
&Verbar;Senecio: A very large genus of composite plants including the groundsel and the golden ragwort.
Skewbald: Marked with spots and patches of white and some color other than black; -- usually distinguished from piebald, in which the colors are properly white and black. Said of horses.
Sulphion: A hypothetical radical, SO4, regarded as forming the acid or negative constituent of sulphuric acid and the sulphates in electrolytic decomposition; -- so called in accordance with the binary theory of salts.
Sorn: To obtrude one's self on another for bed and board.
Sea god: A marine deity; a fabulous being supposed to live in, or have dominion over, the sea, or some particular sea or part of the sea, as Neptune.
Shrag: To trim, as trees; to lop.
&Verbar;Subimago: A stage in the development of certain insects, such as the May flies, intermediate between the pupa and imago. In this stage, the insect is able to fly, but subsequently sheds a skin before becoming mature. Called also pseudimago.
Shram: To cause to shrink or shrivel with cold; to benumb.
Singularly: In a singular manner; in a manner, or to a degree, not common to others; extraordinarily; as, to be singularly exact in one's statements; singularly considerate of others.
Supersemination: The sowing of seed over seed previously sown.
Shrap: A place baited with chaff to entice birds.
Stevedore: One whose occupation is to load and unload vessels in port; one who stows a cargo in a hold.
Spurge: Any plant of the genus Euphorbia. See Euphorbia.
Shortage: Amount or extent of deficiency, as determined by some requirement or standard; as, a shortage in money accounts.
Skittish: Easily frightened; timorous; shy; untrustworthy; as, a skittish colt.
Stelene: Resembling, or used as, a stela; columnar.
Soda pop: a popular non-alcoholic beverage, sweetened by various means, containing flavoring and supersaturated with carbon dioxide, so as to be effervescent when the container is opened; -- in different localities it is variously called also soda, pop, mineral water, and minerals. It has many variants. The sweetening agent may be natural, such as cane sugar or corn syrup, or artificial, such as saccharin or aspartame.  The flavoring varies widely, popular variants being fruit juices, fruit sirups, cream, or cola flavoring; the soda pop is usually served chilled.
Subcultrate: Having a form resembling that of a colter, or straight on one side and curved on the other.
&Verbar;Stannum: The technical name of tin. See Tin.
Suffraginous: Of or pertaining to the hock of a beast.
Subtonic: A subtonic sound or element; a vocal consonant, as b, d, g, n, etc.; a subvocal.
&Verbar;Subsellium: One of the stalls of the lower range where there are two ranges. See Illust. of Stall.
Sharp-witted: Having an acute or nicely discerning mind.
Spinach: A common pot herb (Spinacia oleracea) belonging to the Goosefoot family.
South: To turn or move toward the south; to veer toward the south.
Sparkling: Emitting sparks; glittering; flashing; brilliant; lively; as, sparkling wine; sparkling eyes.
Stop-gap: That which closes or fills up an opening or gap; hence, a temporary expedient.
Screening: the process of examining or testing objects methodically to find those having desirable properties.  See screen{3}.
Scalper: One who, or that which, scalps.
Spherosome: The body wall of any radiate animal.
Songcraft: The art of making songs or verses; metrical composition; versification.
Scepterellate: Having a straight shaft with whorls of spines; -- said of certain sponge spicules. See Illust. under Spicule.
Sight-hole: A hole for looking through; a peephole.
Schiedam: Holland gin made at Schiedam in the Netherlands.
Scalpel: A small knife with a thin, keen blade, -- used by surgeons, and in dissecting.
Self-estimation: The act of estimating one's self; self-esteem.
Stupendous: Astonishing; wonderful; amazing; especially, astonishing in magnitude or elevation; as, a stupendous pile.
Seascape: A picture representing a scene at sea.  Compare landscape.
Smoker: One who dries or preserves by smoke.
Si: A syllable applied, in solmization, to the note B; more recently, to the seventh tone of any major diatonic scale. It was added to Guido's scale by Le Maire about the end of the 17th century.
So: Be as you are; stand still; stop; that will do; right as you are; -- a word used esp. to cows; also used by sailors.
Strick: A bunch of hackled flax prepared for drawing into slivers.
Stump: To walk clumsily, as if on stumps.
Step-down: Transforming or converting a current of high potential or voltage into one of low voltage; as, a step-down transformer.
Strict: Strained; drawn close; tight; as, a strict embrace; a strict ligature.
Supernal: Being in a higher place or region; locally higher; as, the supernal orbs; supernal regions.
Subsextuple: Having the ratio of one to six; as, a subsextuple proportion.
Snakestone: A kind of hone slate or whetstone obtained in Scotland.
Stercobilin: A coloring matter found in the fæces, a product of the alteration of the bile pigments in the intestinal canal, -- identical with hydrobilirubin.
Signalment: The act of signaling, or of signalizing; hence, description by peculiar, appropriate, or characteristic marks.
Stian: A sty on the eye. See Styan.
Stillage: A low stool to keep the goods from touching the floor.
&Verbar;Sans: Without; deprived or destitute of. Rarely used as an English word.
Suboxide: An oxide containing a relatively small amount of oxygen, and less than the normal proportion; as, potassium suboxide, K4O.
Silverspot: Any one of numerous species of butterflies of the genus Argynnis and allied genera, having silvery spots on the under side of the wings. See Illust. under Aphrodite.
Spray-paint: To paint (a surface) by means of a spray, using a spray can or spray gun.
Sextodecimo: A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into sixteen leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size of a book; -- usually written 16mo, or 16°.
Securely: In a secure manner; without fear or apprehension; without danger; safely.
Sort: To join or associate with others, esp. with others of the same kind or species; to agree.
Seek-no-further: A kind of choice winter apple, having a subacid taste; -- formerly called go-no-further.
Sumac: Any plant of the genus Rhus, shrubs or small trees with usually compound leaves and clusters of small flowers. Some of the species are used in tanning, some in dyeing, and some in medicine. One, the Japanese Rhus vernicifera, yields the celebrated Japan varnish, or lacquer.
Syphilitic: Of or pertaining to syphilis; of the nature of syphilis; affected with syphilis.
Seismometric: Of or pertaining to seismometry, or seismometer; as, seismometric instruments; seismometric measurements.
Scissor: To cut with scissors or shears; to prepare with the aid of scissors.
Smaragdine: Of or pertaining to emerald; resembling emerald; of an emerald green.
&Verbar;Syncytium: Tissue in which the cell or partition walls are wholly wanting and the cell bodies fused together, so that the tissue consists of a continuous mass of protoplasm in which nuclei are imbedded, as in ordinary striped muscle.
Strum: To play on an instrument of music, or as on an instrument, in an unskillful or noisy way; to thrum; as, to strum a piano.
Saltatorial: Relating to leaping; saltatory; as, saltatorial exercises.
Squeegee roller: A small India-rubber roller with a handle, used esp. in printing and photography as a squeegee.
Semaphorist: One who manages or operates a semaphore.
Sometime: Having been formerly; former; late; whilom.
space station: a manned artificial satellite orbiting the earth designed for extended occupation and use by multiple crews in succession.
Seneschal: An officer in the houses of princes and dignitaries, in the Middle Ages, who had the superintendence of feasts and domestic ceremonies; a steward. Sometimes the seneschal had the dispensing of justice, and was given high military commands.
Sory: Green vitriol, or some earth imregnated with it.
Superficialist: One who attends to anything superficially; a superficial or shallow person; a sciolist; a smatterer.
Seleniferous: Containing, or impregnated with, selenium; as, seleniferous pyrites.
Sharp-cut: Cut sharply or definitely, or so as to make a clear, well-defined impression, as the lines of an engraved plate, and the like; clear-cut; hence, having great distinctness; well-defined; clear.
Scioptic: Of or pertaining to an optical arrangement for forming images in a darkened room, usually called scioptic ball.
Spectrobolometer: A combination of spectroscope and bolometer for determining the distribution of energy in a spectrum.
Sore: In a sore manner; with pain; grievously.
Stereochromic: Pertaining to the art of stereochromy; produced by stereochromy.
Starless: Being without stars; having no stars visible; as, a starless night.
&Verbar;Sadda: A work in the Persian tongue, being a summary of the Zend-Avesta, or sacred books.
Striker: One who, or that which, strikes; specifically, a blacksmith's helper who wields the sledge.
submarine sandwich: A large sandwich on an elongated roll, usually incompletely cut into two halves, filed with various cold cuts, meatballs, lettuce, cheese, tomatoes, olives, etc., and spiced variously, and often having oil or other dressing applied; called also hoagie, hero, hero sandwich, grinder, sub, submarine, poor boy, and Italian sandwich.  A single such sandwich may consitute a substantial meal.  Very large variants are sometimes prepared for social gatherings and cut into pieces for individual consumption.
Suet: The fat and fatty tissues of an animal, especially the harder fat about the kidneys and loins in beef and mutton, which, when melted and freed from the membranes, forms tallow.
Suborbital: Situated under or below the orbit.
Surgeon: One whose profession or occupation is to cure diseases or injuries of the body by manual operation; one whose occupation is to cure local injuries or disorders (such as wounds, dislocations, tumors, etc.), whether by manual operation, or by medication and constitutional treatment.
Spruntly: In a sprunt manner; smartly; vigorously; youthfully.
&Verbar;Sph\u00e6ridium: A peculiar sense organ found upon the exterior of most kinds of sea urchins, and consisting of an oval or sherical head surmounting a short pedicel. It is generally supposed to be an olfactory organ.
Singleness: The quality or state of being single, or separate from all others; the opposite of doubleness, complication, or multiplicity.
Sylviculture: The cultivation of forest trees for timber or other purposes; forestry; arboriculture.
Sambo: A colloquial or humorous appellation for a negro; sometimes, the offspring of a black person and a mulatto; a zambo.
Seigniorage: Something claimed or taken by virtue of sovereign prerogative; specifically, a charge or toll deducted from bullion brought to a mint to be coined; the difference between the cost of a mass of bullion and the value as money of the pieces coined from it.
Senior: A person who is older than another; one more advanced in life.
Sea spider: Any maioid crab; a spider crab. See Maioid, and Spider crab, under Spider.
Semantic: pertaining to the meanings of words.
Suprachoroid: Situated above the choroid; -- applied to the layer of the choroid coat of the eyeball next to the sclerotic.
Spadroon: A sword, especially a broadsword, formerly used both to cut and thrust.
Swing: The act of swinging; a waving, oscillating, or vibratory motion of a hanging or pivoted object; oscillation; as, the swing of a pendulum.
Sunn: An East Indian leguminous plant (Crotalaria juncea) and its fiber, which is also called sunn hemp.
Servian: Of or pertaining to Servia, a kingdom of Southern Europe.
Sinalbin: A glucoside found in the seeds of white mustard (Brassica alba, formerly Sinapis alba), and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
standoff: Serving to keep two objects or parts of a machine separated; as, a standoff insulator.
Servility: The quality or state of being servile; servileness.
Sandpit: A pit or excavation from which sand is or has been taken.
Staffman: A workman employed in silk throwing.
Stilted: Elevated as if on stilts; hence, pompous; bombastic; as, a stilted style; stilted declamation.
Stir: The act or result of stirring; agitation; tumult; bustle; noise or various movements.
Symptomatic: Of or pertaining to symptoms; happening in concurrence with something; being a symptom; indicating the existence of something else.
Subpeduncular: Situated beneath the peduncle; as, the subpeduncular lobe of the cerebellum.
Stringhalt: An habitual sudden twitching of the hinder leg of a horse, or an involuntary or convulsive contraction of the muscles that raise the hock.
&Verbar;Selaginella: A genus of cryptogamous plants resembling Lycopodia, but producing two kinds of spores; also, any plant of this genus. Many species are cultivated in conservatories.
&Verbar;Strombus: A genus of marine gastropods in which the shell has the outer lip dilated into a broad wing. It includes many large and handsome species commonly called conch shells, or conchs. See Conch.
&Verbar;Sequela: One who, or that which, follows.
Semitontine: Lit., half-tontine; -- used to designate a form of tontine life insurance. See Tontine insurance.
Superfuse: To pour (something) over or on something else.
Somnambular: Of or pertaining to somnambulism; somnambulistic.
Self-reproof: The act of reproving one's self; censure of one's conduct by one's own judgment.
Saponul: A soapy mixture obtained by treating an essential oil with an alkali; hence, any similar compound of an essential oil.
Simony: The crime of buying or selling ecclesiastical preferment; the corrupt presentation of any one to an ecclesiastical benefice for money or reward.
Supposition: The act of supposing, laying down, imagining, or considering as true or existing, what is known not to be true, or what is not proved.
Statemonger: One versed in politics, or one who dabbles in state affairs.
Syngraph: A writing signed by both or all the parties to a contract or bond.
Scythed: Armed with scythes, as a chariot.
Speculum: A mirror, or looking-glass; especially, a metal mirror, as in Greek and Roman archæology.
Spermatophorous: Producing seed, or sperm; seminiferous; as, the so-called spermatophorous cells.
Siberian: Of or pertaining to Siberia, a region comprising all northern Asia and belonging to Russia; as, a Siberian winter.
Stalactitic: Of or pertaining to a stalactite; having the form or characters of a stalactite; stalactic.
Scalene: A triangle having its sides and angles unequal.
&Verbar;Sursum corda: In the Eucharist, the versicles immediately before the preface, inviting the people to join in the service by “lifting up the heart” to God.
Sophistication: The act of sophisticating; adulteration; as, the sophistication of drugs.
Shipbuilder: A person whose occupation is to construct ships and other vessels; a naval architect; a shipwright.
Shandrydan: A jocosely depreciative name for a vehicle.
Superparticular: Of or pertaining to a ratio when the excess of the greater term over the less is a unit, as the ratio of 1 to 2, or of 3 to 4.
Stimulus: A goad; hence, something that rouses the mind or spirits; an incentive; as, the hope of gain is a powerful stimulus to labor and action.
Solitarily: In a solitary manner; in solitude; alone.
&Verbar;Synentognathi: An order of fishes, resembling the Physoclisti, without spines in the dorsal, anal, and ventral fins. It includes the true flying fishes.
Sensibleness: The quality or state of being sensible; sensibility; appreciation; capacity of perception; susceptibility.
shrink-wrap: a type of plastic film, usually transparent, that shrinks upon application of heat, and may be used to form a wrapping around objects that fits tightly and closely follows the contours of the wrapped object; -- also called shrink-pack, shrinkpack or shrink-wrapping.
Specious: Presenting a pleasing appearance; pleasing in form or look; showy.
Scratchbrush: A stiff wire brush for cleaning iron castings and other metal.
Subhyoidean: Situated or performed beneath the hyoid bone; as, subhyoidean laryngotomy.
Sanctum: A sacred place; hence, a place of retreat; a room reserved for personal use; as, an editor's sanctum.
Stellular: Having the shape or appearance of little stars; radiated.
Sabbatic: Of or pertaining to the Sabbath; resembling the Sabbath; enjoying or bringing an intermission of labor.
Sanctus: A part of the Mass, or, in Protestant churches, a part of the communion service, of which the first words in Latin are Sanctus, sanctus, sanctus [Holy, holy, holy]; -- called also Tersanctus.
Scornful: Full of scorn or contempt; contemptuous; disdainful.
Stonebrearer: A machine for crushing or hammering stone.
Sasin: The Indian antelope (Antilope bezoartica syn.  Antilope cervicapra), noted for its beauty and swiftness. It has long, spiral, divergent horns.
Signify: To show by a sign; to communicate by any conventional token, as words, gestures, signals, or the like; to announce; to make known; to declare; to express; as, a signified his desire to be present.
Stannel: The kestrel; -- called also standgale, standgall, stanchel, stand hawk, stannel hawk, steingale, stonegall.
Saccharify: To convert into, or to impregnate with, sugar.
Spadeful: As much as a spade will hold or lift.
Streamless: Destitute of streams, or of a stream, as a region of country, or a dry channel.
Splotch: A spot; a stain; a daub.
Saturity: The state of being saturated; fullness of supply.
&Verbar;Scampavia: A long, low war galley used by the Neapolitans and Sicilians in the early part of the nineteenth century.
Strontianite: Strontium carbonate, a mineral of a white, greenish, or yellowish color, usually occurring in fibrous massive forms, but sometimes in prismatic crystals.
Sadducize: To adopt the principles of the Sadducees.
Shadrach: A mass of iron on which the operation of smelting has failed of its intended effect; -- so called from Shadrach, one of the three Hebrews who came forth unharmed from the fiery furnace of Nebuchadnezzar. (See Dan. iii. 26, 27.)
Suppletive: Supplying deficiencies; supplementary; as, a suppletory oath.
Swath: A line of grass or grain cut and thrown together by the scythe in mowing or cradling.
Syzygy: The point of an orbit, as of the moon or a planet, at which it is in conjunction or opposition; -- commonly used in the plural.
Strap: To beat or chastise with a strap.
Sober-minded: Having a disposition or temper habitually sober.
Sulphuring: Exposure to the fumes of burning sulphur, as in bleaching; the process of bleaching by exposure to the fumes of sulphur.
Self-consistency: The quality or state of being self-consistent.
Sororicide: The murder of one's sister; also, one who murders or kills one's own sister.
Subsidiary: One who, or that which, contributes aid or additional supplies; an assistant; an auxiliary.
Spirit: To animate with vigor; to excite; to encourage; to inspirit; as, civil dissensions often spirit the ambition of private men; -- sometimes followed by up.
Saulie: A hired mourner at a funeral.
Sharpshooter: One skilled in shooting at an object with exactness; a good marksman.
Speediness: The quality or state of being speedy.
Sole: Being or acting without another; single; individual; only.
&Verbar;Stegosauria: An extinct order of herbivorous dinosaurs, including the genera Stegosaurus, Omosaurus, and their allies.
Spermatic: Of or pertaining to semen; as, the spermatic fluid, the spermatic vessels, etc.
Speight: A woodpecker; -- called also specht, spekt, spight.
Siphoid: A siphon bottle. See under Siphon, n.
Signboard: A board, placed on or before a shop, office, etc., on which ssome notice is given, as the name of a firm, of a business, or the like.
Spermatin: A substance allied to alkali albumin and to mucin, present in semen, to which it is said to impart the mucilaginous character.
Sublimation: The act or process of subliming, or the state or result of being sublimed.
&Verbar;Splenalgia: Pain over the region of the spleen.
Shunt winding: A winding so arranged as to divide the armature current and lead a portion of it around the field-magnet coils; -- opposed to series winding.
Sirkeer: Any one of several species of Asiatic cuckoos of the genus Taccocua, as the Bengal sirkeer (T. sirkee).
Supernaturalness: The quality or state of being supernatural.
Stinkstone: One of the varieties of calcite, barite, and feldspar, which emit a fetid odor on being struck; -- called also swinestone.
Smithing: The act or art of working or forging metals, as iron, into any desired shape.
Scutter: To run quickly; to scurry; to scuttle.
Seidlitz: Of or pertaining to Seidlitz, a village in Bohemia.
Shipwreck: To destroy, as a ship at sea, by running ashore or on rocks or sandbanks, or by the force of wind and waves in a tempest.
Scottering: The burning of a wad of pease straw at the end of harvest.
Semibarbarism: The quality or state of being half barbarous or uncivilized.
Subtleness: The quality or state of being subtle; subtlety.
Superincumbent: Lying or resting on something else.
Soboliferous: Producing soboles. See Illust. of Houseleek.
Sundrops: Any one of the several species of Kneiffia, esp. K. fruticosa (syn. Œnothera fruticosa), of the Evening-primrose family, having flowers that open by daylight.
Scrape: The act of scraping; also, the effect of scraping, as a scratch, or a harsh sound; as, a noisy scrape on the floor; a scrape of a pen.
Strong-minded: Having a vigorous mind; esp., having or affecting masculine qualities of mind; -- said of women.
Saponifier: That which saponifies; any reagent used to cause saponification.
Swounds: An exclamation contracted from God's wounds; -- used as an oath.
Steelbow goods: Those goods on a farm, such as corn, cattle, implements of husbandry, etc., which may not be carried off by a removing tenant, as being the property of the landlord.
Swordbill: A humming bird (Docimastes ensiferus) having a very long, slender bill, exceeding the length of the body of the bird.
Supervenient: Coming as something additional or extraneous; coming afterwards.
Subnotochordal: Situated on the ventral side of the notochord; as, the subnotochordal rod.
Sulphine: Any one of a series of basic compounds which consist essentially of sulphur united with hydrocarbon radicals. In general they are oily or crystalline deliquescent substances having a peculiar odor; as, trimethyl sulphine, (CH3)3S.OH.  Cf. Sulphonium.
Splenology: The branch of science which treats of the spleen.
Sciagraph: An old term for a vertical section of a building; -- called also sciagraphy. See Vertical section, under Section.
&Verbar;Si quis: A notification by a candidate for orders of his intention to inquire whether any impediment may be alleged against him.
Spermoblast: One of the cells formed by the division of the spermospore, each of which is destined to become a spermatozoid; a spermatocyte; a spermatoblast.
Sea moss: Any branched marine bryozoan resembling moss.
Sciotheric: Of or pertaining to a sundial.
Steep-down: Deep and precipitous; having steep descent.
