Sculptor: One who sculptures; one whose occupation is to carve statues, or works of sculpture.
Stalking-horse: A horse, or a figure resembling a horse, behind which a hunter conceals himself from the game he is aiming to kill.
Summerhouse: A rustic house or apartment in a garden or park, to be used as a pleasure resort in summer.
Shingle: To subject to the process of shindling, as a mass of iron from the pudding furnace.
Sanity: The condition or quality of being sane; soundness of health of body or mind, especially of the mind; saneness.
Sane: Being in a healthy condition; not deranged; acting rationally; -- said of the mind.
Squill: A European bulbous liliaceous plant (Urginea maritima, formerly Scilla maritima), of acrid, expectorant, diuretic, and emetic properties, used in medicine.  Called also sea onion.
Skilling: A money od account in Sweden, Norwey, Denmark, and North Germany, and also a coin. It had various values, from three fourths of a cent in Norway to more than two cents in Lübeck.
Snatcher: One who snatches, or takes abruptly.
Sacerdotal: Of or pertaining to priests, or to the order of priests; relating to the priesthood; priesty; as, sacerdotal dignity; sacerdotal functions.
Slipstring: One who has shaken off restraint; a prodigal.
Synodic: Of or pertaining to a synod; transacted in, or authorized by, a synod; as, synodical proceedings or forms.
Stavewood: A tall tree (Simaruba amara) growing in tropical America. It is one of the trees which yields quassia.
Steve: To pack or stow, as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve.
Smaltine: A tin-white or gray mineral of metallic luster. It is an arsenide of cobalt, nickel, and iron. Called also speiskobalt.
Self-excite: To energize or excite (the field magnets of a dynamo) by induction from the residual magnetism of its cores, leading all or a part of the current thus produced through the field-magnet coils.
Self-sacrificing: Yielding up one's own interest, feelings, etc; sacrificing one's self.
Soleness: The state of being sole, or alone; singleness.
Supraocular: Above the eyes; -- said of certain scales of fishes and reptiles.
Steadfastness: The quality or state of being steadfast; firmness; fixedness; constancy.
Shard-borne: Borne on shards or scaly wing cases.
Sundew: Any plant of the genus Drosera, low bog plants whose leaves are beset with pediceled glands which secrete a viscid fluid that glitters like dewdrops and attracts and detains insects. After an insect is caught, the glands curve inward like tentacles and the leaf digests it. Called also lustwort.
Sociology: That branch of philosophy which treats of the constitution, phenomena, and development of human society; social science.
Sunder: To expose to the sun and wind.
Shasta: A mountain peak, etc., in California.
Shaker: A person or thing that shakes, or by means of which something is shaken.
Swayed: Bent down, and hollow in the back; sway-backed; -- said of a horse.
Swagman: A bushman carrying a swag and traveling on foot; -- called also swagsman, swagger, and swaggie.
Sauciness: The quality or state of being saucy; that which is saucy; impertinent boldness; contempt of superiors; impudence.
Sutor: A kind of sirup made by the Indians of Arizona from the fruit of some cactaceous plant (probably the Cereus giganteus).
Soler: A loft or garret. See Solar, n.
Shaken: Caused to shake; agitated; as, a shaken bough.
Suent: Uniformly or evenly distributed or spread; even; smooth. See Suant.
Succubous: Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one is covered by the base of the next higher leaf, as in hepatic mosses of the genus Plagiochila.
Swill: The wash, or mixture of liquid substances, given to swine; hogwash; -- called also swillings.
&Verbar;Supercilium: The eyebrow, or the region of the eyebrows.
Stenography: The art of writing in shorthand, by using abbreviations or characters for whole words; shorthand.
Stockfish: Salted and dried fish, especially codfish, hake, ling, and torsk; also, codfish dried without being salted.
Supplement: To fill up or supply by addition; to add something to.
Signification: The act of signifying; a making known by signs or other means.
Self-esteem: The holding a good opinion of one's self; self-complacency.
Self-destroyer: One who destroys himself; a suicide.
Suede: Swedish glove leather, -- usually made from lambskins tanned with willow bark. Also used adjectively; as, suede gloves.
Signality: The quality or state of being signal or remarkable.
Slash: A long cut; a cut made at random.
Squawberry: A local name for the partridge berry; also, for the deerberry.
Semeiography: A description of the signs of disease.
Self-applying: Applying to or by one's self.
Silt: To flow through crevices; to percolate.
Squirrel: Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Sciurus and several allied genera of the family Sciuridæ. Squirrels generally have a bushy tail, large erect ears, and strong hind legs. They are commonly arboreal in their habits, but many species live in burrows.
Spermatorrhea: Abnormally frequent involuntary emission of the semen without copulation.
Silk: The fine, soft thread produced by various species of caterpillars in forming the cocoons within which the worm is inclosed during the pupa state, especially that produced by the larvæ of Bombyx mori.
Sycoceryl: A radical, of the aromatic series, regarded as an essential ingredient of certain compounds found in the waxy resin of an Australian species of fig.
Silo: A pit or vat for packing away green fodder for winter use so as to exclude air and outside moisture. See Ensilage.
&Verbar;Scrutin de liste: Voting for a group of candidates for the same kind of office on one ticket or ballot, containing a list of them; -- the method, used in France, as from June, 1885, to Feb., 1889, in elections for the Chamber of Deputies, each elector voting for the candidates for the whole department in which he lived, as disting. from scrutin d'arrondissement (d&adot_;`rôN`dēs`mäN"), or voting by each elector for the candidate or candidates for his own arrondissement only.
Shamoying: A process used in preparing certain kinds of leather, which consists in frizzing the skin, and working oil into it to supply the place of the astringent (tannin, alum, or the like) ordinarily used in tanning.
Slabbing: Adapted for forming slabs, or for dressing flat surfaces.
Scantly: In a scant manner; not fully or sufficiently; narrowly; penuriously.
Scantle: To scant; to be niggard of; to divide into small pieces; to cut short or down.
Splashboard: A guard in the front part of vehicle, to prevent splashing by a mud or water from the horse's heels; -- in the United States commonly called dashboard.
Sawyer: One whose occupation is to saw timber into planks or boards, or to saw wood for fuel; a sawer.
Strongly: In a strong manner; so as to be strong in action or in resistance; with strength; with great force; forcibly; powerfully; firmly; vehemently; as, a town strongly fortified; he objected strongly.
Syringeal: Of or pertaining to the syrinx; as, the syringeal muscle.
Self-sufficient: Sufficient for one's self without external aid or coöperation.
Solecistical: Pertaining to, or involving, a solecism; incorrect.
Sax-tuba: A powerful instrument of brass, curved somewhat like the Roman buccina, or tuba.
&Verbar;Specie: abl. of L. species sort, kind.  Used in the phrase in specie, that is, in sort, in kind, in (its own) form.
&Verbar;Sauter: To fry lightly and quickly, as meat, by turning or tossing it over frequently in a hot pan greased with a little fat.
Sight-seeing: The act of seeing sights; eagerness for novelties or curiosities.
Shekinah: The visible majesty of the Divine Presence, especially when resting or dwelling between the cherubim on the mercy seat, in the Tabernacle, or in the Temple of Solomon; -- a term used in the Targums and by the later Jews, and adopted by Christians.
Septuagesimal: Consisting of seventy days, years, etc.; reckoned by seventies.
Sterilization: The act or process of sterilizing, or rendering sterile; also, the state of being sterile.
Seamy: Having a seam; containing seams, or showing them.
Smudge: To stifle or smother with smoke; to smoke by means of a smudge.
Soft-hearted: Having softness or tenderness of heart; susceptible of pity or other kindly affection; gentle; meek.
&Verbar;Sorosis: A fleshy fruit formed by the consolidation of many flowers with their receptacles, ovaries, etc., as the breadfruit, mulberry, and pineapple.
&Verbar;Singspiel: A dramatic work, partly in dialogue and partly in song, of a kind popular in Germany in the latter part of the 18th century. It was often comic, had modern characters, and patterned its music on folk song with strictly subordinated accompaniment.
Sural: Of or pertaining to the calf of the leg; as, the sural arteries.
Surah: A soft twilled silk fabric much used for women's dresses; -- called also surah silk.
Sapajou: Any one of several species of South American monkeys of the genus Cebus, having long and prehensile tails. Some of the species are called also capuchins. The bonnet sapajou (C. subcristatus), the golden-handed sapajou (C. chrysopus), and the white-throated sapajou (C. hypoleucus) are well known species. See Capuchin.
Schillerization: The act or process of producing schiller in a mineral mass.
Stillatitious: Falling in drops; drawn by a still.
Stableness: The quality or state of being stable, or firmly established; stability.
Slicer: One who, or that which, slices; specifically, the circular saw of the lapidary.
Signeted: Stamped or marked with a signet.
Spinal: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the backbone, or vertebral column; rachidian; vertebral.
Surgical: Of or pertaining to surgeons or surgery; done by means of surgery; used in surgery; as, a surgical operation; surgical instruments.
Systemic: Of or relating to a system; common to a system; as, the systemic circulation of the blood.
Scratch hit: a base hit which was weakly batted, barely allowing the batter to reach first base safely.
Spotted: Marked with spots; as, a spotted garment or character.
Sackbut: A brass wind instrument, like a bass trumpet, so contrived that it can be lengthened or shortened according to the tone required; -- said to be the same as the trombone.
Stuckle: A number of sheaves set together in the field; a stook.
Seeker: One who seeks; that which is used in seeking or searching.
Sclerite: A hard chitinous or calcareous process or corpuscle, especially a spicule of the Alcyonaria.
Sprawls: Small branches of a tree; twigs; sprays.
Sibylline: Pertaining to the sibyls; uttered, written, or composed by sibyls; like the productions of sibyls.
Stratocracy: A military government; government by military chiefs and an army.
Sensory: Of or pertaining to the sensorium or sensation; as, sensory impulses; -- especially applied to those nerves and nerve fibers which convey to a nerve center impulses resulting in sensation; also sometimes loosely employed in the sense of afferent, to indicate nerve fibers which convey impressions of any kind to a nerve center.
Syndactyl: Having two or more digits wholly or partly united. See Syndactylism.
Sea slater: Any isopod crustacean of the genus Ligia.
Swainmote: A court held before the verders of the forest as judges, by the steward of the court, thrice every year, the swains, or freeholders, within the forest composing the jury.
Seniorize: To exercise authority; to rule; to lord it.
Synocil: A sense organ found in certain sponges. It consists of several filaments, each of which arises from a single cell.
Suist: One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; a selfish person; a selfist.
Sunstroke: Any affection produced by the action of the sun on some part of the body; especially, a sudden prostration of the physical powers, with symptoms resembling those of apoplexy, occasioned by exposure to excessive heat, and often terminating fatally; coup de soleil.
Sorbile: Fit to be drunk or sipped.
Solisequious: Following the course of the sun; as, solisequious plants.
Symbolize: To make to agree in properties or qualities.
Subgenus: A subdivision of a genus, comprising one or more species which differ from other species of the genus in some important character or characters; as, the azaleas now constitute a subgenus of Rhododendron.
Scan: To mount by steps; to go through with step by step.
Subacid: Moderately acid or sour; as, some plants have subacid juices.
Scab: To become covered with a scab; as, the wound scabbed over.
Scad: A small carangoid fish (Trachurus saurus) abundant on the European coast, and less common on the American. The name is applied also to several allied species.
Snuffler: One who snuffles; one who uses cant.
Scar: A marine food fish, the scarus, or parrot fish.
Sea captain: The captain of a vessel that sails upon the sea.
Subcordate: Somewhat cordate; somewhat like a heart in shape.
Scale: To lead up by steps; to ascend.
Stalled: Put or kept in a stall; hence, fatted.
Spilikin: One of a number of small pieces or pegs of wood, ivory, bone, or other material, for playing a game, or for counting the score in a game, as in cribbage. In the plural (spilikins), a game played with such pieces; pushpin.
Somatics: The science which treats of the general properties of matter; somatology.
Seek-sorrow: One who contrives to give himself vexation.
Sychnocarpous: Having the capacity of bearing several successive crops of fruit without perishing; as, sychnocarpous plants.
&Verbar;Septemvir: One of a board of seven men associated in some office.
Seljukian: Of or pertaining to Seljuk, a Tartar chief who embraced Mohammedanism, and began the subjection of Western Asia to that faith and rule; of or pertaining to the dynasty founded by him, or the empire maintained by his descendants from the 10th to the 13th century.
Southron: An inhabitant of the more southern part of a country; formerly, a name given in Scotland to any Englishman.
Subtraction: The act or operation of subtracting or taking away a part.
Sixteen: The number greater by a unit than fifteen; the sum of ten and six; sixteen units or objects.
Snide: Tricky; deceptive; contemptible; as, a snide lawyer; snide goods.
&Verbar;Sura: One of the sections or chapters of the Koran, which are one hundred and fourteen in number.
Schoharie grit: The formation belonging to the middle of the three subdivisions of the Corniferous period in the American Devonian system; -- so called from Schoharie, in New York, where it occurs. See the Chart of Geology.
Severy: A bay or compartment of a vaulted ceiling.
Shakefork: A fork for shaking hay; a pitchfork.
Soloist: One who sings or plays a solo.
Severe: Serious in feeling or manner; sedate; grave; austere; not light, lively, or cheerful.
&Verbar;Sirvente: A peculiar species of poetry, for the most part devoted to moral and religious topics, and commonly satirical, -- often used by the troubadours of the Middle Ages.
Suffragette: A woman who advocates the right to vote for women; a woman suffragist.
Saxonism: An idiom of the Saxon or Anglo-Saxon language.
Stromatology: The history of the formation of stratified rocks.
Saxonist: One versed in the Saxon language.
Scissors: A cutting instrument resembling shears, but smaller, consisting of two cutting blades with handles, movable on a pin in the center, by which they are held together. Often called a pair of scissors.
Stormy: Characterized by, or proceeding from, a storm; subject to storms; agitated with furious winds; biosterous; tempestous; as, a stormy season; a stormy day or week.
Self-knowledge: Knowledge of one's self, or of one's own character, powers, limitations, etc.
Saliency: Quality of being salient; hence, vigor.
Sprinter: One who sprints; one who runs in sprint races; as, a champion sprinter.
Supralapsarianism: The doctrine, belief, or principles of the Supralapsarians.
Snag: To cut the snags or branches from, as the stem of a tree; to hew roughly.
Salience: The quality or condition of being salient; a leaping; a springing forward; an assaulting.
Snap: Done, performed, made, executed, carried through, or the like, quickly and without deliberation; as, a snap judgment or decision; a snap political convention.
Sticky: Having the quality of sticking to a surface; adhesive; gluey; viscous; viscid; glutinous; tenacious.
Sea louse: Any one of numerous species of isopod crustaceans of Cymothoa, Livoneca, and allied genera, mostly parasites on fishes.
Self-depraved: Corrupted or depraved by one's self.
Sinopite: A brick-red ferruginous clay used by the ancients for red paint.
&Verbar;Sordes: Foul matter; excretion; dregs; filthy, useless, or rejected matter of any kind; specifically (Med.), the foul matter that collects on the teeth and tongue in low fevers and other conditions attended with great vital depression.
Sounding balloon: An unmanned balloon sent aloft for meteorological or aëronautic purposes.
Stopping-out: A method adopted in etching, to keep the acid from those parts which are already sufficiently corroded, by applying varnish or other covering matter with a brush, but allowing the acid to act on the other parts.
Spontoon: A kind of half-pike, or halberd, formerly borne by inferior officers of the British infantry, and used in giving signals to the soldiers.
Synthesist: One who employs synthesis, or who follows synthetic methods.
Sorrento work: Ornamental work, mostly carved in olivewood, decorated with inlay, made at or near Sorrento, Italy. Hence, more rarely, jig-saw work and the like done anywhere.
Streetwalker: A common prostitute who walks the streets to find customers.
Sentry: A soldier placed on guard; a sentinel.
Shuttlewise: Back and forth, like the movement of a shuttle.
Sundog: A luminous spot occasionally seen a few degrees from the sun, supposed to be formed by the intersection of two or more halos, or in a manner similar to that of halos.
Sustainment: The act of sustaining; maintenance; support.
Symmetrical: Involving or exhibiting symmetry; proportional in parts; having its parts in due proportion as to dimensions; as, a symmetrical body or building.
Scruff: The nape of the neck; the loose outside skin, as of the back of the neck.
Suability: Liability to be sued; the state of being subjected by law to civil process.
Satin: A silk cloth, of a thick, close texture, and overshot woof, which has a glossy surface.
Spearwood: An Australian tree (Acacia Doratoxylon), and its tough wood, used by the natives for spears.
Sweatiness: Quality or state of being sweaty.
Shedder: One who, or that which, sheds; as, a shedder of blood; a shedder of tears.
Self: The individual as the object of his own reflective consciousness; the man viewed by his own cognition as the subject of all his mental phenomena, the agent in his own activities, the subject of his own feelings, and the possessor of capacities and character; a person as a distinct individual; a being regarded as having personality.
Saprophyte: Any plant growing on decayed animal or vegetable matter, as most fungi and some flowering plants with no green color, as the Indian pipe.
Spirally: In a spiral form, manner, or direction.
Springboard: An elastic board, secured at the ends, or at one end, often by elastic supports, used in performing feats of agility or in exercising.
Sea porcupine: Any fish of the genus Diodon, and allied genera, whose body is covered with spines. See Illust. under Diodon.
&Verbar;Scudo: A silver coin, and money of account, used in Italy and Sicily, varying in value, in different parts, but worth about 4 shillings sterling, or about 96 cents; also, a gold coin worth about the same.
Satrapal: Of or pertaining to a satrap, or a satrapy.
Spermato-: Combining forms from Gr. spe`rma, -atos, seed, sperm, semen (of plants or animals); as, spermatoblast, spermoblast.
Stephanion: The point on the side of the skull where the temporal line, or upper edge of the temporal fossa, crosses the coronal suture.
Sulphur: A nonmetallic element occurring naturally in large quantities, either combined as in the sulphides (as pyrites) and sulphates (as gypsum), or native in volcanic regions, in vast beds mixed with gypsum and various earthy materials, from which it is melted out. Symbol S. Atomic weight 32. The specific gravity of ordinary octohedral sulphur is 2.05; of prismatic sulphur, 1.96.
Stress: To press; to urge; to distress; to put to difficulties.
Skimmer: One who, or that which, skims; esp., a utensil with which liquids are skimmed.
Stave: To burst in pieces by striking against something; to dash into fragments.
Schizopelmous: Having the two flexor tendons of the toes entirely separate, and the flexor hallucis going to the first toe only.
Synergism: The doctrine or theory, attributed to Melanchthon, that in the regeneration of a human soul there is a coöperation, or joint agency, on the part both of God and of man.
Socle: A plain block or plinth forming a low pedestal; any base; especially, the base of a statue, column, or the like. See Plinth.
Seraphine: A wind instrument whose sounding parts are reeds, consisting of a thin tongue of brass playing freely through a slot in a plate. It has a case, like a piano, and is played by means of a similar keybord, the bellows being worked by the foot. The melodeon is a portable variety of this instrument.
Saporosity: The quality of a body by which it excites the sensation of taste.
Supportable: Capable of being supported, maintained, or endured; endurable.
&Verbar;Saccharomycetes: A family of fungi consisting of the one genus Saccharomyces.
Spy: One who keeps a constant watch of the conduct of others.
Superfecundity: Superabundant fecundity or multiplication of the species.
Spindle-shaped: Having the shape of a spindle.
Submental: Situated under the chin; as, the submental artery.
Similarity: The quality or state of being similar; likeness; resemblance; as, a similarity of features.
Square-toes: A precise person; -- used contemptuously or jocularly.
Sheol: The place of departed spirits; Hades; also, the grave.
&Verbar;Synechia: A disease of the eye, in which the iris adheres to the cornea or to the capsule of the crystalline lens.
Saltwort: A name given to several plants which grow on the seashore, as the Batis maritima, and the glasswort. See Glasswort.
Stenting: An opening in a wall in a coal mine.
Sentencer: One who pronounced a sentence or condemnation.
Spa: A spring or mineral water; -- so called from a place of this name in Belgium.
Schottish: A Scotch round dance in 2-4 time, similar to the polka, only slower; also, the music for such a dance; -- not to be confounded with the Écossaise.
Stethoscopist: One skilled in the use of the stethoscope.
Sarcel: One of the outer pinions or feathers of the wing of a bird, esp. of a hawk.
space sickness: a group of symptoms, prominently nausea, but sometimes including lethargy, headache, and sweating, occuring under the weightless conditions of space flight.
Self-asserting: asserting one's self, or one's own rights or claims; hence, putting one's self forward in a confident or assuming manner.
Systematization: The act or operation of systematizing.
Starchedness: The quality or state of being starched or starchy{5}; stiffness in manners; formality.
Sulphantimonious: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid of antimony (called also thioantimonious acid) analogous to sulpharsenious acid.
Standardize: To reduce to a normal standard; to calculate or adjust the strength of, by means of, and for uses in, analysis.
Squash: Something soft and easily crushed; especially, an unripe pod of pease.
Snapper: One who, or that which, snaps; as, a snapper up of trifles; the snapper of a whip.
Splay: A slope or bevel, especially of the sides of a door or window, by which the opening is made larged at one face of the wall than at the other, or larger at each of the faces than it is between them.
Swanny: Swanlike; as, a swanny glossiness of the neck.
Spitchcocked: Broiled or fried after being split lengthwise; -- said of eels.
Stipulator: One who stipulates, contracts, or covenants.
Sagittocyst: A defensive cell containing a minute rodlike structure which may be expelled. Such cells are found in certain Turbellaria.
&Verbar;Staccato: Disconnected; separated; distinct; -- a direction to perform the notes of a passage in a short, distinct, and pointed manner.  It is opposed to legato, and often indicated by heavy accents written over or under the notes, or by dots when the performance is to be less distinct and emphatic.
Slightness: The quality or state of being slight; slenderness; feebleness; superficiality; also, formerly, negligence; indifference; disregard.
Statocracy: Government by the state, or by political power, in distinction from government by ecclesiastical power.
Stove: To keep warm, in a house or room, by artificial heat; as, to stove orange trees.
Superplant: A plant growing on another, as the mistletoe; an epiphyte.
Sepoy: A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of a European power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldier disciplined in the European manner.
Soapy: Resembling soap; having the qualities of, or feeling like, soap; soft and smooth.
Stigma: A mark made with a burning iron; a brand.
Spinebill: Any species of Australian birds of the genus Acanthorhynchus. They are related to the honey eaters.
Sestet: A piece of music composed for six voices or six instruments; a sextet; -- called also sestuor.
Spouter: One who, or that which, spouts.
Scaldfish: A European flounder (Arnoglossus laterna, or Psetta arnoglossa); -- called also megrim, and smooth sole.
Soaking: Wetting thoroughly; drenching; as, a soaking rain.
&Verbar;Sabot: A kind of wooden shoe worn by the peasantry in France, Belgium, Sweden, and some other European countries.
Saporific: Having the power to produce the sensation of taste; producing taste, flavor, or relish.
Startish: Apt to start; skittish; shy; -- said especially of a horse.
Syncopate: To contract, as a word, by taking one or more letters or syllables from the middle; as, “Gloster” is a syncopated form of “Gloucester.”
&Verbar;Strychnos: A genus of tropical trees and shrubs of the order Loganiaceæ. See Nux vomica.
&Verbar;Scutellum: A rounded apothecium having an elevated rim formed of the proper thallus, the fructification of certain lichens.
Shrinker: One who shrinks; one who withdraws from danger.
Stethoscopy: The art or process of examination by the stethoscope.
Smacking: Making a sharp, brisk sound; hence, brisk; as, a smacking breeze.
Suppletory: That which is to supply what is wanted.
Stethoscope: To auscultate, or examine, with a stethoscope.
Spectrometer: A spectroscope fitted for measurements of the luminious spectra observed with it.
Shyster: A trickish knave; one who carries on any business, especially legal business, in a mean and dishonest way.
Sailing: The act of one who, or that which, sails; the motion of a vessel on water, impelled by wind or steam; the act of starting on a voyage.
Skylark: A lark that mounts and sings as it files, especially the common species (Alauda arvensis) found in Europe and in some parts of Asia, and celebrated for its melodious song; -- called also sky laverock. See under Lark.
&Verbar;Spina bifida: A congenital malformation in which the spinal column is cleft at its lower portion, and the membranes of the spinal cord project as an elastic swelling from the gap thus formed.
Slide: The act of sliding; as, a slide on the ice.
Shilling: A silver coin, and money of account, of Great Britain and its dependencies, equal to twelve pence, or the twentieth part of a pound, equivalent to about twenty-four cents of the United States currency.
&Verbar;Supersedeas: A writ of command to suspend the powers of an officer in certain cases, or to stay proceedings under another writ.
Speculist: One who observes or considers; an observer.
Sulcate: Scored with deep and regular furrows; furrowed or grooved; as, a sulcated stem.
Syntax: Connected system or order; union of things; a number of things jointed together; organism.
Symphony: A consonance or harmony of sounds, agreeable to the ear, whether the sounds are vocal or instrumental, or both.
&Verbar;Stephanotis: A genus of climbing asclepiadaceous shrubs, of Madagascar, Malaya, etc. They have fleshy or coriaceous opposite leaves, and large white waxy flowers in cymes.
Scheming: Given to forming schemes; artful; intriguing.
Skirt: To be on the border; to live near the border, or extremity.
Speiss: A regulus consisting essentially of nickel, obtained as a residue in fusing cobalt and nickel ores with silica and sodium carbonate to make smalt.
Submuscular: Situated underneath a muscle or muscles.
shtick: A person's special talent, line of business, or habitual activity.
Southernwood: A shrubby species of wormwood (Artemisia Abrotanum) having aromatic foliage. It is sometimes used in making beer.
Superannuation: The state of being superannuated, or too old for office or business; the state of being disqualified by old age; decrepitude.
Semibreve: A note of half the time or duration of the breve; -- now usually called a whole note. It is the longest note in general use.
Stearic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, stearin or tallow; resembling tallow.
Stiddy: An anvil; also, a smith shop. See Stithy.
Stearin: One of the constituents of animal fats and also of some vegetable fats, as the butter of cacao. It is especially characterized by its solidity, so that when present in considerable quantity it materially increases the hardness, or raises the melting point, of the fat, as in mutton tallow. Chemically, it is a compound of glyceryl with three molecules of stearic acid, and hence is technically called tristearin, or glyceryl tristearate.
Sumerian: A native of lower Babylonia, anciently called Sumer.
Stereoscope: An optical instrument for giving to pictures the appearance of solid forms, as seen in nature. It combines in one, through a bending of the rays of light, two pictures, taken for the purpose from points of view a little way apart. It is furnished with two eyeglasses, and by refraction or reflection the pictures are superimposed, so as to appear as one to the observer.
Splutter: A confused noise, as of hasty speaking.
Self-homicide: The act of killing one's self; suicide.
Spine-tailed: Having the tail quills ending in sharp, naked tips.
Steeving: The act or practice of one who steeves.
&Verbar;Sesqui-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting that three atoms or equivalents of the substance to the name of which it is prefixed are combined with two of some other element or radical; as, sesquibromide, sesquicarbonate, sesquichloride, sesquioxide.
&Verbar;Syssarcosis: The junction of bones by intervening muscles.
Stereoscopy: The art or science of using the stereoscope, or of constructing the instrument or the views used with it.
Septuple: To multiply by seven; to make sevenfold.
Specific: A specific remedy. See Specific, a., 3.
Smell-less: Destitute of smell; having no odor.
Stirrer: One who, or that which, stirs something; also, one who moves about, especially after sleep; as, an early stirrer.
Sanious: Pertaining to sanies, or partaking of its nature and appearance; thin and serous, with a slight bloody tinge; as, the sanious matter of an ulcer.
Sparrowwort: An evergreen shrub of the genus Erica (E. passerina).
Sinusoidal: Of or pertaining to a sinusoid; like a sinusoid.
Suborder: A division of an order; a group of genera of a little lower rank than an order and of greater importance than a tribe or family; as, cichoraceous plants form a suborder of Compositæ.
Stemmy: Abounding in stems, or mixed with stems; -- said of tea, dried currants, etc.
Squaw man: A white man who has married an Indian squaw; sometimes, one who has gained tribal rights by such a marriage; -- often a term of contempt.
Sprayer: One that sprays; any instrument for vaporizing and spraying liquids.
Subspecies: A group somewhat lessdistinct than speciesusually are, but based on characters more important than those which characterize ordinary varieties; often, a geographical variety or race.
Suffusion: The act or process of suffusing, or state of being suffused; an overspreading.
Smite: The act of smiting; a blow.
Sway-backed: Having the back hollow or sagged, whether naturally or as the result of injury or weakness; -- said of horses and other animals.
Spiteful: Filled with, or showing, spite; having a desire to vex, annoy, or injure; malignant; malicious; as, a spiteful person or act.
Smith: To beat into shape; to forge.
Saintdom: The state or character of a saint.
Smitt: Fine clay or ocher made up into balls, used for marking sheep.
stator: A stationary part in or about which another part (the rotor) revolves, esp. when both are large;
Supernatural: Being beyond, or exceeding, the power or laws of nature; miraculous.
Staggard: The male red deer when four years old.
Smell-feast: One who is apt to find and frequent good tables; a parasite; a sponger.
Sibilation: Utterance with a hissing sound; also, the sound itself; a hiss.
Spheroconic: A nonplane curve formed by the intersection of the surface of an oblique cone with the surface of a sphere whose center is at the vertex of the cone.
Squall: A loud scream; a harsh cry.
Subaid: To aid secretly; to assist in a private manner, or indirectly.
Sea horse: A fabulous creature, half horse and half fish, represented in classic mythology as driven by sea dogs or ridden by the Nereids. It is also depicted in heraldry. See Hippocampus.
Sing: To utter with musical inflections or modulations of voice.
Sine: The length of a perpendicular drawn from one extremity of an arc of a circle to the diameter drawn through the other extremity.
Subtartarean: Being or living under Tartarus; infernal.
Steeple: A spire; also, the tower and spire taken together; the whole of a structure if the roof is of spire form. See Spire.
Stilty: Unreasonably elevated; pompous; stilted; as, a stilty style.
Shill: To put under cover; to sheal.
&Verbar;Siphonopoda: A division of Scaphopoda including those in which the foot terminates in a circular disk.
Saint Nicholas: A Dutch saint, who was reputed to bring gifts to children on Christmas even, giving rise to the modern legend of Santa Claus.
stout: A strong, dark malt brew having a higher percentage of hops than porter; strong porter; a popular variety sold in the U. S. is Guinness' stout.
Sesquibasic: Containing, or acting as, a base in the proportions of a sesqui compound.
Shafted: Furnished with a shaft, or with shafts; as, a shafted arch.
Sepalody: The metamorphosis of other floral organs into sepals or sepaloid bodies.
starchiness: The quality or state of being starchy; stiffness in manners; formality.
Soleship: The state of being sole, or alone; soleness.
Sheelfa: The chaffinch; -- so named from its call note.
Supreme: Highest in authority; holding the highest place in authority, government, or power.
Suppositive: A word denoting or implying supposition, as the words if, granting, provided, etc.
Sailor: One who follows the business of navigating ships or other vessels; one who understands the practical management of ships; one of the crew of a vessel; a mariner; a common seaman.
Shipbuilding: Naval architecturel the art of constructing ships and other vessels.
Specter: Something preternaturally visible; an apparition; a ghost; a phantom.
Structural: Of or pertaining to structure; affecting structure; as, a structural error.
Statistics: The science which has to do with the collection, classification, and analysis of facts of a numerical nature regarding any topic.
Semisextile: An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each other the twelfth part of a circle, or thirty degrees.
Skelp: A wrought-iron plate from which a gun barrel or pipe is made by bending and welding the edges together, and drawing the thick tube thus formed.
spanpiece: The collar of a roof; sparpiece.
Sudatory: A bagnio; a sweating bath; a vapor bath.
Swear: To utter or affirm with a solemn appeal to God for the truth of the declaration; to make (a promise, threat, or resolve) under oath.
Seaming: The act or process of forming a seam or joint.
Swartback: The black-backed gull (Larus marinus); -- called also swarbie.
Season: To become mature; to grow fit for use; to become adapted to a climate.
Stereotomic: Of or pertaining to stereotomy; performed by stereotomy.
Simoniacal: Of or pertaining to simony; guilty of simony; consisting of simony.
Self-restraint: Restraint over one's self; self-control; self-command.
Stakehead: A horizontal bar on a stake, used for supporting the yarns which are kept apart by pins in the bar.
Symbolization: The act of symbolizing; symbolical representation.
Skimmington: A word employed in the phrase, To ride Skimmington; that is to ride on a horse with a woman, but behind her, facing backward, carrying a distaff, and accompanied by a procession of jeering neighbors making mock music; a cavalcade in ridicule of a henpecked man. The custom was in vogue in parts of England.
Self-suspicious: Suspicious or distrustful of one's self.
Sweal: To singe; to scorch; to swale; as, to sweal a pig by singeing off the hair.
Surgy: Rising in surges or billows; full of surges; resembling surges in motion or appearance; swelling.
Synartesis: A fastening or knitting together; the state of being closely jointed; close union.
&Verbar;Succuba: A female demon or fiend. See Succubus.
&Verbar;Sheik: The head of an Arab family, or of a clan or a tribe; also, the chief magistrate of an Arab village. The name is also applied to Mohammedan ecclesiastics of a high grade.
Sensitive: Having sense of feeling; possessing or exhibiting the capacity of receiving impressions from external objects; as, a sensitive soul.
Sequestration: The act of separating, or setting aside, a thing in controversy from the possession of both the parties that contend for it, to be delivered to the one adjudged entitled to it. It may be voluntary or involuntary.
Solubleness: Quality or state of being soluble.
Scurfiness: Quality or state of being scurfy.
Sibilous: Having a hissing sound; hissing; sibilant.
Staphylotomy: The operation of removing a staphyloma by cutting.
Sulpharsenic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid (called also thioarsenic acid) analogous to arsenic acid, and known only in its salts.
&Verbar;Sturiones: An order of fishes including the sturgeons.
Sequacious: Inclined to follow a leader; following; attendant.
Subclass: One of the natural groups, more important than an order, into which some classes are divided; as, the angiospermous subclass of exogens.
Strigine: Of or pertaining to owls; owl-like.
Shirt: To cover or clothe with a shirt, or as with a shirt.
Stephanite: A sulphide of antimony and silver of an iron-black color and metallic luster; called also black silver, and brittle silver ore.
Shank: To fall off, as a leaf, flower, or capsule, on account of disease affecting the supporting footstalk; -- usually followed by off.
Stenographer: One who is skilled in stenography; a writer of shorthand.
Spritsail: A sail extended by a sprit.
-ship: A suffix denoting state, office, dignity, profession, or art; as in lordship, friendship, chancellorship, stewardship, horsemanship.
&Verbar;Scarab\u00e6us: Same as Scarab in both senses.
Superscribe: To write or engrave (a name, address, inscription, or the like) on the top or surface; to write a name, address, or the like, on the outside or cover of (anything); as, to superscribe a letter.
Supraloral: Situated above the lores; as, the supraloral feathers of a bird.
Sneeze: A sudden and violent ejection of air with an audible sound, chiefly through the nose.
Stow: To place or arrange in a compact mass; to put in its proper place, or in a suitable place; to pack; as, to stowbags, bales, or casks in a ship's hold; to stow hay in a mow; to stow sheaves.
Streamlet: A small stream; a rivulet; a rill.
Syncopation: The act of syncopating; the contraction of a word by taking one or more letters or syllables from the middle; syncope.
Sanctifyingly: In a manner or degree tending to sanctify or make holy.
Sign: To be a sign or omen.
Somatopleure: The outer, or parietal, one of the two lamellæ into which the vertebrate blastoderm divides on either side of the notochord, and from which the walls of the body and the amnion are developed. See Splanchnopleure.
&Verbar;Scrotum: The bag or pouch which contains the testicles; the cod.
&Verbar;Salpa: A genus of transparent, tubular, free-swimming oceanic tunicates found abundantly in all the warmer latitudes. See Illustration in Appendix.
Sulkiness: The quality or state of being sulky; sullenness; moroseness; as, sulkiness of disposition.
Spurgall: To gall or wound with a spur.
Sparble: To scatter; to disperse; to rout.
Scotch rite: The ceremonial observed by one of the Masonic systems, called in full the Ancient and Accepted Scotch Rite; also, the system itself, which confers thirty-three degrees, of which the first three are nearly identical with those of the York rite.
Sock: To hurl, drive, or strike violently; -- often with it as an object.
Soppy: Soaked or saturated with liquid or moisture; very wet or sloppy.
&Verbar;Syringoc\u0153le: The central canal of the spinal cord.
Spay: The male of the red deer in his third year; a spade.
Subumbrella: The integument of the under surface of the bell, or disk-shaped body, of a jellyfish.
Sagathy: A mixed woven fabric of silk and cotton, or silk and wool; sayette; also, a light woolen fabric.
Shogunate: The office or dignity of a Shogun.
Spar: A contest at sparring or boxing.
Scorner: One who scorns; a despiser; a contemner; specifically, a scoffer at religion.
&Verbar;Sauria: A division of Reptilia formerly established to include the Lacertilia, Crocodilia, Dinosauria, and other groups. By some writers the name is restricted to the Lacertilia.
&Verbar;Serang: The boatswain of a Lascar or East Ondian crew.
Skepticism: An undecided, inquiring state of mind; doubt; uncertainty.
Strombite: A fossil shell of the genus Strombus.
Souari nut: The large edible nutlike seed of a tall tropical American tree (Caryocar nuciferum) of the same natural order with the tea plant; -- also called butternut.
Serpent-tongued: Having a forked tongue, like a serpent.
Self-evident: Evident without proof or reasoning; producing certainty or conviction upon a bare presentation to the mind; as, a self-evident proposition or truth.
Seclusive: Tending to seclude; keeping in seclusion; secluding; sequestering.
Stabulation: The act of stabling or housing beasts.
Snail-like: In the manner of a snail; slowly.
Smeir: A salt glaze on pottery, made by adding common salt to an earthenware glaze.
Sorbin: An unfermentable sugar, isomeric with glucose, found in the ripe berries of the rowan tree, or sorb, and extracted as a sweet white crystalline substance; -- called also mountain-ash sugar.
Sorbic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the rowan tree, or sorb; specifically, designating an acid, C&unr_;H&unr_;CO&unr_;H, of the acetylene series, found in the unripe berries of this tree, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
&Verbar;Shakudo: An alloy of copper, invented by the Japanese, having a very dark blue color approaching black.
Significate: One of several things signified by a common term.
Separatism: The character or act of a separatist; disposition to withdraw from a church; the practice of so withdrawing.
Semiorbicular: Having the shape of a half orb or sphere.
Salvationist: An evangelist, a member, or a recruit, of the Salvation Army.
Separatist: One who withdraws or separates himself; especially, one who withdraws from a church to which he has belonged; a seceder from an established church; a dissenter; a nonconformist; a schismatic; a sectary.
Somniferous: Causing or inducing sleep; soporific; dormitive; as, a somniferous potion.
Spectral: Of or pertaining to a specter; ghosty.
Scincoidian: Any one of numerous species of lizards of the family Scincidæ or tribe Scincoidea. The tongue is not extensile. The body and tail are covered with overlapping scales, and the toes are margined. See Illust. under Skink.
Stylographic: Of or pertaining to stylography; used in stylography; as, stylographic tablets.
Sea eagle: Any one of several species of fish-eating eagles of the genus Haliæetus and allied genera, as the North Pacific sea eagle (H. pelagicus), which has white shoulders, head, rump, and tail; the European white-tailed eagle (H. albicilla); and the Indian white-tailed sea eagle, or fishing eagle (Polioaëtus ichthyaëtus). The bald eagle and the osprey are also sometimes classed as sea eagles.
Stearoptene: The more solid ingredient of certain volatile oils; -- contrasted with elæoptene.
&Verbar;Serpentaria: The fibrous aromatic root of the Virginia snakeroot (Aristolochia Serpentaria).
Sexualist: One who classifies plants by the sexual method of Linnæus.
Stub: To grub up by the roots; to extirpate; as, to stub up edible roots.
Shakespearean: Of, pertaining to, or in the style of, Shakespeare or his works.
Stud: To adorn with shining studs, or knobs.
Sclerobase: The calcareous or hornlike coral forming the central stem or axis of most compound alcyonarians; -- called also foot secretion. See Illust. under Gorgoniacea, and Cœnenchyma.
Siliquose: Bearing siliques; as, siliquose plants; pertaining to, or resembling, siliques; as, siliquose capsules.
Stum: To renew, as wine, by mixing must with it and raising a new fermentation.
Superficies: The surface; the exterior part, superficial area, or face of a thing.
Subtend: To extend under, or be opposed to; as, the line of a triangle which subtends the right angle; the chord subtends an arc.
Sacker: One who sacks; one who takes part in the storm and pillage of a town.
Superhive: A removable upper part of a hive. The word is sometimes contracted to super.
Scythestone: A stone for sharpening scythes; a whetstone.
Soakage: The act of soaking, or the state of being soaked; also, the quantity that enters or issues by soaking.
Suasible: Capable of being persuaded; easily persuaded.
Servitor: One who serves; a servant; an attendant; one who acts under another; a follower or adherent.
Sloughing: The act of casting off the skin or shell, as do insects and crustaceans; ecdysis.
Stateswoman: A woman concerned in public affairs.
Shadowy: Full of shade or shadows; causing shade or shadow.
&Verbar;Stomapoda: An order of Crustacea including the squillas. The maxillipeds are leglike in form, and the large claws are comblike. They have a large and elongated abdomen, which contains a part of the stomach and heart; the abdominal appendages are large, and bear the gills. Called also Gastrula, Stomatopoda, and Squilloidea.
Sextic: Of the sixth degree or order.
Saliniform: Having the form or the qualities of a salt, especially of common salt.
Stealthy: Done by stealth; accomplished clandestinely; unperceived; secret; furtive; sly.
Swans-down: The down, or fine, soft feathers, of the swan, used on various articles of dress.
Spinescent: Becoming hard and thorny; tapering gradually to a rigid, leafless point; armed with spines.
Sedulous: Diligent in application or pursuit; constant, steady, and persevering in business, or in endeavors to effect an object; steadily industrious; assiduous; as, the sedulous bee.
Sepsin: A soluble poison (ptomaine) present in putrid blood. It is also formed in the putrefaction of proteid matter in general.
Self-restrained: Restrained by one's self or itself; restrained by one's own power or will.
Stroking: The act of rubbing gently with the hand, or of smoothing; a stroke.
Symphonize: To agree; to be in harmony.
Simnel: A kind of cake made of fine flour; a cracknel.
Sphenethmoidal: Relating to the sphenoethmoid bone; sphenoethmoid.
Sulphato-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting a sulphate as an ingredient in certain double salts; as, sulphato-carbonate.
Send: The impulse of a wave by which a vessel is carried bodily.
Stearone: The ketone of stearic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, (C17H35)2.CO, by the distillation of calcium stearate.
Semidouble: Having the outermost stamens converted into petals, while the inner ones remain perfect; -- said of a flower.
Starchwort: The cuckoopint, the tubers of which yield a fine quality of starch.
Softener: One who, or that which, softens.
Salian: Denoting a tribe of Franks who established themselves early in the fourth century on the river Sala [now Yssel]; Salic.
Snath: The handle of a scythe; a snead.
Septically: In a septic manner; in a manner tending to promote putrefaction.
Shoelace: a length of cord for tying the upper parts of a shoe together.  Commercial shoelaces usually come in different lengths, and have each end confined in a narrow plastic tube for convenience in inserting the cords through the holes in a shoe upper.  Also called shoestring.
Subfuscous: Duskish; dusky; moderately dark; brownish; tawny.
Sheeps-eye: A modest, diffident look; a loving glance; -- commonly in the plural.
Spired: Having a spire; being in the form of a spire; as, a spired steeple.
Shilly-shally: Irresolution; hesitation; also, occupation with trifles.
Stygian: Of or pertaining to the river Styx; hence, hellish; infernal. See Styx.
Stepfather: The husband of one's mother by a subsequent marriage.
Semaphoric: Of or pertaining to a semaphore, or semaphores; telegraphic.
Scorse: To deal for the purchase of anything; to practice barter.
Sand: To sprinkle or cover with sand.
Sliminess: The quality or state of being slimy.
Stadtholder: Formerly, the chief magistrate of the United Provinces of Holland; also, the governor or lieutenant governor of a province.
Snacot: A pipefish of the genus Syngnathus. See Pipefish.
Sluiceway: An artificial channel into which water is let by a sluice; specifically, a trough constructed over the bed of a stream, so that logs, lumber, or rubbish can be floated down to some convenient place of delivery.
Sinistrorsal: Rising spirally from right to left (of the spectator); sinistrorse.
Sorbonist: A doctor of the Sorbonne, or theological college, in the University of Paris, founded by Robert de Sorbon, a. d. 1252.  It was suppressed in the Revolution of 1789.
&Verbar;Splenius: A flat muscle of the back of the neck.
Saxony yarn: A fine grade of woolen yarn twisted somewhat harder and smoother than zephyr yarn.
Skinbound: Having the skin adhering closely and rigidly to the flesh; hidebound.
Solferino: A brilliant deep pink color with a purplish tinge, one of the dyes derived from aniline; -- so called from Solferino in Italy, where a battle was fought about the time of its discovery.
Somnial: Of or pertaining to sleep or dreams.
Stirte: imp. of Start, v. i. & t.
Squab-chick: A young chicken before it is fully fledged.
Simonian: One of the followers of Simon Magus; also, an adherent of certain heretical sects in the early Christian church.
Simoniac: One who practices simony, or who buys or sells preferment in the church.
&Verbar;Splenium: The thickened posterior border of the corpus callosum; -- so called in allusion to its shape.
Sea blite: A plant (Suæda maritima) of the Goosefoot family, growing in salt marshes.
Stiffening: Act or process of making stiff.
Scholiast: A maker of scholia; a commentator or annotator.
Sise: Six; the highest number on a die; the cast of six in throwing dice.
&Verbar;Steganopodes: A division of swimming birds in which all four toes are united by a broad web. It includes the pelicans, cormorants, gannets, and others.
Spool: To wind on a spool or spools.
Spoom: To be driven steadily and swiftly, as before a strong wind; to be driven before the wind without any sail, or with only a part of the sails spread; to scud under bare poles.
Spoon: To fish with a spoon bait.
Spook: A spirit; a ghost; an apparition; a hobgoblin.
Sist: A stay or suspension of proceedings; an order for a stay of proceedings.
Seasoning: The act or process by which anything is seasoned.
Sepic: Of or pertaining to sepia; done in sepia; as, a sepic drawing.
Sepia: Of a dark brown color, with a little red in its composition; also, made of, or done in, sepia.
Statehouse: The building in which a State legislature holds its sessions; a State capitol.
Sextolet: A double triplet; a group of six equal notes played in the time of four.
Selfish: Caring supremely or unduly for one's self; regarding one's own comfort, advantage, etc., in disregard, or at the expense, of those of others.
Selfism: Concentration of one's interests on one's self; self-love; selfishness.
Shanghai: A large and tall breed of domestic fowl.
Subalternation: The state of being subalternate; succession of turns; subordination.
Still: To drop, or flow in drops; to distill.
&Verbar;Sabella: A genus of tubicolous annelids having a circle of plumose gills around the head.
Sough: To whistle or sigh, as the wind.
Soldiership: Military qualities or state; martial skill; behavior becoming a soldier.
Sanctimony: Holiness; devoutness; scrupulous austerity; sanctity; especially, outward or artificial saintliness; assumed or pretended holiness; hypocritical devoutness.
&Verbar;Scandalum magnatum: A defamatory speech or writing published to the injury of a person of dignity; -- usually abbreviated scan. mag.
Subcolumnar: Having an imperfect or interrupted columnar structure.
Story-teller: One who tells stories; a narrator of anecdotes,incidents, or fictitious tales; as, an amusing story-teller.
Semioxygenated: Combined with oxygen only in part.
Stovain: A substance, C14H22O2NCl, the hydrochloride of an amino compound containing benzol, used, in solution with strychnine, as a local anæsthetic, esp. by injection into the sheath of the spinal cord, producing anæsthesia below the point of introduction.  Called also amylocaine hydrochloride.  Chemically it is the hydrochloride of the benzoyl ester of 1-(dimethylaminomethyl)-1-methyl propanol.
Solifidian: Holding the tenets of Solifidians; of or pertaining to the solifidians.
Syntonizer: One that syntonizes; specif., a device consisting essentially of a variable inductance coil and condenser with a pair of adjustable spark balls, for attuning the time periods of antennæ in wireless telegraphy (called also syntonizing coil).
Shalloon: A thin, loosely woven, twilled worsted stuff.
Sperge: A charge of wash for the still.
Swifter: To tighten, as slack standing rigging, by bringing the opposite shrouds nearer.
Synchronous: Happening at the same time; simultaneous.
Steerageway: A rate of motion through the water sufficient to render a vessel governable by the helm.
Stern: Being in the stern, or being astern; as, the stern davits.
Skill: To be knowing; to have understanding; to be dexterous in performance.
Shintiyan: A kind of wide loose drawers or trousers worn by women in Mohammedan countries.
Saucer: A small pan or vessel in which sauce was set on a table.
Scantlet: A small pattern; a small quantity.
Semiofficial: Half official; having some official authority or importance; as, a semiofficial statement.
Shinty: A Scotch game resembling hockey; also, the club used in the game.
Surfacer: A form of machine for dressing the surface of wood, metal, stone, etc.
Solidary: Having community of interests and responsibilities.
Shinto: One of the two great systems of religious belief in Japan. Its essence is ancestor worship, and sacrifice to dead heroes.
&Verbar;Streptothrix: A genus of bacilli occurring of the form of long, smooth and apparently branched threads, either straight or twisted.
Sulphydrate: A compound, analogous to a hydrate, regarded as a salt of sulphydric acid, or as a derivative of hydrogen sulphide in which one half of the hydrogen is replaced by a base (as potassium sulphydrate, KSH), or as a hydrate in which the oxygen has been wholly or partially replaced by sulphur.
Self-conjugate: Having the two things that are conjugate parts of the same figure; as, self-conjugate triangles.
Screak: A creaking; a screech; a shriek.
Sylvanite: A telluride of gold and silver, (Au, Ag)Te2, of a steel gray, silver white, or brass yellow. It often occurs in implanted crystals resembling written characters, and hence is called graphic tellurium. H., 1.5-2. Sp.gr., 7.9-8.3.
Stalactiform: Like a stalactite; resembling a stalactite.
Sinuate: To bend or curve in and out; to wind; to turn; to be sinuous.
Staurolitic: Of or pertaining to staurolite; resembling or containing staurolite.
Sonority: The quality or state of being sonorous; sonorousness.
Swampy: Consisting of swamp; like a swamp; low, wet, and spongy; as, swampy land.
Spur-winged: Having one or more spurs on the bend of the wings.
Stational: Of or pertaining to a station.
Sciagraphy: The art or science of projecting or delineating shadows as they fall in nature.
Sectist: One devoted to a sect; a sectary.
Sennight: The space of seven nights and days; a week.
Shellproof: Capable of resisting bombs or other shells; bombproof.
Sinicism: Anything peculiar to the Chinese; esp., a Chinese peculiarity in manners or customs.
Skirmish: A slight fight in war; a light or desultory combat between detachments from armies, or between detached and small bodies of troops.
Semeiology: The study of signs as an element of communication; the analysis of systems of communication; -- also called semiotics.
Scatterling: One who has no fixed habitation or residence; a vagabond.
Sedation: The act of calming, or the state of being calm.
&Verbar;Serape: A blanket or shawl worn as an outer garment by the Spanish Americans, as in Mexico.
Sleepy: Drowsy; inclined to, or overcome by, sleep.
Snood: To bind or braid up, as the hair, with a snood.
Sugar-house: A building in which sugar is made or refined; a sugar manufactory.
Squinch: A small arch thrown across the corner of a square room to support a superimposed mass, as where an octagonal spire or drum rests upon a square tower; -- called also sconce, and sconcheon.
Suburbicarian: Being in the suburbs; -- applied to the six dioceses in the suburbs of Rome subject to the pope as bishop of Rome.
Secretage: A process in which mercury, or some of its salts, is employed to impart the property of felting to certain kinds of furs.
Steersman: One who steers; the helmsman of a vessel.
Sea pear: A pedunculated ascidian of the genus Boltonia.
Startle: A sudden motion or shock caused by an unexpected alarm, surprise, or apprehension of danger.
Stingaree: Any sting ray. See under 6th Ray.
Scripturist: One who is strongly attached to, or versed in, the Scriptures, or who endeavors to regulate his life by them.
Stroam: To wander about idly and vacantly.
Suspensibility: The quality or state of being suspensible.
Salso-acid: Having a taste compounded of saltness and acidity; both salt and acid.
Supposable: Capable of being supposed, or imagined to exist; as, that is not a supposable case.
Sea milkwort: A low, fleshy perennial herb (Glaux maritima) found along northern seashores.
Spill: To be destroyed, ruined, or wasted; to come to ruin; to perish; to waste.
Seventh: One next in order after the sixth; one coming after six others.
Solubility: The quality, condition, or degree of being soluble or solvable; as, the solubility of a salt; the solubility of a problem or intricate difficulty.
Synchronical: Happening at the same time; synchronous.
Seizer: One who, or that which, seizes.
Sternway: The movement of a ship backward, or with her stern foremost.
Simply: In a simple manner or state; considered in or by itself; without addition; along; merely; solely; barely.
Seventy: The sum of seven times ten; seventy units or objects.
Strand: To drift, or be driven, on shore to run aground; as, the ship stranded at high water.
Sacrosciatic: Of or pertaining to both the sacrum and the hip; as, the sacrosciatic foramina formed by the sacrosciatic ligaments which connect the sacrum and the hip bone.
Southwestern: Of or pertaining to the southwest; southwesterly; as, to sail a southwestern course.
Statics: That branch of mechanics which treats of the equilibrium of forces, or relates to bodies as held at rest by the forces acting on them; -- distinguished from dynamics.
Stillness: The quality or state of being still; quietness; silence; calmness; inactivity.
Sternbergite: A sulphide of silver and iron, occurring in soft flexible laminæ varying in color from brown to black.
Swaggy: Inclined to swag; sinking, hanging, or leaning by its weight.
Strangeness: The state or quality of being strange (in any sense of the adjective).
Sociologic: Of or pertaining to sociology, or social science.
Spermatize: To yield seed; to emit seed, or sperm.
Suprapubian: Situated above, or anterior to, the pubic bone.
soteriology: A discourse on health, or the science of promoting and preserving health.
Sideboard: A piece of dining-room furniture having compartments and shelves for keeping or displaying articles of table service.
Scrimping: a. & n. from Scrimp, v. t.
Similize: To liken; to compare; as, to similize a person, thing, or act.
Spinstry: The business of one who spins; spinning.
Secular: A secular ecclesiastic, or one not bound by monastic rules.
&Verbar;Siphonobranchiata: A tribe of gastropods having the mantle border, on one or both sides, prolonged in the form of a spout through which water enters the gill cavity. The shell itself is not always siphonostomatous in this group.
Scourger: One who scourges or punishes; one who afflicts severely.
Sheeting: Cotton or linen cloth suitable for bed sheets. It is sometimes made of double width.
Succinuric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid amide, analogous to succinamic acid, which is obtained as a white crystalline substance by heating urea with succinic anhydride. It is known also in its salts.
shirtwaist: A woman's blouse resembling a men's shirt in cut and style; -- in England called a blouse.
Successive: Following in order or in uninterrupted course; coming after without interruption or interval; following one after another in a line or series; consecutive; as, the successive revolution of years; the successive kings of Egypt; successive strokes of a hammer.
Spinel: Bleached yarn in making the linen tape called inkle; unwrought inkle.
Subsequence: The act or state of following; -- opposed to precedence.
Sicilian: A native or inhabitant of Sicily.
Strapwork: A kind of ornament consisting of a narrow fillet or band folded, crossed, and interlaced.
Sponson: One of the triangular platforms in front of, and abaft, the paddle boxes of a steamboat.
Scurfy: Having or producing scurf; covered with scurf; resembling scurf.
Seashore: The coast of the sea; the land that lies adjacent to the sea or ocean.
Sponsor: One who binds himself to answer for another, and is responsible for his default; a surety.
Stomatogastric: Of or pertaining to the mouth and the stomach; as, the stomatogastric ganglion of certain Mollusca.
Sciolistic: Of or pertaining to sciolism, or a sciolist; partaking of sciolism; resembling a sciolist.
Spermic: Of or pertaining to sperm, or semen.
Semitism: A Semitic idiom; a word of Semitic origin.
Shopgirl: A girl employed in a shop.
&Verbar;Syndesmosis: An articulation formed by means of ligaments.
Sweetbrier: A kind of rose (Rosa rubiginosa) with minutely glandular and fragrant foliage. The small-flowered sweetbrier is Rosa micrantha.
spin drier: a machine that uses centrifugal motion to dry the clothes that are put into it.
Shall: To owe; to be under obligation for.
&Verbar;Sida: A genus of malvaceous plants common in the tropics. All the species are mucilaginous, and some have tough ligneous fibers which are used as a substitute for hemp and flax.
Shale: To take off the shell or coat of; to shell.
Saltpeter: Potassium nitrate; niter; a white crystalline substance, KNO3, having a cooling saline taste, obtained by leaching from certain soils in which it is produced by the process of nitrification (see Nitrification, 2). It is a strong oxidizer, is the chief constituent of gunpowder, and is also used as an antiseptic in curing meat, and in medicine as a diuretic, diaphoretic, and refrigerant.
simvastatin: a chemical substance (C25H38O5) having inhibitory activity on the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, and used in medicine to reduce cholesterol levels in blood.
Sinecurism: The state of having a sinecure.
Staving: A casing or lining of staves; especially, one encircling a water wheel.
Spiritualization: The act of spiritualizing, or the state of being spiritualized.
Sporocarp: A closed body or conceptacle containing one or more masses of spores or sporangia.
Scoter: Any one of several species of northern sea ducks of the genus Oidemia.
Subverter: One who, or that which, subverts; an overthrower.
Squirarch: One who belongs to the squirarchy.
Soft steel: Steel low in carbon; mild steel; ingot iron.
Successful: Resulting in success; assuring, or promotive of, success; accomplishing what was proposed; having the desired effect; hence, prosperous; fortunate; happy; as, a successful use of medicine; a successful experiment; a successful enterprise.
Soam: A chain by which a leading horse draws a plow.
Shadbird: The American, or Wilson's, snipe. See under Snipe. So called because it appears at the same time as the shad.
Senseless: Destitute of, deficient in, or contrary to, sense; without sensibility or feeling; unconscious; stupid; foolish; unwise; unreasonable.
Stibnite: A mineral of a lead-gray color and brilliant metallic luster, occurring in prismatic crystals; sulphide of antimony; -- called also antimony glance, and gray antimony.
Salutatorian: The student who pronounces the salutatory oration at the annual Commencement or like exercises of a college, -- an honor commonly assigned to that member of the graduating class who ranks second in scholarship.
&Verbar;Scyphobranchii: An order of fishes including the blennioid and gobioid fishes, and other related families.
Scarecrow: Anything set up to frighten crows or other birds from cornfields; hence, anything terifying without danger.
Soap: To rub or wash over with soap.
Spoutfish: A marine animal that spouts water; -- applied especially to certain bivalve mollusks, like the long clams (Mya), which spout, or squirt out, water when retiring into their holes.
Slasher: A machine for applying size to warp yarns.
Spicenut: A small crisp cake, highly spiced.
Struntian: A kind of worsted braid, about an inch broad.
Succision: The act of cutting down, as of trees; the act of cutting off.
Scabrous: Rough to the touch, like a file; having small raised dots, scales, or points; scabby; scurfy; scaly.
Slashed: Marked or cut with a slash or slashes; deeply gashed; especially, having long, narrow openings, as a sleeve or other part of a garment, to show rich lining or under vesture.
Supervisory: Of or pertaining to supervision; as, supervisory powers.
&Verbar;Sorema: A heap of carpels belonging to one flower.
Snotty: Foul with snot; hence, mean; dirty.
Semiquaver: A note of half the duration of the quaver; -- now usually called a sixteenth note.
Spancel: To tie or hobble with a spancel.
Supersedure: The act of superseding, or setting aside; supersession; as, the supersedure of trial by jury.
Strockle: A shovel with a turned-up edge, for frit, sand, etc.
Sensitivity: The quality or state of being sensitive; -- used chiefly in science and the arts; as, the sensitivity of iodized silver.
&Verbar;Sartorius: A muscle of the thigh, called the tailor's muscle, which arises from the hip bone and is inserted just below the knee. So named because its contraction was supposed to produce the position of the legs assumed by the tailor in sitting.
Sculpturesque: After the manner of sculpture; resembling, or relating to, sculpture.
Still-hunt: A hunting for game in a quiet and cautious manner, or under cover; stalking; hence, colloquially, the pursuit of any object quietly and cautiously.
Shecklaton: A kind of gilt leather. See Checklaton.
Scone: A cake, thinner than a bannock, made of wheat or barley or oat meal.
Synonymous: Having the character of a synonym; expressing the same thing; conveying the same, or approximately the same, idea.
Stone: To pelt, beat, or kill with stones.
Shirt-waist suit: A costume consisting of a plain belted blouse and skirt of the same material.
Scholium: A marginal annotation; an explanatory remark or comment; specifically, an explanatory comment on the text of a classic author by an early grammarian.
Saturant: A substance used to neutralize or saturate the affinity of another substance.
Saturnian: Any one of numerous species of large handsome moths belonging to Saturnia and allied genera. The luna moth, polyphemus, and promethea, are examples. They belong to the Silkworn family, and some are raised for their silk. See Polyphemus.
Satiety: The state of being satiated or glutted; fullness of gratification, either of the appetite or of any sensual desire; fullness beyond desire; an excess of gratification which excites wearisomeness or loathing; repletion; satiation.
Spongiopilin: A kind of cloth interwoven with small pieces of sponge and rendered waterproof on one side by a covering of rubber.  When moistened with hot water it is used as a poultice.
Schene: An Egyptian or Persian measure of length, varying from thirty-two to sixty stadia.
Smoothbore: Having a bore of perfectly smooth surface; -- distinguished from rifled.
&Verbar;Symploce: The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning and another at the end of successive clauses; as, Justice came down from heaven to view the earth; Justice returned to heaven, and left the earth.
Sabbaton: A round-toed, armed covering for the feet, worn during a part of the sixteenth century in both military and civil dress.
Surbased: Having a surbase, or molding above the base.
Slippage: The act of slipping; also, the amount of slipping.
Sea cocoa: A magnificent palm (Lodoicea Sechellarum) found only in the Seychelles Islands. The fruit is an immense two-lobed nut. It was found floating in the Indian Ocean before the tree was known, and called sea cocoanut, and double cocoanut.
Scapegallows: One who has narrowly escaped the gallows for his crimes.
Saunders-blue: A kind of color prepared from calcined lapis lazuli; ultramarine; also, a blue prepared from carbonate of copper.
Spodumene: A mineral of a white to yellowish, purplish, or emerald-green color, occurring in prismatic crystals, often of great size.  It is a silicate of alumina and lithia. See Hiddenite.
Sweetbread: Either the thymus gland or the pancreas, the former being called neck sweetbread or throat sweetbread, the latter belly sweetbread.  The sweetbreads of ruminants, esp. of the calf, are highly esteemed as food.  See Pancreas, and Thymus.
Sithe: To cut with a scythe; to scythe.
Sock away: to save (money); to put (something) into a reserve store.
Suspender: One who, or that which, suspends; esp., one of a pair of straps or braces worn over the shoulders, for holding up the trousers.
Staleness: The quality or state of being stale.
Sordidness: The quality or state of being sordid.
Sclerodermic: Having the integument, or skin, hard, or covered with hard plates.
Stibic: Antimonic; -- used with reference to certain compounds of antimony.
Serial: A publication appearing in a series or succession of part; a tale, or other writing, published in successive numbers of a periodical.
Snow-broth: Snow and water mixed, or snow just melted; very cold liquor.
Skilts: A kind of large, coarse, short trousers formerly worn.
Scutellate: Formed like a plate or salver; composed of platelike surfaces; as, the scutellated bone of a sturgeon.
Sea-gate: A long, rolling swell of the sea.
Sarum use: A liturgy, or use, put forth about 1087 by St. Osmund, bishop of Sarum, based on Anglo-Saxon and Norman customs.
Suf-: A form of the prefix Sub-.
Scirrhus: An indurated organ or part; especially, an indurated gland.
&Verbar;Schema: An outline or image universally applicable to a general conception, under which it is likely to be presented to the mind; as, five dots in a line are a schema of the number five; a preceding and succeeding event are a schema of cause and effect.
Scotticism: An idiom, or mode of expression, peculiar to Scotland or Scotchmen.
Steelhead: A North Pacific salmon (Salmo Gairdneri) found from Northern California to Siberia; -- called also hardhead, and preestl.
Shiftless: Destitute of expedients, or not using successful expedients; characterized by failure, especially by failure to provide for one's own support, through negligence or incapacity; hence, lazy; improvident; thriftless; as, a shiftless fellow; shiftless management.
Sebat: The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximately corresponding with February.
Sassy bark: The bark of a West African leguminous tree (Erythrophlæum Guineense, used by the natives as an ordeal poison, and also medicinally; -- called also mancona bark.
Spellbind: To bind or hold by, or as if by, a spell or charm; to entrance or fascinate, esp. by eloquence of speech, as in a political campaign.
Sectile: Capable of being cut; specifically (Min.), capable of being severed by the knife with a smooth cut; -- said of minerals.
Stellers sea cow: The rytina; -- called also stellerine and steller.  See rytina.
Scammony: A species of bindweed or Convolvulus (C. Scammonia).
&Verbar;Scutum: An oblong shield made of boards or wickerwork covered with leather, with sometimes an iron rim; -- carried chiefly by the heavy-armed infantry.
Subindividual: A division of that which is individual.
Sty: An inflamed swelling or boil on the edge of the eyelid.
Sulphatic: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or containing, a sulphate or sulphates.
Sachemdom: The government or jurisdiction of a sachem.
Suicidal: Partaking of, or of the nature of, the crime or suicide.
Sea green: The green color of sea water.
Supply: Serving to contain, deliver, or regulate a supply of anything; as, a supply tank or valve.
Sissoo: A leguminous tree (Dalbergia Sissoo) of the northern parts of India; also, the dark brown compact and durable timber obtained from it. It is used in shipbuilding and for gun carriages, railway ties, etc.
Slug: To become reduced in diameter, or changed in shape, by passing from a larger to a smaller part of the bore of the barrel; -- said of a bullet when fired from a gun, pistol, or other firearm.
Submergence: The act of submerging, or the state of being submerged; submersion.
Stockbroker: A broker who deals in stocks.
Strull: A bar so placed as to resist weight.
Short-circuit: To join, as the electrodes of a battery or dynamo or any two points of a circuit, by a conductor of low resistance.
Statuesque: Partaking of, or exemplifying, the characteristics of a statue; having the symmetry, or other excellence, of a statue artistically made; as, statuesquelimbs; a statuesque attitude.
Squawk: Act of squawking; a harsh squeak.
Somnipathy: Sleep from sympathy, or produced by mesmerism or the like.
Soporate: To lay or put to sleep; to stupefy.
Spoil: That which is taken from another by violence; especially, the plunder taken from an enemy; pillage; booty.
Self-consistent: Consistent with one's self or with itself; not deviation from the ordinary standard by which the conduct is guided; logically consistent throughout; having each part consistent with the rest.
Separatistic: Of or pertaining to separatists; characterizing separatists; schismatical.
Supernatant: Swimming above; floating on the surface; as, oil supernatant on water.
Sea legs: Legs able to maintain their possessor upright in stormy weather at sea, that is, ability to stand or walk steadily on deck when a vessel is rolling or pitching in a rough sea.
Superannuate: To last beyond the year; -- said of annual plants.
Septennial: Lasting or continuing seven years; as, septennial parliaments.
Subjunction: Act of subjoining, or state of being subjoined.
Stomatoplastic: Of or pertaining to the operation of forming a mouth where the aperture has been contracted, or in any way deformed.
Sniffing: A rapid inspiratory act, in which the mouth is kept shut and the air drawn in through the nose.
Sea crawfish: Any crustacean of the genus Palinurus and allied genera, as the European spiny lobster (P. vulgaris), which is much used as an article of food. See Lobster.
Scantness: The quality or condition of being scant; narrowness; smallness; insufficiency; scantiness.
Spiritually: In a spiritual manner; with purity of spirit; like a spirit.
Surpass: To go beyond in anything good or bad; to exceed; to excel.
Soldering: a. & n. from Solder, v. t.
Sporadic: Occurring singly, or apart from other things of the same kind, or in scattered instances; separate; single; as, a sporadic fireball; a sporadic case of disease; a sporadic example of a flower.
Speechify: To make a speech; to harangue.
Starmonger: A fortune teller; an astrologer; -- used in contempt.
Sarcoptid: Any species of the genus Sarcoptes and related genera of mites, comprising the itch mites and mange mites.
Synagogical: Of or pertaining to a synagogue.
Seismography: A writing about, or a description of, earthquakes.
Septicidal: Dividing the partitions; -- said of a method of dehiscence in which a pod splits through the partitions and is divided into its component carpels.
&Verbar;Serapis: An Egyptian deity, at first a symbol of the Nile, and so of fertility; later, one of the divinities of the lower world. His worship was introduced into Greece and Rome.
Spearhead: The pointed head, or end, of a spear.
Self-control: Control of one's self; restraint exercised over one's self; self-command.
Supracranial: Situated above, or in the roof of, the cranium.
Sadh: A member of a monotheistic sect of Hindoos. Sadhs resemble the Quakers in many respects.
Sublime: To pass off in vapor, with immediate condensation; specifically, to evaporate or volatilize from the solid state without apparent melting; -- said of those substances, like arsenic, benzoic acid, etc., which do not exhibit a liquid form on heating, except under increased pressure.
Shameless: Destitute of shame; wanting modesty; brazen-faced; insensible to disgrace.
Stoner: One who stones; one who makes an assault with stones.
Slugging match: A boxing match or prize fight marked rather by heavy hitting than skill.
Scrupulosity: The quality or state of being scrupulous; doubt; doubtfulness respecting decision or action; caution or tenderness from the fear of doing wrong or offending; nice regard to exactness and propriety; precision.
&Verbar;Sintoc: A kind of spice used in the East Indies, consisting of the bark of a species of Cinnamomum.
Simulation: The act of simulating, or assuming an appearance which is feigned, or not true; -- distinguished from dissimulation, which disguises or conceals what is true.
Simultaneous: Existing, happening, or done, at the same time; as, simultaneous events.
Spandrel: The irregular triangular space between the curve of an arch and the inclosing right angle; or the space between the outer moldings of two contiguous arches and a horizontal line above them, or another arch above and inclosing them.
Scavenger hunt: a game in which individuals or teams are given a list of items and must go out, gather them together without purchasing them, and bring them back; the first person or team to return with the complete list is the winner. The items are sometimes common but often of a humorous sort.
Sectoral: Of or pertaining to a sector; as, a sectoral circle.
Sightful: Easily or clearly seen; distinctly visible; perspicuous.
Shovelful: As much as a shovel will hold; enough to fill a shovel.
Smeltery: A house or place for smelting.
&Verbar;Sporangium: A spore case in the cryptogamous plants, as in ferns, etc.
