Scavenger: A person whose employment is to clean the streets of a city, by scraping or sweeping, and carrying off the filth. The name is also applied to any animal which devours refuse, carrion, or anything injurious to health.
Supralunar: Beyond the moon; hence, very lofty.
Suppositor: An apparatus for the introduction of suppositories into the rectum.
Suctorial: Adapted for sucking; living by sucking; as, the humming birds are suctorial birds.
Siscowet: A large, fat variety of the namaycush found in Lake Superior; -- called also siskawet, siskiwit.
Strictured: Affected with a stricture; as, a strictured duct.
Superdominant: The sixth tone of the scale; that next above the dominant; -- called also submediant.
Solitariety: The state of being solitary; solitariness.
Supervolute: Having a plainted and convolute arrangement in the bud, as in the morning-glory.
Shameful: Bringing shame or disgrace; injurious to reputation; disgraceful.
Stockman: A herdsman; a ranchman; one owning, or having charge of, herds of live stock.
Self-reproved: Reproved by one's own conscience or one's own sense of guilt.
Sabbatism: Intermission of labor, as upon the Sabbath; rest.
Self-conviction: The act of convicting one's self, or the state of being self-convicted.
Salvatory: A place where things are preserved; a repository.
Seismogram: The trace or record of an earth tremor, made by means of a seismograph.
Streamy: Abounding with streams, or with running water; streamful.
Sextillion: According to the method of numeration (which is followed also in the United States), the number expressed by a unit with twenty-one ciphers annexed. According to the English method, a million raised to the sixth power, or the number expressed by a unit with thirty-six ciphers annexed. See Numeration.
Sulphindigotic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic acid obtained, as a blue solution, by dissolving indigo in sulphuric acid; -- formerly called also cerulic sulphuric acid, but properly called indigo-disulphonic acid.
Sumless: Not to be summed up or computed; so great that the amount can not be ascertained; incalculable; inestimable.
Sustenance: The act of sustaining; support; maintenance; subsistence; as, the sustenance of the body; the sustenance of life.
Serigraph: An autographic device to test the strength of raw silk.
Sempiternal: Of neverending duration; everlasting; endless; having beginning, but no end.
Starost: A nobleman who possessed a starosty.
Shriner: a member of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.  See shrine{4}.
Sovereign: The person, body, or state in which independent and supreme authority is vested; especially, in a monarchy, a king, queen, or emperor.
Sulphamide: Any one of a series of amido compounds obtained by treating sulphuryl chloride with various amines.
Second-class: Of the rank or degree below the best or highest; inferior; second-rate; as, a second-class house; a second-class passage; a second-class citizen.
Sociality: The quality of being social; socialness.
Sublimification: The act of making sublime, or state of being made sublime.
Sporran: A large purse or pouch made of skin with the hair or fur on, worn in front of the kilt by Highlanders when in full dress.
Schistose: Of or pertaining to schist; having the structure of a schist.
Spuminess: The quality or condition of being spumy; spumescence.
Siegework: A temporary fort or parallel where siege guns are mounted.
Scandium: A rare metallic element of the boron group, whose existence was predicted under the provisional name ekaboron by means of the periodic law, and subsequently discovered by spectrum analysis in certain rare Scandinavian minerals (euxenite and gadolinite). It has not yet been isolated. Symbol Sc. Atomic weight 44.
Scheelite: Calcium tungstate, a mineral of a white or pale yellowish color and of the tetragonal system of crystallization.
Silverite: One who favors the use or establishment of silver as a monetary standard; -- so called by those who favor the gold standard.
Scriptorium: In an abbey or monastery, the room set apart for writing or copying manuscripts; in general, a room devoted to writing.
Safely: In a safe manner; danger, injury, loss, or evil consequences.
Sticker: One who, or that which, sticks; as, a bill sticker.
&Verbar;Siamang: A gibbon (Hylobates syndactylus), native of Sumatra. It has the second and third toes partially united by a web.
string theory: A mathematical theory for describing the properties of fundamental particles, which represents the particles as one-dimensional string-like objects, which exist in the normal four dimensions of space-time plus additional dimensions, the total dimensions being ten, eleven, or twenty-six depending on the version of the theory.  The properties of fundamental particles in string theory and their manner of interaction with each other depend upon the modes of vibration of the strings{17}.  The attractiveness of this theory rests in part on its ability to provide a unified treatment of gravity as well as the three other basic forces of nature, in a manner consistent with quantum mechanics.  The great difficulty of doing the calculations required by the theory, however, has thus far (1999) made it impossible to calculate the observable properties, such as the mass, of known particles, such as the electron, proton, mesons, quarks, and neutron; thus there is as yet no experimental verification for the theory.  The most popular version of the theory depends on a mathematical property called supersymmetry, and the theory derived form this principle is properly called superstring theory, a term which is often used interchangeably with string theory.  See also string{17}.
Semifloscule: A floscule, or florest, with its corolla prolonged into a strap-shaped petal; -- called also semifloret.
Snuff: The act of snuffing; perception by snuffing; a sniff.
Salt rheum: A popular name, esp. in the United States, for various cutaneous eruptions, particularly for those of eczema. See Eczema.
Subvene: To come under, as a support or stay; to happen.
Saxifrage: Any plant of the genus Saxifraga, mostly perennial herbs growing in crevices of rocks in mountainous regions.
Sicklebill: Any one of three species of humming birds of the genus Eutoxeres, native of Central and South America. They have a long and strongly curved bill. Called also the sickle-billed hummer.
Strokesman: The man who rows the aftermost oar, and whose stroke is to be followed by the rest.
Self-wrong: Wrong done by a person to himself.
Scitamineous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Scitamineæ), mostly tropical herbs, including the ginger, Indian shot, banana, and the plants producing turmeric and arrowroot.
Sphygmometer: An instrument for measuring the strength of the pulse beat; a sphygmograph.
-some: An adjective suffix having primarily the sense of like or same, and indicating a considerable degree of the thing or quality denoted in the first part of the compound; as in mettlesome, full of mettle or spirit; gladsome, full of gladness; winsome, blithesome, etc.
Scrapepenny: One who gathers and hoards money in trifling sums; a miser.
Shovelnose: The common sand shark. See under Snad.
Screech: A harsh, shrill cry, as of one in acute pain or in fright; a shriek; a scream.
Seriate: Arranged in a series or succession; pertaining to a series.
Supine: A verbal noun; or (according to C.F.Becker), a case of the infinitive mood ending in -um and -u, that in -um being sometimes called the former supine, and that in -u the latter supine.
Submentum: The basal part of the labium of insects. It bears the mentum.
Saker: A falcon (Falco sacer) native of Southern Europe and Asia, closely resembling the lanner.
Sandiness: The quality or state of being sandy, or of being of a sandy color.
Slothful: Addicted to sloth; inactive; sluggish; lazy; indolent; idle.
Spurn: A kick; a blow with the foot.
Sanctuary: A sacred place; a consecrated spot; a holy and inviolable site.
Saithe: The pollock, or coalfish; -- called also sillock.
Scratch: Made, done, or happening by chance; arranged with little or no preparation; determined by circumstances; haphazard; as, a scratch team; a scratch crew for a boat race; a scratch shot in billiards.
Singly: Individually; particularly; severally; as, to make men singly and personally good.
Scobiform: Having the form of, or resembling, sawdust or raspings.
Single: A unit; one; as, to score a single.
split shot: In croquet, etc., a shot or stroke in which one drives in different directions one's own and the opponent's ball placed in contact.
Sacerdotalism: The system, style, spirit, or character, of a priesthood, or sacerdotal order; devotion to the interests of the sacerdotal order.
Scooper: One who, or that which, scoops.
Sulphionide: A binary compound of sulphion, or one so regarded; thus, sulphuric acid, H2SO4, is a sulphionide.
Spectatorship: The office or quality of a spectator.
Styliform: Having the form of, or resembling, a style, pin, or pen; styloid.
Symposiac: A conference or conversation of philosophers at a banquet; hence, any similar gathering.
Searcloth: To cover, as a sore, with cerecloth.
Senseful: Full of sense, meaning, or reason; reasonable; judicious.
Stepping-stone: A stone to raise the feet above the surface of water or mud in walking.
Substantiality: The quality or state of being substantial; corporiety; materiality.
Samson: An Israelite of Bible record (see Judges xiii.), distinguished for his great strength; hence, a man of extraordinary physical strength.
&Verbar;Salamandroidea: A division of Amphibia including the Salamanders and allied groups; the Urodela.
&Verbar;Streptoneura: An extensive division of gastropod Mollusca in which the loop or visceral nerves is twisted, and the sexes separate. It is nearly to equivalent to Prosobranchiata.
switcheroo: a sudden and unexpected change or reversal of position, attitude, or action.
Subscriptive: Of or pertaining to a subscription, or signature.
Subtilism: The quality or state of being subtile; subtility; subtlety.
Searcher: One who, or that which, searches or examines; a seeker; an inquirer; an examiner; a trier.
&Verbar;Signorina: Miss; -- a title of address among the Italians.
Syncretism: Attempted union of principles or parties irreconcilably at variance with each other.
Stalky: Hard as a stalk; resembling a stalk.
Spawl: To scatter spittle from the mouth; to spit, as saliva.
Squealer: One who, or that which, squeals.
Solarize: To become injured by undue or too long exposure to the sun's rays in the camera; -- an older term now replaced by overexpose.
Southeastern: Of or pertaining to the southeast; southeasterly.
Searching: Exploring thoroughly; scrutinizing; penetrating; trying; as, a searching discourse; a searching eye.
Scrofulous: Pertaining to scrofula, or partaking of its nature; as, scrofulous tumors; a scrofulous habit of body.
Superroyal: Larger than royal; -- said of a particular size of printing and writing paper. See the Note under Paper, n.
Stellify: To turn into a star; to cause to appear like a star; to place among the stars, or in heaven.
Stealingly: By stealing, or as by stealing, furtively, or by an invisible motion.
Stomatology: Scientific study or knowledge of the mouth.
Sting ray: Any one of numerous rays of the family Dasyatidæ, syn. Trygonidæ, having one or more large sharp barbed dorsal spines, on the whiplike tail, capable of inflicting severe wounds. Some species reach a large size, and some, esp., on the American Pacific coast, are very destructive to oysters.
Sper: To shut in; to support; to inclose; to fasten.
Semibull: A bull issued by a pope in the period between his election and coronation.
Sleeper: Something lying in a reclining posture or position.
Somebody: A person unknown or uncertain; a person indeterminate; some person.
Sea-born: Born of the sea; produced by the sea.
Subkingdom: One of the several primary divisions of either the animal, or vegetable kingdom, as, in zoölogy, the Vertebrata, Tunicata, Mollusca, Articulata, Molluscoidea, Echinodermata, Cœlentera, and the Protozoa; in botany, the Phanerogamia, and the Cryptogamia.
Sacciform: Having the general form of a sac.
Stalworthhood: The quality or state of being stalworth; stalwartness; boldness; daring.
Saussurite: A tough, compact mineral, of a white, greenish, or grayish color. It is near zoisite in composition, and in part, at least, has been produced by the alteration of feldspar.
Stycerin: A triacid alcohol, related to glycerin, and obtained from certain styryl derivatives as a yellow, gummy, amorphous substance; -- called also phenyl glycerin.
Swather: A device attached to a mowing machine for raising the uncut fallen grain and marking the limit of the swath.
Suttee: A Hindoo widow who immolates herself, or is immolated, on the funeral pile of her husband; -- so called because this act of self-immolation is regarded as envincing excellence of wifely character.
Saturated: Filled to repletion; holding by absorption, or in solution, all that is possible; as, saturated garments; a saturated solution of salt.
&Verbar;Sivatherium: A genus of very large extinct ruminants found in the Tertiary formation of India. The snout was prolonged in the form of a proboscis. The male had four horns, the posterior pair being large and branched. It was allied to the antelopes, but very much larger than any exsisting species.
Syriac: Of or pertaining to Syria, or its language; as, the Syriac version of the Pentateuch.
Sidetrack: To transfer to a siding from a main line of track.
Syrian: Of or pertaining to Syria; Syriac.
Scissure: A longitudinal opening in a body, made by cutting; a cleft; a fissure.
Simulty: Private grudge or quarrel; as, domestic simulties.
Subumbonal: Beneath or forward of the umbos of a bivalve shell.
Swinesty: A sty, or pen, for swine.
Snot: To blow, wipe, or clear, as the nose.
Suffocate: To become choked, stifled, or smothered.
Snob: A vulgar person who affects to be better, richer, or more fashionable, than he really is; a vulgar upstart; one who apes his superiors.
Sovereignty: The quality or state of being sovereign, or of being a sovereign; the exercise of, or right to exercise, supreme power; dominion; sway; supremacy; independence; also, that which is sovereign; a sovereign state; as, Italy was formerly divided into many sovereignties.
Snod: Trimmed; smooth; neat; trim; sly; cunning; demure.
Sewing: The act or occupation of one who sews.
Shyness: The quality or state of being shy.
Subministrate: To supply; to afford; to subminister.
Superfamily: A group intermediate between a family and a suborder.
Stout: Strong; lusty; vigorous; robust; sinewy; muscular; hence, firm; resolute; dauntless.
Saddle: To put a saddle upon; to equip (a beast) for riding.
Stench: To cause to emit a disagreeable odor; to cause to stink.
Sacrovertebral: Of or pertaining to the sacrum and that part of the vertebral column immediately anterior to it; as, the sacrovertebral angle.
&Verbar;Spatangus: A genus of heart-shaped sea urchins belonging to the Spatangoidea.
Superioress: A woman who acts as chief in a convent, abbey, or nunnery; a lady superior.
Stop order: An order in a financial market that aims to limit losses by fixing a figure at which purchases shall be sold or sales bought in, as where stock is bought at 100 and the broker is directed to sell if the market price drops to 98.
Sculpture: To form with the chisel on, in, or from, wood, stone, or metal; to carve; to engrave.
Scenography: The art or act of representing a body on a perspective plane; also, a representation or description of a body, in all its dimensions, as it appears to the eye.
Spectrophotometry: The art of comparing, photometrically, the brightness of two spectra, wave length by wave length; the use of the spectrophotometer.
Sauba ant: A South American ant (Œcodoma cephalotes) remarkable for having two large kinds of workers besides the ordinary ones, and for the immense size of its formicaries. The sauba ant cuts off leaves of plants and carries them into its subterranean nests, and thus often does great damage by defoliating trees and cultivated plants.
Saccharine: A trade name for benzoic sulphinide.
Staple: Pertaining to, or being a market or staple for, commodities; as, a staple town.
&Verbar;Stater: The principal gold coin of ancient Greece.  It varied much in value, the stater best known at Athens being worth about £1 2s., or about $5.35 (in 1890 value).  The Attic silver tetradrachm was in later times called stater.
Saleswoman: A woman whose occupation is to sell goods or merchandise.
Stonewort: Any plant of the genus Chara; -- so called because they are often incrusted with carbonate of lime. See Chara.
Spiral: A plane curve, not reëntrant, described by a point, called the generatrix, moving along a straight line according to a mathematical law, while the line is revolving about a fixed point called the pole.  Cf. Helix.
Silundum: A form of silicon carbide, produced in the electric furnace, possessing great hardness, and high electrical resistance, and not subject to oxidation below 2880° F., or 1600° C.
Saxhorn: A name given to a numerous family of brass wind instruments with valves, invented by Antoine Joseph Adolphe Sax (known as Adolphe Sax), of Belgium and Paris, and much used in military bands and in orchestras.
Satyric: Of or pertaining to satyrs; burlesque; as, satyric tragedy.
Storybook: A book containing stories, or short narratives, either true or false.
Slush: To smear with slush or grease; as, to slush a mast.
Snape: To bevel the end of a timber to fit against an inclined surface.
Spikenard: An aromatic plant. In the United States it is the Aralia racemosa, often called spignet, and used as a medicine. The spikenard of the ancients is the Nardostachys Jatamansi, a native of the Himalayan region.  From its blackish roots a perfume for the hair is still prepared in India.
Suspense: The state of being suspended; specifically, a state of uncertainty and expectation, with anxiety or apprehension; indetermination; indecision; as, the suspense of a person waiting for the verdict of a jury.
Seck: Barren; unprofitable. See Rent seck, under Rent.
Spir\u00e6ic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the meadowsweet (Spiræa); formerly, designating an acid which is now called salicylic acid.
Sphalerite: Zinc sulphide; -- called also blende, black-jack, false galena, etc. See Blende (a).
Sublation: The act of taking or carrying away; removal.
&Verbar;Stapes: The innermost of the ossicles of the ear; the stirrup, or stirrup bone; -- so called from its form. See Illust. of Ear.
Sectarianize: To imbue with sectarian feelings; to subject to the control of a sect.
&Verbar;Salmis: A ragout of partly roasted game stewed with sauce, wine, bread, and condiments suited to provoke appetite.
slit-shell: Any species of Pleurotomaria, a genus of beautiful, pearly, spiral gastropod shells having a deep slit in the outer lip.  Many fossil species are known, and a few living ones are found in deep water in tropical seas.
Spinnerule: One of the numerous small spinning tubes on the spinnerets of spiders.
Stimulate: To excite as if with a goad; to excite, rouse, or animate, to action or more vigorous exertion by some pungent motive or by persuasion; as, to stimulate one by the hope of reward, or by the prospect of glory.
Sagacity: The quality of being sagacious; quickness or acuteness of sense perceptions; keenness of discernment or penetration with soundness of judgment; shrewdness.
Sexagenarian: A person who is sixty years old.
Spatula: An implement shaped like a knife, flat, thin, and somewhat flexible, used for spreading paints, fine plasters, drugs in compounding prescriptions, etc.  Cf. Palette knife, under Palette.
Signpost: A post on which a sign hangs, or on which papers are placed to give public notice of anything.
Snappish: Apt to snap at persons or things; eager to bite; as, a snapping cur.
Sounding: The act of one who, or that which, sounds (in any of the senses of the several verbs).
Spriggy: Full of sprigs or small branches.
Spoke: To furnish with spokes, as a wheel.
Spokeshave: A kind of drawing knife or planing tool for dressing the spokes of wheels, the shells of blocks, and other curved work.
Shredding: The act of cutting or tearing into shreds.
Sea whip: A gorgonian having a simple stem.
Slugabed: One who indulges in lying abed; a sluggard.
Scalary: Resembling a ladder; formed with steps.
Self-healing: Having the power or property of healing itself.
Samarium: A rare metallic element of doubtful identity.
Sphincter: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sphincter; as, a sphincter muscle.
Shearwater: Any one of numerous species of long-winged oceanic birds of the genus Puffinus and related genera. They are allied to the petrels, but are larger. The Manx shearwater (P. Anglorum), the dusky shearwater (P. obscurus), and the greater shearwater (P. major), are well-known species of the North Atlantic. See Hagdon.
&Verbar;Seah: A Jewish dry measure containing one third of an ephah.
Sizar: One of a body of students in the universities of Cambridge (Eng.) and Dublin, who, having passed a certain examination, are exempted from paying college fees and charges. A sizar corresponded to a servitor at Oxford.
Syngenesian: Having the stamens united by the anthers; of or pertaining to the Syngenesia.
Spoonful: The quantity which a spoon contains, or is able to contain; as, a teaspoonful; a tablespoonful.
Sternpost: A straight piece of timber, or an iron bar or beam, erected on the extremity of the keel to support the rudder, and receive the ends of the planks or plates of the vessel.
&Verbar;Shin Shu: The leading and most progressive Buddhist sect of Japan, resting its faith rather upon Amida than Gautama Buddha. Rites and ceremonies are held useless without uprightness.
Satirize: To make the object of satire; to attack with satire; to censure with keenness or severe sarcasm.
Spinneret: One of the special jointed organs situated on the under side, and near the end, of the abdomen of spiders, by means of which they spin their webs. Most spiders have three pairs of spinnerets, but some have only two pairs. The ordinary silk line of the spider is composed of numerous smaller lines jointed after issuing from the spinnerets.
Stowing: A method of working in which the waste is packed into the space formed by excavating the vein.
Supertonic: The note next above the keynote; the second of the scale.
Sinuation: A winding or bending in and out.
Slug-horn: An erroneous form of the Scotch word slughorne, or sloggorne, meaning slogan.
Stillbirth: The birth of a dead fetus.
Silicofluoric: Containing, or composed of, silicon and fluorine; especially, denoting the compounds called silicofluorides.
Satanophany: An incarnation of Satan; a being possessed by a demon.
Stratum: A bed of earth or rock of one kind, formed by natural causes, and consisting usually of a series of layers, which form a rock as it lies between beds of other kinds. Also used figuratively.
Shanny: The European smooth blenny (Blennius pholis). It is olive-green with irregular black spots, and without appendages on the head.
Sludger: A bucket for removing mud from a bored hole; a sand pump.
Seminality: The quality or state of being seminal.
Spekboom: The purslane tree of South Africa, -- said to be the favorite food of elephants.
Supererogation: The act of supererogating; performance of more than duty or necessity requires.
sprawl: The position or state resulting from sprawling; as, he sat on the couch in a sprawl; uncontrolled urban sprawl.
Sling: A drink composed of spirit (usually gin) and water sweetened.
Systemizer: One who systemizes, or reduces to system; a systematizer.
&Verbar;Scolex: The embryo produced directly from the egg in a metagenetic series, especially the larva of a tapeworm or other parasitic worm. See Illust. of Echinococcus.
Slink: The young of a beast brought forth prematurely, esp. a calf brought forth before its time.
Safe: To render safe; to make right.
Subsistent: Having real being; as, a subsistent spirit.
Saros: A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of which has been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or a little short of 10 years.
Scalloped: Furnished with a scallop; made or done with or in a scallop.
Shetland pony: One of a small, hardy breed of horses, with long mane and tail, which originated in the Shetland Islands; a sheltie.
Semitransept: The half of a transept; as, the north semitransept of a church.
Slippery: Having the quality opposite to adhesiveness; allowing or causing anything to slip or move smoothly, rapidly, and easily upon the surface; smooth; glib; as, oily substances render things slippery.
Star: To be bright, or attract attention, as a star; to shine like a star; to be brilliant or prominent; to play a part as a theatrical star.
Sleuth: The track of man or beast as followed by the scent.
Satinette: One of a breed of fancy frilled pigeons allied to the owls and turbits, having the body white, the shoulders tricolored, and the tail bluish black with a large white spot on each feather.
Spinifex: A genus of chiefly Australian grasses, the seeds of which bear an elastic spine. Spinifex hirsutus (black grass) and Spinifex longifolius are useful as sand binders. Spinifex paradoxusis a valuable perennial fodder plant. Also, a plant of this genus.
Spheromere: Any one of the several symmetrical segments arranged around the central axis and composing the body of a radiate anmal.
Sweven: A vision seen in sleep; a dream.
Sudoral: Of or pertaining to sweat; as, sudoral eruptions.
Sea squirt: An ascidian. See Illust. under Tunicata.
Schist: Any crystalline rock having a foliated structure (see Foliation) and hence admitting of ready division into slabs or slates. The common kinds are mica schist, and hornblendic schist, consisting chiefly of quartz with mica or hornblende and often feldspar.
&Verbar;Sacculus: A little sac; esp., a part of the membranous labyrinth of the ear.
Sightliness: The state of being sightly; comeliness; conspicuousness.
Shawm: A wind instrument of music, formerly in use, supposed to have resembled either the clarinet or the hautboy in form.
Strouding: Material for strouds; a kind of coarse cloth used in trade with the North American Indians.
Slavophil: One, not being a Slav, who is interested in the development and prosperity of that race.
Sevennight: A week; any period of seven consecutive days and nights. See Sennight.
Serum-therapy: The treatment of disease by the injection of blood serum from immune animals.
Saracen: Anciently, an Arab; later, a Mussulman; in the Middle Ages, the common term among Christians in Europe for a Mohammedan hostile to the crusaders.
Sinister: On the left hand, or the side of the left hand; left; -- opposed to dexter, or right.
Snowshed: A shelter to protect from snow, esp. a long roof over an exposed part of a railroad.
Survey: The act of surveying; a general view, as from above.
Spineback: A fish having spines in, or in front of, the dorsal fins.
Spotty: Full of spots; marked with spots.
Sleety: Of or pertaining to sleet; characterized by sleet; as, a sleety storm; sleety weather.
Seventeen: The number greater by one than sixteen; the sum of ten and seven; seventeen units or objects.
Stria: A minute groove, or channel; a threadlike line, as of color; a narrow structural band or line; a striation; as, the striæ, or groovings, produced on a rock by a glacier passing over it; the striæ on the surface of a shell; a stria of nervous matter in the brain.
Setigerous: Covered with bristles; having or bearing a seta or setæ; setiferous; as, setigerous glands; a setigerous segment of an annelid; specifically (Bot.), tipped with a bristle.
Showman: One who exhibits a show; a proprietor of a show.
Shadiness: Quality or state of being shady.
Sagebrush: A low irregular shrub (Artemisia tridentata), of the order Compositæ, covering vast tracts of the dry alkaline regions of the American plains; -- called also sagebush, and wild sage.
Stanzaic: Pertaining to, or consisting of, stanzas; as, a couplet in stanzaic form.
Stepson: A son of one's husband or wife by a former marriage.
Sepiment: Something that separates; a hedge; a fence.
Sagittate: Shaped like an arrowhead; triangular, with the two basal angles prolonged downward.
&Verbar;Se\u00f1or: A Spanish title of courtesy corresponding to the English Mr. or Sir; also, a gentleman.
Sinistrorse: Turning to the left (of the spectator) in the ascending line; -- the opposite of dextrorse. See Dextrorse.
Sprechery: Movables of an inferior description; especially, such as have been collected by depredation.
Stylobate: The uninterrupted and continuous flat band, coping, or pavement upon which the bases of a row of columns are supported. See Sub-base.
Soffit: The under side of the subordinate parts and members of buildings, such as staircases, entablatures, archways, cornices, or the like. See Illust. of Lintel.
Seawan: The name used by the Algonquin Indians for the shell beads which passed among the Indians as money.
Spleenful: Displaying, or affected with, spleen; angry; fretful; melancholy.
Sortie: The sudden issuing of a body of troops, usually small, from a besieged place to attack or harass the besiegers; a sally.
Summarize: To comprise in, or reduce to, a summary; to present briefly.
Syllabify: To form or divide into syllables.
Souterly: Of or pertaining to a cobbler or cobblers; like a cobbler; hence, vulgar; low.
&Verbar;Similiter: The technical name of the form by which either party, in pleading, accepts the issue tendered by his opponent; -- called sometimes a joinder in issue.
Synedral: Growing on the angles of a stem, as the leaves in some species of Selaginella.
Sejant: Sitting, as a lion or other beast.
Stiff-neckedness: The quality or state of being stiff-necked; stubbornness.
Slicking: The act or process of smoothing.
Stableboy: A boy or man who attends in a stable; a groom; a hostler.
&Verbar;Siesta: A short sleep taken about the middle of the day, or after dinner; a midday nap.
Senatusconsult: A decree of the Roman senate.
Seggar: A case or holder made of fire clay, in which fine pottery is inclosed while baking in the kin.
Second: To follow in the next place; to succeed; to alternate.
Sharpie: A long, sharp, flat-bottomed boat, with one or two masts carrying a triangular sail. They are often called Fair Haven sharpies, after the place on the coast of Connecticut where they originated.
Seedcake: A sweet cake or cooky containing aromatic seeds, as caraway.
Subvaginal: Situated under or inside a sheath or vaginal membrane; as, the subvaginal, or subdural, spaces about the optic nerve.
Saffrony: Having a color somewhat like saffron; yellowish.
Sursanure: A wound healed or healing outwardly only.
Socotrine: Of or pertaining to Socotra, an island in the Indian Ocean, on the east coast of Africa.
Somniloquism: The act or habit of talking in one's sleep; somniloquy.
Siliquiform: Having the form of a silique.
Scriptural: Contained in the Scriptures; according to the Scriptures, or sacred oracles; biblical; as, a scriptural doctrine.
Superimpose: To lay or impose on something else; as, a stratum of earth superimposed on another stratum.
Striation: The quality or condition of being striated.
Selvage: The edge of cloth which is woven in such a manner as to prevent raveling.
Somatocyst: A cavity in the primary nectocalyx of certain Siphonophora. See Illust. under Nectocalyx.
Sailcloth: Duck or canvas used in making sails.
Sarpo: A large toadfish of the Southern United States and the Gulf of Mexico (Batrachus tau, var. pardus).
Supernaturality: The quality or state of being supernatural.
Suberite: Any sponge of the genus Suberites and allied genera. These sponges have a fine and compact texture, and contain minute siliceous spicules.
Straw-colored: Being of a straw color. See Straw color, under Straw, n.
Suspensory: That which suspends, or holds up, as a truss
Spignet: An aromatic plant of America. See Spikenard.
Sailmaker: One whose occupation is to make or repair sails.
Sea serpent: Any marine snake. See Sea snake.
Slake: To go out; to become extinct.
Sewe: To perform the duties of a sewer. See 3d Sewer.
Secede: To withdraw from fellowship, communion, or association; to separate one's self by a solemn act; to draw off; to retire; especially, to withdraw from a political or religious body.
Smile: The act of smiling; a peculiar change or brightening of the face, which expresses pleasure, moderate joy, mirth, approbation, or kindness; -- opposed to frown.
&Verbar;Stringendo: Urging or hastening the time, as to a climax.
&Verbar;Scansores: An artifical group of birds formerly regarded as an order. They are distributed among several orders by modern ornithologists.
Scrutable: Discoverable by scrutiny, inquiry, or critical examination.
Steely: Made of steel; consisting of steel.
Sulphamic: Of or pertaining to a sulphamide; derived from, or related to, a sulphamide; specifically, designating an amido acid derivative, NH2.SO2.OH, of sulphuric acid (analogous to sulphonic acid) which is not known in the free state, but is known in its salts.
Sterquilinous: Pertaining to a dunghill; hence, mean; dirty; paltry.
Scissile: Capable of being cut smoothly; scissible.
Splitter: One who, or that which, splits.
Scye: Arm scye, a cutter's term for the armhole or part of the armhole of the waist of a garment.
Scotal: The keeping of an alehouse by an officer of a forest, and drawing people to spend their money for liquor, for fear of his displeasure.
Shipful: As much or as many as a ship will hold; enough to fill a ship.
Sectarian: One of a sect; a member or adherent of a special school, denomination, or religious or philosophical party; one of a party in religion which has separated itself from established church, or which holds tenets different from those of the prevailing denomination in a state.
Salination: The act of washing with salt water.
Semitranslucent: Slightly clear; transmitting light in a slight degree.
Structureless: Without a definite structure, or arrangement of parts; without organization; devoid of cells; homogeneous; as, a structureless membrane.
Skippingly: In a skipping manner; by skips, or light leaps.
Subdeposit: That which is deposited beneath something else.
Session: The act of sitting, or the state of being seated.
Stepdaughter: A daughter of one's wife or husband by a former marriage.
Stockholder: One who is a holder or proprietor of stock in the public funds, or in the funds of a bank or other stock company.
Standing: The act of stopping, or coming to a stand; the state of being erect upon the feet; stand.
Seaboat: A boat or vessel adapted to the open sea; hence, a vessel considered with reference to her power of resisting a storm, or maintaining herself in a heavy sea; as, a good sea boat.
&Verbar;Systasis: A political union, confederation, or league.
Spinner: One who, or that which, spins one skilled in spinning; a spinning machine.
Sea lawyer: The gray snapper. See under Snapper.
Sculptile: Formed by carving; graven; as, sculptile images.
Spiculiform: Having the shape of a spicule.
Stamen: A thread; especially, a warp thread.
Specialist: One who devotes himself to some specialty; as, a medical specialist, one who devotes himself to diseases of particular parts of the body, as the eye, the ear, the nerves, etc.
Subdural: Situated under the dura mater, or between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane.
Seraskierate: The office or authority of a seraskier.
Specialism: Devotion to a particular and restricted part or branch of knowledge, art, or science; as, medical specialism.
Summity: The height or top of anything.
Sulphocarbonic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphacid, H2CSO2 (called also thiocarbonic acid), or an acid, H2CS3, analogous to carbonic acid, obtained as a yellow oily liquid of a pungent odor, and forming salts.
Swan: Any one of numerous species of large aquatic birds belonging to Cygnus, Olor, and allied genera of the subfamily Cygninæ. They have a large and strong beak and a long neck, and are noted for their graceful movements when swimming. Most of the northern species are white. In literature the swan was fabled to sing a melodious song, especially at the time of its death.
Stoccado: A stab; a thrust with a rapier.
Sifter: One who, or that which, sifts.
&Verbar;Sopor: Profound sleep from which a person can be roused only with difficulty.
Scrophulariaceous: Of or pertaining to a very large natural order of gamopetalous plants (Scrophulariaceæ, or Scrophularineæ), usually having irregular didynamous flowers and a two-celled pod. The order includes the mullein, foxglove, snapdragon, figwort, painted cup, yellow rattle, and some exotic trees, as the Paulownia.
&Verbar;Sabretasche: A leather case or pocket worn by cavalry at the left side, suspended from the sword belt.
shrug off: To ignore; to disregard; to brush aside; to minimize{2} the effects of; as, to shrug off predictions of disaster.
Sphingid: Of or pertaining to a sphinx, or the family Sphingidæ.
Stepbrother: A brother by the marriage of one's father with the mother of another, or of one's mother with the father of another.
Semiparabola: One branch of a parabola, being terminated at the principal vertex of the curve.
Stahlism: The Stahlian theory, that every vital action is a function or operation of the soul.
Suspectful: Apt to suspect or mistrust; full of suspicion; suspicious; as, to be suspectful of the motives of others.
Scaler: One who, or that which, scales; specifically, a dentist's instrument for removing tartar from the teeth.
soul: By or for African-Americans, or characteristic of their culture; as, soul music; soul newspapers; soul food.
Scaled: Covered with scales, or scalelike structures; -- said of a fish, a reptile, a moth, etc.
Sperrylite: An arsenide of platinum occuring in grains and minute isometric crystals of tin-white color. It is found near Sudbury, Ontario Canada, and is the only known compound of platinum occuring in nature.
Starosty: A castle and domain conferred on a nobleman for life.
Skin-deep: Not deeper than the skin; hence, superficial.
&Verbar;Sarcoma: A tumor of fleshy consistence; -- formerly applied to many varieties of tumor, now restricted to a variety of malignant growth made up of cells resembling those of fetal development without any proper intercellular substance.
Sea beast: Any large marine mammal, as a seal, walrus, or cetacean.
Sanicle: Any plant of the umbelliferous genus Sanicula, reputed to have healing powers.
Soliloquize: To utter a soliloquy; to talk to one's self.
Subscriber: One who subscribes; one who contributes to an undertaking by subscribing.
Score: To keep the score in a game; to act as scorer.
Scorn: To scoff; to mock; to show contumely, derision, or reproach; to act disdainfully.
Starkly: In a stark manner; stiffly; strongly.
Sojourning: The act or state of one who sojourns.
Sawmill: A mill for sawing, especially one for sawing timber or lumber.
Sacramental: That which relates to a sacrament.
Skittle: Pertaining to the game of skittles.
Scotograph: An instrument for writing in the dark, or without seeing.
Sway: The act of swaying; a swaying motion; the swing or sweep of a weapon.
Scarify: To scratch or cut the skin of; esp. (Med.), to make small incisions in, by means of a lancet or scarificator, so as to draw blood from the smaller vessels without opening a large vein.
Sectility: The state or quality of being sectile.
Stilbene: A hydrocarbon, C14H12, produced artificially in large, fine crystals; -- called also diphenyl ethylene, toluylene, etc.
Sublimity: The quality or state of being sublime (in any sense of the adjective).
Sexton: An under officer of a church, whose business is to take care of the church building and the vessels, vestments, etc., belonging to the church, to attend on the officiating clergyman, and to perform other duties pertaining to the church, such as to dig graves, ring the bell, etc.
Strass: A brilliant glass, used in the manufacture of artificial paste gems, which consists essentially of a complex borosilicate of lead and potassium.  Cf. Glass.
Succession: The act of succeeding, or following after; a following of things in order of time or place, or a series of things so following; sequence; as, a succession of good crops; a succession of disasters.
Subcorneous: Situated under a horny part or layer.
Smokejack: A contrivance for turning a spit by means of a fly or wheel moved by the current of ascending air in a chimney.
Shoer: One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts on shoes; as, a shoer of horses.
Series: A number of things or events standing or succeeding in order, and connected by a like relation; sequence; order; course; a succession of things; as, a continuous series of calamitous events.
Sequestrable: Capable of being sequestered; subject or liable to sequestration.
Scoparin: A yellow gelatinous or crystalline substance found in broom (Cytisus scoparius) accompanying sparteïne.
Supersaliency: The act of leaping on anything.
Stage director: One who prepares a play for production. He arranges the details of the stage settings, the business to be used, all stage effects, and instructs the actors, excepting usually the star, in the general interpretation of their parts.
Sideling: Inclining to one side; directed toward one side; sloping; inclined; as, sideling ground.
Sideline: A line pertaining or attached to the side of a thing.
slipper orchid: any of several chiefly American wildflowers having an inflated pouchlike lip; difficult or impossible to cultivate in the garden.
Seminose: A carbohydrate of the glucose group found in the thickened endosperm of certain seeds, and extracted as yellow sirup having a sweetish-bitter taste.
Surrender: The act of surrendering; the act of yielding, or resigning one's person, or the possession of something, into the power of another; as, the surrender of a castle to an enemy; the surrender of a right.
Savin: A coniferous shrub (Juniperus Sabina) of Western Asia, occasionally found also in the northern parts of the United States and in British America. It is a compact bush, with dark-colored foliage, and produces small berries having a glaucous bloom. Its bitter, acrid tops are sometimes used in medicine for gout, amenorrhœa, etc.
Stipulaceous: Of or pertaining to stipules; resembling stipules; furnished with stipules; growing on stipules, or close to them; occupying the position of stipules; as, stipular glands and stipular tendrils.
Showroom: A room or apartment where a show is exhibited.
Sideromancy: Divination by burning straws on red-hot iron, and noting the manner of their burning.
Snary: Resembling, or consisting of, snares; entangling; insidious.
Surfoot: Tired or sore of foot from travel; lamed.
Superaltar: A raised shelf or stand on the back of an altar, on which different objects can be placed; a predella or gradino.
Soritical: Of or pertaining to a sorites; resembling a sorites.
Snarl: The act of snarling; a growl; a surly or peevish expression; an angry contention.
Snare: To catch with a snare; to insnare; to entangle; hence, to bring into unexpected evil, perplexity, or danger.
Subsecutive: Following in a train or succession.
Sensori-volitional: Concerned both in sensation and volition; -- applied to those nerve fibers which pass to and from the cerebro-spinal axis, and are respectively concerned in sensation and volition.
&Verbar;Stylaster: Any one of numerous species of delicate, usually pink, calcareous hydroid corals of the genus Stylaster.
Suprabranchial: Situated above the branchiæ; -- applied especially to the upper division of the gill cavity of bivalve mollusks.
Shy: A sudden start aside, as by a horse.
Sabellianism: The doctrines or tenets of Sabellius. See Sabellian, n.
She: This or that female; the woman understood or referred to; the animal of the female sex, or object personified as feminine, which was spoken of.
&Verbar;Stroma: The connective tissue or supporting framework of an organ; as, the stroma of the kidney.
Sulpician: One of an order of priests established in France in 1642 to educate men for the ministry. The order was introduced soon afterwards into Canada, and in 1791 into the United States.
Sibylist: One who believes in a sibyl or the sibylline prophecies.
Scream: A sharp, shrill cry, uttered suddenly, as in terror or in pain; a shriek; a screech.
Surrogation: The act of substituting one person in the place of another.
Spilth: Anything spilt, or freely poured out; slop; effusion.
Storer: One who lays up or forms a store.
Simple: To gather simples, or medicinal plants.
Seamanlike: Having or showing the skill of a practical seaman.
Snip: A single cut, as with shears or scissors; a clip.
Stored: Collected or accumulated as a reserve supply; as, stored electricity.
Smew: small European merganser (Mergus albellus) which has a white crest; -- called also smee, smee duck, white merganser, and white nun.
Sutured: Having a suture or sutures; knit or united together.
Supawn: Boiled Indian meal; hasty pudding; mush.
Shorten: To become short or shorter; as, the day shortens in northern latitudes from June to December; a metallic rod shortens by cold.
Surfman: One who serves in a surfboat in the life-saving service.
Sitz bath: A tub in which one bathes in a sitting posture; also, a bath so taken; a hip bath.
Steamship: A ship or seagoing vessel propelled by the power of steam; a steamer.
Springing: The act or process of one who, or that which, springs.
Strangles: A disease in horses and swine, in which the upper part of the throat, or groups of lymphatic glands elsewhere, swells.
Strangler: One who, or that which, strangles.
&Verbar;Siliquosa: A Linnæan order of plants including those which bear siliques.
Sprinkling: The act of one who, or that which, sprinkles.
Seven-thirties: A name given to three several issues of United States Treasury notes, made during the Civil War, in denominations of $50 and over, bearing interest at the rate of seven and three tenths (thirty hundredths) per cent annually. Within a few years they were all redeemed or funded.
Sinupalliate: Having a pallial sinus. See under Sinus.
Siamese: A native or inhabitant of Siam; pl., the people of Siam.
Sammier: A machine for pressing the water from skins in tanning.
&Verbar;Sortita: The air sung by any of the principal characters in an opera on entering.
Spermaceti: A white waxy substance obtained from cavities in the head of the sperm whale, and used making candles, oilments, cosmetics, etc. It consists essentially of ethereal salts of palmitic acid with ethal and other hydrocarbon bases.  The substance of spermaceti after the removal of certain impurities is sometimes called cetin.
Straddle: The act of standing, sitting, or walking, with the feet far apart.
Scavenge: To remove the burned gases from the cylinder after a working stroke; as, this engine does not scavenge well.
Shoddy: Made wholly or in part of shoddy; containing shoddy; as, shoddy cloth; shoddy blankets; hence, colloquially, not genuine; sham; pretentious; as, shoddy aristocracy.
Spark gap: The space filled with air or other dielectric between high potential terminals (as of an electrostatic machine, induction coil, or condenser), through which the discharge passes; the air gap of a jump spark.
Sulphophosphoric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid of phosphorus, analogous to phosphoric acid, and known in its salts.
Slip-on: A kind of overcoat worn upon the shoulders in the manner of a cloak.
Shovelhead: A shark (Sphryna tiburio) allied to the hammerhead, and native of the warmer parts of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- called also bonnet shark.
Secularity: Supreme attention to the things of the present life; worldliness.
Sunless: Destitute or deprived of the sun or its rays; shaded; shadowed.
Sheepback: A rounded knoll of rock resembling the back of a sheep. -- produced by glacial action. Called also roche moutonnée; -- usually in the plural.
Silique: An oblong or elongated seed vessel, consisting of two valves with a dissepiment between, and opening by sutures at either margin. The seeds are attached to both edges of the dissepiment, alternately upon each side of it.
&Verbar;Stabat Mater: A celebrated Latin hymn, beginning with these words, commemorating the sorrows of the mother of our Lord at the foot of the cross. It is read in the Mass of the Sorrows of the Virgin Mary, and is sung by Catholics when making “the way of the cross” (Via Crucis). See Station, 7 (c).
Slotting: The act or process of making slots, or mortises.
&Verbar;Senhora: A Portuguese title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also, a lady.
Stet: To cause or direct to remain after having been marked for omission; to mark with the word stet, or with a series of dots below or beside the matter; as, the proof reader stetted a deled footnote.
Steamy: Consisting of, or resembling, steam; vaporous; misty.
Sancho: The nine of trumps in sancho pedro.
Stook: To set up, as sheaves of grain, in stooks.
Spadefish: An American market fish (Chætodipterus faber) common on the southern coasts; -- called also angel fish, moonfish, and porgy.
Stylist: One who is a master or a model of style, especially in writing or speaking; a critic of style.
Sultriness: The quality or state of being sultry.
Spirtle: To spirt in a scattering manner.
Stylish: Having style or artistic quality; given to, or fond of, the display of style; highly fashionable; modish; as, a stylish dress, house, manner.
Sternocostal: Of or pertaining to the sternum and the ribs; as, the sternocostal cartilages.
Spissitude: The quality or state of being spissated; as, the spissitude of coagulated blood, or of any coagulum.
Self-regulative: Tending or serving to regulate one's self or itself.
Slow-witted: Dull of apprehension; not possessing quick intelligence.
Sea girdles: A kind of kelp (Laminaria digitata) with palmately cleft fronds; -- called also sea wand, seaware, and tangle.
Sulphinic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of a series of acids regarded as acid ethereal salts of hyposulphurous acid; as, methyl sulphinic acid, CH3.SO.OH, a thick unstable liquid.
Shield-bearer: One who, or that which, carries a shield.
Squarroso-dentate: Having the teeth bent out of the plane of the lamina; -- said of a leaf.
Sinapism: A plaster or poultice composed principally of powdered mustard seed, or containing the volatile oil of mustard seed. It is a powerful irritant.
Swingletree: A whiffletree, or whippletree. See Singletree.
Sluicy: Falling copiously or in streams, as from a sluice.
Subpedunculate: Supported on, or growing from, a very short stem; having a short peduncle.
Sainthood: The state of being a saint; the condition of a saint.
Shag-rag: The unkempt and ragged part of the community.
Sphere: To place in a sphere, or among the spheres; to insphere.
Spiritualism: The quality or state of being spiritual.
Spathaceous: Having a spathe; resembling a spathe; spathal.
Sleeve: To furnish with sleeves; to put sleeves into; as, to sleeve a coat.
Stilton cheese: A peculiarly flavored unpressed cheese made from milk with cream added; -- so called from the village or parish of Stilton, England, where it was originally made. It is very rich in fat.
&Verbar;Sputum: That which is expectorated; a salival discharge; spittle; saliva.
Spirited: Animated or possessed by a spirit.
Strawberry: A fragrant edible berry, of a delicious taste and commonly of a red color, the fruit of a plant of the genus Fragaria, of which there are many varieties. Also, the plant bearing the fruit. The common American strawberry is Fragaria virginiana; the European, F. vesca. There are also other less common species.
Spiritual-minded: Having the mind set on spiritual things, or filled with holy desires and affections.
Stealthiness: The state, quality, or character of being stealthy; stealth.
Sulphide: A binary compound of sulphur, or one so regarded; -- formerly called sulphuret.
Substitutional: Of or pertaining to substitution; standing in the place of another; substituted.
Spurry: An annual herb (Spergula arvensis) with whorled filiform leaves, sometimes grown in Europe for fodder.
Sawhorse: A kind of rack, shaped like a double St. Andrew's cross, on which sticks of wood are laid for sawing by hand; -- called also buck, and sawbuck.
Stylagalmaic: Performing the office of columns; as, Atlantes and Caryatides are stylagalmaic figures or images.
Soda water: originally, a beverage consisting of a weak solution of sodium bicarbonate to which an acid (such as phosphoric acid) has been added to generate carbon dioxide and thus cause effervescence; the term now is also used as a synonym for soda pop.  Soda water without flavoring is used as a beverage or as a component of a mixed beverage.  It is typically bottled or canned under pressure so that the carbon dioxide and effervescence will be preserved until use.
Sowens: A nutritious article of food, much used in Scotland, made from the husk of the oat by a process not unlike that by which common starch is made; -- called flummery in England.
&Verbar;Subulicornes: A division of insects having slender or subulate antennæ. The dragon flies and May flies are examples.
Subduplicate: Expressed by the square root; -- said of ratios.
Sirupy: Like sirup, or partaking of its qualities.
Succussive: Characterized by a shaking motion, especially an up and down movement, and not merely tremulous oscillation; as, the succussive motion in earthquakes.
Shrinkage: The act of shrinking; a contraction into less bulk or measurement.
Sagittary: Pertaining to, or resembling, an arrow.
Specialization: The act of specializing, or the state of being spezialized.
Sensualist: One who is sensual; one given to the indulgence of the appetites or senses as the means of happiness.
Suable: Capable of being sued; subject by law to be called to answer in court.
&Verbar;Simia: A Linnæan genus of Quadrumana which included the types of numerous modern genera. By modern writers it is usually restricted to the genus which includes the orang-outang.
Strobilation: The act or phenomenon of spontaneously dividing transversely, as do certain species of annelids and helminths; transverse fission. See Illust. under Syllidian.
Sucking: Drawing milk from the mother or dam; hence, colloquially, young, inexperienced, as, a sucking infant; a sucking calf.
Stylistic: Of or pertaining to style in language.
Secondarily: In a secondary manner or degree.
Seizor: One who seizes, or takes possession.
Studio: The working room of an artist.
Sertularian: Any species of Sertularia, or of Sertularidæ, a family of hydroids having branched chitinous stems and simple sessile hydrothecæ. Also used adjectively.
Sensualism: The condition or character of one who is sensual; subjection to sensual feelings and appetite; sensuality.
Scrofula: A constitutional disease, generally hereditary, especially manifested by chronic enlargement and cheesy degeneration of the lymphatic glands, particularly those of the neck, and marked by a tendency to the development of chronic intractable inflammations of the skin, mucous membrane, bones, joints, and other parts, and by a diminution in the power of resistance to disease or injury and the capacity for recovery. Scrofula is now generally held to be tuberculous in character, and may develop into general or local tuberculosis (consumption).
Sea grape: The gulf weed. See under Gulf.
&Verbar;Solano: A hot, oppressive wind which sometimes blows in the Mediterranean, particularly on the eastern coast of Spain.
&Verbar;Sempervivum: A genus of fleshy-leaved plants, of which the houseleek (Sempervivum tectorum) is the commonest species.
Salagane: The esculent swallow. See under Esculent.
Seminate: To sow; to spread; to propagate.
Slander: To defame; to injure by maliciously uttering a false report; to tarnish or impair the reputation of by false tales maliciously told or propagated; to calumniate.
Satiny: Like or composed of satin; glossy; as, to have a satiny appearance; a satiny texture.
Shide: A thin board; a billet of wood; a splinter.
Stickleback: Any one of numerous species of small fishes of the genus Gasterosteus and allied genera. The back is armed with two or more sharp spines. They inhabit both salt and brackish water, and construct curious nests. Called also sticklebag, sharpling, and prickleback.
&Verbar;Stragulum: The mantle, or pallium, of a bird.
Stepmother: The wife of one's father by a subsequent marriage.
Semicolon: The punctuation mark [;] indicating a separation between parts or members of a sentence more distinct than that marked by a comma.
Striking: Affecting with strong emotions; surprising; forcible; impressive; very noticeable; as, a striking representation or image; a striking resemblance.
Semiform: A half form; an imperfect form.
Solanaceous: Of or pertaining to plants of the natural order Solanaceæ, of which the nightshade (Solanum) is the type. The order includes also the tobacco, ground cherry, tomato, eggplant, red pepper, and many more.
Socager: A tennant by socage; a socman.
&Verbar;Sphrigosis: A condition of vegetation in which there is too abundant growth of the stem and leaves, accompanied by deficiency of flowers and fruit.
Sea heath: A low perennial plant (Frankenia lævis) resembling heath, growing along the seashore in Europe.
Storage: The act of depositing in a store or warehouse for safe keeping; also, the safe keeping of goods in a warehouse.
Screwer: One who, or that which, screws.
Swinge: The sweep of anything in motion; a swinging blow; a swing.
Stentorian: Of or pertaining to a stentor; extremely loud; powerful; as, a stentorian voice; stentorian lungs.
Supradecompound: More than decompound; divided many times.
Supernaturalize: To treat or regard as supernatural.
Socinianism: The tenets or doctrines of Faustus Socinus, an Italian theologian of the sixteenth century, who denied the Trinity, the deity of Christ, the personality of the Devil, the native and total depravity of man, the vicarious atonement, and the eternity of future punishment. His theory was, that Christ was a man divinely commissioned, who had no existence before he was conceived by the Virgin Mary; that human sin was the imitation of Adam's sin, and that human salvation was the imitation and adoption of Christ's virtue; that the Bible was to be interpreted by human reason; and that its language was metaphorical, and not to be taken literally.
Strobiline: Of or pertaining to a strobile; strobilaceous; strobiliform; as, strobiline fruits.
Stagely: Pertaining to a stage; becoming the theater; theatrical.
Submersed: Being or growing under water, as the leaves of aquatic plants.
Spicular: Resembling a dart; having sharp points.
Swimbel: A moaning or sighing sound or noise; a sough.
Subarytenoid: Situated under the arytenoid cartilage of the larynx.
Stage manager: One in control of the stage during the production of a play. He directs the stage hands, property man, etc., has charge of all details behind the curtain, except the acting, and has a general oversight of the actors. Sometimes he is also the stage director.
Salal-berry: The edible fruit of the Gaultheria Shallon, an ericaceous shrub found from California northwards. The berries are about the size of a common grape and of a dark purple color.
Silkiness: The quality or state of being silky or silken; softness and smoothness.
Soothsay: A true saying; a proverb; a prophecy.
Schoolgirl: A girl belonging to, or attending, a school.
Signalize: To make signal or eminent; to render distinguished from what is common; to distinguish.
Slackness: The quality or state of being slack.
spanworm: The larva of any geometrid moth, as the cankerworm; a geometer; a measuring worm.
Silva: The forest trees of a region or country, considered collectively.
Sparpoil: To scatter; to spread; to disperse.
Scaffold: To furnish or uphold with a scaffold.
Speed counter: A device for automatically counting the revolutions or pulsations of an engine or other machine; -- called also simply counter.
Spontaneity: The quality or state of being spontaneous, or acting from native feeling, proneness, or temperament, without constraint or external force.
Shepherdia: A genus of shrubs having silvery scurfy leaves, and belonging to the same family as Elæagnus; also, any plant of this genus. See Buffalo berry, under Buffalo.
Sematology: The doctrine of signs as the expression of thought or reasoning; the science of indicating thought by signs.
Surd: A quantity which can not be expressed by rational numbers; thus, √2 is a surd.
Sure: In a sure manner; safely; certainly.
Sinew-shrunk: Having the sinews under the belly shrunk by excessive fatigue.
Steadfast: Firmly fixed or established; fast fixed; firm.
Sweetness: The quality or state of being sweet (in any sense of the adjective); gratefulness to the taste or to the smell; agreeableness.
Spate: A river flood; an overflow or inundation.
Stereo-chemistry: Chemistry considered with reference to the space relations of atoms.
Swallowfish: The European sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). It has large pectoral fins.
Seismometry: The mensuration of such phenomena of earthquakes as can be expressed in numbers, or by their relation to the coördinates of space.
Subtract: To withdraw, or take away, as a part from the whole; to deduct; as, subtract 5 from 9, and the remainder is 4.
Smothered mate: Checkmate given when movement of the king is completely obstructed by his own men.  This can only occur when an opponent moves a knight into a position to give a check to the king.
Sublative: Having power, or tending, to take away.
&Verbar;Sclerosis: Induration; hardening; especially, that form of induration produced in an organ by increase of its interstitial connective tissue.
Slabber: A saw for cutting slabs from logs.
Sea pie: A dish of crust or pastry and meat or fish, etc., cooked together in alternate layers, -- a common food of sailors; as, a three-decker sea pie.
Symbolism: The act of symbolizing, or the state of being symbolized; as, symbolism in Christian art is the representation of truth, virtues, vices, etc., by emblematic colors, signs, and forms.
Sea urchin: Any one of numerous species of echinoderms of the order Echinoidea.
Scotch: A slight cut or incision; a score.
Star chamber: An ancient high court exercising jurisdiction in certain cases, mainly criminal, which sat without the intervention of a jury.  It consisted of the king's council, or of the privy council only with the addition of certain judges.  It could proceed on mere rumor or examine witnesses; it could apply torture.  It was abolished by the Long Parliament in 1641.
Speculatist: One who speculates, or forms theories; a speculator; a theorist.
Subdeacon: One belonging to an order in the Roman Catholic Church, next interior to the order of deacons; also, a member of a minor order in the Greek Church.
Sur-: A prefix signifying over, above, beyond, upon.
Somehow: In one way or another; in some way not yet known or designated; by some means; as, the thing must be done somehow; he lives somehow.
Spindleshanks: A person with slender shanks, or legs; -- used humorously or in contempt.
Snugly: In a snug manner; closely; safely.
Stigonomancy: Divination by writing on the bark of a tree.
Sledding: The act of transporting or riding on a sled.
Siphonifer: Any cephalopod having a siphonate shell.
&Verbar;Salpinx: The Eustachian tube, or the Fallopian tube.
Soko: An African anthropoid ape, supposed to be a variety of the chimpanzee.
Syllabus: A compendium containing the heads of a discourse, and the like; an abstract.
Symposium: A drinking together; a merry feast.
Set-off: That which is set off against another thing; an offset.
Snotter: A rope going over a yardarm, used to bend a tripping line to, in sending down topgallant and royal yards in vessels of war; also, the short line supporting the heel of the sprit in a small boat.
Survivor: One who survives or outlives another person, or any time, event, or thing.
Striction: The act of constricting, or the state of being constricted.
Sifflement: The act of whistling or hissing; a whistling sound; sibilation.
s: A contraction for is or (colloquially) for has.
Salicin: A glucoside found in the bark and leaves of several species of willow (Salix) and poplar, and extracted as a bitter white crystalline substance.
&Verbar;Sauce: A soft crayon for use in stump drawing or in shading with the stump.
Sclerotic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from ergot or the sclerotium of a fungus growing on rye.
Syphiloderm: A cutaneous affection due to syphilis.
Stockade: To surround, fortify, or protect with a stockade.
Steeling: The process of pointing, edging, or overlaying with steel; specifically, acierage. See Steel, v.
Statecraft: The art of conducting state affairs; state management; statesmanship.
Stagy: Having an air or manner characteristic of the stage; theatrical; artificial; as, a stagy tone or bearing; -- chiefly used depreciatively.
Socome: A custom of tenants to grind corn at the lord's mill.
Sarplar: A large bale or package of wool, containing eighty tods, or 2,240 pounds, in weight.
Sheepcot: A small inclosure for sheep; a pen; a fold.
Swine-pox: A variety of the chicken pox, with acuminated vesicles containing a watery fluid; the water pox.
&Verbar;Savant: A man of learning; one versed in literature or science; a person eminent for acquirements.
Slickness: The state or quality of being slick; smoothness; sleekness.
Sacchulmic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained as a dark amorphous substance by the long-continued boiling of sucrose with very dilute sulphuric acid. It resembles humic acid.
Signatory: A signer; one who signs or subscribes; as, a conference of signatories.
Serous: Thin; watery; like serum; as, the serous fluids.
Specifiable: Admitting specification; capable of being specified.
Scope: That at which one aims; the thing or end to which the mind directs its view; that which is purposed to be reached or accomplished; hence, ultimate design, aim, or purpose; intention; drift; object.
Serpentinize: To convert (a magnesian silicate) into serpentine.
Subdichotomy: A subordinate, or inferior, division into parts; a subdivision.
Silicification: Thae act or process of combining or impregnating with silicon or silica; the state of being so combined or impregnated; as, the silicification of wood.
Sandwich: To make into a sandwich; also, figuratively, to insert between portions of something dissimilar; to form of alternate parts or things, or alternating layers of a different nature; to interlard.
Synosteology: That part of anatomy which treats of joints; arthrology.
Shook: To pack, as staves, in a shook.
Somniloquence: The act of talking in one's sleep; somniloquism.
&Verbar;Septum: A wall separating two cavities; a partition; as, the nasal septum.
Subcaliber: Smaller than the caliber of a firearm.
Sportful: Full of sport; merry; frolicsome; full of jesting; indulging in mirth or play; playful; wanton; as, a sportful companion.
Swimmingly: In an easy, gliding manner, as if swimming; smoothly; successfully; prosperously.
Suffruticose: Woody in the lower part of the stem, but with the yearly branches herbaceous, as sage, thyme, hyssop, and the like.
Searedness: The state of being seared or callous; insensibility.
Swingletail: The thrasher, or fox shark. See Thrasher.
Seirospore: One of several spores arranged in a chain as in certain algæ of the genus Callithamnion.
Schemer: One who forms schemes; a projector; esp., a plotter; an intriguer.
Semiproof: Half proof; evidence from the testimony of a single witness.
Sickle: A reaping instrument consisting of a steel blade curved into the form of a hook, and having a handle fitted on a tang. The sickle has one side of the blade notched, so as always to sharpen with a serrated edge.  Cf. Reaping hook, under Reap.
Synergist: One who holds the doctrine of synergism.
Satisfaction: The act of satisfying, or the state of being satisfied; gratification of desire; contentment in possession and enjoyment; repose of mind resulting from compliance with its desires or demands.
&Verbar;Siluroidei: An order of fishes, the Nematognathi.
Silky: Of or pertaining to silk; made of, or resembling, silk; silken; silklike; as, a silky luster.
Synallagmatic: Imposing reciprocal obligations upon the parties; as, a synallagmatic contract.
Savoy: A variety of the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea major), having curled leaves, -- much cultivated for winter use.
Sardius: A precious stone, probably a carnelian, one of which was set in Aaron's breastplate.
Savor: To perceive by the smell or the taste; hence, to perceive; to note.
Sisterly: Like a sister; becoming a sister, affectionate; as, sisterly kindness; sisterly remorse.
Stiltify: To raise upon stilts, or as upon stilts; to stilt.
&Verbar;Sarracenia: A genus of American perennial herbs growing in bogs; the American pitcher plant.
Soften: To become soft or softened, or less rude, harsh, severe, or obdurate.
Solvable: Susceptible of being solved, resolved, or explained; admitting of solution.
Solar parallax: The parallax of the sun, that is, the angle subtended at the sun by the semidiameter of the earth. It is 8.”80, and is the fundamental datum.
Sphene: A mineral found usually in thin, wedge-shaped crystals of a yellow or green to black color. It is a silicate of titanium and calcium; titanite.
Sogginess: The quality or state of being soggy; soddenness; wetness.
Semolina: The purified fine, hard parts of durum wheat, derived mostly from the endosperm, rounded by the attrition of the millstones, -- used in cookery, such as in the preparation of Italian pasta.
Soda bread: a bread made with buttermilk and leavened with baking soda.
&Verbar;Samurai: In the former feudal system of Japan, the class or a member of the class, of military retainers of the daimios, constituting the gentry or lesser nobility. They possessed power of life and death over the commoners, and wore two swords as their distinguishing mark. Their special rights and privileges were abolished with the fall of feudalism in 1871.  They were referred to as “a cross between a knight and a gentleman”.
Somatopleuric: Of or pertaining to the somatopleure.
Settle: To become fixed or permanent; to become stationary; to establish one's self or itself; to assume a lasting form, condition, direction, or the like, in place of a temporary or changing state.
Slowness: The quality or state of being slow.
Solo whist: A card game played with the full pack ranking as at whist, each player declaring for which of seven different points he proposes to play.
Solomons seal: A mystic symbol consisting of two interlaced triangles forming a star with six points, often with one triangle dark and one light, symbolic of the union of soul and body.  It is shaped identically to the hexagram and Star of David, distinguished only in its usage.
Stationary: One who, or that which, is stationary, as a planet when apparently it has neither progressive nor retrograde motion.
Solidification: Act of solidifying, or state of being solidified.
Sparsely: In a scattered or sparse manner.
Self-government: The act of governing one's self, or the state of being governed by one's self; self-control; self-command.
Samian: A native or inhabitant of Samos.
Suspired: Ardently desired or longed for; earnestly coveted.
Substruct: To build beneath something; to lay as the foundation.
Semicalcareous: Half or partially calcareous; as, a semicalcareous plant.
&Verbar;Solen: A cradle, as for a broken limb. See Cradle, 6.
Subtrahend: The sum or number to be subtracted, or taken from another (the minuend) to find the difference.
Swipe: To give a swipe to; to strike forcibly with a sweeping motion, as a ball.
Sodden: To soak; to make heavy with water.
Sermonic: Like, or appropriate to, a sermon; grave and didactic.
Sinaic: Of or pertaining to Mount Sinai; given or made at Mount Sinai; as, the Sinaitic law.
Suffering: Being in pain or grief; having loss, injury, distress, etc.
Splice: A junction or joining made by splicing.
Stopper: To close or secure with a stopper.
Struthious: Of or pertaining to the Struthiones, or Ostrich tribe.
&Verbar;Spatangoidea: An order of irregular sea urchins, usually having a more or less heart-shaped shell with four or five petal-like ambulacra above. The mouth is edentulous and situated anteriorly, on the under side.
Sepal: A leaf or division of the calyx.
Stopped: Made by complete closure of the mouth organs; shut; -- said of certain consonants (p, b, t, d, etc.).
&Verbar;Solfeggiare: To sol-fa. See Sol-fa, v. i.
Senescent: Growing old; decaying with the lapse of time.
Spinosity: The quality or state of being spiny or thorny; spininess.
Songful: Disposed to sing; full of song.
Self-diffusive: Having power to diffuse itself; diffusing itself.
Society: The relationship of men to one another when associated in any way; companionship; fellowship; company.
Self-annihilation: Annihilation by one's own acts; annihilation of one's desires.
Sixpence: An English silver coin of the value of six pennies; half a shilling, or about twelve cents.
Sulphotungstic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, hypothetical sulphacid of tungsten (called also sulphowolframic acid), analogous to sulphuric acid, and known in its salts.
Superfecundation: Fertilization of two ova, at the same menstruation, by two different acts of coition.
Sagenitic: Resembling sagenite; -- applied to quartz when containing acicular crystals of other minerals, most commonly rutile, also tourmaline, actinolite, and the like.
Shipping note: A document used in shipping goods by sea. In the case of free goods the shipping notes are the receiving note, addressed by the shipper to the chief officer of the vessel, requesting him to receive on board specified goods, and a receipt for the mate to sign, on receiving whose signature it is called the mate's receipt, and is surrendered by the shipper for the bills of lading.
Stanza: A number of lines or verses forming a division of a song or poem, and agreeing in meter, rhyme, number of lines, etc., with other divisions; a part of a poem, ordinarily containing every variation of measure in that poem; a combination or arrangement of lines usually recurring, whether like or unlike, in measure.
Sodalite: A mineral of a white to blue or gray color, occuring commonly in dodecahedrons, also massive.  It is a silicate of alumina and soda with some chlorine.
Sodality: A fellowship or fraternity; a brotherhood.
Stichometrical: Of or pertaining to stichometry; characterized by stichs, or lines.
Swastika: A symbol or ornament in the form of a Greek cross with the ends of the arms at right angles all in the same direction, and each prolonged to the height of the parallel arm of the cross. A great many modified forms exist, ogee and volute as well as rectilinear, while various decorative designs, as Greek fret or meander, are derived from or closely associated with it. The swastika is found in remains from the Bronze Age in various parts of Europe, esp. at Hissarlik (Troy), and was in frequent use as late as the 10th century. It is found in ancient Persia, in India, where both Jains and  Buddhists used (or still use) it as religious symbol, in China and Japan, and among Indian tribes of North, Central, and South America. It is usually thought to be a charm, talisman, or religious token, esp. a sign of good luck or benediction. Max MüLler distinguished from the swastika, with arms prolonged to the right, the suavastika, with arms prolonged to the left, but this distinction is not commonly recognized. Other names for the swastika are fylfot and gammadion.
Strewment: Anything scattered, as flowers for decoration.
Suprapedal: Situated above the foot of a mollusk; as, the suprapedal gland.
Sephardic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Jews (the Sephardim, also called Spanish or Portuguese Jews) descended from Jewish families driven from Spain by the Inquisition.
Syphilis: The pox, or venereal disease; a chronic, specific, infectious disease, usually communicated by sexual intercourse or by hereditary transmission, and occurring in three stages known as primary, secondary, and tertiary syphilis. See under Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary.
Sephardim: Jews who are descendants of the former Jews of Spain and Portugal. They are as a rule darker than the northern Jews, and have more delicate features.
Sustentation: The act of sustaining, or the state of being sustained; preservation from falling; support; sustenance; maintenance.
Somewhat: In some degree or measure; a little.
Sulphauric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid of gold (aurum), known only in its salts.
Selenide: A binary compound of selenium, or a compound regarded as binary; as, ethyl selenide.
Snatch block: a kind of block with an opening in one side to receive the bight of a rope.
Schoolfellow: One bred at the same school; an associate in school.
&Verbar;Scrophularia: A genus of coarse herbs having small flowers in panicled cymes; figwort.
Snithe: Sharp; piercing; cutting; -- applied to the wind.
Swarthily: In a swarthy manner; with a tawny hue; duskily.
Stalagmitic: Having the form or structure of stalagmites.
Shillalah: An oaken sapling or cudgel; any cudgel; -- so called from Shillelagh, a place in Ireland of that name famous for its oaks.
Semitonic: Of or pertaining to a semitone; consisting of a semitone, or of semitones.
Safflower: An annual composite plant (Carthamus tinctorius), the flowers of which are used as a dyestuff and in making rouge; bastard, or false, saffron.
Subvitalized: Imperfectly vitalized; having naturally but little vital power or energy.
Sheepskin: The skin of a sheep; or, leather prepared from it.
Sell: An imposition; a cheat; a hoax.
Sandworm: Any one of numerous species of annelids which burrow in the sand of the seashore.
Semicircular: Having the form of half of a circle.
Sharebroker: A broker who deals in railway or other shares and securities.
Sonorific: Producing sound; as, the sonorific quality of a body.
Straightly: A variant of Straitly. See 1st Straight.
Stringpiece: A long piece of timber, forming a margin or edge of any piece of construction; esp.:
Station: To place; to set; to appoint or assign to the occupation of a post, place, or office; as, to station troops on the right of an army; to station a sentinel on a rampart; to station ships on the coast of Africa.
Secretion: The act of secreting or concealing; as, the secretion of dutiable goods.
Sandwort: Any plant of the genus Arenaria, low, tufted herbs (order Caryophyllaceæ.)
Shieldless: Destitute of a shield, or of protection.
Sonometer: An instrument for exhibiting the transverse vibrations of cords, and ascertaining the relations between musical notes. It consists of a cord stretched by weight along a box, and divided into different lengths at pleasure by a bridge, the place of which is determined by a scale on the face of the box.
Semitertian: Having the characteristics of both a tertian and a quotidian intermittent.
Sylph: An imaginary being inhabiting the air; a fairy.
Skipper: The master of a fishing or small trading vessel; hence, the master, or captain, of any vessel.
Swanskin: The act of a swan with the down or the feathers on.
Synpelmous: Having the two main flexor tendons of the toes blended together.
Subcartilaginous: Situated under or beneath a cartilage or cartilages.
&Verbar;Scotia: A concave molding used especially in classical architecture.
