Sea saurian: Any marine saurian; esp. (Paleon.), the large extinct species of Mosasaurus, Ichthyosaurus, Plesiosaurus, and related genera.
Sinamine: A bitter white crystalline nitrogenous substance, obtained indirectly from oil of mustard and ammonia; -- called also allyl melamine.
Sophister: To maintain by sophistry, or by a fallacious argument.
Statant: In a standing position; as, a lion statant.
Selectness: The quality or state of being select.
Sea wormwood: A European species of wormwood (Artemisia maritima) growing by the sea.
Siren: Of or pertaining to a siren; bewitching, like a siren; fascinating; alluring; as, a siren song.
Semiamplexicaul: Partially amplexicaul; embracing the stem half round, as a leaf.
Solace: To take comfort; to be cheered.
&Verbar;Sauropoda: An extinct order of herbivorous dinosaurs having the feet of a saurian type, instead of birdlike, as they are in many dinosaurs. It includes the largest known land animals, belonging to Brontosaurus, Camarasaurus, and allied genera. See Illustration in Appendix.
&Verbar;Synchondrosis: An immovable articulation in which the union is formed by cartilage.
Sarcomatous: Of or pertaining to sarcoma; resembling sarcoma.
spin the bottle: a party game in which a player spins a bottle and kisses the person that it points to when it stops spinning; -- usually played by children.
Susceptor: One who undertakes anything; specifically, a godfather; a sponsor; a guardian.
Sorter: One who, or that which, sorts.
Sumbul: The musky root of an Asiatic umbelliferous plant, Ferula Sumbul. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.
&Verbar;Syncrisis: A figure of speech in which opposite things or persons are compared.
&Verbar;Sunna: A collection of traditions received by the orthodox Mohammedans as of equal authority with the Koran.
Scintillate: To emit sparks, or fine igneous particles.
Stabling: The act or practice of keeping horses and cattle in a stable.
Stepped: Provided with a step or steps; having a series of offsets or parts resembling the steps of stairs; as, a stepped key.
Seismograph: An apparatus for registering the shocks and undulatory motions of earthquakes.
Sharp-set: Eager in appetite or desire of gratification; affected by keen hunger; ravenous; as, an eagle or a lion sharp-set.
Survivorship: The state of being a survivor.
Sozzle: One who spills water or other liquids carelessly; specifically, a sluttish woman.
Seizure: The act of seizing, or the state of being seized; sudden and violent grasp or gripe; a taking into possession; as, the seizure of a thief, a property, a throne, etc.
Skeletology: That part of anatomy which treats of the skeleton; also, a treatise on the skeleton.
Self-involution: Involution in one's self; hence, abstraction of thought; reverie.
Seannachie: A bard among the Highlanders of Scotland, who preserved and repeated the traditions of the tribes; also, a genealogist.
Setout: A display, as of plate, equipage, etc.; that which is displayed.
Sarcous: Fleshy; -- applied to the minute structural elements, called sarcous elements, or sarcous disks, of which striated muscular fiber is composed.
Sarcasm: A keen, reproachful expression; a satirical remark uttered with some degree of scorn or contempt; a taunt; a gibe; a cutting jest.
Shaffle: To hobble or limp; to shuffle.
Santoninic: Of or pertaining to santonin; -- used specifically to designate an acid not known in the free state, but obtained in its salts.
Substantiation: The act of substantiating or proving; evidence; proof.
Secession: The act of seceding; separation from fellowship or association with others, as in a religious or political organization; withdrawal.
Supraoccipital: Situated over, or in the upper part of, the occiput; of or pertaining to the supraoccipital bone.
Slyly: In a sly manner; shrewdly; craftily.
Sycite: A nodule of flint, or a pebble, which resembles a fig.
Somner: A summoner; esp., one who summons to an ecclesiastical court.
Sea cock: In a steamship, a cock or valve close to the vessel's side, for closing a pipe which communicates with the sea.
Subdititious: Put secretly in the place of something else; foisted in.
Supping: The act of one who sups; the act of taking supper.
Straightway: Immediately; without loss of time; without delay.
&Verbar;Spongi\u00e6: The grand division of the animal kingdom which includes the sponges; -- called also Spongida, Spongiaria, Spongiozoa, and Porifera.
Stoicism: The opinions and maxims of the Stoics.
&Verbar;Sucre: A silver coin of Ecuador, worth 68 cents.
Sheatfish: A European siluroid fish (Silurus glanis) allied to the cat-fishes. It is the largest fresh-water fish of Europe, sometimes becoming six feet or more in length. See Siluroid.
Sodamide: A greenish or reddish crystalline substance, NaNH2, obtained by passing ammonia over heated sodium.
Superstruct: To build over or upon another structure; to erect upon a foundation.
Sess: A tax; an assessment. See Cess.
&Verbar;Scrutator: One who scrutinizes; a close examiner or inquirer.
&Verbar;Saengerfest: A festival of singers; a German singing festival.
Signalist: One who makes signals; one who communicates intelligence by means of signals.
Swannery: A place where swans are bred.
Sable: To render sable or dark; to drape darkly or in black.
Sanskrit: Of or pertaining to Sanskrit; written in Sanskrit; as, a Sanskrit dictionary or inscription.
single-minded: Having a single purpose; concentrating on a single goal; hence, artless; guileless; single-hearted.
Snail: Any one of numerous species of terrestrial air-breathing gastropods belonging to the genus Helix and many allied genera of the family Helicidæ. They are abundant in nearly all parts of the world except the arctic regions, and feed almost entirely on vegetation; a land snail.
Solemnization: The act of solemnizing; celebration; as, the solemnization of a marriage.
Sedimentation: The act of depositing a sediment; specifically (Geol.), the deposition of the material of which sedimentary rocks are formed.
Skinful: As much as a skin can hold.
Spare: The act of sparing; moderation; restraint.
Spark: To play the spark, beau, or lover.
Stack: To lay in a conical or other pile; to make into a large pile; as, to stack hay, cornstalks, or grain; to stack or place wood.
Sourde: To have origin or source; to rise; to spring.
Scut: The tail of a hare, or of a deer, or other animal whose tail is short, esp. when carried erect; hence, sometimes, the animal itself.
Subdivision: The act of subdividing, or separating a part into smaller parts.
Scup: A marine sparoid food fish (Stenotomus chrysops, or S. argyrops), common on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It appears bright silvery when swimming in the daytime, but shows broad blackish transverse bands at night and when dead. Called also porgee, paugy, porgy, scuppaug.
Subinfer: To infer from an inference already made.
Swasher: One who makes a blustering show of valor or force of arms.
Schizont: In certain Sporozoa, a cell formed by the growth of a sporozoite or merozoite (in a cell or corpuscle of the host) which segment by superficial cleavage, without encystment or conjugation, into  merozoites.
Scud: The act of scudding; a driving along; a rushing with precipitation.
Scug: A place of shelter; the declivity of a hill.
Scum: To form a scum; to become covered with scum. Also used figuratively.
Styca: An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worth half a farthing.
Setwall: A plant formerly valued for its restorative qualities (Valeriana officinalis, or V. Pyrenaica).
Swallower: One who swallows; also, a glutton.
Shelfy: Abounding in shelves; full of dangerous shallows.
Syringin: A glucoside found in the bark of the lilac (Syringa) and extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly called also lilacin.
Syn\u00e6resis: The union, or drawing together into one syllable, of two vowels that are ordinarily separated in syllabification; synecphonesis; -- the opposite of diæresis.
Supertax: A tax in addition to the usual or normal tax; specif., in the United Kingdom, an income tax of sixpence for every pound in addition to the normal income tax of one shilling and twopence for every pound, imposed, by the Finance Act of 1909-1910 (c. 8, ss 66, 72), on the amount by which the  income of any person exceeds £3,000 when his total income exceeds £5,000.
Soda biscuit: a bicuit leavened with baking soda and with buttermilk or sour milk.
&Verbar;Solarium: An apartment freely exposed to the sun; anciently, an apartment or inclosure on the roof of a house; in modern times, an apartment in a hospital, used as a resort for convalescents.
Sprig: To mark or adorn with the representation of small branches; to work with sprigs; as, to sprig muslin.
Soliloquy: The act of talking to one's self; a discourse made by one in solitude to one's self; monologue.
Scovel: A mop for sweeping ovens; a malkin.
&Verbar;Succus: The expressed juice of a plant, for medicinal use.
Shagbark: A rough-barked species of hickory (Carya alba), its nut. Called also shellbark. See Hickory.
Sandbagger: An assaulter whose weapon is a sand bag. See Sand bag, under Sand.
Scolytid: Any one of numerous species of small bark-boring beetles of the genus Scolytus and allied genera. Also used adjectively.
spin doctor: a spokesperson for a political party or candidate who tries to forestall negative publicity.
Substrate: To strew or lay under anything.
Systematic: Of or pertaining to system; consisting in system; methodical; formed with regular connection and adaptation or subordination of parts to each other, and to the design of the whole; as, a systematic arrangement of plants or animals; a systematic course of study.
Sea scurf: Any bryozoan which forms rounded or irregular patches of coral on stones, seaweeds, etc.
Stock-still: Still as a stock, or fixed post; perfectly still.
Saturator: One who, or that which, saturates.
Saving: Something kept from being expended or lost; that which is saved or laid up; as, the savings of years of economy.
Spoken: Uttered in speech; delivered by word of mouth; oral; as, a spoken narrative; the spoken word.
Sacrilegious: Violating sacred things; polluted with sacrilege; involving sacrilege; profane; impious.
Swage: To shape by means of a swage; to fashion, as a piece of iron, by forcing it into a groove or mold having the required shape.
Steeper: A vessel, vat, or cistern, in which things are steeped.
Spunk: Wood that readily takes fire; touchwood; also, a kind of tinder made from a species of fungus; punk; amadou.
Seapiece: A picture representing a scene at sea; a marine picture.
Saccharimetry: The act, process or method of determining the amount and kind of sugar present in sirup, molasses, and the like, especially by the employment of polarizing apparatus.
Strictly: In a strict manner; closely; precisely.
Scaup: A bed or stratum of shellfish; scalp.
Scaur: A precipitous bank or rock; a scar.
&Verbar;Shaitan: An evil spirit; the evil one; the devil.
Sermoning: The act of discoursing; discourse; instruction; preaching.
Stavesacre: A kind of larkspur (Delphinium Staphysagria), and its seeds, which are violently purgative and emetic.  They are used as a parasiticide, and in the East for poisoning fish.
Self-seeker: One who seeks only his own interest, advantage, or pleasure.
Stillson wrench: A pipe wrench having an adjustable L-shaped jaw piece sliding in a sleeve that is pivoted to, and loosely embraces, the handle. Pressure on the handle increases the grip.
Sweeping: Cleaning off surfaces, or cleaning away dust, dirt, or litter, as a broom does; moving with swiftness and force; carrying everything before it; including in its scope many persons or things; as, a sweeping flood; a sweeping majority; a sweeping accusation.
Star-bowlines: The men in the starboard watch.
sloam: A layer of earth between coal seams.
Sthenic: Strong; active; -- said especially of morbid states attended with excessive action of the heart and blood vessels, and characterized by strength and activity of the muscular and nervous system; as, a sthenic fever.
Superserviceable: Overofficious; doing more than is required or desired.
Sprightly: Sprightlike, or spiritlike; lively; brisk; animated; vigorous; airy; gay; as, a sprightly youth; a sprightly air; a sprightly dance.
Surrebuter: The reply of a plaintiff to a defendant's rebutter.
Shipshape: In a shipshape or seamanlike manner.
Soil: That which soils or pollutes; a soiled place; spot; stain.
Shoat: A young hog. Same as Shote.
&Verbar;Sepsis: The poisoning of the system by the introduction of putrescent material into the blood.
Snowdrop: A bulbous plant (Galanthus nivalis) bearing white flowers, which often appear while the snow is on the ground. It is cultivated in gardens for its beauty.
Shoal: To cause to become more shallow; to come to a more shallow part of; as, a ship shoals her water by advancing into that which is less deep.
Supernaculum: A kind of mock Latin term intended to mean, upon the nail; -- used formerly by topers.
Shoad: A train of vein material mixed with rubbish; fragments of ore which have become separated by the action of water or the weather, and serve to direct in the discovery of mines.
Somnour: A summoner; an apparitor; a sompnour.
&Verbar;Sanbenito: Anciently, a sackcloth coat worn by penitents on being reconciled to the church.
Stream gold: Gold in alluvial deposits; placer gold.
Soft-finned: Having the fin rays cartilaginous or flexible; without spines; -- said of certain fishes.
Surfboat: A boat intended for use in heavy surf. It is built with a pronounced sheer, and with a view to resist the shock of waves and of contact with the beach.
Sweetwort: Any plant of a sweet taste.
Slinger: One who slings, or uses a sling.
Sanable: Capable of being healed or cured; susceptible of remedy.
Scrofulide: Any affection of the skin dependent on scrofula.
Separatical: Of or pertaining to separatism in religion; schismatical.
Sirius: The Dog Star. See Dog Star.
Screed: A breach or rent; a breaking forth into a loud, shrill sound; as, martial screeds.
Sleeved: Having sleeves; furnished with sleeves; -- often in composition; as, long-sleeved.
Sprightliness: The quality or state of being sprightly; liveliness; life; briskness; vigor; activity; gayety; vivacity.
Spenserian: Of or pertaining to the English poet Spenser; -- specifically applied to the stanza used in his poem “The Faërie Queene.”
Screen: To provide with a shelter or means of concealment; to separate or cut off from inconvenience, injury, or danger; to shelter; to protect; to protect by hiding; to conceal; as, fruits screened from cold winds by a forest or hill.
Self-satisfaction: The quality or state of being self-satisfied.
Scratcher: One who, or that which, scratches; specifically (Zoöl.), any rasorial bird.
Spiegel iron: A fusible white cast iron containing a large amount of carbon (from three and a half to six per cent) and some manganese. When the manganese reaches twenty-five per cent and upwards it has a granular structure, and constitutes the alloy ferro manganese, largely used in the manufacture of Bessemer steel. Called also specular pig iron, spiegel, and spiegeleisen.
Silesia: A kind of linen cloth, originally made in Silesia, a province of Prussia.
Syphilodermatous: Of or pertaining to the cutaneous manifestations of syphilis.
Spleenwort: Any fern of the genus Asplenium, some species of which were anciently used as remedies for disorders of the spleen.
Spherical: Having the form of a sphere; like a sphere; globular; orbicular; as, a spherical body.
Stowage: The act or method of stowing; as, the stowage of provisions in a vessel.
Sulphureted: Combined or impregnated with sulphur; sulphurized.
Suprarenal: Situated above, or anterior to, the kidneys.
Standage: A reservoir in which water accumulates at the bottom of a mine.
Smokehouse: A building where meat or fish is cured by subjecting it to a dense smoke.
Spatterdashes: Coverings for the legs, to protect them from water and mud; long gaiters.
Storax: Any one of a number of similar complex resins obtained from the bark of several trees and shrubs of the Styrax family. The most common of these is liquid storax, a brown or gray semifluid substance of an agreeable aromatic odor and balsamic taste, sometimes used in perfumery, and in medicine as an expectorant.
Sweetener: One who, or that which, sweetens; one who palliates; that which moderates acrimony.
Saltigrade: One of the Saltigradæ, a tribe of spiders which leap to seize their prey.
Sharock: An East Indian coin of the value of 121/2 pence sterling, or about 25 cents.
Smudginess: The quality or state of being smudged, soiled, or blurred.
Snub: A knot; a protuberance; a song.
Sanction: To give sanction to; to ratify; to confirm; to approve.
Strontia: An earth of a white color resembling lime in appearance, and baryta in many of its properties. It is an oxide of the metal strontium.
Strontic: Of or pertaining to strontium; containing, or designating the compounds of, strontium.
Subcontract: A contract under, or subordinate to, a previous contract.
&Verbar;Spiroch\u00e6ta: A genus of Spirobacteria similar to Spirillum, but distinguished by its motility. One species, the Spirochæte Obermeyeri, is supposed to be the cause of relapsing fever.
Scurvy: A disease characterized by livid spots, especially about the thighs and legs, due to extravasation of blood, and by spongy gums, and bleeding from almost all the mucous membranes. It is accompanied by paleness, languor, depression, and general debility. It is occasioned by confinement, innutritious food, and hard labor, but especially by lack of fresh vegetable food, or confinement for a long time to a limited range of food, which is incapable of repairing the waste of the system. It was formerly prevalent among sailors and soldiers.
Stopover: the act or privilege of stopping over; stopping at a station or airport beyond the time of the departure of the train or airplane on which one came, with the purpose of continuing one's journey on a subsequent train or airplane; the temporary interruption of one's journey.
&Verbar;Streptococcus: A long or short chain of micrococci, more or less curved.
Set-to: A contest in boxing, in an argument, or the like.
Sodio-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of sodium or one of its compounds.
Strophiole: A crestlike excrescence about the hilum of certain seeds; a caruncle.
Swirl: A whirling motion; an eddy, as of water; a whirl.
Septuagenarian: A person who is seventy years of age; a septuagenary.
Stable stand: The position of a man who is found at his standing in the forest, with a crossbow or a longbow bent, ready to shoot at a deer, or close by a tree with greyhounds in a leash ready to slip; -- one of the four presumptions that a man intends stealing the king's deer.
Sided: Having (such or so many) sides; -- used in composition; as, one-sided; many-sided.
Sunglow: A rosy flush in the sky seen after sunset.
Sallenders: An eruption on the hind leg of a horse.
Snuffle: The act of snuffing; a sound made by the air passing through the nose when obstructed.
Schoolmate: A pupil who attends the same school as another.
Shrimp: Any one of numerous species of macruran Crustacea belonging to Crangon and various allied genera, having a slender body and long legs. Many of them are used as food. The larger kinds are called also prawns. See Illust. of Decapoda.
Smouch: A dark soil or stain; a smutch.
Sea bird: Any swimming bird frequenting the sea; a sea fowl.
Shrouded: Provided with a shroud or shrouds.
Stumble: A trip in walking or running.
Sample: To make or show something similar to; to match.
Sachemship: Office or condition of a sachem.
Semicubical: Of or pertaining to the square root of the cube of a quantity.
Shots: The refuse of cattle taken from a drove.
&Verbar;Sudamina: Minute vesicles surrounded by an area of reddened skin, produced by excessive sweating.
Self-important: Having or manifesting an exaggerated idea of one's own importance or merit.
Spoilsmonger: One who promises or distributes public offices and their emoluments as the price of services to a party or its leaders.
Speeder: One who, or that which, speeds.
Stellar: Of or pertaining to stars; astral; as, a stellar figure; stellary orbs.
Squabble: A scuffle; a wrangle; a brawl.
Spinster: A woman who spins, or whose occupation is to spin.
Self-determination: Determination by one's self; or, determination of one's acts or states without the necessitating force of motives; -- applied to the voluntary or activity.
Sciniph: Some kind of stinging or biting insect, as a flea, a gnat, a sandfly, or the like.
Stutter: The act of stuttering; a stammer. See Stammer, and Stuttering.
Soosoo: A kind of dolphin (Platanista Gangeticus) native of the river Ganges; the Gangetic dolphin. It has a long, slender, somewhat spatulate beak.
Sulphonic: Pertaining to, or derived from, a sulphone; -- used specifically to designate any one of a series of acids (regarded as acid ethereal salts of sulphurous acid) obtained by the oxidation of the mercaptans, or by treating sulphuric acid with certain aromatic bases (as benzene); as, phenyl sulphonic acid, C6H5.SO2.OH, a stable colorless crystalline substance.
Solidarity: An entire union or consolidation of interests and responsibilities; fellowship; community.
Searchless: Impossible to be searched; inscrutable; impenetrable.
Sulphuryl: The hypothetical radical SO2; -- called also sulphon.
Set: An evil beast-headed god with high square ears and a long snout; his was the brother and murderer of Osiris.  Called also Seth
Split dynamometer: An electric dynamometer having two coils so arranged that one carries the primary current, and the other the secondary current, of a transformer.
Saying: That which is said; a declaration; a statement, especially a proverbial one; an aphorism; a proverb.
Semiglutin: A peptonelike body, insoluble in alcohol, formed by boiling collagen or gelatin for a long time in water. Hemicollin, a like body, is also formed at the same time, and differs from semiglutin by being partly soluble in alcohol.
Solder: To unite (metallic surfaces or edges) by the intervention of a more fusible metal or metallic alloy applied when melted; to join by means of metallic cement.
Semiring: One of the incomplete rings of the upper part of the bronchial tubes of most birds.  The semirings form an essential part of the syrinx, or musical organ, of singing birds.
Stramonium: A poisonous plant (Datura Stramonium); stinkweed. See Datura, and Jamestown weed.
Signiorship: State or position of a signior.
Sea lemon: Any one of several species of nudibranchiate mollusks of the genus Doris and allied genera, having a smooth, thick, convex yellow body.
Snying: A curved plank, placed edgewise, to work in the bows of a vessel.
Scorpion: Any one of numerous species of pulmonate arachnids of the order Scorpiones, having a suctorial mouth, large claw-bearing palpi, and a caudal sting.
Salicylous: Pertaining to, or designating, a substance formerly called salicylous acid, and now salicylal.
Spoilsman: One who serves a cause or a party for a share of the spoils; in United States politics, one who makes or recognizes a demand for public office on the ground of partisan service; also, one who sanctions such a policy in appointments to the public service.
Syriasm: A Syrian idiom; a Syrianism; a Syriacism.
Staircase: A flight of stairs with their supporting framework, casing, balusters, etc.
Slattern: To consume carelessly or wastefully; to waste; -- with away.
Sacchulmin: An amorphous huminlike substance resembling sacchulmic acid, and produced together with it.
Suscitate: To rouse; to excite; to call into life and action.
Sopition: The act of putting to sleep, or the state of being put to sleep; sleep.
Separator: One who, or that which, separates.
Strophic: Pertaining to, containing, or consisting of, strophes.
&Verbar;Salam: A salutation or compliment of ceremony in the east by word or act; an obeisance, performed by bowing very low and placing the right palm on the forehead.
Suiting: Among tailors, cloth suitable for making entire suits of clothes.
Spry: Having great power of leaping or running; nimble; active.
Spineless: Having no spine, or vertebral column.
Settledness: The quality or state of being settled; confirmed state.
Seminiferous: Seed-bearing; producing seed; pertaining to, or connected with, the formation of semen; as, seminiferous cells or vesicles.
Stockwork: A system of working in ore, etc., when it lies not in strata or veins, but in solid masses, so as to be worked in chambers or stories.
Sheepsplit: A split of a sheepskin; one of the thin sections made by splitting a sheepskin with a cutting knife or machine.
Shallot: A small kind of onion (Allium Ascalonicum) growing in clusters, and ready for gathering in spring; a scallion, or eschalot.
Sunbeam: A beam or ray of the sun.
Sprung: Said of a spar that has been cracked or strained.
Shallon: An evergreen shrub (Gaultheria Shallon) of Northwest America; also, its fruit. See Salal-berry.
Silicated: Combined or impregnated with silicon or silica; as, silicated hydrogen; silicated rocks.
Seamed: Out of condition; not in good condition; -- said of a hawk.
Scillitin: A bitter principle extracted from the bulbs of the squill (Scilla), and probably consisting of a complex mixture of several substances.
Selenitic: Of or pertaining to selenite; resembling or containing selenite.
Stovepipe: Pipe made of sheet iron in length and angular or curved pieces fitting together, -- used to connect a portable stove with a chimney flue.
Stone-blind: As blind as a stone; completely blind.
Sirloin: A loin of beef, or a part of a loin.
Subnasal: Situated under the nose; as, the subnasal point, or the middle point of the inferior border of the anterior nasal aperture.
&Verbar;Schizopoda: A division of shrimplike Thoracostraca in which each of the thoracic legs has a long fringed upper branch (exopodite) for swimming.
Servitude: The state of voluntary or compulsory subjection to a master; the condition of being bound to service; the condition of a slave; slavery; bondage; hence, a state of slavish dependence.
Split-tail: A California market fish (Pogonichthys macrolepidotus) belonging to the Carp family.
Sweepstake: A winning of all the stakes or prizes.
Sublunar: Situated beneath the moon; hence, of or pertaining to this world; terrestrial; earthly.
Subzonal: Situated under a zone, or zona; -- applied to a membrane between the zona radiata and the umbilical vesicle in the mammal embryo.
Swordfish: A very large oceanic fish (Xiphias gladius), the only representative of the family Xiphiidæ. It is highly valued as a food fish. The bones of the upper jaw are consolidated, and form a long, rigid, swordlike beak; the dorsal fin is high and without distinct spines; the ventral fins are absent. The adult is destitute of teeth. It becomes sixteen feet or more long.
Similative: Implying or indicating likeness or resemblance.
Statutory: Enacted by statute; depending on statute for its authority; as, a statutory provision.
Subconsciousness: The state or quality of being subconscious; a state of mind in which perception and other mental processes occur without distinct consciousness.
Semilenticular: Half lenticular or convex; imperfectly resembling a lens.
Sassaby: A large African antelope (Alcelaphus lunata), similar to the hartbeest, but having its horns regularly curved.
Spangly: Resembling, or consisting of, spangles; glittering; as, spangly light.
Statute: An act of the legislature of a state or country, declaring, commanding, or prohibiting something; a positive law; the written will of the legislature expressed with all the requisite forms of legislation; -- used in distinction from common law. See Common law, under Common, a.
Supersecular: Being above the world, or secular things.
Slumpy: Easily broken through; boggy; marshy; swampy.
Stereotypic: Of or pertaining to stereotype, or stereotype plates.
Spondaic: Of or pertaining to a spondee; consisting of spondees.
Suberization: Conversion of the cell walls into cork tissue by development of suberin; -- commonly taking place in exposed tissues, as when a callus forms over a wound. Suberized cell walls are impervious to water.
Superjacent: Situated immediately above; as, superjacent rocks.
Senna: The leaves of several leguminous plants of the genus Cassia. (C. acutifolia, C. angustifolia, etc.). They constitute a valuable but nauseous cathartic medicine.
Somberly: In a somber manner; sombrously; gloomily; despondingly.
Solanine: A poisonous alkaloid glucoside extracted from the berries of common nightshade (Solanum nigrum), and of bittersweet, and from potato sprouts, as a white crystalline substance having an acrid, burning taste; -- called also solonia, and solanina.
steller: The rytina; -- called also stellerine and Steller's sea cow.  See rytina.
Sweltry: Suffocating with heat; oppressively hot; sultry.
Semiprecious: Somewhat precious; as, semiprecious stones or metals.  Used mostly of gemstones used in jewelry, such as amethyst, garnet, or iolite, which are sufficiently rare to have commercial value, but are not considered as precious, as are the diamond, emerald, and ruby.
Sigillated: Decorated by means of stamps; -- said of pottery.
Sleid: To sley, or prepare for use in the weaver's sley, or slaie.
Self-induction: Induction in a circuit due to the action of one portion of a current upon an adjacent portion during periods of varying current strength. The nature of the induction is such as to oppose the action which produces it.
Snaphead: A hemispherical or rounded head to a rivet or bolt; also, a swaging tool with a cavity in its face for forming such a rounded head.
Snaky: Of or pertaining to a snake or snakes; resembling a snake; serpentine; winding.
Sidebone: A morbid growth or deposit of bony matter and at the sides of the coronet and coffin bone of a horse.
Streamline: Of or pert. to a stream line; designating a motion or flow that is free from turbulence, like that of a particle in a streamline; hence, designating a surface, body, etc., that is designed so as to afford an unbroken flow of a fluid about it, esp. when the resistance to flow is the least possible; as, a streamline body for an automobile or airship; -- the current usuage prefers the term streamlined.
&Verbar;Scyphophori: An order of fresh-water fishes inhabiting tropical Africa. They have rudimentary electrical organs on each side of the tail.
Salvability: The quality or condition of being salvable; salvableness.
Swindle: The act or process of swindling; a cheat.
Spicose: Having spikes, or ears, like corn spikes.
&Verbar;Sapindus: A genus of tropical and subtropical trees with pinnate leaves and panicled flowers. The fruits of some species are used instead of soap, and their round black seeds are made into necklaces.
Simulatory: Simulated, or capable of being simulated.
Seepage: The act or process of seeping; percolation.
Stipple: A mode of execution which produces the effect by dots or small points instead of lines.
Swanmark: A mark of ownership cut on the bill or swan.
Spinigerous: Bearing a spine or spines; thorn-bearing.
Spittle: The thick, moist matter which is secreted by the salivary glands; saliva; spit.
Sanctity: The state or quality of being sacred or holy; holiness; saintliness; moral purity; godliness.
Shorthorn: One of a breed of large, heavy domestic cattle having short horns. The breed was developed in England.
Seepy: Oozy; -- applied to land under cultivation that is not well drained.
Skerry: A rocky isle; an insulated rock.
Snakes-head: The Guinea-hen flower; -- so called in England because its spotted petals resemble the scales of a snake's head.
Swiss: Of or pertaining to Switzerland, or the people of Switzerland.
Self-action: Action by, or originating in, one's self or itself.
Soldanrie: The country ruled by a soldan, or sultan.
Sea breach: A breaking or overflow of a bank or a dike by the sea.
Syllabic: Of or pertaining to a syllable or syllables; as, syllabic accent.
Sickly: To make sick or sickly; -- with over, and probably only in the past participle.
Singularize: To make singular or single; to distinguish.
Stupose: Composed of, or having, tufted or matted filaments like tow; stupeous.
Stylohyal: A segment in the hyoidean arch between the epihyal and tympanohyal.
Styloglossal: Of or pertaining to styloid process and the tongue.
Simpler: One who collects simples, or medicinal plants; a herbalist; a simplist.
&Verbar;Sericterium: A silk gland, as in the silkworms.
Soboles: A shoot running along under ground, forming new plants at short distances.
&Verbar;Syrma: A long dress, trailing on the floor, worn by tragic actors in Greek and Roman theaters.
Schediasm: Cursory writing on a loose sheet.
Scullion: A servant who cleans pots and kettles, and does other menial services in the kitchen.
Silicotungstic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of a series of double acids of silicon and tungsten, known in the free state, and also in their salts (called silicotungstates).
&Verbar;Sederunt: A sitting, as of a court or other body.
Scathe: To do harm to; to injure; to damage; to waste; to destroy.
Swaip: To walk proudly; to sweep along.
Scabby: Affected with scabs; full of scabs.
Slating: The act of covering with slate, slates, or a substance resembling slate; the work of a slater.
&Verbar;Stretto: The crowding of answer upon subject near the end of a fugue.
Saucy: Showing impertinent boldness or pertness; transgressing the rules of decorum; treating superiors with contempt; impudent; insolent; as, a saucy fellow.
Splinterproof: Proof against the splinters, or fragments, of bursting shells.
Straight-out: Acting without concealment, obliquity, or compromise; hence, unqualified; thoroughgoing.
Servitorship: The office, rank, or condition of a servitor.
Sharer: One who shares; a participator; a partaker; also, a divider; a distributer.
Speech: To make a speech; to harangue.
Sandhiller: A nickname given to any “poor white” living in the pine woods which cover the sandy hills in Georgia and South Carolina.
Shearman: One whose occupation is to shear cloth.
Sauce: To accompany with something intended to give a higher relish; to supply with appetizing condiments; to season; to flavor.
Stiff-tailed: Having the quill feathers of the tail somewhat rigid.
Sustentative: Adapted to sustain, strengthen, or corroborate; as, sustentative citations or quotations.
Selfishly: In a selfish manner; with regard to private interest only or chiefly.
Syllogism: The regular logical form of every argument, consisting of three propositions, of which the first two are called the premises, and the last, the conclusion. The conclusion necessarily follows from the premises; so that, if these are true, the conclusion must be true, and the argument amounts to demonstration
Steel: To overlay, point, or edge with steel; as, to steel a razor; to steel an ax.
Steen: To line, as a well, with brick, stone, or other hard material.
Steek: To pierce with a sharp instrument; hence, to stitch; to sew; also, to fix; to fasten.
Steed: A horse, especially a spirited horse for state or war; -- used chiefly in poetry or stately prose.
Shock: Bushy; shaggy; as, a shock hair.
Slavery: The condition of a slave; the state of entire subjection of one person to the will of another.
Self-destructive: Destroying, or tending to destroy, one's self or itself; rucidal.
Suppleness: The quality or state of being supple; flexibility; pliableness; pliancy.
Seasickness: The peculiar sickness, characterized by nausea and prostration, which is caused by the pitching or rolling of a vessel.
switchboard: an elctrical apparatus consisting predominantly of a panel on which are switches or other means of completing electrical circuits; -- used especially for the devices used in telephone exchanges.  See sense 2.
Steep: A precipitous place, hill, mountain, rock, or ascent; any elevated object sloping with a large angle to the plane of the horizon; a precipice.
Saltirewise: In the manner of a saltire; -- said especially of the blazoning of a shield divided by two lines drawn in the direction of a bend and a bend sinister, and crossing at the center.
Stoutness: The state or quality of being stout.
Splenic: Of or pertaining to the spleen; lienal; as, the splenic vein.
Stork-billed: Having a bill like that of the stork.
Scavage: A toll or duty formerly exacted of merchant strangers by mayors, sheriffs, etc., for goods shown or offered for sale within their precincts.
Sagenite: Acicular rutile occurring in reticulated forms imbedded in quartz.
Sense: To perceive by the senses; to recognize.
Skua: Any jager gull; especially, the Megalestris skua; -- called also boatswain.
Seashell: The shell of any marine mollusk.
Sargasso: The gulf weed. See under Gulf.
Sweepwasher: One who extracts the residuum of precious metals from the sweepings, potsherds, etc., of refineries of gold and silver, or places where these metals are used.
Short-winded: Affected with shortness of breath; having a quick, difficult respiration, as dyspnoic and asthmatic persons.
Stentorin: A blue coloring matter found in some stentors. See Stentor, 2.
&Verbar;Shama: A saxicoline singing bird (Kittacincla macroura) of India, noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement it imitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy. Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rump white, the under parts chestnut.
Securer: One who, or that which, secures.
Sliding: That slides or slips; gliding; moving smoothly.
Surroyal: One of the terminal branches or divisions of the beam of the antler of the stag or other large deer.
Stalactite: A pendent cone or cylinder of calcium carbonate resembling an icicle in form and mode of attachment. Stalactites are found depending from the roof or sides of caverns, and are produced by deposition from waters which have percolated through, and partially dissolved, the overlying limestone rocks.
Student: A person engaged in study; one who is devoted to learning; a learner; a pupil; a scholar; especially, one who attends a school, or who seeks knowledge from professional teachers or from books; as, the students of an academy, a college, or a university; a medical student; a hard student.
&Verbar;Syllepsis: A figure of speech by which a word is used in a literal and metaphorical sense at the same time.
Sny: An upward bend in a piece of timber; the sheer of a vessel.
Slogan: The war cry, or gathering word, of a Highland clan in Scotland.
Suchospondylous: Having dorsal vertebræ with long and divided transverse processes; -- applied to certain reptiles.
Samiel: A hot and destructive wind that sometimes blows, in Turkey, from the desert. It is identical with the simoom of Arabia and the kamsin of Syria.
Secretory: Secreting; performing, or connected with, the office of secretion; secernent; as, secretory vessels, nerves.
Suwarrow: The giant cactus (Cereus giganteus); -- so named by the Indians of Arizona.  Called also saguaro.
Shittim: The wood of the shittah tree.
Supereminence: The quality or state of being supereminent; distinguished eminence; as, the supereminence of Cicero as an orator, or Lord Chatham as a statesman.
Stereo-: A combining form meaning solid, hard, firm, as in stereo-chemistry, stereography.
Subnect: To tie or fasten beneath; to join beneath.
Slot machine: A machine the operation of which is started by dropping a coin into a slot, for delivering small articles of merchandise, showing one's weight, exhibiting pictures, throwing dice, gambling, etc.
Scarab: Any one of numerous species of lamellicorn beetles of the genus Scarabæus, or family Scarabæidæ, especially the sacred, or Egyptian, species (Scarabæus sacer, and Scarabæus Egyptiorum).
Sembling: The practice of attracting the males of Lepidoptera or other insects by exposing the female confined in a cage.
Scammoniate: Made from scammony; as, a scammoniate aperient.
Scots: Of or pertaining to the Scotch; Scotch; Scottish; as, Scots law; a pound Scots (1s. 8d.).
Shroud-laid: Composed of four strands, and laid right-handed with a heart, or center; -- said of rope. See Illust. under Cordage.
Seamstress: A woman whose occupation is sewing; a needlewoman.
&Verbar;Squamata: A division of edentates having the body covered with large, imbricated horny scales. It includes the pangolins.
Specificate: To show, mark, or designate the species, or the distinguishing particulars of; to specify.
Shelving: The act of fitting up shelves; as, the job of shelving a closet.
Scaffolding: A scaffold; a supporting framework; as, the scaffolding of the body.
Succussion: The act of shaking; a shake; esp. (Med.), a shaking of the body to ascertain if there be a liquid in the thorax.
Schematism: Combination of the aspects of heavenly bodies.
Sporocyst: An asexual zooid, usually forming one of a series of larval forms in the agamic reproduction of various trematodes and other parasitic worms. The sporocyst generally develops from an egg, but in its turn produces other larvæ by internal budding, or by the subdivision of a part or all of its contents into a number of minute germs. See Redia.
Schematist: One given to forming schemes; a projector; a schemer.
Saint: To act or live as a saint.
Spar-hung: Hung with spar, as a cave.
Sheading: A tithing, or division, in the Isle of Man, in which there is a coroner, or chief constable. The island is divided into six sheadings.
Self-regulated: Regulated by one's self or by itself.
Sterlet: A small sturgeon (Acipenser ruthenus) found in the Caspian Sea and its rivers, and highly esteemed for its flavor. The finest caviar is made from its roe.
Spectrally: In the form or manner of a specter.
Substitutive: Tending to afford or furnish a substitute; making substitution; capable of being substituted.
Spreader: One who, or that which, spreads, expands, or propagates.
&Verbar;Secondo: The second part in a concerted piece.
Sinus: An opening; a hollow; a bending.
Sperm whale: A very large toothed whale (Physeter macrocephalus), having a head of enormous size. The upper jaw is destitute of teeth. In the upper part of the head, above the skull, there is a large cavity, or case, filled with oil and spermaceti. This whale sometimes grows to the length of more than eighty feet. It is found in the warmer parts of all the oceans. Called also cachalot, and spermaceti whale.
Strip-leaf: Tobacco which has been stripped of its stalks before packing.
Suppute: To reckon; to compute; to suppose; to impute.
Silure: A fish of the genus Silurus, as the sheatfish; a siluroid.
Spearer: One who uses a spear; as, a spearer of fish.
Starred: Adorned or studded with stars; bespangled.
&Verbar;Syconium: A collective fleshy fruit, in which the ovaries are hidden within a hollow receptacle, as in the fig.
Siphonet: One of the two dorsal tubular organs on the hinder part of the abdomen of aphids. They give exit to the honeydew. See Illust. under Aphis.
Stackstand: A staging for supporting a stack of hay or grain; a staddle{2}; a rickstand.
Saneness: The state of being sane; sanity.
Stingo: Old beer; sharp or strong liquor.
Statesmanlike: Having the manner or wisdom of statesmen; becoming a statesman.
Sequestrator: One who sequesters property, or takes the possession of it for a time, to satisfy a demand out of its rents or profits.
Selectman: One of a board of town officers chosen annually in the New England States to transact the general public business of the town, and have a kind of executive authority. The number is usually from three to seven in each town.
Sufism: A refined mysticism among certain classes of Mohammedans, particularly in Persia, who hold to a kind of pantheism and practice extreme asceticism in their lives.
Seasonable: Occurring in good time, in due season, or in proper time for the purpose; suitable to the season; opportune; timely; as, a seasonable supply of rain.
Select: To choose and take from a number; to take by preference from among others; to pick out; to cull; as, to select the best authors for perusal.
Sicklewort: A plant of the genus Coronilla (C. scorpioides); -- so named from its curved pods.
Sashery: A collection of sashes; ornamentation by means of sashes.
Sulphuration: The act or process of combining or impregnating with sulphur or its compounds; also, the state of being so combined or impregnated.
Sauterne: A white wine made in the district of Sauterne, France.
Solanicine: An alkaloid produced by the action of hydrochloric acid on solanidine, as a tasteless yellow crystalline substance.
Shortening: The act of making or becoming short or shorter.
Scoundreldom: The domain or sphere of scoundrels; scoundrels, collectively; the state, ideas, or practices of scoundrels.
Shoplifter: One who steals anything in a shop, or takes goods privately from a shop; one who, under pretense of buying goods, takes occasion to steal.
Solid-drawn: Drawn out from a heated solid bar, as by a process of spiral rolling which first hollows the bar and then expands the cavity by forcing the bar over a pointed mandrel fixed in front of the rolls; -- said of a weldless tube.
stomping ground: Same as stamping ground.  See under stamp.
Sawtooth: An arctic seal (Lobodon carcinophaga), having the molars serrated; -- called also crab-eating seal.
Sensist: One who, in philosophy, holds to sensism.
Smithery: The workshop of a smith; a smithy or stithy.
Solver: One who, or that which, solves.
slinger ring: tubular ring around the propeller hub of an airplane through which antifreeze solution is spread over the blades.
Slive: To cut; to split; to separate.
Supplemental: Added to supply what is wanted; additional; being, or serving as, a supplement; as, a supplemental law; a supplementary sheet or volume.
Squabash: To crush; to quash; to squash.
Sextant: The sixth part of a circle.
Seize: To fall or rush upon suddenly and lay hold of; to gripe or grasp suddenly; to reach and grasp.
Self-binder: A reaping machine containing mechanism for binding the grain into sheaves.
Shack up: to live together in a sexual relationship, without being legally married.
Symptomatology: The doctrine of symptoms; that part of the science of medicine which treats of the symptoms of diseases; semeiology.
Sugariness: The quality or state of being sugary, or sweet.
Silk-stocking: Wearing silk stockings (which among men were formerly worn chiefly by the luxurious or aristocratic); hence, elegantly dressed; aristocratic; luxurious; -- chiefly applied to men, often by way of reproach.
Sharpness: The quality or condition of being sharp; keenness; acuteness.
Supraglotic: Situated above the glottis; -- applied to that part of the cavity of the larynx above the true vocal cords.
Silverberry: A tree or shrub (Elæagnus argentea) with silvery foliage and fruit.
Semirecondite: Half hidden or half covered; said of the head of an insect when half covered by the shield of the thorax.
Suspensible: Capable of being suspended; capable of being held from sinking.
Seersucker: A light fabric, originally made in the East Indies, of silk and linen, usually having alternating stripes, and a slightly craped or puckered surface; also, a cotton fabric of similar appearance.
Stanch: To prop; to make stanch, or strong.
Sauger: An American fresh-water food fish (Stizostedion Canadense); -- called also gray pike, blue pike, hornfish, land pike, sand pike, pickering, and pickerel.
Sacrilege: The sin or crime of violating or profaning sacred things; the alienating to laymen, or to common purposes, what has been appropriated or consecrated to religious persons or uses.
Systaltic: Capable of, or taking place by, alternate contraction and dilatation; as, the systaltic action of the heart.
Sheepbite: To bite or nibble like a sheep; hence, to practice petty thefts.
Sapphire: Of or resembling sapphire; sapphirine; blue.
staple: To sort according to its staple; as, to staple cotton.
Salute: The act of saluting, or expressing kind wishes or respect; salutation; greeting.
Salubrious: Favorable to health; healthful; promoting health; as, salubrious air, water, or climate.
Self-will: One's own will, esp. when opposed to that of others; obstinacy.
Sippet: A small sop; a small, thin piece of toasted bread soaked in milk, broth, or the like; a small piece of toasted or fried bread cut into some special shape and used for garnishing.
&Verbar;Siphonata: A tribe of bivalve mollusks in which the posterior mantle border is prolonged into two tubes or siphons. Called also Siphoniata. See Siphon, 2 (a), and Quahaug.
Stereographically: In a stereographical manner; by delineation on a plane.
&Verbar;Squamula: One of the little hypogynous scales found in the flowers of grasses; a lodicule.
Self-discipline: Correction or government of one's self for the sake of improvement.
Squeeze: The act of one who squeezes; compression between bodies; pressure.
Solleret: A flexible steel shoe (or one of the plates forming such a shoe), worn with mediæval armor.
Subjection: The act of subjecting, or of bringing under the dominion of another; the act of subduing.
Stringency: The quality or state of being stringent.
Steerage: The act or practice of steering, or directing; as, the steerage of a ship.
Succinct: Girded or tucked up; bound; drawn tightly together.
Substitution: The act of substituting or putting one person or thing in the place of another; as, the substitution of an agent, attorney, or representative to act for one in his absense; the substitution of bank notes for gold and silver as a circulating medium.
Superfluity: A greater quantity than is wanted; superabundance; as, a superfluity of water; a superfluity of wealth.
Sheepmaster: A keeper or feeder of sheep; also, an owner of sheep.
Silvics: The science treating of the life of trees in the forest.
Savanna: A tract of level land covered with the vegetable growth usually found in a damp soil and warm climate, -- as grass or reeds, -- but destitute of trees.
Suberic: Of or pertaining to cork; specifically, designating an acid, C6H12.(CO2H)2, homologous with oxalic acid, and obtained from cork and certain fatty oils, as a white crystalline substance.
Stannotype: A photograph taken upon a tin plate; a tintype.
Sawdust: Dust or small fragments of wood (or of stone, etc.) made by the cutting of a saw.
Snipe: To shoot at (detached men of an enemy's force) at long range, esp. when not in action.
Suberin: A material found in the cell walls of cork. It is a modification of lignin.
Subserve: To be subservient or subordinate; to serve in an inferior capacity.
Scrimmage: Formerly, a skirmish; now, a general row or confused fight or struggle.
Squamozygomatic: Of or pertaining to both the squamosal and zygomatic bones; -- applied to a bone, or a center of ossification, in some fetal skulls.
&Verbar;Salon: An apartment for the reception of company; hence, in the plural, fashionable parties; circles of fashionable society.
Sea withwind: A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus Soldanella) growing on the seacoast of Europe.
Self-assured: Assured by or of one's self; self-reliant; complacent.
Sketchbook: A book of sketches or for sketches.
Seizin: Possession; possession of an estate of froehold. It may be either in deed or in law; the former when there is actual possession, the latter when there is a right to such possession by construction of law. In some of the United States seizin means merely ownership.
Saxatile: Of or pertaining to rocks; living among rocks; as, a saxatile plant.
Stereometric: Of or pertaining to stereometry; performed or obtained by stereometry.
Superinduce: To bring in, or upon, as an addition to something.
Snobbish: Of or pertaining to a snob; characteristic of, or befitting, a snob; vulgarly pretentious.
&Verbar;Shadoof: A machine, resembling a well sweep, used in Egypt for raising water from the Nile for irrigation.
Statoblast: One of a peculiar kind of internal buds, or germs, produced in the interior of certain Bryozoa and sponges, especially in the fresh-water species; -- also called winter buds.
Strophiolate: Furnished with a strophiole, or caruncle, or that which resembles it.
Starfish: Any one of numerous species of echinoderms belonging to the class Asterioidea, in which the body is star-shaped and usually has five rays, though the number of rays varies from five to forty or more.  The rays are often long, but are sometimes so short as to appear only as angles to the disklike body. Called also sea star, five-finger, and stellerid.
&Verbar;Saxifraga: A genus of exogenous polypetalous plants, embracing about one hundred and eighty species. See Saxifrage.
Subcarbonate: A carbonate containing an excess of the basic constituent.
Smock frock: A coarse frock, or shirt, worn over the other dress, as by farm laborers.
Subdiversify: To diversify aggain what is already diversified.
Spitzenburgh: A kind of red and yellow apple, of medium size and spicy flavor. It originated at Newtown, on Long Island.
Shot-free: Free from charge or expense; hence, unpunished; scot-free.
Short-handed: Short of, or lacking the regular number of, servants or helpers.
Samarskite: A rare mineral having a velvet-black color and submetallic luster. It is a niobate of uranium, iron, and the yttrium and cerium metals.
Subcuticular: Situated under the cuticle, or scarfskin.
Squacco: A heron (Ardea comata) found in Asia, Northern Africa, and Southern Europe.
Spirifer: Any one of numerous species of fossil brachipods of the genus Spirifer, or Delthyris, and allied genera, in which the long calcareous supports of the arms form a large spiral, or helix, on each side.
&Verbar;Synapticula: One of numerous calcareous processes which extend between, and unite, the adjacent septa of certain corals, especially of the fungian corals.
Sacramentarian: Of or pertaining a sacrament, or to the sacramentals; sacramental.
Solvability: The quality or state of being solvable; as, the solvability of a difficulty; the solvability of a problem.
Shamrock: A trifoliate plant used as a national emblem by the Irish. The legend is that St. Patrick once plucked a leaf of it for use in illustrating the doctrine of the trinity.
Sundryman: One who deals in sundries, or a variety of articles.
Stannine: A mineral of a steel-gray or iron-black color; tin pyrites. It is a sulphide of tin, copper, and iron.
&Verbar;Synangium: The divided part beyond the pylangium in the aortic trunk of the amphibian heart.
Saltatorious: Capable of leaping; formed for leaping; saltatory; as, a saltatorious insect or leg.
Salaried: Receiving a salary; paid by a salary; having a salary attached; as, a salaried officer; a salaried office.
Sunken: Lying on the bottom of a river or other water; sunk.
Schedule: To form into, or place in, a schedule.
Stallion: A male horse not castrated; a male horse kept for breeding.
Self-existence: Inherent existence; existence possessed by virtue of a being's own nature, and independent of any other being or cause; -- an attribute peculiar to God.
Suburb: An outlying part of a city or town; a smaller place immediately adjacent to a city; in the plural, the region which is on the confines of any city or large town; as, a house stands in the suburbs; a garden situated in the suburbs of Paris.
Statuary: One who practices the art of making statues.
Stronghold: A fastness; a fort or fortress; fortfield place; a place of security.
Slack: To render slack; to make less tense or firm; as, to slack a rope; to slacken a bandage.
Slepez: A burrowing rodent (Spalax typhlus), native of Russia and Asia Minor. It has the general appearance of a mole, and is destitute of eyes. Called also mole rat.
Scuppernong: An American grape, a form of Vitis vulpina, found in the Southern Atlantic States, and often cultivated.
Sidesaddle: A saddle for women, in which the rider sits with both feet on one side of the animal mounted.
Sematic: Significant; ominous; serving as a warning of danger; -- applied esp. to the warning colors or forms of certain animals.
Symmetry: A due proportion of the several parts of a body to each other; adaptation of the form or dimensions of the several parts of a thing to each other; the union and conformity of the members of a work to the whole.
Souchong: A kind of black tea of a fine quality.
Sweepage: The crop of hay got in a meadow.
Strato-cumulus: Large balls or rolls of dark cloud which frequently cover the whole sky, esp. in winter, and give it at times an undulated appearance.
Servile: An element which forms no part of the original root; -- opposed to radical.
Supple-jack: A climbing shrub (Berchemia volubilus) of the Southern United States, having a tough and pliable stem.
Slowback: A lubber; an idle fellow; a loiterer.
Stromb: Any marine univalve mollusk of the genus Strombus and allied genera. See Conch, and Strombus.
Smift: A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
Stethometer: An apparatus for measuring the external movements of a given point of the chest wall, during respiration; -- also called thoracometer.
Seleniureted: Combined with selenium as in a selenide; as, seleniureted hydrogen.
Sea mat: Any bryozoan of the genus Flustra or allied genera which form frondlike corals.
Sublimated: Refined by, or as by, sublimation; exalted; purified.
Studdery: A stud, or collection of breeding horses and mares; also, a place for keeping a stud.
Sanjak: A district or a subvision of a vilayet.
Subjectivity: The quality or state of being subjective; character of the subject.
Superinspect: To over see; to superintend by inspection.
Sleep-at-noon: A plant (Tragopogon pratensis) which closes its flowers at midday; a kind of goat's beard.
Subterranity: A place under ground; a subterrany.
Sorehead: One who is disgruntled by a failure in politics, or the like.
Sortilege: The act or practice of drawing lots; divination by drawing lots.
Senility: The quality or state of being senile; old age.
Soil pipe: A pipe or drain for carrying off night soil.
Subaudition: The act of understanding, or supplying, something not expressed; also, that which is so understood or supplied.
Slushy: Abounding in slush; characterized by soft mud or half-melted snow; as, the streets are slushy; the snow is slushy.
Scorifier: One who, or that which, scorifies; specifically, a small flat bowl-shaped cup used in the first heating in assaying, to remove the earth and gangue, and to concentrate the gold and silver in a lead button.
Subseptuple: Having the ratio of one to seven.
Stage: To exhibit upon a stage, or as upon a stage; to display publicly.
Sarcology: That part of anatomy which treats of the soft parts. It includes myology, angiology, neurology, and splanchnology.
Sotadic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the lascivious compositions of the Greek poet Sotades.
Sleekness: The quality or state of being sleek; smoothness and glossiness of surface.
Stanchless: Incapable of being stanched, or stopped.
Skiffling: Rough dressing by knocking off knobs or projections; knobbing.
Stichic: Of or pertaining to stichs, or lines; consisting of stichs, or lines.
Self-complacent: Satisfied with one's own character, capacity, and doings; self-satisfied.
Sottish: Like a sot; doltish; very foolish; drunken.
Spectrological: Of or pertaining to spectrology; as, spectrological studies or experiments.
Sacral: Of or pertaining to the sacrum; in the region of the sacrum.
Sea fowl: Any bird which habitually frequents the sea, as an auk, gannet, gull, tern, or petrel; also, all such birds, collectively.
Silhouette: To represent by a silhouette; to project upon a background, so as to be like a silhouette.
Seditionary: An inciter or promoter of sedition.
Submarine: A submarine boat; a ship that can travel under the surface of the water.  Most such ships are ships of war, as part of a navy, but submarines are also used for oceanic research.  Also called sub and (from the German U-Boot) U-boat.
Solicit: To ask from with earnestness; to make petition to; to apply to for obtaining something; as, to solicit person for alms.
Significance: The quality or state of being significant.
Sentimentalist: One who has, or affects, sentiment or fine feeling.
Smokable: Capable of being smoked; suitable or ready to be smoked; as, smokable tobacco.
Serrate: Notched on the edge, like a saw.
Sutling: Belonging to sutlers; engaged in the occupation of a sutler.
Sea gherkin: Any small holothurian resembling in form a gherkin.
Snite: To blow, as the nose; to snuff, as a candle.
Stocky: Short and thick; thick rather than tall or corpulent.
Splasher: One who, or that which, splashes.
Singularity: The quality or state of being singular; some character or quality of a thing by which it is distinguished from all, or from most, others; peculiarity.
Self-uned: One with itself; separate from others.
Spine: A sharp appendage to any of a plant; a thorn.
Shipmaster: The captain, master, or commander of a ship.
Stereogram: A diagram or picture which represents objects in such a way as to give the impression of relief or solidity; also, a stereograph.
Symphyseotomy: The operation of dividing the symphysis pubis for the purpose of facilitating labor; -- formerly called the Sigualtian section.
Subjugate: To subdue, and bring under the yoke of power or dominion; to conquer by force, and compel to submit to the government or absolute control of another; to vanquish.
Sainfoin: A leguminous plant (Onobrychis sativa) cultivated for fodder.
Subahdar: A viceroy; a governor of a subah; also, a native captain in the British native army.
Sepidaceous: Like or pertaining to the cuttlefishes of the genus Sepia.
Selenography: The science that treats of the physical features of the moon; -- corresponding to physical geography in respect to the earth.
Stogie: an inexpensive cigar; same as stogy.
Sillabub: A dish made by mixing wine or cider with milk, and thus forming a soft curd; also, sweetened cream, flavored with wine and beaten to a stiff froth.
Surrenderee: The person to whom a surrender is made.
Semicrystalline: Half crystalline; -- said of certain cruptive rocks composed partly of crystalline, partly of amorphous matter.
&Verbar;Stylops: A genus of minute insects parasitic, in their larval state, on bees and wasps. It is the typical genus of the group Strepsiptera, formerly considered a distinct order, but now generally referred to the Coleoptera. See Strepsiptera.
Spattling-poppy: A kind of catchfly (Silene inflata) which is sometimes frothy from the action of captured insects.
Subordination: The act of subordinating, placing in a lower order, or subjecting.
Secondhand: Not original or primary; received from another; as, secondhand information.
Superalimentation: The act of overfeeding, or making one take food in excess of the natural appetite for it.
Steeve: The angle which a bowsprit makes with the horizon, or with the line of the vessel's keel; -- called also steeving.
&Verbar;Sargassum: A genus of algæ including the gulf weed.
Sesban: A leguminous shrub (Sesbania aculeata) which furnishes a fiber used for making ropes.
Sentence method: A method of teaching reading by giving first attention to phrases and sentences and later analyzing these into their verbal and alphabetic components; -- contrasted with alphabet method and word method.  See also phonics.
Spongeous: Resembling sponge; having the nature or qualities of sponge.
Sesame: Either of two annual herbaceous plants of the genus Sesamum (S. Indicum, and S. orientale), from the seeds of which an oil is expressed; also, the small obovate, flattish seeds of these plants, sometimes used as food. See Benne.
Subacromial: Situated beneath the acromial process of the scapula.
Self-righteousness: The quality or state of being self-righteous; pharisaism.
Salvo: A concentrated fire from pieces of artillery, as in endeavoring to make a break in a fortification; a volley.
Spalt: To split off; to cleave off, as chips from a piece of timber, with an ax.
Shoaly: Full of shoals, or shallow places.
Some: Consisting of a greater or less portion or sum; composed of a quantity or number which is not stated; -- used to express an indefinite quantity or number; as, some wine; some water; some persons.  Used also pronominally; as, I have some.
Stinging: Piercing, or capable of piercing, with a sting; inflicting acute pain as if with a sting, goad, or pointed weapon; pungent; biting; as, stinging cold; a stinging rebuke.
Salve: To save, as a ship or goods, from the perils of the sea.
Somatist: One who admits the existence of material beings only; a materialist.
Spirituosity: The quality or state of being spirituous; spirituousness.
Shorage: Duty paid for goods brought on shore.
Superimpregnation: The act of impregnating, or the state of being impregnated, in addition to a prior impregnation; superfetation.
Shakings: Deck sweepings, refuse of cordage, canvas, etc.
Shawfowl: The representation or image of a fowl made by fowlers to shoot at.
Sphex: Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphex and allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to the thorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp, under Sand.
Strangury: A painful discharge of urine, drop by drop, produced by spasmodic muscular contraction.
Sink: A drain to carry off filthy water; a jakes.
Seraphicism: The character, quality, or state of a seraph; seraphicalness.
Semaphore: A signal telegraph; an apparatus for giving signals by the disposition of lanterns, flags, oscillating arms, etc.
&Verbar;Scherzo: A playful, humorous movement, commonly in 3-4 measure, which often takes the place of the old minuet and trio in a sonata or a symphony.
Semimetallic: Of or pertaining to a semimetal; possessing metallic properties in an inferior degree; resembling metal.
Scopiferous: Bearing a tuft of brushlike hairs.
Second-sight: The power of discerning what is not visible to the physical eye, or of foreseeing future events, esp. such as are of a disastrous kind; the capacity of a seer; prophetic vision.
Sesquialter: A stop on the organ, containing several ranks of pipes which reënforce some of the high harmonics of the ground tone, and make the sound more brilliant.
Samaroid: Resembling a samara, or winged seed vessel.
Self-exaltation: The act of exalting one's self, or the state of being so exalted.
Stauroscope: An optical instrument used in determining the position of the planes of light-vibration in sections of crystals.
Stricken: Struck; smitten; wounded; as, the stricken deer.
Surname: To name or call by an appellation added to the original name; to give a surname to.
Saccule: A little sac; specifically, the sacculus of the ear.
Sternforemost: With the stern, instead of the bow, in advance; hence, figuratively, in an awkward, blundering manner.
Sea raven: An American cottoid fish (Hemitripterus Americanus) allied to the sculpins, found on the northern Atlantic coasts.
spread-eagle: To assume a spread-eagled position; -- it may be done reclining, for relaxation, or momentarily, as an exhibitionary maneuver in a sport.
Spareness: The quality or state of being lean or thin; leanness.
Self-motion: Motion given by inherent power, without external impulse; spontaneous or voluntary motion.
Scarce: With difficulty; hardly; scantly; barely; but just.
Surchargement: The act of surcharging; also, surcharge, surplus.
Self-assumed: Assumed by one's own act, or without authority.
Scrivener: A professional writer; one whose occupation is to draw contracts or prepare writings.
Silicofluoride: A fluosilicate; a salt of silicofluoric acid.
Shred: To cut or tear into small pieces, particularly narrow and long pieces, as of cloth or leather.
Silico-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of silicon or its compounds; as, silicobenzoic, silicofluoride, etc.
Somersault: A leap in which a person turns his heels over his head and lights upon his feet; a turning end over end.
Seductive: Tending to lead astray; apt to mislead by flattering appearances; tempting; alluring; as, a seductive offer.
Sabadilla: A Mexican liliaceous plant (Schœnocaulon officinale); also, its seeds, which contain the alkaloid veratrine. It was formerly used in medicine as an emetic and purgative.
Satisfy: To give satisfaction; to afford gratification; to leave nothing to be desired.
Stibonium: The hypothetical radical SbH4, analogous to ammonium; -- called also antimonium.
Semibarbaric: Half barbarous or uncivilized; as, semibarbaric display.
Supravulgar: Being above the vulgar or common people.
shop talk: conversation about a matters pertaining to person's occupation; -- often used of such discussions when conducted outside of working hours, as in social gatherings.
Synchrony: The concurrence of events in time; synchronism.
Shoulder: To push with the shoulder; to make one's way, as through a crowd, by using the shoulders; to move swaying the shoulders from side to side.
Smoky: Emitting smoke, esp. in large quantities or in an offensive manner; fumid; as, smoky fires.
Self-interest: Private interest; the interest or advantage of one's self.
Silicon: A nonmetalic element analogous to carbon. It always occurs combined in nature, and is artificially obtained in the free state, usually as a dark brown amorphous powder, or as a dark crystalline substance with a meetallic luster. Its oxide is silica, or common quartz, and in this form, or as silicates, it is, next to oxygen, the most abundant element of the earth's crust. Silicon is characteristically the element of the mineral kingdom, as carbon is of the organic world. Symbol Si. Atomic weight 28. Called also silicium.
S: the nineteenth letter of the English alphabet, is a consonant, and is often called a sibilant, in allusion to its hissing sound. It has two principal sounds; one a mere hissing, as in sack, this; the other a vocal hissing (the same as that of z), as in is, wise. Besides these it sometimes has the sounds of sh and zh, as in sure, measure. It generally has its hissing sound at the beginning of words, but in the middle and at the end of words its sound is determined by usage. In a few words it is silent, as in isle, débris.  With the letter h it forms the digraph sh.  See Guide to pronunciation, §§ 255-261.
Smoke: To apply smoke to; to hang in smoke; to disinfect, to cure, etc., by smoke; as, to smoke or fumigate infected clothing; to smoke beef or hams for preservation.
Scomfish: To suffocate or stifle; to smother.
Stickiness: The quality of being sticky; as, the stickiness of glue or paste.
Saccharone: A white crystalline substance, C6H8O6, obtained by the oxidation of saccharin, and regarded as the lactone of saccharonic acid.
Sarcoblast: A minute yellowish body present in the interior of certain rhizopods.
Serio-comic: Having a mixture of seriousness and sport; serious and comical.
Seminar: A group of students engaged, under the guidance of an instructor, in original research in a particular line of study, and in the exposition of the results by theses, lectures, etc.; -- formerly called also seminary, now seldom used in this sense.
Self-help: of, pertaining to, or useful for the process of developing one's capabilities or solving one's problems; as, self-help books on writing for profit.
Scot-free: Free from payment of scot; untaxed; hence, unhurt; clear; safe.
Sarcle: To weed, or clear of weeds, with a hoe.
Squamipen: Any one of a group of fishes having the dorsal and anal fins partially covered with scales.
Spekehouse: The parlor or reception room of a convent.
Squiry: The body of squires, collectively considered; squirarchy.
Squirt: An instrument out of which a liquid is ejected in a small stream with force.
Smart: Causing a smart; pungent; pricking; as, a smart stroke or taste.
Substitutionary: Of or pertaining to substitution; substitutional.
Salmon: Of a reddish yellow or orange color, like that of the flesh of the salmon.
Stoolball: A kind of game with balls, formerly common in England, esp. with young women.
Sans-culottic: Pertaining to, or involving, sans-culottism; radical; revolutionary; Jacobinical.
Shaffler: A hobbler; one who limps; a shuffer.
Sternum: A plate of cartilage, or a series of bony or cartilaginous plates or segments, in the median line of the pectoral skeleton of most vertebrates above fishes; the breastbone.
Seven-shooter: A firearm, esp. a pistol, with seven barrels or chambers for cartridges, or one capable of firing seven shots without reloading.
Self-indulgence: Indulgence of one's appetites, desires, or inclinations; -- the opposite of self-restraint, and self-denial.
Sulphuret: A sulphide; as, a sulphuret of potassium.
Somewhither: To some indeterminate place; to some place or other.
&Verbar;Samaj: A society or congregation; a church or religious body.
Semicubium: A half bath, or one that covers only the lewer extremities and the hips; a sitz-bath; a half bath, or hip bath.
Sulphone: Any one of a series of compounds analogous to the ketones, and consisting of the sulphuryl group united with two hydrocarbon radicals; as, dimethyl sulphone, (CH&unr_;)&unr_;.SO&unr_;.
&Verbar;Scleriasis: A morbid induration of the edge of the eyelid.
&Verbar;Sampan: A Chinese boat from twelve to fifteen feet long, covered with a house, and sometimes used as a permanent habitation on the inland waters.
&Verbar;Sahib: A respectful title or appellation given to Europeans of rank.
Snakish: Having the qualities or characteristics of a snake; snaky.
Scotching: Dressing stone with a pick or pointed instrument.
Shrug: To raise or draw up the shoulders, as in expressing doubt, indifference, dislike, dread, or the like.
Stereoscopic: Of or pertaining to the stereoscope; characteristic of, or adapted to, the stereoscope; as, a stereoscopic effect; the stereoscopic function of the eyeglasses; stereoscopic views.
Sapience: The quality of being sapient; wisdom; sageness; knowledge.
Stingy: Extremely close and covetous; meanly avaricious; niggardly; miserly; penurious; as, a stingy churl.
Solidism: The doctrine that refers all diseases to morbid changes of the solid parts of the body. It rests on the view that the solids alone are endowed with vital properties, and can receive the impression of agents tending to produce disease.
Stereotomy: The science or art of cutting solids into certain figures or sections, as arches, and the like; especially, the art of stonecutting.
Subsidize: To furnish with a subsidy; to purchase the assistance of by the payment of a subsidy; to aid or promote, as a private enterprise, with public money; as, to subsidize a steamship line.
Stirrup: A kind of ring, or bent piece of metal, wood, leather, or the like, horizontal in one part for receiving the foot of a rider, and attached by a strap to the saddle, -- used to assist a person in mounting a horse, and to enable him to sit steadily in riding, as well as to relieve him by supporting a part of the weight of the body.
Suint: A peculiar substance obtained from the wool of sheep, consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters. It is used as a source of potash and also for the manufacture of gas.
Snowshoe: A slight frame of wood three or four feet long and about one third as wide, with thongs or cords stretched across it, and having a support and holder for the foot; -- used by persons for walking on soft snow.
SOS: The letters signified by the signal ( . . . --- . . . ) prescribed by the International Radiotelegraphic Convention of 1912 for use by ships in distress.
Styrax: A genus of shrubs and trees, mostly American or Asiatic, abounding in resinous and aromatic substances. Styrax officinalis yields storax, and S. Benzoin yields benzoin.
Suing: The process of soaking through anything.
Suine: A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fatty ingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine.
Societarian: Of or pertaining to society; social.
Standstill: A standing without moving forward or backward; a stop; a state of rest.
Spectrophotometer: An instrument for measuring or comparing the intensities of the colors of the spectrum.
Saucebox: A saucy, impudent person; especially, a pert child.
Southerliness: The quality or state of being southerly; direction toward the south.
Supernatation: The act of floating on the surface of a fluid.
Sheath: A case for the reception of a sword, hunting knife, or other long and slender instrument; a scabbard.
Side-wheel: Having a paddle wheel on each side; -- said of steam vessels; as, a side-wheel steamer.
Senate: An assembly or council having the highest deliberative and legislative functions.
Spring: A leap; a bound; a jump.
Substantiveness: The quality or state of being substantive.
Spir\u00e6a: A genus of shrubs or perennial herbs including the meadowsweet and the hardhack.
Sprint: The act of sprinting; a run of a short distance at full speed.
Seventeenth: The next in order after the sixteenth; one coming after sixteen others.
Sitophobia: A version to food; refusal to take nourishment.
Spellwork: Power or effect of magic; that which is wrought by magic; enchantment.
Seaman: One whose occupation is to assist in the management of ships at sea; a mariner; a sailor; -- applied both to officers and common mariners, but especially to the latter. Opposed to landman, or landsman.
Self-active: Acting of one's self or of itself; acting without depending on other agents.
Sea-bordering: Bordering on the sea; situated beside the sea.
Sea-walled: Surrounded, bounded, or protected by the sea, as if by a wall.
Sciscitation: The act of inquiring; inquiry; demand.
Sapindaceous: Of or pertaining to an order of trees and shrubs (Sapindaceæ), including the (typical) genus Sapindus, the maples, the margosa, and about seventy other genera.
&Verbar;Selachostomi: A division of ganoid fishes which includes the paddlefish, in which the mouth is armed with small teeth.
Stannofluoride: Any one of a series of double fluorides of tin (stannum) and some other element.
Shogun: A title originally conferred by the Mikado on the military governor of the eastern provinces of Japan. By gradual usurpation of power the Shoguns (known to foreigners as Tycoons) became finally the virtual rulers of Japan. The title was abolished in 1867.
Sensuous: Of or pertaining to the senses, or sensible objects; addressing the senses; suggesting pictures or images of sense.
Smoldering: Being in a state of suppressed activity; quiet but not dead.
Spiranthy: The occasional twisted growth of the parts of a flower.
Sea term: A term used specifically by seamen; a nautical word or phrase.
&Verbar;Silurus: A genus of large malacopterygious fishes of the order Siluroidei. They inhabit the inland waters of Europe and Asia.
Synopsis: A general view, or a collection of heads or parts so arranged as to exhibit a general view of the whole; an abstract or summary of a discourse; a syllabus; a conspectus.
Suant: Spread equally over the surface; uniform; even.
Stammering: A disturbance in the formation of sounds.  It is due essentially to long-continued spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm, by which expiration is prevented, and hence it may be considered as a spasmodic inspiration.
Shebang: A jocosely depreciative name for a dwelling or shop; a primitive dwelling; a shanty.
Stubble: The stumps of wheat, rye, barley, oats, or buckwheat, left in the ground; the part of the stalk left by the scythe or sickle.
Suburbed: Having a suburb or suburbs on its outer part.
Supercarpal: Situated above, or in the upper part of, the carpus.
&Verbar;Sfumato: Having vague outlines, and colors and shades so mingled as to give a misty appearance; -- said of a painting.
Scarlet: To dye or tinge with scarlet.
Self-imposed: Voluntarily taken on one's self; as, self-imposed tasks.
Setose: Thickly set with bristles or bristly hairs.
