Swearer: One who swears; one who calls God to witness for the truth of his declaration.
Scald: One of the ancient Scandinavian poets and historiographers; a reciter and singer of heroic poems, eulogies, etc., among the Norsemen; more rarely, a bard of any of the ancient Teutonic tribes.
Saprophytism: State or fact of being saprophytic.
Stolidity: The state or quality of being stolid; dullness of intellect; obtuseness; stupidity.
Seraglio: An inclosure; a place of separation.
Sea turn: A breeze, gale, or mist from the sea.
Scenograph: A perspective representation or general view of an object.
Studious: Given to study; devoted to the acquisition of knowledge from books; as, a studious scholar.
Scragged: Rough with irregular points, or a broken surface; scraggy; as, a scragged backbone.
Stupefaction: The act of stupefying, or the state of being stupefied.
Scalp: To make a small, quick profit by slight fluctuations of the market; -- said of brokers who operate in this way on their own account.
Serr: To crowd, press, or drive together.
Scaly: Covered or abounding with scales; as, a scaly fish.
shrug: A gesture consisting of drawing up the shoulders, -- a motion usually expressing doubt, indifference, or dislike; -- it is sometimes accompanied by a slight turning of the hands outward or upward.  Such a gesture may be made, as in answering "who knows" to a question, suggesting utter ignorance of an answer and a disinclination to pursue the topic further.
Spender: One who spends; esp., one who spends lavishly; a prodigal; a spendthrift.
Scrappily: In a scrappy manner; in scraps.
Sea coal: Coal brought by sea; -- a name by which mineral coal was formerly designated in the south of England, in distinction from charcoal, which was brought by land.
Sanitary: Of or pertaining to health; designed to secure or preserve health; relating to the preservation or restoration of health; hygienic; as, sanitary regulations. See the Note under Sanatory.
Serranoid: Any fish of the family Serranidæ, which includes the striped bass, the black sea bass, and many other food fishes.
Sponsal: Relating to marriage, or to a spouse; spousal.
Subopercular: Situated below the operculum; pertaining to the suboperculum.
Seared: Scorched; cauterized; hence, figuratively, insensible; not susceptible to moral influences.
Supercolumniation: The putting of one order above another; also, an architectural work produced by this method; as, the putting of the Doric order in the ground story, Ionic above it, and Corinthian or Composite above this.
Sprue: Strictly, the hole through which melted metal is poured into the gate, and thence into the mold.
Subalternate: A particular proposition, as opposed to a universal one. See Subaltern, 2.
Skinless: Having no skin, or a very thin skin; as, skinless fruit.
Stillborn: Dead at the birth; as, a stillborn child.
Strigose: Set with stiff, straight bristles; hispid; as, a strigose leaf.
Scyle: To hide; to secrete; to conceal.
Saline: A crude potash obtained from beet-root residues and other similar sources.
Sublineation: A mark of a line or lines under a word in a sentence, or under another line; underlining.
Salina: A salt marsh, or salt pond, inclosed from the sea.
Squiggle: To move about like an eel; to squirm.
Social: Of or pertaining to society; relating to men living in society, or to the public as an aggregate body; as, social interest or concerns; social pleasure; social benefits; social happiness; social duties.
Samoyedes: An ignorant and degraded Turanian tribe which occupies a portion of Northern Russia and a part of Siberia.
Self-starter: A mechanism (usually one operated by electricity, compressed air, a spring, or an explosive gas), attached to an internal-combustion engine, as on an automobile, and used as a means of starting the engine without cranking it by hand; -- called also a starter.
Sea elephant: A very large seal (Macrorhinus proboscideus) of the Antarctic seas, much hunted for its oil. It sometimes attains a length of thirty feet, and is remarkable for the prolongation of the nose of the adult male into an erectile elastic proboscis, about a foot in length. Another species of smaller size (M. angustirostris) occurs on the coast of Lower California, but is now nearly extinct.
Sphacelation: The process of becoming or making gangrenous; mortification.
Servaline: Related to, or resembling, the serval.
Septillion: According to the French method of numeration (which is followed also in the United States), the number expressed by a unit with twenty-four ciphers annexed. According to the English method, the number expressed by a unit with forty-two ciphers annexed. See Numeration.
Simile: A word or phrase by which anything is likened, in one or more of its aspects, to something else; a similitude; a poetical or imaginative comparison.
Spectacular: Of or pertaining to a shows; of the nature of a show.
Seminific: Forming or producing seed, or the male generative product of animals or of plants.
Stern-wheel: Having a paddle wheel at the stern; as, a stern-wheel steamer.
Sophomoric: Of or pertaining to a sophomore; resembling a sophomore; hence, pretentious; inflated in style or manner; as, sophomoric affectation.
Superterrene: Being above ground, or above the earth.
Skid road: A road along which logs are dragged to the skidway or landing; -- called also travois road or travoy road.
Stiff-necked: Stubborn; inflexibly obstinate; contumacious; as, stiff-necked pride; a stiff-necked people.
Statement: The act of stating, reciting, or presenting, orally or on paper; as, to interrupt a speaker in the statement of his case.
Syndic: An officer of government, invested with different powers in different countries; a magistrate.
Selenate: A salt of selenic acid; -- formerly called also seleniate.
Scummy: Covered with scum; of the nature of scum.
Suprascalpular: Situated above, or on the anterior side of, the scapula.
Semimetal: An element possessing metallic properties in an inferior degree and not malleable, as arsenic, antimony, bismuth, molybdenum, uranium, etc.
Supparasite: To flatter; to cajole; to act the parasite.
Sorbonical: Belonging to the Sorbonne or to a Sorbonist.
Savoyard: A native or inhabitant of Savoy.
Subsizar: An under sizar; a student of lower rank than a sizar.
Slidometer: An instrument for indicating and recording shocks to railway cars occasioned by sudden stopping.
Superior: One who is above, or surpasses, another in rank, station, office, age, ability, or merit; one who surpasses in what is desirable; as, Addison has no superior as a writer of pure English.
Sevenscore: Seven times twenty, that is, a hundred and forty.
Shirting: Cloth, specifically cotton cloth, suitable for making shirts.
Sergeant: Formerly, in England, an officer nearly answering to the more modern bailiff of the hundred; also, an officer whose duty was to attend on the king, and on the lord high steward in court, to arrest traitors and other offenders. He is now called sergeant-at-arms, and two of these officers, by allowance of the sovereign, attend on the houses of Parliament (one for each house) to execute their commands, and another attends the Court Chancery.
Saponin: A poisonous glucoside found in many plants, as in the root of soapwort (Saponaria), in the bark of soap bark (Quillaia), etc. It is extracted as a white amorphous powder, which occasions a soapy lather in solution, and produces a local anæsthesia. Formerly called also struthiin, quillaiin, senegin, polygalic acid, etc. By extension, any one of a group of related bodies of which saponin proper is the type.
Spit curl: A little lock of hair, plastered in a spiral form on the temple or forehead with spittle, or other adhesive substance.
Sea compass: The mariner's compass. See under Compass.
Storehouse: A building for keeping goods of any kind, especially provisions; a magazine; a repository; a warehouse.
Single-acting: Having simplicity of action; especially (Mach.), acting or exerting force during strokes in one direction only; -- said of a reciprocating engine, pump, etc.
Steepled: Furnished with, or having the form of, a steeple; adorned with steeples.
Strumstrum: A rude musical instrument somewhat like a cittern.
Supramundane: Being or situated above the world or above our system; celestial.
Stammer: Defective utterance, or involuntary interruption of utterance; a stutter.
&Verbar;Spermatium: One of the motionless spermatozoids in the conceptacles of certain fungi.
Syncarp: A kind of aggregate fruit in which the ovaries cohere in a solid mass, with a slender receptacle, as in the magnolia; also, a similar multiple fruit, as a mulberry.
Seedling: A plant reared from the seed, as distinguished from one propagated by layers, buds, or the like.
Self-sacrifice: The act of sacrificing one's self, or one's interest, for others; self-devotion.
Spile: To supply with a spile or a spigot; to make a small vent in, as a cask.
Swamp: To sink or stick in a swamp; figuratively, to become involved in insuperable difficulties.
Slatch: The period of a transitory breeze.
Secrete: To deposit in a place of hiding; to hide; to conceal; as, to secrete stolen goods; to secrete one's self.
Spilt: imp. & p. p. of Spill. Spilled.
Shedding: The act of shedding, separating, or casting off or out; as, the shedding of blood.
Stringent: Binding strongly; making strict requirements; restrictive; rigid; severe; as, stringent rules.
Seye: imp. pl. & p. p. of See.
Sleek: To make even and smooth; to render smooth, soft, and glossy; to smooth over.
Sleet: To snow or hail with a mixture of rain.
Sleep: A natural and healthy, but temporary and periodical, suspension of the functions of the organs of sense, as well as of those of the voluntary and rational soul; that state of the animal in which there is a lessened acuteness of sensory perception, a confusion of ideas, and a loss of mental control, followed by a more or less unconscious state.
Scandal: To treat opprobriously; to defame; to asperse; to traduce; to slander.
Spongiose: Somewhat spongy; spongelike; full of small cavities like sponge; as, spongious bones.
Stoniness: The quality or state of being stony.
Socialness: The quality or state of being social.
Subarcuate: Having a figure resembling that of a bow; somewhat curved or arched.
Septimole: A group of seven notes to be played in the time of four or six.
Substantival: Of or pertaining to a substantive; of the nature of substantive.
Sulphacid: An acid in which, to a greater or less extent, sulphur plays a part analogous to that of oxygen in an oxyacid; thus, thiosulphuric and sulpharsenic acids are sulphacids; -- called also sulphoacid. See the Note under Acid, n., 2.
Slur: A mark or stain; hence, a slight reproach or disgrace; a stigma; a reproachful intimation; an innuendo.
Six-footer: One who is six feet tall.
Slum: To visit or frequent slums, esp. out of curiosity, or for purposes of study, etc.  Also called go slumming.
Slub: To draw out and twist slightly; -- said of slivers of wool.
Schatchen: A person whose business is marriage brokage; a marriage broker, esp. among certain Jews.
Sheet cable: The cable belonging to the sheet anchor.
Shoot: The act of shooting; the discharge of a missile; a shot; as, the shoot of a shuttle.
Straitness: The quality or condition of being strait; especially, a pinched condition or situation caused by poverty; as, the straitnessof their circumstances.
Saporous: Having flavor or taste; yielding a taste.
Sponsion: The act of becoming surety for another.
Stead: To help; to support; to benefit; to assist.
Scaphite: Any fossil cephalopod shell of the genus Scaphites, belonging to the Ammonite family and having a chambered boat-shaped shell. Scaphites are found in the Cretaceous formation.
Steak: A slice of beef, broiled, or cut for broiling; -- also extended to the meat of other large animals; as, venison steak; bear steak; pork steak; turtle steak.
Steal: To practice, or be guilty of, theft; to commit larceny or theft.
Shooi: The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus);- so called from its cry.
Soss: Anything dirty or muddy; a dirty puddle.
Synoptist: Any one of the authors of the three synoptic Gospels, which give a history of our Lord's life and ministry, in distinction from the writer of John's Gospel, which gives a fuller record of his teachings.
Spinthariscope: A small instrument containing a minute particle of a radium compound mounted in front of a fluorescent screen and viewed with magnifying lenses. The tiny flashes produced by the continual bombardment of the screen by the α rays are thus rendered visible.
Stopple: To close the mouth of anything with a stopple, or as with a stopple.
Semi-Saxon: Half Saxon; -- specifically applied to the language intermediate between Saxon and English, belonging to the period 1150-1250.
Scholarly: Like a scholar, or learned person; showing the qualities of a scholar; as, a scholarly essay or critique.
Subtegulaneous: Under the roof or eaves; within doors.
&Verbar;Sobriquet: An assumed name; a fanciful epithet or appellation; a nickname.
Superintend: To have or exercise the charge and oversight of; to oversee with the power of direction; to take care of with authority; to supervise; as, an officer superintends the building of a ship or the construction of a fort.
specification: The act of specifying or determining by a mark or limit; notation of limits.
Steatite: A massive variety of talc, of a grayish green or brown color. It forms extensive beds, and is quarried for fireplaces and for coarse utensils. Called also potstone, lard stone, and soapstone.
Sufficiency: The quality or state of being sufficient, or adequate to the end proposed; adequacy.
Sobbing: A series of short, convulsive inspirations, the glottis being suddenly closed so that little or no air enters into the lungs.
Subcelestial: Being beneath the heavens; as, subcelestial glories.
Sea marge: Land which borders on the sea; the seashore.
Sworder: One who uses, or fights with, a sword; a swordsman; a soldier; a cutthroat.
Star of David: A symbol consisting of two overlapped equilateral triangles forming a star with six points, used as a symbol of Judaism.  It is also called Magen David, Mogen David, and Shield of David, and is shaped identically to the hexagram and Solomon's seal.  It is used on the flag of the modern state of Israel.
Scandinavian: Of or pertaining to Scandinavia, that is, Sweden, Norway, and Denmark.
Surge: To let go or slacken suddenly, as a rope; as, to surge a hawser or messenger; also, to slacken the rope about (a capstan).
Sepulture: The act of depositing the dead body of a human being in the grave; burial; interment.
Sheep-shearer: One who shears, or cuts off the wool from, sheep.
Scorch: To be burnt on the surface; to be parched; to be dried up.
Spiritualness: The quality or state of being spiritual or spiritual-minded; spirituality.
Subtense: A line subtending, or stretching across; a chord; as, the subtense of an arc.
Shoveler: One who, or that which, shovels.
Stupid: Very dull; insensible; senseless; wanting in understanding; heavy; sluggish; in a state of stupor; -- said of persons.
Surviving: Remaining alive; yet living or existing; as, surviving friends; surviving customs.
Sexennial: Lasting six years, or happening once in six years.
Subsumption: The act of subsuming, or of including under another.
Support: The act, state, or operation of supporting, upholding, or sustaining.
Sacalait: A kind of fresh-water bass; the crappie.
Savvy: Comprehension; knowledge of affairs; mental grasp; also, practical know-how; common sense.
Superheat: The increase of temperature communicated to steam by superheating it.
Surprisal: The act of surprising, or state of being surprised; surprise.
Stancher: One who, or that which, stanches, or stops, the flowing, as of blood.
Sinistrally: Toward the left; in a sinistral manner.
Sepaloid: Like a sepal, or a division of a calyx.
&Verbar;Sapor: Power of affecting the organs of taste; savor; flavor; taste.
Seaworthiness: The state or quality of being seaworthy, or able to resist the ordinary violence of wind and weather.
Squalid: Dirty through neglect; foul; filthy; extremely dirty.
Surface loading: The weight supported per square unit of surface; the quotient obtained by dividing the gross weight, in pounds, of a fully loaded flying machine, by the total area, in square feet, of its supporting surface.
Sinic: Of or pertaining to the Chinese and allied races; Chinese.
Spurn-water: A channel at the end of a deck to restrain the water.
Stichomancy: Divination by lines, or passages of books, taken at hazard.
Stablish: To settle permanently in a state; to make firm; to establish; to fix.
Schistosity: The quality or state of being schistose.
Silicic: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, silica; specifically, designating compounds of silicon; as, silicic acid.
Singletree: The pivoted or swinging bar to which the traces of a harnessed horse are fixed; a whiffletree.
Superordination: The ordination of a person to fill a station already occupied; especially, the ordination by an ecclesiastical official, during his lifetime, of his successor.
Soldiering: The act of serving as a soldier; the state of being a soldier; the occupation of a soldier.
Subtriplicate: Expressed by the cube root; -- said especially of ratios.
Sourness: The quality or state of being sour.
Synodal: A tribute in money formerly paid to the bishop or archdeacon, at the time of his Easter visitation, by every parish priest, now made to the ecclesiastical commissioners; a procuration.
Sky-blue: Having the blue color of the sky; azure; as, a sky-blue stone.
Sulks: The condition of being sulky; a sulky mood or humor; as, to be in the sulks.
Stereobate: The lower part or basement of a building or pedestal; -- used loosely for several different forms of basement.
Sterilizer: One that sterilizes anything; specif., an apparatus for sterilizing equipment or an organic fluid.
Sarcocol: A gum resin obtained from certain shrubs of Africa (Penæa), -- formerly thought to cause healing of wounds and ulcers.
Selenonium: A hypothetical radical of selenium, analogous to sulphonium.
Subcrustaceous: Occurring beneath a crust or scab; as, a subcrustaceous cicatrization.
Sark: To cover with sarking, or thin boards.
Shroff: A banker, or changer of money.
Secessionism: The doctrine or policy of secession; the tenets of secession; the tenets of secessionists.
Sard: A variety of carnelian, of a rich reddish yellow or brownish red color. See the Note under Chalcedony.
Seaport: A port on the seashore, or one accessible for seagoing vessels. Also used adjectively; as, a seaport town.
Shandygaff: A mixture of strong beer and ginger beer.
Sanctification: The act of sanctifying or making holy; the state of being sanctified or made holy;
Spondyl: A joint of the backbone; a vertebra.
Sulphanilic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an anilene sulphonic acid which is obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Swell: Having the characteristics of a person of rank and importance; showy; dandified; distinguished; as, a swell person; a swell neighborhood.
Stand-by: One who, or that which, stands by one in need; something upon which one relies for constant use or in an emergency.
Swallowtail: A kind of tenon or tongue used in making joints. See Dovetail.
Sawfish: Any one of several species of elasmobranch fishes of the genus Pristis. They have a sharklike form, but are more nearly allied to the rays. The flattened and much elongated snout has a row of stout toothlike structures inserted along each edge, forming a sawlike organ with which it mutilates or kills its prey.
&Verbar;Stellerida: An extensive group of echinoderms, comprising the starfishes and ophiurans.
Sleuthhound: A hound that tracks animals by the scent; specifically, a bloodhound.
Sibilate: To pronounce with a hissing sound, like that of the letter s; to mark with a character indicating such pronunciation.
&Verbar;Splanchnapophysis: Any element of the skeleton in relation with the alimentary canal, as the jaws and hyoidean apparatus.
Staghound: A large and powerful hound formerly used in hunting the stag, the wolf, and other large animals. The breed is nearly extinct.
Sea reed: The sea-sand reed. See under Reed.
Steatomatous: Of the nature of a steatoma.
Sewage: The contents of a sewer or drain; refuse liquids or matter carried off by sewers
Spini-spirulate: Having spines arranged spirally. See Spicule.
Stud-horse: A stallion, esp. one kept for breeding.
Smut: To gather smut; to be converted into smut; to become smutted.
Stop: The act of stopping, or the state of being stopped; hindrance of progress or of action; cessation; repression; interruption; check; obstruction.
&Verbar;Symphysis: An articulation formed by intervening cartilage; as, the pubic symphysis.
Supra-acromial: Situated above the acromial process of the scapula.
Shifty: Full of, or ready with, shifts; fertile in expedients or contrivance.
Sorites: An abridged form of stating of syllogisms in a series of propositions so arranged that the predicate of each one that precedes forms the subject of each one that follows, and the conclusion unites the subject of the first proposition with the predicate of the last proposition
Strawboard: Pasteboard made of pulp of straw.
Simplesse: a trade name for a fat substitute prepared as microparticles of protein from whey.  It has little fat, but has a consistency and taste resembling fat, and is thus used to prepare foods low in fat for dietetic purposes.
Simplistic: Of or pertaining to simples, or a simplist.
Scantily: In a scanty manner; not fully; not plentifully; sparingly; parsimoniously.
Syndicate: To unite to form a syndicate.
Standpoint: A fixed point or station; a basis or fundamental principle; a position from which objects or principles are viewed, and according to which they are compared and judged.
Springal: An ancient military engine for casting stones and arrows by means of a spring.
Spinose: Full of spines; armed with thorns; thorny.
Semilens: The half of a lens divided along a plane passing through its axis.
Sturdy: A disease in sheep and cattle, marked by great nervousness, or by dullness and stupor.
Sinapisin: A substance extracted from mustard seed and probably identical with sinalbin.
Sidelong: Lateral; oblique; not being directly in front; as, a sidelong glance.
Shellwork: Work composed of shells, or adorned with them.
Shaddock: A tree (Citrus decumana) and its fruit, which is a large species of orange; -- called also forbidden fruit, and pompelmous.
Spontaneous: Proceeding from natural feeling, temperament, or disposition, or from a native internal proneness, readiness, or tendency, without constraint; as, a spontaneous gift or proposition.
Suffix: To add or annex to the end, as a letter or syllable to a word; to append.
Saddled: Having a broad patch of color across the back, like a saddle; saddle-backed.
Stink: A strong, offensive smell; a disgusting odor; a stench.
Schizognathism: The condition of having a schizognathous palate.
Sting: To pierce or wound with a sting; as, bees will sting an animal that irritates them; the nettles stung his hands.
Shipyard: A yard, place, or inclosure where ships are built or repaired.
Swough: A sound; a groan; a moan; a sough.
Supersession: The act of superseding, or the state of being superseded; supersedure.
Stratography: A description of an army, or of what belongs to an army.
Sandpiper: Any one of numerous species of small limicoline game birds belonging to Tringa, Actodromas, Ereunetes, and various allied genera of the family Tringidæ.
Spousal: Marriage; nuptials; espousal; -- generally used in the plural; as, the spousals of Hippolita.
Sublobular: Situated under, or at the bases of, the lobules of the liver.
&Verbar;Siderosis: A sort of pneumonia occuring in iron workers, produced by the inhalation of particles of iron.
Subdiaconate: The office or rank of a subdeacon.
Septuagint: A Greek version of the Old Testament; -- so called because it was believed to be the work of seventy (or rather of seventy-two) translators.
Scrutinous: Closely examining, or inquiring; careful; strict.
Susurringly: In the manner of a whisper.
Salamandrine: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a salamander; enduring fire.
Sloping: Inclining or inclined from the plane of the horizon, or from a horizontal or other right line; oblique; declivous; slanting.
Sparoid: Of or pertaining to the Sparidæ, a family of spinous-finned fishes which includes the scup, sheepshead, and sea bream.
Saw-toothed: Having a tooth or teeth like those of a saw; serrate.
Subjective: Of or pertaining to a subject.
Switching power supply: a device used as part of an electronic device, which transforms electrical current from an AC line circuit to DC for use in electronic devices, and which can use either 110 volt or 220 volt AC line curent.
Supersulphurize: To impregnate or combine with an excess of sulphur.
Sodic: Of or pertaining to sodium; containing sodium.
Soda jerk: a person who serves soda, ice cream, similar foods from behind a soda fountain.
Studied: Closely examined; read with diligence and attention; made the subject of study; well considered; as, a studied lesson.
Strangulation: The act of strangling, or the state of being strangled.
Stinginess: The quality or state of being stingy.
streamline: to design or modify so as to present the least possible resistance to fluid flow; -- used mostly of vehicles, such as automobiles, airplanes, or ships.
Save-all: Anything which saves fragments, or prevents waste or loss.
Siluroid: Belonging to the Siluroidei, or Nematognathi, an order of fishes including numerous species, among which are the American catfishes and numerous allied fresh-water species of the Old World, as the sheatfish (Silurus glanis) of Europe.
&Verbar;Sporozoa: An extensive division of parasitic Protozoa, which increase by sporulation. It includes the Gregarinida.
Spatter-dock: The common yellow water lily (Nuphar advena).
Supervisor: One who supervises; an overseer; an inspector; a superintendent; as, a supervisor of schools.
Split-tongued: Having a forked tongue, as that of snakes and some lizards.
Satrap: The governor of a province in ancient Persia; hence, a petty autocrat despot.
Succorer: One who affords succor; a helper.
Stramazoun: A direct descending blow with the edge of a sword.
Semicirque: A semicircular hollow or opening among trees or hills.
Sixty-fourth: Constituting or being one of sixty-four equal parts into which a thing is divided.
Self-deceived: Deceived or misled respecting one's self by one's own mistake or error.
&Verbar;Susurrus: The act of whispering; a whisper; a murmur.
Suffice: To satisfy; to content; to be equal to the wants or demands of.
Stabber: One who, or that which, stabs; a privy murderer.
Signior: Sir; Mr. The English form and pronunciation for the Italian Signor and the Spanish Señor.
Siphonarid: Any one of numerous species of limpet-shaped pulmonate gastropods of the genus Siphonaria. They cling to rocks between high and low water marks and have both lunglike organs and gills.
Stairhead: The head or top of a staircase.
Shoddy fever: A febrile disease characterized by dyspnœa and bronchitis caused by inhaling dust.
Stibial: Like, or having the qualities of, antimony; antimonial.
Scribbling: The act of writing hastily or idly.
Search: The act of seeking or looking for something; quest; inquiry; pursuit for finding something; examination.
Splendid: Possessing or displaying splendor; shining; very bright; as, a splendid sun.
&Verbar;Syngenesia: A Linnæan class of plants in which the stamens are united by the anthers.
Sunset: The descent of the sun below the horizon; also, the time when the sun sets; evening. Also used figuratively.
Saynd: p. p. of Senge, to singe.
Stature: The natural height of an animal body; -- generally used of the human body.
Septate: Divided by partition or partitions; having septa; as, a septate pod or shell.
Superintendence: The act of superintending; care and oversight for the purpose of direction; supervision.
Supraclavicle: A bone which usually connects the clavicle with the post-temporal in the pectorial arch of fishes.
Surrey: A four-wheeled pleasure carriage, (commonly two-seated) somewhat like a phaeton, but having a straight bottom.
Semitone: Half a tone; -- the name commonly applied to the smaller intervals of the diatonic scale.
Scariose: Thin, dry, membranous, and not green.
Squalidity: The quality or state of being squalid; foulness; filthiness.
Safety bicycle: A bicycle with equal or nearly equal wheels, usually about 28 inches diameter, driven by pedals connected to the rear (driving) wheel by a multiplying gear.  Since the 1930's this has been the most common type of bicycle, now simply called bicycle.  The older high-wheelers are often referred to as bone-rattlers.
&Verbar;Sportula: A gift; a present; a prize; hence, an alms; a largess.
Sausage: An article of food consisting of meat (esp. pork) minced and highly seasoned, and inclosed in a cylindrical case or skin usually made of the prepared intestine of some animal.
Shemitic: Of or pertaining to Shem, the son of Noah, or his descendants. See Semitic.
Syncretistic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, syncretism; as, a syncretistic mixture of the service of Jehovah and the worship of idols.
Stake: To fasten, support, or defend with stakes; as, to stake vines or plants.
Stepchild: A bereaved child; one who has lost father or mother.
Succinyl: A hypothetical radical characteristic of succinic acid and certain of its derivatives.
Soothsayer: One who foretells events by the art of soothsaying; a prognosticator.
Slaughter: To visit with great destruction of life; to kill; to slay in battle.
Strychnic: Of or pertaining to strychnine; produced by strychnine; as, strychnic compounds; strychnic poisoning
Sinapoline: A nitrogenous base, CO.(NH.C3H5)2, related to urea, extracted from mustard oil, and also produced artifically, as a white crystalline substance; -- called also diallyl urea.
Spermatogenetic: Relating to, or connected with, spermatogenesis; as, spermatogenetic function.
Stipulary: Of or pertaining to stipules; stipular.
Suscipient: One who takes or admits; one who receives.
Sourly: In a sour manner; with sourness.
Shooter: One who shoots, as an archer or a gunner.
Sundowner: A tramp or vagabond in the Australian bush; -- so called from his coming to sheep stations at sunset of ask for supper and a bed, when it is too late to work; -- called also traveler and swagman (but not all swagmen are sundowners).
Side-taking: A taking sides, as with a party, sect, or faction.
Spirant: A term used differently by different authorities; -- by some as equivalent to fricative, -- that is, as including all the continuous consonants, except the nasals m, n, ng; with the further exception, by others, of the liquids r, l, and the semivowels w, y; by others limited to f, v, th surd and sonant, and the sound of German ch, -- thus excluding the sibilants, as well as the nasals, liquids, and semivowels. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 197-208.
Snails: God's nails, or His nails, that is, the nails with which the Savior was fastened to the cross; -- an ancient form of oath, corresponding to 'Od's bodikins (dim. of body, i.e., God's dear body).
Stubborn: Firm as a stub or stump; stiff; unbending; unyielding; persistent; hence, unreasonably obstinate in will or opinion; not yielding to reason or persuasion; refractory; harsh; -- said of persons and things; as, stubborn wills; stubborn ore; a stubborn oak; as stubborn as a mule.
Self-confident: Confident of one's own strength or powers; relying on one's judgment or ability; self-reliant.
Scansorial: Capable of climbing; as, the woodpecker is a scansorial bird; adapted for climbing; as, a scansorial foot.
Smilodon: An extinct genus of saber-toothed tigers. See Mach&unr_;rodus.
Spadiceous: Of a bright clear brown or chestnut color.
Sectionalism: A disproportionate regard for the interests peculiar to a section of the country; local patriotism, as distinguished from national.
Shrewmouse: A shrew; especially, the erd shrew.
Strabismometer: An instrument for measuring the amount of strabismus.
Summation: The act of summing, or forming a sum, or total amount; also, an aggregate.
Seduction: The act of seducing; enticement to wrong doing; enticement to fail in some duty.
Shimmer: A faint, tremulous light; a gleaming; a glimmer.
Subcoracoid: Situated under the coracoid process of the scapula; as, the subcoracoid dislocation of the humerus.
Sacred: Set apart by solemn religious ceremony; especially, in a good sense, made holy; set apart to religious use; consecrated; not profane or common; as, a sacred place; a sacred day; sacred service.
Sanhedrin: the great council of the Jews, which consisted of seventy members, to whom the high priest was added. It had jurisdiction of religious matters.
Suslik: A ground squirrel (Spermophilus citillus) of Europe and Asia. It has large cheek pouches.
Statistician: One versed in statistics; one who collects and classifies facts for statistics.
Sarcenet: A species of fine thin silk fabric, used for linings, etc.
Seraphim: The Hebrew plural of Seraph.  Cf. Cherubim.
Seraphic: Of or pertaining to a seraph; becoming, or suitable to, a seraph; angelic; sublime; pure; refined.
Septentrion: Of or pertaining to the north; northern.
Shopworn: Somewhat worn or damaged by having been kept for a time in a shop.
Stitching: The act of one who stitches.
Succursal: Serving to aid or help; serving as a chapel of ease; tributary.
Shader: One who, or that which, shades.
Symplectic: Plaiting or joining together; -- said of a bone next above the quadrate in the mandibular suspensorium of many fishes, which unites together the other bones of the suspensorium.
Samphire: A fleshy, suffrutescent, umbelliferous European plant (Crithmum maritimum). It grows among rocks and on cliffs along the seacoast, and is used for pickles.
Swimming: Vertigo; dizziness; as, a swimming in the head.
Squilgee: To swab, press, or treat with a squilgee; as, to squilgee a vessel's deck.
Shagginess: The quality or state of being shaggy; roughness; shaggedness.
Silverware: Dishes, vases, ornaments, and utensils of various sorts, made of silver.
Still-burn: To burn in the process of distillation; as, to still-burn brandy.
Smithcraft: The art or occupation of a smith; smithing.
Superexalt: To exalt to a superior degree; to exalt above others.
Shirtless: Not having or wearing a shirt.
Salimeter: An instrument for measuring the amount of salt present in any given solution.
Self-examinant: One who examines himself; one given to self-examination.
Surprise: To come or fall suddenly and unexpectedly; to take unawares; to seize or capture by unexpected attack.
Symbolistic: Characterized by the use of symbols; as, symbolistic poetry.
Square-rigged: Having the sails extended upon yards suspended horizontally by the middle, as distinguished from fore-and-aft sails; thus, a ship and a brig are square-rigged vessels.
Surquedous: Having or exhibiting surquedry; arrogant; insolent.
Sepulcher: To bury; to inter; to entomb; as, obscurely sepulchered.
&Verbar;Solidungula: A tribe of ungulates which includes the horse, ass, and related species, constituting the family Equidæ.
Subrogate: To put in the place of another; to substitute.
Spong: An irregular, narrow, projecting part of a field.
Sieve: A utensil for separating the finer and coarser parts of a pulverized or granulated substance from each other. It consist of a vessel, usually shallow, with the bottom perforated, or made of hair, wire, or the like, woven in meshes.
Sieva: A small variety of the Lima bean (Phaseolus lunatus).
Strife: The act of striving; earnest endeavor.
Septiform: Having the form of a septum.
Sagination: The act of fattening or pampering.
Sprain: The act or result of spraining; lameness caused by spraining; as, a bad sprain of the wrist.
&Verbar;Signora: Madam; Mrs; -- a title of address or respect among the Italians.
Stipitiform: Having the shape of a stalk; stalklike.
Somite: One of the actual or ideal serial segments of which an animal, esp. an articulate or vertebrate, is composed; somatome; metamere.
slip-joint pliers: pliers with a joint adjustable to two positions in order to increase the opening of the jaws.
Semivitrified: Half or imperfectly vitrified; partially converted into glass.
Stypticity: The quality or state of being styptic; astringency.
Squalidness: Quality or state of being squalid.
Stifler: One who, or that which, stifles.
Self-contradiction: The act of contradicting one's self or itself; repugnancy in conceptions or in terms; a proposition consisting of two members, one of which contradicts the other; as, to be and not to be at the same time is a self-contradiction.
Seventieth: One next in order after the sixty-ninth.
Selenhydric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen selenide, H2Se, regarded as an acid analogous to sulphydric acid.
State socialism: A form of socialism, esp. advocated in Germany, which, while retaining the right of private property and the institution of the family and other features of the present form of the state, would intervene by various measures intended to give or maintain equality of opportunity, as compulsory state insurance, old-age pensions, etc., answering closely to socialism of the chair.
Sampler: One who makes up samples for inspection; one who examines samples, or by samples; as, a wool sampler.
Stormwind: A heavy wind; a wind that brings a storm; the blast of a storm.
Sagittal: Of or pertaining to an arrow; resembling an arrow; furnished with an arrowlike appendage.
Sol-fa: The gamut, or musical scale. See Tonic sol-fa, under Tonic, n.
&Verbar;Stylopodium: An expansion at the base of the style, as in umbelliferous plants.
Sandman: A mythical person who makes children sleepy, so that they rub their eyes as if there were sand in them.
Sea devil: Any very large ray, especially any species of the genus Manta or Cephaloptera, some of which become more than twenty feet across and weigh several tons. See also Ox ray, under Ox.
Subtilty: The quality or state of being subtile; thinness; fineness; as, the subtility of air or light.
Sebesten: The mucilaginous drupaceous fruit of two East Indian trees (Cordia Myxa, and Cordia latifolia), sometimes used medicinally in pectoral diseases.
Sedimentary: Of or pertaining to sediment; formed by sediment; containing matter that has subsided.
Stammel: Of the color of stammel; having a red color, thought inferior to scarlet.
Spad: A nail one or two inches long, of iron, brass, tin, or tinner iron, with a hole through the flattened head, used to mark stations in underground surveying.
Suckanhock: A kind of seawan. See Note under Seawan.
Secretary: One who keeps, or is intrusted with, secrets.
Squeegee: To smooth, clean, press, or treat with a squeegee; to squilgee.
Sunroof: a panel in the roof of an automobile, usually above the driver's seat, that can be opened.
Stadimeter: A horizontal graduated bar mounted on a staff, used as a stadium, or telemeter, for measuring distances.
Sleepwalker: One who walks in his sleep; a somnambulist.
Salvable: Capable of being saved; admitting of salvation.
Sunwise: In the direction of the sun's apparent motion, or from the east southward and westward, and so around the circle; also, in the same direction as the movement of the hands of a watch lying face upward.
Spacious: Extending far and wide; vast in extent.
Synchronize: To assign to the same date or period of time; as, to synchronize two events of Greek and Roman history.
Son-in-law: The husband of one's daughter; a man in his relationship to his wife's parents.
Superinduction: The act of superinducing, or the state of being superinduced.
Symmetrian: One eminently studious of symmetry of parts.
&Verbar;Scala: A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of the humerus.
Santalaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Santalaceæ), of which the genus Santalum is the type, and which includes the buffalo nut and a few other North American plants, and many peculiar plants of the southern hemisphere.
Sea-built: Built at, in, or by the sea.
Sweet-scented: Having a sweet scent or smell; fragrant.
Springer: One who, or that which, springs; specifically, one who rouses game.
Spiracle: The nostril, or one of the nostrils, of whales, porpoises, and allied animals.
Solemnly: In a solemn manner; with gravity; seriously; formally.
Stratified: Having its substance arranged in strata, or layers; as, stratified rock.
Silkman: A dealer in silks; a silk mercer.
Siemens-Martin process: See Open-hearth process, etc., under Open.
Stubbed: Reduced to a stub; short and thick, like something truncated; blunt; obtuse.
Spelter: Zinc; -- especially so called in commerce and arts.
Saddlery: The materials for making saddles and harnesses; the articles usually offered for sale in a saddler's shop.
Siliceous: Of or pertaining to silica; containing silica, or partaking of its nature.
Sulphonium: A hypothetical radical, SH3, regarded as the type and nucleus of the sulphines.
Self-accused: Accused by one's self or by one's conscience.
Saccate: Having the form of a sack or pouch; furnished with a sack or pouch, as a petal.
slime mold: An unusual fungus-like protist of the phylum Myxomycota or the class Myxomycetes, having a stage of growth in which it comprises a naked noncellular multinucleate mass of creeping protoplasm having characteristics of both plants and animals; it also has a propagative phase in which it develops fruiting bodies bearing spores; it is sometimes classified as a protist.  It is called also acellular slime mold.
Sulphonal: A substance employed as a hypnotic, produced by the union of mercaptan and acetone.
Sabbatarian: Of or pertaining to the Sabbath, or the tenets of Sabbatarians.
Scribism: The character and opinions of a Jewish scribe in the time of Christ.
Stowaway: One who conceals himself board of a vessel about to leave port, or on a railway train, in order to obtain a free passage.
Stadtholderate: The office or position of a stadtholder.
Strigment: Scraping; that which is scraped off.
Steedless: Having no steed; without a horse.
Supranaturalism: The state of being supernatural; belief in supernatural agency or revelation; supernaturalism.
Supranaturalist: Of or pertaining to supernaturalism; supernaturalistic.
Shareholder: One who holds or owns a share or shares in a joint fund or property.
&Verbar;Stegosaurus: A genus of large Jurassic dinosaurs remarkable for a powerful dermal armature of plates and spines.
&Verbar;Sclerotium: A hardened body formed by certain fungi, as by the Claviceps purpurea, which produces ergot.
Scutiped: Having the anterior surface of the tarsus covered with scutella, or transverse scales, in the form of incomplete bands terminating at a groove on each side; -- said of certain birds.
Struvite: A crystalline mineral found in guano. It is a hydrous phosphate of magnesia and ammonia.
spanner: One who, or that which, spans.
Self-fertilized: Fertilized by pollen from the same flower.
Scorpionwort: A leguminous plant (Ornithopus scorpioides) of Southern Europe, having slender curved pods.
Speck: To cause the presence of specks upon or in, especially specks regarded as defects or blemishes; to spot; to speckle; as, paper specked by impurities in the water used in its manufacture.
Scholiastic: Of or pertaining to a scholiast, or his pursuits.
specific: Of or pertaining to a species; characterizing or constituting a species; possessing the peculiar property or properties of a thing which constitute its species, and distinguish it from other things; as, the specific form of an animal or a plant; the specific qualities of a drug; the specific distinction between virtue and vice.
Sonant: Of or pertaining to sound; sounding.
Sternohyoid: Of or pertaining to the sternum and the hyoid bone or cartilage.
Sechium: The edible fruit of a West Indian plant (Sechium edule) of the Gourd family. It is soft, pear-shaped, and about four inches long, and contains a single large seed. The root of the plant resembles a yam, and is used for food.
Self-registering: Registering itself; -- said of any instrument so contrived as to record its own indications of phenomena, whether continuously or at stated times, as at the maxima and minima of variations; as, a self-registering anemometer or barometer.
Species: Visible or sensible presentation; appearance; a sensible percept received by the imagination; an image.
&Verbar;Sipunculacea: A suborder of Gephyrea, including those which have the body unarmed and the intestine opening anteriorly.
Saintly: Like a saint; becoming a holy person.
Staphylomatous: Of or pertaining to staphyloma; affected with staphyloma.
Synesis: A construction in which adherence to some element in the sense causes a departure from strict syntax, as in “Philip went down to Samaria and preached Christ unto them.”
Sacculo-cochlear: Pertaining to the sacculus and cochlea of the ear.
Schizoc\u0153lous: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a schizocœle.
Stoichiometry: The art or process of calculating the atomic proportions, combining weights, and other numerical relations of chemical elements and their compounds.
Sculp: To sculpture; to carve; to engrave.
&Verbar;Solatium: Anything which alleviates or compensates for suffering or loss; a compensation; esp., an additional allowance, as for injured feelings.
Shatter-brained: Disordered or wandering in intellect; hence, heedless; wild; similar to scatter-brained.
Squint-eyed: Having eyes that squint; having eyes with axes not coincident; cross-eyed; also called squinty-eyed.
Scull: To impel a boat with a scull or sculls.
Spheroidicity: The quality or state of being spheroidal.
&Verbar;Salsola: A genus of plants including the glasswort. See Glasswort.
Subduer: One who, or that which, subdues; a conqueror.
&Verbar;Salix: A genus of trees or shrubs including the willow, osier, and the like, growing usually in wet grounds.
Stentorophonic: Speaking or sounding very loud; stentorian.
Sulphydric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen sulphide, which is regarded as an acid, especially when in solution.
Soporific: A medicine, drug, plant, or other agent that has the quality of inducing sleep; a narcotic.
Spermary: An organ in which spermatozoa are developed; a sperm gland; a testicle.
Stile: A step, or set of steps, for ascending and descending, in passing a fence or wall.
Slavish: Of or pertaining to slaves; such as becomes or befits a slave; servile; excessively laborious; as, a slavish life; a slavish dependance on the great.
Smallsword: A light sword used for thrusting only; especially, the sword worn by civilians of rank in the eighteenth century.
Skiascope: A device for determining the refractive state of the eye by observing the movements of the retinal lights and shadows.
Sesquisulphide: A sulphide, analogous to a sesquioxide, containing three atoms of sulphur to two of the other ingredient; -- formerly called also sesquisulphuret; as, orpiment, As2S3 is arsenic sesquisulphide.
Saxifragaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Saxifragaceæ) of which saxifrage is the type. The order includes also the alum root, the hydrangeas, the mock orange, currants and gooseberries, and many other plants.
Self-partiality: That partiality to himself by which a man overrates his own worth when compared with others.
Sauerkraut: Cabbage cut fine and allowed to ferment in a brine made of its own juice with salt, -- a German dish.
Syllogistic: Of or pertaining to a syllogism; consisting of a syllogism, or of the form of reasoning by syllogisms; as, syllogistic arguments or reasoning.
Sawfly: Any one of numerous species of hymenopterous insects belonging to the family Tenthredinidæ. The female usually has an ovipositor containing a pair of sawlike organs with which she makes incisions in the leaves or stems of plants in which to lay the eggs. The larvæ resemble those of Lepidoptera.
Saurognathous: Having the bones of the palate arranged as in saurians, the vomer consisting of two lateral halves, as in the woodpeckers (Pici).
Sapsago: A kind of Swiss cheese, of a greenish color, flavored with melilot.
Stichometry: Measurement of books by the number of lines which they contain.
Subtractive: Tending, or having power, to subtract.
Swordplayer: A fencer; a gladiator; one who exhibits his skill in the use of the sword.
Survive: To remain alive; to continue to live.
Sterility: The quality or condition of being sterile.
Sanitarian: An advocate of sanitary measures; one especially interested or versed in sanitary measures.
Suretyship: The state of being surety; the obligation of a person to answer for the debt, default, or miscarriage of another.
Spoondrift: Spray blown from the tops of waves during a gale at sea; also, snow driven in the wind at sea; -- written also spindrift.
Saltatory: Leaping or dancing; having the power of, or used in, leaping or dancing.
&Verbar;Supplicat: A petition; esp., a written one, with a certificate that the conditions have been complied with.
Spirulate: Having the color spots, or structural parts, arranged spirally.
&Verbar;Scolopendra: A genus of venomous myriapods including the centipeds. See Centiped.
Spathose: Having a spathe; resembling a spathe; spatheceous; spathal.
Steamboat: A boat or vessel propelled by steam power; -- generally used of river or coasting craft, as distinguished from ocean steamers.
Surcle: A little shoot; a twig; a sucker.
Sanctuarize: To shelter by means of a sanctuary or sacred privileges.
Sparseness: The quality or state of being sparse; as, sparseness of population.
Sarabaite: One of certain vagrant or heretical Oriental monks in the early church.
&Verbar;Sacrum: That part of the vertebral column which is directly connected with, or forms a part of, the pelvis.
Subagent: A person employed by an agent to transact the whole, or a part, of the business intrusted to the latter.
Spectroheliograph: An apparatus for making spectroheliograms, consisting of a spectroscopic camera used in combination with a telescope, and provided with clockwork for moving the  sun's image across the slit.
Sightsman: One who reads or performs music readily at first sight.
Supination: The act of turning the hand palm upward; also, position of the hand with the palm upward.
Silverbill: An Old World finch of the genus Minia, as the M. Malabarica of India, and M. cantans of Africa.
Spectacle: Something exhibited to view; usually, something presented to view as extraordinary, or as unusual and worthy of special notice; a remarkable or noteworthy sight; a show; a pageant; a gazingstock.
Surgery: The art of healing by manual operation; that branch of medical science which treats of manual operations for the healing of diseases or injuries of the body; that branch of medical science which has for its object the cure of local injuries or diseases, as wounds or fractures, tumors, etc., whether by manual operation or by medicines and constitutional treatment.
Semicope: A short cope, or an inferier kind of cope.
Stell: A prop; a support, as for the feet in standing or cilmbing.
Sufferer: One who suffers; one who endures or undergoes suffering; one who sustains inconvenience or loss; as, sufferers by poverty or sickness; men are sufferers by fire or by losses at sea.
Snout: To furnish with a nozzle or point.
Succulence: The quality or condition of being succulent; juiciness; as, the succulence of a peach.
Shrivel: To cause to shrivel or contract; to cause to shrink onto corruptions.
Spader: One who, or that which, spades; specifically, a digging machine.
Scapegrace: A graceless, unprincipled person; one who is wild and reckless.
Suffixion: The act of suffixing, or the state of being suffixed.
Sphenographer: One skilled in sphenography; a sphenographist.
&Verbar;Senza: Without; as, senza stromenti, without instruments.
Stridulatory: Stridulous; able to stridulate; used in stridulating; adapted for stridulation.
Suasion: The act of persuading; persuasion; as, moral suasion.
Sprit: A small boom, pole, or spar, which crosses the sail of a boat diagonally from the mast to the upper aftmost corner, which it is used to extend and elevate.
Scumble: To cover lighty, as a painting, or a drawing, with a thin wash of opaque color, or with color-crayon dust rubbed on with the stump, or to make any similar additions to the work, so as to produce a softened effect.
Stonecutter: One whose occupation is to cut stone; also, a machine for dressing stone.
Spatter: To throw something out of the mouth in a scattering manner; to sputter.
Splendor: Great brightness; brilliant luster; brilliancy; as, the splendor ot the sun.
Scopate: Having the surface closely covered with hairs, like a brush.
Shrike: Any one of numerous species of oscinine birds of the family Laniidæ, having a strong hooked bill, toothed at the tip. Most shrikes are insectivorous, but the common European gray shrike (Lanius excubitor), the great northern shrike (L. borealis), and several others, kill mice, small birds, etc., and often impale them on thorns, and are, on that account called also butcher birds. See under Butcher.
Salol: A white crystalline substance consisting of phenol salicylate.
Shinplaster: Formerly, a jocose term for a bank note greatly depreciated in value; also, for paper money of a denomination less than a dollar.
Superabundance: The quality or state of being superabundant; a superabundant quantity; redundancy; excess.
Solarization: Injury of a photographic picture caused by exposing it for too long a time to the sun's light in the camera; burning; excessive insolation.
Snow banner: A bannerlike stream of snow blown into the air from a mountain peak, often having a pinkish color and extending horizontally for several miles across the sky.
Striate: Marked with striaæ, or fine grooves, or lines of color; showing narrow structural bands or lines; as, a striated crystal; striated muscular fiber.
Stroker: One who strokes; also, one who pretends to cure by stroking.
Scaroid: Of or pertaining to the Scaridæ, a family of marine fishes including the parrot fishes.
Statist: A statesman; a politician; one skilled in government.
Snack: A share; a part or portion; -- obsolete, except in the colloquial phrase, to go snacks, i. e., to share.
Sabian: An adherent of the Sabian religion; a worshiper of the heavenly bodies.
Stair: One step of a series for ascending or descending to a different level; -- commonly applied to those within a building.
Superb: Grand; magnificent; august; stately; as, a superb edifice; a superb colonnade.
&Verbar;Siva: One of the triad of Hindoo gods. He is the avenger or destroyer, and in modern worship symbolizes the reproductive power of nature.
Schoolmaster: The man who presides over and teaches a school; a male teacher of a school.
Seneschalship: The office, dignity, or jurisdiction of a seneschal.
Sensificatory: Susceptible of, or converting into, sensation; as, the sensificatory part of a nervous system.
Stail: A handle, as of a mop; a stale.
Sherry: A Spanish light-colored dry wine, made in Andalusia. As prepared for commerce it is colored a straw color or a deep amber by mixing with it cheap wine boiled down.
Stain: A discoloration by foreign matter; a spot; as, a stain on a garment or cloth.
Strategist: One skilled in strategy, or the science of directing great military movements.
staple gun: A device used to drive a heavy staple{8} through multiple objects, so as to fasten them together; it has a spring mechanism which stores force as a lever is pulled by the operator's hand, and the force is released all at once to drive the staple fully into the object to be fastened.
&Verbar;Sph\u00e6renchyma: Vegetable tissue composed of thin-walled rounded cells, -- a modification of parenchyma.
&Verbar;Serein: A mist, or very fine rain, which sometimes falls from a clear sky a few moments after sunset.
Sunflower: Any plant of the genus Helianthus; -- so called probably from the form and color of its flower, which is large disk with yellow rays. The commonly cultivated sunflower is Helianthus annuus, a native of America.
Smithsonian: Of or pertaining to the Englishman J. L. M. Smithson, or to the national institution of learning which he endowed at Washington, D. C.; as, the Smithsonian Institution; Smithsonian Reports.
Standard: Being, affording, or according with, a standard for comparison and judgment; as, standard time; standard weights and measures; a standard authority as to nautical terms; standard gold or silver.
Secancy: A cutting; an intersection; as, the point of secancy of one line by another.
Semipenniform: Half or partially penniform; as, a semipenniform muscle.
Selenocentric: As seen or estimated from the center of the moon; with the moon central.
Shifter: One who, or that which, shifts; one who plays tricks or practices artifice; a cozener.
Scraggedness: Quality or state of being scragged.
Sangaree: Wine and water sweetened and spiced, -- a favorite West Indian drink.
Stucco: To overlay or decorate with stucco, or fine plaster.
Secondary: One who occupies a subordinate, inferior, or auxiliary place; a delegate or deputy; one who is second or next to the chief officer; as, the secondary, or undersheriff of the city of London.
Super-: A prefix signifying above, over, beyond, and hence often denoting in a superior position, in excess, over and above, in addition, exceedingly; as in superimpose, supersede, supernatural, superabundance.
Sciatically: With, or by means of, sciatica.
Socket: An opening into which anything is fitted; any hollow thing or place which receives and holds something else; as, the sockets of the teeth.
Smattering: A slight, superficial knowledge of something; sciolism.
Single-surfaced: Having one surface; -- said specif. of aëroplanes or aërocurves that are covered with fabric, etc., on only one side.
Secure: To make safe; to relieve from apprehensions of, or exposure to, danger; to guard; to protect.
Seemer: One who seems; one who carries or assumes an appearance or semblance.
Somatology: The doctrine or the science of the general properties of material substances; somatics.
Stinter: One who, or that which, stints.
Soever: A word compounded of so and ever, used in composition with who, what, where, when, how, etc., and indicating any out of all possible or supposable persons, things, places, times, ways, etc. It is sometimes used separate from the pronoun or adverb.
Sperate: Hoped for, or to be hoped for.
Sensual: Pertaining to, consisting in, or affecting, the sense, or bodily organs of perception; relating to, or concerning, the body, in distinction from the spirit.
Stacte: One of the sweet spices used by the ancient Jews in the preparation of incense.  It was perhaps an oil or other form of myrrh or cinnamon, or a kind of storax.
Spoliative: Serving to take away, diminish, or rob; esp. (Med.), serving to diminish sensibly the amount of blood in the body; as, spoliative bloodletting.
Steamboating: The occupation or business of running a steamboat, or of transporting merchandise, passengers, etc., by steamboats.
Self-righteous: Righteous in one's own esteem; pharisaic.
Short-jointed: Having short intervals between the joints; -- said of a plant or an animal, especially of a horse whose pastern is too short.
Sociologist: One who treats of, or devotes himself to, the study of sociology.
Self-positing: The act of disposing or arranging one's self or itself.
Sponger: One who sponges, or uses a sponge.
Scriptory: Of or pertaining to writing; expressed in writing; used in writing; as, scriptory wills; a scriptory reed.
Savory: An aromatic labiate plant (Satureia hortensis), much used in cooking; -- also called summer savory.
Stoutly: In a stout manner; lustily; boldly; obstinately; as, he stoutly defended himself.
Subdelegate: To appoint to act as subdelegate, or as a subordinate; to depete.
Stockdove: A common European wild pigeon (Columba ænas), so called because at one time believed to be the stock of the domestic pigeon, or, according to some, from its breeding in the stocks, or trunks, of trees.
stands: a structure (often made of wood and sometimes temporary) with seats or benches where people can sit to watch an event (such as a game or parade).
Supernacular: Like supernaculum; first-rate; as, a supernacular wine.
Sleepwaking: The state of one mesmerized, or in a partial and morbid sleep.
space probe: an unmanned rocket carrying instruments to explore objects or conditions in outer space; -- used mostly for vehicles travelling beyond the earth's gravitational field, rather than in orbital or suborbital flight.
Sulphurwort: The hog's fennel. See under Fennel.
Squamellate: Furnished or covered with little scales; squamulose.
Spigot: A pin or peg used to stop the vent in a cask; also, the plug of a faucet or cock.
Stack-guard: A covering or protection, as of canvas, for a stack.
Scaldic: Of or pertaining to the scalds of the Norsemen; as, scaldic poetry.
Silver-gray: Having a gray color with a silvery luster; as, silver-gray hair.
Stratagem: An artifice or trick in war for deceiving the enemy; hence, in general, artifice; deceptive device; secret plot; evil machination.
Seer: A person who foresees events; a prophet.
Seep: To run or soak through fine pores and interstices; to ooze.
Shrewd: Inclining to shrew; disposing to curse or scold; hence, vicious; malicious; evil; wicked; mischievous; vexatious; rough; unfair; shrewish.
Stereotype: To prepare for printing in stereotype; to make the stereotype plates of; as, to stereotype the Bible.
Seed: To sprinkle with seed; to plant seeds in; to sow; as, to seed a field.
Subterrane: A cave or room under ground.
Seel: Good fortune; favorable opportunity; prosperity. [Obs.] “So have I seel”.
Seek: To make search or inquiry; to endeavor to make discovery.
Said: Before-mentioned; already spoken of or specified; aforesaid; -- used chiefly in legal style.
Saic: A kind of ketch very common in the Levant, which has neither topgallant sail nor mizzen topsail.
Surbate: To make sore or bruise, as the feet by travel.
Sain: To sanctify; to bless so as to protect from evil influence.
Sail: To pass or move upon, as in a ship, by means of sails; hence, to move or journey upon (the water) by means of steam or other force.
Spoonworm: A gephyrean worm of the genus Thalassema, having a spoonlike proboscis.
Shrill-gorged: Having a throat which produces a shrill note.
Sparada: A small California surf fish (Micrometrus aggregatus); -- called also shiner.
Sanders: An old name of sandalwood, now applied only to the red sandalwood. See under Sandalwood.
Shug: To writhe the body so as to produce friction against one's clothes, as do those who have the itch.
Strenger: the original compar. & superl. of Strong.
Stonebird: The yellowlegs; -- called also stone snipe. See Tattler, 2.
Snowbird: An arctic finch (Plectrophenax nivalis syn. Plectrophanes nivalis) common, in winter, both in Europe and the United States, and often appearing in large flocks during snowstorms.  It is partially white, but variously marked with chestnut and brown.  Called also snow bunting, snowflake, snowfleck, and snowflight.
Sphenoid: A wedge-shaped crystal bounded by four equal isosceles triangles. It is the hemihedral form of a square pyramid.
&Verbar;Santon: A Turkish saint; a kind of dervish, regarded by the people as a saint: also, a hermit.
Sibilance: The quality or state of being sibilant; sibilation.
Stride: The act of stridding; a long step; the space measured by a long step; as, a masculine stride.
Saprophagan: One of a tribe of beetles which feed upon decaying animal and vegetable substances; a carrion beetle.
Savageness: The state or quality of being savage.
Slugging average: a measure of the effectiveness of a batter at reaching base and advancing other runners, calculated as the sum of the number of bases reached on each hit, divided by the total number of times at bat.  A double counts two bases, a triple three, a home run four.  Thus a batter with four singles, two doubles and a triple in 20 official times at bat would have a slugging average of 0.550, and a batting average of 0.350.  Also called slugging percentage.  Compare batting average.
Syncategorematic: Not capable of being used as a term by itself; -- said of words, as an adverb or preposition.
Systole: The shortening of the long syllable.
Supersaturation: The operation of supersaturating, or the state of being supersaturated.
Shrievalty: The office, or sphere of jurisdiction, of a sheriff; sheriffalty.
sandlot: a vacant lot, especially one where children play games.
Substantialness: The quality or state of being substantial; as, the substantialness of a wall or column.
&Verbar;Stadium: A Greek measure of length, being the chief one used for itinerary distances, also adopted by the Romans for nautical and astronomical measurements. It was equal to 600 Greek or 625 Roman feet, or 125 Roman paces, or to 606 feet 9 inches English. This was also called the Olympic stadium, as being the exact length of the foot-race course at Olympia.
&Verbar;Sertularia: A genus of delicate branching hydroids having small sessile hydrothecæ along the sides of the branches.
Shouldered: Having shoulders; -- used in composition; as, a broad-shouldered man.
Suspension: The act of suspending, or the state of being suspended; pendency; as, suspension from a hook.
Spyglass: A small telescope for viewing distant terrestrial objects.
Schoolman: One versed in the niceties of academical disputation or of school divinity.
Shittah: A tree that furnished the precious wood of which the ark, tables, altars, boards, etc., of the Jewish tabernacle were made; -- now believed to have been the wood of the Acacia Seyal, which is hard, fine grained, and yellowish brown in color.
Silverfin: A small North American fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Notropis Whipplei).
Subpurchaser: A purchaser who buys from a purchaser; one who buys at second hand.
Spyboat: A boat sent to make discoveries and bring intelligence.
Slavism: The common feeling and interest of the Slavonic race.
Stinkweed: Stramonium. See Jamestown weed, and Datura.
Schizognath: Any bird with a schizognathous palate.
Sententious: Abounding with sentences, axioms, and maxims; full of meaning; terse and energetic in expression; pithy; as, a sententious style or discourse; sententious truth.
Smasher: One who, or that which, smashes or breaks things to pieces.
Spot cash: Cash paid or ready for payment at once upon delivery of property purchased.
Solely: Singly; alone; only; without another; as, to rest a cause solely one argument; to rely solelyn one's own strength.
Saponify: To convert into soap, as tallow or any fat; hence (Chem.), to subject to any similar process, as that which ethereal salts undergo in decomposition; as, to saponify ethyl acetate.
Stercoranism: The doctrine or belief of the Stercoranists.
Stercoranist: A nickname formerly given to those who held, or were alleged to hold, that the consecrated elements in the eucharist undergo the process of digestion in the body of the recipient.
Stationariness: The quality or state of being stationary; fixity.
&Verbar;Sarigue: A small South American opossum (Didelphys opossum), having four white spots on the face.
&Verbar;Sanhita: A collection of vedic hymns, songs, or verses, forming the first part of each Veda.
Sinology: That branch of systemized knowledge which treats of the Chinese, their language, literature, etc.
Stibine: Antimony hydride, or hydrogen antimonide, a colorless gas produced by the action of nascent hydrogen on antimony. It has a characteristic odor and burns with a characteristic greenish flame. Formerly called also antimoniureted hydrogen.
Shabble: A kind of crooked sword or hanger.
Submedian: Next to the median (on either side); as, the submedian teeth of mollusks.
Sapwood: The alburnum, or part of the wood of any exogenous tree next to the bark, being that portion of the tree through which the sap flows most freely; -- distinguished from heartwood.
Salamstone: A kind of blue sapphire brought from Ceylon.
&Verbar;Scyphistoma: The young attached larva of Discophora in the stage when it resembles a hydroid, or actinian.
Spirometry: The act or process of measuring the chest capacity by means of a spirometer.
Satanism: The evil and malicious disposition of Satan; a diabolical spirit.
Set-fair: In plastering, a particularly good troweled surface.
Saiva: One of an important religious sect in India which regards Siva with peculiar veneration.
Sliver: A long piece cut or rent off; a sharp, slender fragment, as of glass; a splinter.
Self-colored: Being of a single color; -- applied to flowers, animals, and textile fabrics.
Solemn: Marked with religious rites and pomps; enjoined by, or connected with, religion; sacred.
Stunt: A feat hard to perform; an act which is striking for the skill, strength, or the like, required to do it; a feat.
Stokehold: The space, or any of the spaces, in front of the boilers of a ship, from which the furnaces are fed; the stokehole of a ship; also, a room containing a ship's boilers; as, forced draft with  closed stokehold; -- called also, in American ships, fireroom.
Stokehole: The mouth to the grate of a furnace; also, the space in front of the furnace, where the stokers stand.
Sea-island: Of or pertaining to certain islands along the coast of South Carolina and Georgia; as, sea-island cotton, a superior cotton of long fiber produced on those islands.
&Verbar;Se\u00f1orita: A Spanish title of courtesy given to a young lady; Miss; also, a young lady.
Suture: The act of sewing; also, the line along which two things or parts are sewed together, or are united so as to form a seam, or that which resembles a seam.
Stinger: One who, or that which, stings.
Sulphoarsenic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, sulphur and arsenic; -- said of an acid which is the same as arsenic acid with the substitution of sulphur for oxygen.
Spider web: The silken web which is formed by most kinds of spiders, particularly the web spun to entrap their prey; -- also called cobweb. See Geometric spider, Triangle spider, under Geometric, and Triangle.
Self-indignation: Indignation at one's own character or actions.
Solitude: state of being alone, or withdrawn from society; a lonely life; loneliness.
Scuffle: A rough, haphazard struggle, or trial of strength; a disorderly wrestling at close quarters.
Self-devoted: Devoted in person, or by one's own will.
Stiletto: To stab or kill with a stiletto.
Schorly: Pertaining to, or containing, schorl; as, schorly granite.
Severalty: A state of separation from the rest, or from all others; a holding by individual right.
Silentiary: One appointed to keep silence and order in court; also, one sworn not to divulge secrets of state.
Stilbite: A common mineral of the zeolite family, a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime, usually occurring in sheaflike aggregations of crystals, also in radiated masses. It is of a white or yellowish color, with pearly luster on the cleavage surface. Called also desmine.
Suboperculum: The lower opercular bone in fishes.
Spondee: A poetic foot of two long syllables, as in the Latin word lēgēs.
Syenite: Orig., a rock composed of quartz, hornblende, and feldspar, anciently quarried at Syene, in Upper Egypt, and now called granite.
&Verbar;S\u00e9ance: A session, as of some public body; especially, a meeting of spiritualists to receive spirit communications, so called.
Striped: Having stripes of different colors; streaked.
Sales tax: a tax imposed upon the retail sale of goods or the sale of services, usually collected by the seller at the time of purchase; -- it is typically calculated as a percentage of the price of the object sold, being commonly from 3% to 7% of the base price.
Steading: The barns, stables, cattle-yards, etc., of a farm; -- called also onstead, farmstead, farm offices, or farmery.
Speculator: One who speculates. Specifically: (a) An observer; a contemplator; hence, a spy; a watcher.
Sirenia: An order of large aquatic herbivorous mammals, including the manatee, dugong, rytina, and several fossil genera.
Saxonic: Relating to the Saxons or Anglo- Saxons.
Security: The condition or quality of being secure; secureness.
Smuggle: To import or export in violation of the customs laws.
Scalebeam: The lever or beam of a balance; the lever of a platform scale, to which the poise for weighing is applied.
&Verbar;Sandix: A kind of minium, or red lead, made by calcining carbonate of lead, but inferior to true minium.
Shabby: Torn or worn to rage; poor; mean; ragged.
slip clutch: a friction clutch that will slip when the torque is too great
Scanty: Wanting amplitude or extent; narrow; small; not abundant.
Sigh: A deep and prolonged audible inspiration or respiration of air, as when fatigued or grieved; the act of sighing.
&Verbar;Sudra: The lowest of the four great castes among the Hindoos. See Caste.
Snaggy: Full of snags; full of short, rough branches or sharp points; abounding with knots.
Sconce: To shut up in a sconce; to imprison; to insconce.
Sporangiophore: The axis or receptacle in certain ferns (as Trichomanes), which bears the sporangia.
Speak: To utter with the mouth; to pronounce; to utter articulately, as human beings.
Stare: The act of staring; a fixed look with eyes wide open.
Subdivide: To be, or to become, subdivided.
Secureness: The condition or quality of being secure; exemption from fear; want of vigilance; security.
Spur: To spur on one's horse; to travel with great expedition; to hasten; hence, to press forward in any pursuit.
Standel: A young tree, especially one reserved when others are cut.
Sensationalism: The doctrine held by Condillac, and by some ascribed to Locke, that our ideas originate solely in sensation, and consist of sensations transformed; sensualism; -- opposed to intuitionalism, and rationalism.
Stock-blind: Blind as a stock; wholly blind.
Socratic: Of or pertaining to Socrates, the Grecian sage and teacher. (b. c. 469-399), or to his manner of teaching and philosophizing.
Somnambulation: The act of walking in sleep, called also sleepwalking.
Spatangoid: Of or pertaining to the Spatangoidea.
Siderographic: Of or pertaining to siderography; executed by engraved plates of steel; as, siderographic art; siderographic impressions.
Sunglass: A convex lens of glass for producing heat by converging the sun's rays into a focus.
Squeak: A sharp, shrill, disagreeable sound suddenly uttered, either of the human voice or of any animal or instrument, such as is made by carriage wheels when dry, by the soles of leather shoes, or by a pipe or reed.
Such: Of that kind; of the like kind; like; resembling; similar; as, we never saw such a day; -- followed by that or as introducing the word or proposition which defines the similarity, or the standard of comparison; as, the books are not such that I can recommend them, or, not such as I can recommend; these apples are not such as those we saw yesterday; give your children such precepts as tend to make them better.
Suck: The act of drawing with the mouth.
Sensationalist: An advocate of, or believer in, philosophical sensationalism.
Squeal: A shrill, sharp, somewhat prolonged cry.
&Verbar;Sarcorhamphi: A division of raptorial birds comprising the vultures.
Smelling: The act of one who smells.
Sigillative: Fit to seal; belonging to a seal; composed of wax.
Staddle: To leave the staddles, or saplings, of, as a wood when it is cut.
Situation: Manner in which an object is placed; location, esp. as related to something else; position; locality site; as, a house in a pleasant situation.
Swartness: The quality or state of being swart.
Senary: Of six; belonging to six; containing six.
Suicidism: The quality or state of being suicidal, or self-murdering.
Steaminess: The quality or condition of being steamy; vaporousness; mistiness.
Scourer: One who, or that which, scours.
Subcarboniferous: Of or pertaining to the lowest division of the Carboniferous formations underlying the proper coal measures. It was a marine formation characterized in general by beds of limestone.
Scapholunar: Of or pertaining to the scaphoid and lunar bones of the carpus.
Synchronism: The concurrence of events in time; simultaneousness.
Scleroid: Having a hard texture, as nutshells.
Silkworm: The larva of any one of numerous species of bombycid moths, which spins a large amount of strong silk in constructing its cocoon before changing to a pupa.
Shive: A slice; as, a shive of bread.
&Verbar;Sault: A rapid in some rivers; as, the Sault Ste. Marie.
&Verbar;Staminodium: An abortive stamen, or any organ modified from an abortive stamen.
Squierie: A company of squires; the whole body of squires.
Scotist: A follower of (Joannes) Duns Scotus, the Franciscan scholastic (d. 1308), who maintained certain doctrines in philosophy and theology, in opposition to the Thomists, or followers of Thomas Aquinas, the Dominican scholastic.
Sideflash: A disruptive discharge between a conductor traversed by an oscillatory current of high frequency (as lightning) and neighboring masses of metal, or between different parts of the same conductor.
Seclusion: The act of secluding, or the state of being secluded; separation from society or connection; a withdrawing; privacy; as, to live in seclusion.
Semitangent: The tangent of half an arc.
Swivel: To swing or turn, as on a pin or pivot.
Scotoscope: An instrument that discloses objects in the dark or in a faint light.
&Verbar;Septulum: A little septum; a division between small cavities or parts.
Sapucaia: A Brazilian tree. See Lecythis, and Monkey-pot.
Sea cucumber: Any large holothurian, especially one of those belonging to the genus Pentacta, or Cucumaria, as the common American and European species. (P. frondosa).
Sickleman: One who uses a sickle; a reaper.
Sunrise: The first appearance of the sun above the horizon in the morning; more generally, the time of such appearance, whether in fair or cloudy weather; as, to begin work at sunrise.
Superficiality: The quality or state of being superficial; also, that which is superficial.
Saintlike: Resembling a saint; suiting a saint; becoming a saint; saintly.
South southerly: the old squaw; -- so called in imitation of its cry. Called also southerly, and southerland. See under Old.
Scranch: To grind with the teeth, and with a crackling sound; to craunch.
Siphoniferous: Siphon-bearing, as the shell of the nautilus and other cephalopods.
Sabrina work: A variety of appliqué work for quilts, table covers, etc.
&Verbar;Synclinorium: A mountain range owing its origin to the progress of a geosynclinal, and ending in a catastrophe of displacement and upturning.
Supremacy: The state of being supreme, or in the highest station of power; highest or supreme authority or power; as, the supremacy of a king or a parliament.
Semiangle: The half of a given, or measuring, angle.
Snipebill: A plane for cutting deep grooves in moldings.
Sexfid: Six-cleft; as, a sexfid calyx or nectary.
Stratagemical: Containing stratagem; as, a stratagemical epistle.
Stem-clasping: Embracing the stem with its base; amplexicaul, as a leaf or petiole.
Stramash: A turmoil; a broil; a fray; a fight.
Supralapsarian: Of or pertaining to the Supralapsarians, or their doctrine.
Series turns: The turns in a series circuit.
Sententiary: One who read lectures, or commented, on the Sentences of Peter Lombard, Bishop of Paris (1159-1160), a school divine.
Sugarplum: A kind of candy or sweetneat made up in small balls or disks.
sentential: Comprising sentences; as, a sentential translation.
&Verbar;Storthing: The Parliament of Norway, chosen by indirect election once in three years, but holding annual sessions.
