&Verbar;Sachet: A scent bag, or perfume cushion, to be laid among handkerchiefs, garments, etc., to perfume them.
Synomocy: Sworn brotherhood; a society in ancient Greece nearly resembling a modern political club.
Silicify: To become converted into silica, or to be impregnated with silica.
Synochal: Of or pertaining to synocha; like synocha.
Satellitious: Pertaining to, or consisting of, satellites.
Sph\u00e6rospore: One of the nonsexual spores found in red algæ; a tetraspore.
Similar: That which is similar to, or resembles, something else, as in quality, form, etc.
Sprod: A salmon in its second year.
Sylviculturist: One who cultivates forest trees, especially as a business.
Systematism: The reduction of facts or principles to a system.
Sideroscope: An instrument for detecting small quantities of iron in any substance by means of a very delicate combination of magnetic needles.
Salic: Of or pertaining to the Salian Franks, or to the Salic law so called.
Stab culture: A culture made by inoculating a solid medium, as gelatin, with the puncture of a needle or wire; -- called also stab. The growths are usually of characteristic form.
Stegnotic: Tending to render costive, or to diminish excretions or discharges generally.
Saccharonic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, saccharone; specifically, designating an unstable acid which is obtained from saccharone (a) by hydration, and forms a well-known series of salts.
Suillage: A drain or collection of filth.
&Verbar;Spirillum: A genus of common motile microörganisms (Spirobacteria) having the form of spiral-shaped filaments. One species is said to be the cause of relapsing fever.
Systematist: One who forms a system, or reduces to system.
Suburban: One who dwells in the suburbs.
Shiraz: A kind of Persian wine; -- so called from the place whence it is brought.
Subsesqui-: A prefix (also used adjectively) denoting the combination of constituents (especially electro-negative and electro-positive bodies) in the proportion of two to three; as, a subsesqui acetate, i. e., a salt having two equivalents of acetic acid to three of the base.
Scarcement: An offset where a wall or bank of earth, etc., retreats, leaving a shelf or footing.
Semi-Arianism: The doctrines or tenets of the Semi-Arians.
Spread: imp. & p. p. of Spread, v.
Sylvicoline: Of or pertaining to the family of warblers (Sylvicolidæ). See Warbler.
Supra-esophagal: Situated above, or on the dorsal side of, the esophagus; as, the supra-esophageal ganglion of Crustacea.
Sea-ear: Any species of ear-shaped shells of the genus Haliotis. See Abalone.
Scotticize: To cause to become like the Scotch; to make Scottish.
spannishing: The full blooming of a flower.
Strike zone: the area above home plate where, if a pitched ball passes through and is not hit by the batter, the pitch counts as a strike.  Specifically, it is directly above home plate and at a height from the knees to the shoulders of the batter.
Screwing: a. & n. from Screw, v. t.
Septempartite: Divided nearly to the base into seven parts; as, a septempartite leaf.
&Verbar;Squama: A scale cast off from the skin; a thin dry shred consisting of epithelium.
&Verbar;Stola: A long garment, descending to the ankles, worn by Roman women.
Sisyphus: A king of Corinth, son of Æolus, famed for his cunning. He was killed by Theseus, and in the lower world was condemned by Pluto to roll to the top of a hill a huge stone, which constantly rolled back again, making his task incessant.
Sheathy: Forming or resembling a sheath or case.
Self-seeking: The act or habit of seeking one's own interest or happiness; selfishness.
Sourish: Somewhat sour; moderately acid; as, sourish fruit; a sourish taste.
Subtypical: Deviating somewhat from the type of a species, genus, or other group; slightly aberrant.
Slatterpouch: A dance or game played by boys, requiring active exercise.
&Verbar;Sigla: The signs, abbreviations, letters, or characters standing for words, shorthand, etc., in ancient manuscripts, or on coins, medals, etc.
&Verbar;Sagitta: A small constellation north of Aquila; the Arrow.
&Verbar;Saurur\u00e6: An extinct order of birds having a long vertebrated tail with quills along each side of it. Archæopteryx is the type. See Archæopteryx, and Odontornithes.
Suety: Consisting of, or resembling, suet; as, a suety substance.
Scleroderm: One of a tribe of plectognath fishes (Sclerodermi) having the skin covered with hard scales, or plates, as the cowfish and the trunkfish.
&Verbar;Spica: A kind of bandage passing, by successive turns and crosses, from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance to a spike of a barley.
Sorrage: The blades of green or barley.
Saccharimeter: An instrument for ascertaining the quantity of saccharine matter in any solution, as the juice of a plant, or brewers' and distillers' worts.
Setiparous: Producing setæ; -- said of the organs from which the setæ of annelids arise.
Suprafoliaceous: Inserted into the stem above the leaf, petiole, or axil, as a peduncle or flower.
Shortstop: The player stationed in the field bewtween the second and third bases.
Setting-up exercise: Any one of a series of gymnastic exercises used, as in drilling recruits, for the purpose of giving an erect carriage, supple muscles, and an easy control of the limbs.
&Verbar;Stufa: A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
Siphonic: Of or pertaining to a siphon.
Stenograph: A production of stenography; anything written in shorthand.
Self-defensive: Defending, or tending to defend, one's own person, property, or reputation.
Spherulite: A minute spherical crystalline body having a radiated structure, observed in some vitreous volcanic rocks, as obsidian and pearlstone.
Sandglass: An instrument for measuring time by the running of sand. See Hourglass.
Seed-lac: A species of lac. See the Note under Lac.
Septfoil: A European herb, the tormentil. See Tormentil.
Slater: Any terrestrial isopod crustacean of the genus Porcellio and allied genera; a sow bug.
Stepper: One who, or that which, steps; as, a quick stepper.
Schetic: Of or pertaining to the habit of the body; constitutional.
Sea scorpion: A European sculpin (Cottus scorpius) having the head armed with short spines.
Stabbingly: By stabbing; with intent to injure covertly.
Scillain: A glucoside extracted from squill (Scilla) as a light porous substance.
Sufferance: The state of suffering; the bearing of pain; endurance.
Sea-roving: Cruising at random on the ocean.
Subornation: The act of suborning; the crime of procuring a person to take such a false oath as constitutes perjury.
Sego: A liliaceous plant (Calochortus Nuttallii) of Western North America, and its edible bulb; -- so called by the Ute Indians and the Mormons.
Sincerity: The quality or state of being sincere; honesty of mind or intention; freedom from simulation, hypocrisy, disguise, or false pretense; sincereness.
Slot: The track of a deer; hence, a track of any kind.
Slice: To cut into thin pieces, or to cut off a thin, broad piece from.
Slop: Any kind of outer garment made of linen or cotton, as a night dress, or a smock frock.
Sermonize: To preach or discourse to; to affect or influence by means of a sermon or of sermons.
Sake: a traditional alcoholic drink of Japan. It is made from rice.
Suggestive medicine: Treatment by commands or positive statements addressed to a more or less hypnotized patient.
Selenium: A nonmetallic element of the sulphur group of atomic number 34, analogous to sulphur in its compounds. It is found in small quantities with sulphur and some sulphur ores, and obtained in the free state as a dark reddish powder or crystalline mass, or as a dark metallic-looking substance. It exhibits under the action of light a remarkable variation in electric conductivity, and is used in certain electric apparatus. Symbol Se. Atomic weight 78.96.
Slick: A slick, or smooth and slippery, surface or place; a sleek.
&Verbar;Scorpiones: A division of arachnids comprising the scorpions.
Silvery: Resembling, or having the luster of, silver; grayish white and lustrous; of a mild luster; bright.
Shingles: A kind of herpes (Herpes zoster) which spreads half way around the body like a girdle, and is usually attended with violent neuralgic pain.
Stipitate: Supported by a stipe; elevated on a stipe, as the fronds of most ferns, or the pod of certain cruciferous plants.
Slog: to walk heavily; to plod; to walk through resisting terrain, as in mud.
Superfluous: More than is wanted or is sufficient; rendered unnecessary by superabundance; unnecessary; useless; excessive; as, a superfluous price.
Squarer: One who, or that which, squares.
Subzygomatic: Situated under the zygoma or zygomatic process.
&Verbar;Stomatoda: A division of Protozoa in which a mouthlike opening exists.
Swiftly: In a swift manner; with quick motion or velocity; fleetly.
spin the plate: a game in which something round (as a plate) is spun on edge and the name of a player is called; the named player must catch the spinning object before it falls or pay a forfeit.
Soubrette: A female servant or attendant; specifically, as a term of the theater, a lady's maid, in comedies, who acts the part of an intrigante; a meddlesome, mischievous female servant or young woman.
&Verbar;Scintilla: A spark; the least particle; an iota; a tittle.
&Verbar;Sforzando: Forcing or forced; -- a direction placed over a note, to signify that it must be executed with peculiar emphasis and force; -- marked fz (an abbreviation of forzando), sf, sfz, or &unr_;.
Signal: To communicate by signals; as, to signal orders.
Soul: To indue with a soul; to furnish with a soul or mind.
Soup: To sweep. See Sweep, and Swoop.
Sour: To become sour; to turn from sweet to sour; as, milk soon sours in hot weather; a kind temper sometimes sours in adversity.
Sidewalk: A walk for foot passengers at the side of a street or road; a foot pavement.
Shipworm: Any long, slender, worm-shaped bivalve mollusk of Teredo and allied genera. The shipworms burrow in wood, and are destructive to wooden ships, piles of wharves, etc. See Teredo.
Somatotropism: A directive influence exercised by a mass of matter upon growing organs.
&Verbar;Saengerbund: A singers' union; an association of singers or singing clubs, esp. German.
Self-posited: Disposed or arranged by an action originating in one's self or in itself.
Sultanship: The office or dignity of a sultan.
Shad-waiter: A lake whitefish; the roundfish. See Roundfish.
Snobbery: The quality of being snobbish; snobbishness.
Subtilize: To refine in argument; to make very nice distinctions.
Surmark: A mark made on the molds of a ship, when building, to show where the angles of the timbers are to be placed.
Saltbush: An Australian plant (Atriplex nummularia) of the Goosefoot family.
Scolecite: A zeolitic mineral occuring in delicate radiating groups of white crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime. Called also lime mesotype.
Sonance: A sound; a tune; as, to sound the tucket sonance.
Sabianism: The doctrine of the Sabians; the Sabian religion; that species of idolatry which consists in worshiping the sun, moon, and stars; heliolatry.
Sustainer: One who, or that which, sustains.
Sea king: One of the leaders among the Norsemen who passed their lives in roving the seas in search of plunder and adventures; a Norse pirate chief. See the Note under Viking.
Spongiolite: One of the microscopic siliceous spicules which occur abundantly in the texture of sponges, and are sometimes found fossil, as in flints.
squeteague: An American sciænoid fish (Cynoscion regalis), abundant on the Atlantic coast of the United States, and much valued as a food fish.  It is of a bright silvery color, with iridescent reflections.  Called also weakfish, squitee, chickwit, and sea trout.  The spotted squeteague (Cynoscion nebulosus) of the Southern United States is a similar fish, but the back and upper fins are spotted with black.  It is called also spotted weakfish and squit, and, locally, sea trout, and sea salmon.  See also under squitee.
Simple-minded: Artless; guileless; simple-hearted; undesigning; unsuspecting; devoid of duplicity.
Scauper: A tool with a semicircular edge, -- used by engravers to clear away the spaces between the lines of an engraving.
Scorer: One who, or that which, scores.
Sleeky: Of a sleek, or smooth, and glossy appearance.
Shude: The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterate oil cake, or linseed cake.
Sophomore: One belonging to the second of the four classes in an American college, or one next above a freshman.
Subside: To sink or fall to the bottom; to settle, as lees.
Stayship: A remora, -- fabled to stop ships by attaching itself to them.
Solomon: One of the kings of Israel, noted for his superior wisdom and magnificent reign; hence, a very wise man.
Sericin: A gelatinous nitrogenous material extracted from crude silk and other similar fiber by boiling water; -- called also silk gelatin.
Shovel: To take up and throw with a shovel; as, to shovel earth into a heap, or into a cart, or out of a pit.
Sultana: The wife of a sultan; a sultaness.
&Verbar;Stipes: The second joint of a maxilla of an insect or a crustacean.
Stepstone: A stone laid before a door as a stair to rise on in entering the house.
Something: In some degree; somewhat; to some extent; at some distance.
Scissors-tailed: Having the outer feathers much the longest, the others decreasing regularly to the median ones.
Scortatory: Pertaining to lewdness or fornication; lewd.
Sinch: To gird with a sinch; to tighten the sinch or girth of (a saddle); as, to sinch up a sadle.
Since: Seeing that; because; considering; -- formerly followed by that.
Saint-Simonian: A follower of the Count de St. Simon, who died in 1825, and who maintained that the principle of property held in common, and the just division of the fruits of common labor among the members of society, are the true remedy for the social evils which exist.
Skepticize: To doubt; to pretend to doubt of everything.
Self-color: A color not mixed or variegated.
Sapodilla: A tall, evergeen, tropical American tree (Achras Sapota); also, its edible fruit, the sapodilla plum.
Study: To apply the mind to; to read and examine for the purpose of learning and understanding; as, to study law or theology; to study languages.
Solenaceous: Of or pertaining to the solens or family Solenidæ.
Smock: To provide with, or clothe in, a smock or a smock frock.
Stull: A framework of timber covered with boards to support rubbish; also, a framework of boards to protect miners from falling stones.
Sacrifice: To make offerings to God, or to a deity, of things consumed on the altar; to offer sacrifice.
Syllabism: The expressing of the sounds of a language by syllables, rather than by an alphabet or by signs for words.
Syllabist: One who forms or divides words into syllables, or is skilled in doing this.
Spermospore: The male germinal or seminal cell, from the breaking up of which the spermoblasts are formed and ultimately the spermatozoids; a spermatospore.
Slurred: Marked with a slur; performed in a smooth, gliding style, like notes marked with a slur.
Southing: Tendency or progress southward; as, the southing of the sun.
Stulp: A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.
Salina period: The period in which the American Upper Silurian system, containing the brine-producing rocks of central New York, was formed. See the Chart of Geology.
Stercoraceous: Of or pertaining to dung; partaking of the nature of, or containing, dung.
Spectroscope: An optical instrument for forming and examining spectra (as that of solar light, or those produced by flames in which different substances are volatilized), so as to determine, from the position of the spectral lines, the composition of the substance.
Supplial: The act of supplying; a supply.
Sinapoleic: Of or pertaining to mustard oil; specifically, designating an acid of the oleic acid series said to occur in mistard oil.
Spectroscopy: the art and science dealing with the use of a spectroscope, and the production and analysis of spectra; the action of using a spectroscope.
Suspiral: A breathing hole; a vent or ventiduct.
Smock-faced: Having a feminine countenance or complexion; smooth-faced; girlish.
&Verbar;Sublingua: A process or fold below the tongue in some animals.
Swathe: A bandage; a band; a swath.
Softa: Any one attached to a Mohammedan mosque, esp. a student of the higher branches of theology in a mosque school.
Subventionize: To come to the aid of; to subsidize; to support.
Sturgeon: Any one of numerous species of large cartilaginous ganoid fishes belonging to Acipenser and allied genera of the family Acipenseridæ. They run up rivers to spawn, and are common on the coasts and in the large rivers and lakes of North America, Europe, and Asia.  Caviar is prepared from the roe, and isinglass from the air bladder.
Sensitize: To render sensitive, or susceptible of being easily acted on by the actinic rays of the sun; as, sensitized paper or plate.
Sauterelle: An instrument used by masons and others to trace and form angles.
Sunproof: Impervious to the rays of the sun.
Stimulation: The act of stimulating, or the state of being stimulated.
Salamandroid: Like or pertaining to the salamanders.
Skylight: A window placed in the roof of a building, in the ceiling of a room, or in the deck of a ship, for the admission of light from above.
Scarificator: An instrument, principally used in cupping, containing several lancets moved simultaneously by a spring, for making slight incisions.
Sea gown: A gown or frock with short sleeves, formerly worn by mariners.
Sea corn: A yellow cylindrical mass of egg capsules of certain species of whelks (Buccinum), which resembles an ear of maize.
Self-examination: An examination into one's own state, conduct, and motives, particularly in regard to religious feelings and duties.
Seerfish: A scombroid food fish of Madeira (Cybium Commersonii).
Shunless: Not to be shunned; inevitable; unavoidable.
Sci\u00e6noid: Of or pertaining to the Sciænidæ, a family of carnivorous marine fishes which includes the meagre (Sciaena umbra or Sciaena aquila), and fish of the drum and croaker families.  The croaker is so called because it may make a croaking noise by use of its bladder; the Atlantic croaker (Micropogonias undulatus, formerly Micropogon undulatus) and the squeteague are a members of the croaker family, and the kingfish is a drum.
Shekel: An ancient weight and coin used by the Jews and by other nations of the same stock.
Studfish: Any one of several species of small American minnows of the genus Fundulus, as F. catenatus.
Spider stitch: A stitch in lace making used to fill in open spaces with threads resembling a cobweb.
Singer: One who sings; especially, one whose profession is to sing.
&Verbar;Silicoidea: An extensive order of Porifera, which includes those that have the skeleton composed mainly of siliceous fibers or spicules.
Subahdary: The office or jurisdiction of a subahdar.
Sloven: A man or boy habitually negligent of neathess and order; -- the correlative term to slattern, or slut.
Serenata: A piece of vocal music, especially one on an amoreus subject; a serenade.
Saltness: The quality or state of being salt, or state of being salt, or impregnated with salt; salt taste; as, the saltness of sea water.
Shoehorn: to squeeze or force into a tight-fitting space, with or as though with a shoehorn; -- often used figuratively.
&Verbar;Strepsiptera: A group of small insects having the anterior wings rudimentary, and in the form of short and slender twisted appendages, while the posterior ones are large and membranous. They are parasitic in the larval state on bees, wasps, and the like; -- called also Rhipiptera. See Illust. under Rhipipter.
Stillion: A stand, as for casks or vats in a brewery, or for pottery while drying.
Saphenous: Manifest; -- applied to the two principal superficial veins of the lower limb of man.
Strawy: Of or pertaining to straw; made of, or resembling, straw.
Structurist: One who forms structures; a builder; a constructor.
Serum: The watery portion of certain animal fluids, as blood, milk, etc.
Space: To arrange or adjust the spaces in or between; as, to space words, lines, or letters.
Senile: Of or pertaining to old age; proceeding from, or characteristic of, old age; affected with the infirmities of old age; as, senile weakness.
Superposition: The act of superposing, or the state of being superposed; as, the superposition of rocks; the superposition of one plane figure on another, in geometry.
Syntonin: A proteid substance (acid albumin) formed from the albuminous matter of muscle by the action of dilute acids; -- formerly called musculin. See Acid albumin, under Albumin.
Solidity: The state or quality of being solid; density; consistency, -- opposed to fluidity; compactness; fullness of matter, -- opposed to openness or hollowness; strength; soundness, -- opposed to weakness or instability; the primary quality or affection of matter by which its particles exclude or resist all others; hardness; massiveness.
Slider: One who, or that which, slides; especially, a sliding part of an instrument or machine.
Suburethral: Situated under the urethra, or under its orifice.
Streaming: The act or operation of that which streams; the act of that which sends forth, or which runs in, streams.
Sentiently: In a sentient or perceptive way.
Superaddition: The act of adding something in excess or something extraneous; also, something which is added in excess or extraneously.
Subsidence: The act or process of subsiding.
sloat: A narrow piece of timber which holds together large pieces; a slat; as, the sloats of a cart.
START: A Treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union which provided for stepwise reductions in the number of nuclear weapons possessed by each country.
Sensibility: The quality or state of being sensible, or capable of sensation; capacity to feel or perceive.
Skein: A flight of wild fowl (wild geese or the like).
Satisfactory: Giving or producing satisfaction; yielding content; especially, relieving the mind from doubt or uncertainty, and enabling it to rest with confidence; sufficient; as, a satisfactory account or explanation.
Serration: Condition of being serrate; formation in the shape of a saw.
Sigmoid: Curved in two directions, like the letter S, or the Greek ς.
Stercorary: A place, properly secured from the weather, for containing dung.
Summer-fallow: To plow and work in summer, in order to prepare for wheat or other crop; to plow and let lie fallow.
Stillhouse: A house in which distillation is carried on; a distillery.
Sulphocyanate: A salt of sulphocyanic acid; -- also called thiocyanate, and formerly inaccurately sulphocyanide.
Subarctic: Approximately arctic; belonging to a region just without the arctic circle.
Stuffer: One who, or that which, stuffs.
Sacramentalism: The doctrine and use of sacraments; attachment of excessive importance to sacraments.
&Verbar;Sao: Any marine annelid of the genus Hyalinæcia, especially H. tubicola of Europe, which inhabits a transparent movable tube resembling a quill in color and texture.
&Verbar;Sal: An East Indian timber tree (Shorea robusta), much used for building purposes. It is of a light brown color, close-grained, heavy, and durable.
Strengthful: Abounding in strength; full of strength; strong.
Stretch: Act of stretching, or state of being stretched; reach; effort; struggle; strain; as, a stretch of the limbs; a stretch of the imagination.
spacecraft: a vehicle capable of travelling in or into outer space; at present, all such vehicles are powered by rocket engine.
Spleget: A cloth dipped in a liquid for washing a sore.
Stagnant: That stagnates; not flowing; not running in a current or steam; motionless; hence, impure or foul from want of motion; as, a stagnant lake or pond; stagnant blood in the veins.
Sacculo-utricular: Pertaining to the sacculus and utriculus of the ear.
&Verbar;Spiritoso: Spirited; spiritedly; -- a direction to perform a passage in an animated, lively manner.
Sacramentalist: One who holds the doctrine of the real objective presence of Christ's body and blood in the holy eucharist.
Spectroscopic: Of or pertaining to a spectroscope, or spectroscopy.
Siphon: To convey, or draw off, by means of a siphon, as a liquid from one vessel to another at a lower level.
Sorel: A young buck in the third year. See the Note under Buck.
Sopite: To lay asleep; to put to sleep; to quiet.
Sanative: Having the power to cure or heal; healing; tending to heal; sanatory.
Service station: a business where automobiles may be serviced and repaired, usually also having a gasoline vending apparatus, in which case it is also called a gas station or gasoline station.  Facilities for repair of automobiles but without a gasoline dispensing function are commonly called repair shops.
Suppalpation: The act of enticing by soft words; enticement.
Superfetation: The formation of a fetus at the result of an impregnation occurring after another impregnation but before the birth of the offspring produced by it. This is possible only when there is a double uterus, or where menstruation persists up to the time of the second impregnation.
&Verbar;Synizesis: An obliteration of the pupil of the eye.
Saligenin: A phenol alcohol obtained, by the decomposition of salicin, as a white crystalline substance; -- called also hydroxy-benzyl alcohol.
&Verbar;Synanthesis: The simultaneous maturity of the anthers and stigmas of a blossom.
Stylo-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the styloid process of the temporal bone; as, stylohyal, stylomastoid, stylomaxillary.
Swainish: Pertaining to, or resembling, a swain; rustic; ignorant.
Selvagee: A skein or hank of rope yarns wound round with yarns or marline, -- used for stoppers, straps, etc.
Seminymph: The pupa of insects which undergo only a slight change in passing to the imago state.
Sheepfold: A fold or pen for sheep; a place where sheep are collected or confined.
&Verbar;Sula: A genus of sea birds including the booby and the common gannet.
Staid: Sober; grave; steady; sedate; composed; regular; not wild, volatile, flighty, or fanciful.
&Verbar;Stegnosis: Constipation; also, constriction of the vessels or ducts.
Sphygmographic: Relating to, or produced by, a sphygmograph; as, a sphygmographic tracing.
Stultification: The act of stultifying, or the state of being stultified.
Strathspey: A lively Scottish dance, resembling the reel, but slower; also, the tune.
Stagehouse: A house where a stage regularly stops for passengers or a relay of horses.
Scaleback: Any one of numerous species of marine annelids of the family Polynoidæ, and allies, which have two rows of scales, or elytra, along the back. See Illust. under Chætopoda.
Sprocket: A tooth or projection, as on the periphery of a wheel, shaped so as to engage with a chain.
Socinian: One of the followers of Socinus; a believer in Socinianism.
Single tax: A tax levied upon land alone, irrespective of improvements, -- advocated by certain economists as the sole source of public revenue.
Sustain: One who, or that which, upholds or sustains; a sustainer.
Stenoderm: Any species of bat belonging to the genus Stenoderma, native of the West Indies and South America. These bats have a short or rudimentary tail and a peculiarly shaped nose membrane.
Sufflate: To blow up; to inflate; to inspire.
Sporification: Spore formation. See Spore formation (b), under Spore.
Sneak current: A current which, though too feeble to blow the usual fuse or to injure at once telegraph or telephone instruments, will in time burn them out.
Squirter: One who, or that which, squirts.
Stereotyped: Formed into, or printed from, stereotype plates.
Subulate: Very narrow, and tapering gradually to a fine point from a broadish base; awl-shaped; linear.
Supercargo: An officer or person in a merchant ship, whose duty is to manage the sales, and superintend the commercial concerns, of the voyage.
Spearwort: A name given to several species of crowfoot (Ranunculus) which have spear-shaped leaves.
Silicide: A binary compound of silicon, or one regarded as binary.
Stereotyper: One who stereotypes; one who makes stereotype plates, or works in a stereotype foundry.
Spray gun: a container for liquid, fitted with a conduit that can be supplied with compressed air, desiged to allowing the contents to be sprayed as an aerosol.  Such devices are used to spray paints and various other liquids.
Semidiurnal: Pertaining to, or accomplished in, half a day, or twelve hours; occurring twice every day.
&Verbar;Scoria: The recrement of metals in fusion, or the slag rejected after the reduction of metallic ores; dross.
Shunting: Switching; as, shunting engine, yard, etc.
Squeezer: One who, or that which, squeezes; as, a lemon squeezer.
Suprahepatic: Situated over, or on the dorsal side of, the liver; -- applied to the branches of the hepatic veins.
Squelch: To make a sound like that made by the feet of one walking in mud or slush; to make a kind of swashing sound; to squish; also, to move with such a sound.
Slatternliness: The quality or state of being slatternly; slovenliness; untidiness.
Seclude: To shut up apart from others; to withdraw into, or place in, solitude; to separate from society or intercourse with others.
Spongy: Soft, and full of cavities; of an open, loose, pliable texture; as, a spongy excrescence; spongy earth; spongy cake; spongy bones.
Slavocracy: The persons or interest formerly representing slavery politically, or wielding political power for the preservation or advancement of slavery.
Sponge: To suck in, or imbibe, as a sponge.
Style: To entitle; to term, name, or call; to denominate.
Salify: To combine or impregnate with a salt.
Stinkingly: In a stinking manner; with an offensive smell.
Sheriff: The chief officer of a shire or county, to whom is intrusted the execution of the laws, the serving of judicial writs and processes, and the preservation of the peace.
Sakieh: A kind of water wheel used in Egypt for raising water, from wells or pits, in buckets attached to its periphery or to an endless rope.
Stamp: The act of stamping, as with the foot.
Stilt: To raise on stilts, or as if on stilts.
&Verbar;Solenoglypha: A suborder of serpents including those which have tubular erectile fangs, as the viper and rattlesnake. See Fang.
Suspensive: Tending to suspend, or to keep in suspense; causing interruption or delay; uncertain; doubtful.
Schoolboy: A boy belonging to, or attending, a school.
Shattery: Easily breaking into pieces; not compact; loose of texture; brittle; as, shattery spar.
Smegma: The matter secreted by any of the sebaceous glands.
Sift: To separate with a sieve, as the fine part of a substance from the coarse; as, to sift meal or flour; to sift powder; to sift sand or lime.
Sea bass: A large marine food fish (Serranus atrarius syn. Centropristis atrarius) which abounds on the Atlantic coast of the United States.  It is dark bluish, with black bands, and more or less varied with small white spots and blotches.  Called also, locally, blue bass, black sea bass, blackfish, bluefish, and black perch.
Sea tang: A kind of seaweed; tang; tangle.
Smallness: The quality or state of being small.
Shuttlecock: To send or toss to and fro; to bandy; as, to shuttlecock words.
Stratification: The act or process of laying in strata, or the state of being laid in the form of strata, or layers.
Standergrass: A plant (Orchis mascula); -- called also standerwort, and long purple. See Long purple, under Long.
Saxicava: Any species of marine bivalve shells of the genus Saxicava. Some of the species are noted for their power of boring holes in limestone and similar rocks.
Strenuous: Eagerly pressing or urgent; zealous; ardent; earnest; bold; valiant; intrepid; as, a strenuous advocate for national rights; a strenuous reformer; a strenuous defender of his country.
Settling: The act of one who, or that which, settles; the act of establishing one's self, of colonizing, subsiding, adjusting, etc.
Skedaddle: To betake one's self to flight, as if in a panic; to flee; to run away.
Spray can: a small can containing a liquid under pressure of a gas that forces the liquid out in an aerosol form when the valve is opened.
Still life: a type of painting in which inanimate objects such as flowers or fruit are represented.
Shropshire: An English breed of black-faced hornless sheep similar to the Southdown, but larger, now extensively raised in many parts of the world.
Soursop: The large succulent and slightly acid fruit of a small tree (Anona muricata) of the West Indies; also, the tree itself. It is closely allied to the custard apple.
Samite: A species of silk stuff, or taffeta, generally interwoven with gold.
Sexuality: The quality or state of being distinguished by sex.
Stapedial: Of or pertaining to the stapes.
Stalactitiform: Having the form of a stalactite; stalactiform.
Space suit: a protective suit covering the whole body, completely airtight and designed to withstand internal pressure, worn by astronauts to protect them from the vacuum and other hazards of outer space.  It typically contains an air supply and other life-support equipment to allow functioning independent of any other equipment for a period of time while in space.
Strengthening: That strengthens; giving or increasing strength.
squish: A sound like that made by the feet of one walking in mud or slush; a gushing, swashing, or splashing sound; a squishing sound.
Sun-dried: Dried by the heat of the sun; as, sun-dried tomatoes.
Stupidity: The quality or state of being stupid; extreme dullness of perception or understanding; insensibility; sluggishness.
Sublumbar: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the lumbar region of the vertebral column.
Saturnine: Born under, or influenced by, the planet Saturn.
Suspiration: The act of sighing, or fetching a long and deep breath; a deep respiration; a sigh.
Sundown: The setting of the sun; sunset.
Subaltern: A person holding a subordinate position; specifically, a commissioned military officer below the rank of captain.
Sea anemone: Any one of numerous species of soft-bodied Anthozoa, belonging to the order Actinaria; an actinian.
Serpiginous: Creeping; -- said of lesions which heal over one portion while continuing to advance at another.
Stylomaxillary: Of or pertaining to the styloid process and the maxilla.
&Verbar;Spermogonium: A conceptacle of certain lichens, which contains spermatia.
Starlike: Resembling a star; stellated; radiated like a star; as, starlike flowers.
Stone-deaf: As deaf as a stone; completely deaf.
Silkweed: Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates whose seed vessels contain a long, silky down; milkweed.
Speaker: One who speaks.
Shingling: The act of covering with shingles; shingles, collectively; a covering made of shingles.
Salicyl: The hypothetical radical of salicylic acid and of certain related compounds.
Siliculose: Bearing silicles; pertaining to, or resembling, silicles.
&Verbar;Stiacciato: The lowest relief, -- often used in Italian sculpture of the 15th and 16th centuries.
Squeamish: Having a stomach that is easily turned or nauseated; hence, nice to excess in taste; fastidious; easily disgusted; apt to be offended at trifling improprieties.
Salicylal: A thin, fragrant, colorless oil, HO.C6H4.CHO, found in the flowers of meadow sweet (Spiræa), and also obtained by oxidation of salicin, saligenin, etc. It reddens on exposure. Called also salicylol, salicylic aldehyde, and formerly salicylous acid or spiroylous acid.
Seposition: The act of setting aside, or of giving up.
Shadow: To cut off light from; to put in shade; to shade; to throw a shadow upon; to overspead with obscurity.
Spathic: Like spar; foliated or lamellar; spathose.
Sabbathless: Without Sabbath, or intermission of labor; hence, without respite or rest.
Sherardize: To subject to the process of vapor galvanizing (which see, below).
Scandia: A chemical earth, the oxide of scandium.
Scandic: Of or pertaining to scandium; derived from, or containing, scandium.
Secernment: The act or process of secreting.
Skinflint: A penurious person; a miser; a niggard.
Spandex: An elastic textile material, used for clothing
Sear: The catch in a gunlock by which the hammer is held cocked or half cocked.
&Verbar;Styx: The principal river of the lower world, which had to be crossed in passing to the regions of the dead.
Seak: Soap prepared for use in milling cloth.
Separatrix: The decimal point; the dot placed at the left of a decimal fraction, to separate it from the whole number which it follows. The term is sometimes also applied to other marks of separation.
Seam: A denomination of weight or measure.
Seal: To affix one's seal, or a seal.
Sciatica: Neuralgia of the sciatic nerve, an affection characterized by paroxysmal attacks of pain in the buttock, back of the thigh, or in the leg or foot, following the course of the branches of the sciatic nerve. The name is also popularly applied to various painful affections of the hip and the parts adjoining it. See Ischiadic passion, under Ischiadic.
Same: Not different or other; not another or others; identical; unchanged.
Scrapbook: A blank book in which extracts cut from books and papers may be pasted and kept.
Sarcophile: A flesh-eating animal, especially any one of the carnivorous marsupials.
Samp: An article of food consisting of maize broken or bruised, which is cooked by boiling, and usually eaten with milk; coarse hominy.
Stinkball: A composition of substances which in combustion emit a suffocating odor; -- used formerly in naval warfare.
Superpartient: Of or pertaining to a ratio when the excess of the greater term over the less is more than a unit, as that of 3 to 5, or 7 to 10.
Shepherdish: Resembling a shepherd; suiting a shepherd; pastoral.
Sponginess: The quality or state of being spongy.
Stocker: One who makes or fits stocks, as of guns or gun carriages, etc.
Selah: A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms; by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musical performance of the song.
Septuary: Something composed of seven; a week.
Stoker: One who is employed to tend a furnace and supply it with fuel, especially the furnace of a locomotive or of a marine steam boiler; also, a machine for feeding fuel to a fire.
Suppression: The act of suppressing, or the state of being suppressed; repression; as, the suppression of a riot, insurrection, or tumult; the suppression of truth, of reports, of evidence, and the like.
Sternmost: Farthest in the rear; farthest astern; as, the sternmost ship in a convoy.
&Verbar;Spermococcus: The nucleus of the sperm cell.
Silverless: Having no silcver; hence, without money; impecunious.
Shebeen: A low public house; especially, a place where spirits and other excisable liquors are illegally and privately sold.
Skiver: An inferior quality of leather, made of split sheepskin, tanned by immersion in sumac, and dyed. It is used for hat linings, pocketbooks, bookbinding, etc.
Sulphurator: An apparatus for impregnating with, or exposing to the action of, sulphur; especially, an apparatus for fumigating or bleaching by means of the fumes of burning sulphur.
Self-respect: Respect for one's self; regard for one's character; laudable self-esteem.
Squamoid: Resembling a scale; also, covered with scales; scaly.
Spore: One of the minute grains in flowerless plants, which are analogous to seeds, as serving to reproduce the species.
Sempiternity: Future duration without end; the relation or state of being sempiternal.
Spermaphore: That part of the ovary from which the ovules arise; the placenta.
Subtectacle: A space under a roof; a tabernacle; a dwelling.
Subcontrary: A subcontrary proposition; a proposition inferior or contrary in a lower degree.
Scrimption: A small portion; a pittance; a little bit.
Scottish: Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Scotland, their country, or their language; as, Scottish industry or economy; a Scottish chief; a Scottish dialect.
Sterrometal: Any alloy of copper, zinc, tin, and iron, of which cannon are sometimes made.
Sport: To divert; to amuse; to make merry; -- used with the reciprocal pronoun.
&Verbar;Scyll\u00e6a: A genus of oceanic nudibranchiate mollusks having the small branched gills situated on the upper side of four fleshy lateral lobes, and on the median caudal crest.
Simar: A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.
Siphonobranchiate: Having a siphon, or siphons, to convey water to the gills; belonging or pertaining to the Siphonobranchiata.
Scumbling: A mode of obtaining a softened effect, in painting and drawing, by the application of a thin layer of opaque color to the surface of a painting, or part of the surface, which is too bright in color, or which requires harmonizing.
Slash pine: A kind of pine tree (Pinus Cubensis) found in Southern Florida and the West Indies; -- so called because it grows in “slashes.”
&Verbar;Saboti\u00e8re: A kind of freezer for ices.
Syn-: A prefix meaning with, along with, together, at the same time. Syn- becomes sym- before p, b, and m, and syl- before l.
Sepulchral: Of or pertaining to burial, to the grave, or to monuments erected to the memory of the dead; as, a sepulchral stone; a sepulchral inscription.
Stockjobber: One who speculates in stocks for gain; one whose occupation is to buy and sell stocks. In England a jobber acts as an intermediary between brokers.
Sagacious: Of quick sense perceptions; keen-scented; skilled in following a trail.
Suboctave: Containing one part of eight; having the ratio of one to eight.
Sharp-sighted: Having quick or acute sight; -- used literally and figuratively.
Suspire: A long, deep breath; a sigh.
Star-read: Doctrine or knowledge of the stars; star lore; astrology; astronomy.
Spastic: Of or pertaining to spasm; spasmodic; especially, pertaining to tonic spasm; tetanic.
Shapely: Well-formed; having a regular shape; comely; symmetrical.
Spurling-line: The line which forms the communication between the steering wheel and the telltale.
Swan-upping: A yearly expedition on the Thames to take up young swans and mark them, as by Companies of Dyers and Vintners; -- called also swan-hopping.
Soluble: Susceptible of being dissolved in a fluid; capable of solution; as, some substances are soluble in alcohol which are not soluble in water.
&Verbar;Sauropsida: A comprehensive group of vertebrates, comprising the reptiles and birds.
Self-denial: The denial of one's self; forbearing to gratify one's own desires; self-sacrifice.
&Verbar;Siphonium: A bony tube which, in some birds, connects the tympanium with the air chambers of the articular piece of the mandible.
Statuesquely: In a statuesque manner; in a way suggestive of a statue; like a statue.
Sculpin: Any one of numerous species of marine cottoid fishes of the genus Cottus, or Acanthocottus, having a large head armed with several sharp spines, and a broad mouth. They are generally mottled with yellow, brown, and black. Several species are found on the Atlantic coasts of Europe and America.
&Verbar;Suspensorium: Anything which suspends or holds up a part: especially, the mandibular suspensorium (a series of bones, or of cartilages representing them) which connects the base of the lower jaw with the skull in most vertebrates below mammals.
Snapdragon: Any plant of the scrrophulariaceous genus Antirrhinum, especially the cultivated A. majus, whose showy flowers are fancifully likened to the face of a dragon.
Seafaring: Following the business of a mariner; as, a seafaring man.
Shaver: One who shaves; one whose occupation is to shave.
Suilline: Of or pertaining to a hog or the Hog family (Suidæ).
Subdivine: Partaking of divinity; divine in a partial or lower degree.
Sea language: The peculiar language or phraseology of seamen; sailor's cant.
Scaling: Adapted for removing scales, as from a fish; as, a scaling knife; adapted for removing scale, as from the interior of a steam boiler; as, a scaling hammer, bar, etc.
Self-abuse: The abuse of one's own self, powers, or faculties.
Sulpho-: A prefix (also used adjectively) designating sulphur as an ingredient in certain compounds.  Cf. Thio-.
Snooze: To doze; to drowse; to take a short nap; to slumber.
Skulk: One who, or that which, skulks.
Synecdoche: A figure or trope by which a part of a thing is put for the whole (as, fifty sail for fifty ships), or the whole for a part (as, the smiling year for spring), the species for the genus (as, cutthroat for assassin), the genus for the species (as, a creature for a man), the name of the material for the thing made, etc.
Skull: The skeleton of the head of a vertebrate animal, including the brain case, or cranium, and the bones and cartilages of the face and mouth. See Illusts. of Carnivora, of Facial angles under Facial, and of Skeleton, in Appendix.
Signalman: A man whose business is to manage or display signals; especially, one employed in setting the signals by which railroad trains are run or warned.
&Verbar;Schizonemertea: A group of nemerteans comprising those having a deep slit along each side of the head. See Illust. in Appendix.
Sedative: A remedy which allays irritability and irritation, and irritative activity or pain.
Sunshade: Anything used as a protection from the sun's rays.
&Verbar;Shaster: A treatise for authoritative instruction among the Hindoos; a book of institutes; especially, a treatise explaining the Vedas.
Sustained: Held up to a certain pitch, degree, or level; uniform; as, sustained pasion; a sustained style of writing; a sustained note in music.
Spur-shell: Any one of several species of handsome marine gastropod shells of the genus Trochus, or Imperator.  The shell is conical, with the margin toothed somewhat like the rowel of a spur.
Slopwork: The manufacture of slops, or cheap ready-made clothing; also, such clothing; hence, hasty, slovenly work of any kind.
Semester: A period of six months; especially, a term in a college or university which divides the year into two terms.
Synchronistic: Of or pertaining to synchronism; arranged according to correspondence in time; as, synchronistic tables.
Succise: Appearing as if a part were cut off at the extremity.
Saturable: Capable of being saturated; admitting of saturation.
Snakehead: A loose, bent-up end of one of the strap rails, or flat rails, formerly used on American railroads. It was sometimes so bent by the passage of a train as to slip over a wheel and pierce the bottom of a car.
Smelling salts: An aromatic preparation of carbonate of ammonia and, often, some scent, to avoid or relieve faintness, headache, or the like.
Salutary: Wholesome; healthful; promoting health; as, salutary exercise.
Surrein: To override; to exhaust by riding.
Smallage: A biennial umbelliferous plant (Apium graveolens) native of the seacoats of Europe and Asia. When deprived of its acrid and even poisonous properties by cultivation, it becomes celery.
Suprasphenoidal: Situated above the sphenoidal bone; as, the suprasphenoidal appendage, or pituitary body.
Suresby: One to be sure of, or to be relied on.
Silliness: The quality or state of being silly.
Similitude: The quality or state of being similar or like; resemblance; likeness; similarity; as, similitude of substance.
Semi-Pelagianism: The doctrines or tenets of the Semi-Pelagians.
Symmetrist: One eminently studious of symmetry of parts.
&Verbar;Spiccato: Detached; separated; -- a term indicating that every note is to be performed in a distinct and pointed manner.
Seine: A large net, one edge of which is provided with sinkers, and the other with floats. It hangs vertically in the water, and when its ends are brought together or drawn ashore incloses the fish.
Stream clock: An instrument for ascertaining the velocity of the blood in a vessel.
Sheepshead: A large and valuable sparoid food fish (Archosargus probatocephalus syn. Diplodus probatocephalus) found on the Atlantic coast of the United States.  It often weighs from ten to twelve pounds.
Swede: A native or inhabitant of Sweden.
Stigmatically: With a stigma, or mark of infamy or deformity.
Suasive: Having power to persuade; persuasive; suasory.
Subservience: The quality or state of being subservient; instrumental fitness or use; hence, willingness to serve another's purposes; in a derogatory sense, servility.
&Verbar;Spahi: Formerly, one of the Turkish cavalry.
Sans-culottism: Extreme republican principles; the principles or practice of the sans-culottes.
Strapping: Tall; strong; lusty; large; as, a strapping fellow.
Subsignation: The act of writing the name under something, as for attestation.
Shragger: One who lops; one who trims trees.
Skiving: The act of paring or splitting leather or skins.
&Verbar;Solus: Alone; -- chiefly used in stage directions, and the like.
Subscribe: To sign one's name to a letter or other document.
Switzer: A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Swiss.
Stethal: One of the higher alcohols of the methane series, homologous with ethal, and found in small quantities as an ethereal salt of stearic acid in spermaceti.
Squail: To throw sticks at cocks; to throw anything about awkwardly or irregularly.
Speed: To cause to be successful, or to prosper; hence, to aid; to favor.
Spinescence: The state or quality of being spinescent or spiny; also, a spiny growth or covering, as of certain animals.
Senecas: A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part of Western New York. This tribe was the most numerous and most warlike of the Five Nations.
Sphragistics: The science of seals, their history, age, distinctions, etc., esp. as verifying the age and genuiness of documents.
Spaad: A kind of spar; earth flax, or amianthus.
Scale-winged: Having the wings covered with small scalelike structures, as the Lepidoptera; scaly-winged.
Shudder: The act of shuddering, as with fear.
Shack: The grain left after harvest or gleaning; also, nuts which have fallen to the ground.
Splanchnotomy: The dissection, or anatomy, of the viscera.
Statal: Of, pertaining to, or existing with reference to, a State of the American Union, as distinguished from the general government.
Suite: A retinue or company of attendants, as of a distinguished personage; as, the suite of an ambassador. See Suit, n., 5.
Sardonyx: A variety of onyx consisting of sard and white chalcedony in alternate layers.
Smeary: Tending to smear or soil; adhesive; viscous.
Stonerunner: The ring plover, or the ringed dotterel.
stick-tight: any of several plants having seeds tipped with barbs that may cling to fur or clothing, especially those of the genus Bidens, also called bur marigold, beggar-ticks, and Beggar's ticks, which have prickly flattened achenes.
Sacramentary: An ancient book of the Roman Catholic Church, written by Pope Gelasius, and revised, corrected, and abridged by St. Gregory, in which were contained the rites for Mass, the sacraments, the dedication of churches, and other ceremonies. There are several ancient books of the same kind in France and Germany.
Steeple-crowned: Bearing a steeple; as, a steeple-crowned building.
Self-repelling: Made up of parts, as molecules or atoms, which mutually repel each other; as, gases are self-repelling.
Spark plug: In internal-combustion engines with electric ignition, a plug, screwed into the cylinder head, connected with the induction coil or magneto circuit on the outside, and used to produce a spark to ignite the fuel-air mixture in the engine.
Self-activity: The quality or state of being self-active; self-action.
Sulpharsenious: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid (called also thioarsenious acid) analogous to arsenious acid, and known only in its salts.
Stiff: Not easily bent; not flexible or pliant; not limber or flaccid; rigid; firm; as, stiff wood, paper, joints.
Star-crossed: Not favored by the stars; ill-fated.
Specksioneer: The chief harpooner, who also directs in cutting up the speck, or blubber; -- so called among whalers.
Saxophone: A wind instrument of brass, containing a reed, and partaking of the qualities both of a brass instrument and of a clarinet.
Solanidine: An alkaloid produced by the decomposition of solanine, as a white crystalline substance having a harsh bitter taste.
Suprastapedial: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that part of the columella of the ear which projects above the connection with the stapes, as in many animals.
Sumptuous: Involving large outlay or expense; costly; expensive; hence, luxurious; splendid; magnificient; as, a sumptuous house or table; sumptuous apparel.
Symbolic: Of or pertaining to a symbol or symbols; of the nature of a symbol; exhibiting or expressing by resemblance or signs; representative; as, the figure of an eye is symbolic of sight and knowledge.
Surculose: Producing suckers, or shoots resembling suckers.
Shirr: A series of close parallel runnings which are drawn up so as to make the material between them set full by gatherings; -- called also shirring, and gauging.
Scioptics: The art or process of exhibiting luminous images, especially those of external objects, in a darkened room, by arrangements of lenses or mirrors.
Satrapy: The government or jurisdiction of a satrap; a principality.
Saur: Soil; dirt; dirty water; urine from a cowhouse.
Sorgo: Indian millet and its varieties. See Sorghum.
Squirely: Becoming a squire; like a squire.
Sterilize: To make sterile or unproductive; to impoverish, as land; to exhaust of fertility.
Smaragdite: A green foliated kind of amphibole, observed in eclogite and some varietis of gabbro.
Shire: A portion of Great Britain originally under the supervision of an earl; a territorial division, usually identical with a county, but sometimes limited to a smaller district; as, Wiltshire, Yorkshire, Richmondshire, Hallamshire.
Supervene: To come as something additional or extraneous; to occur with reference or relation to something else; to happen upon or after something else; to be added; to take place; to happen.
Shirk: One who lives by shifts and tricks; one who avoids the performance of duty or labor.
Stylohyoid: Of or pertaining to the styloid process and the hyoid bone.
&Verbar;Sheriat: The sacred law of the Turkish empire.
&Verbar;Struthiones: A division, or order, of birds, including only the African ostriches.
Saccharinic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, saccharin; specifically, designating a complex acid not known in the free state but well known in its salts, which are obtained by boiling dextrose and levulose (invert sugar) with milk of lime.
Storm-beat: Beaten, injured, or impaired by storms.
&Verbar;Spermophyta: Plants which produce seed; phænogamia. These plants constitute the highest grand division of the vegetable kingdom.
Self-sufficiency: The quality or state of being self-sufficient.
Sickliness: The quality or state of being sickly.
Siluridan: Any fish of the family Siluridæ or of the order Siluroidei.
Simoom: A hot, dry, suffocating, dust-laden wind, that blows occasionally in Arabia, Syria, and neighboring countries, generated by the extreme heat of the parched deserts or sandy plains.
&Verbar;Sans-culotte: A fellow without breeches; a ragged fellow; -- a name of reproach given in the first French revolution to the extreme republican party, who rejected breeches as an emblem peculiar to the upper classes or aristocracy, and adopted pantaloons.
Subsemitone: The sensible or leading note, or sharp seventh, of any key; subtonic.
Significator: One who, or that which, signifies.
Sportling: A little person or creature engaged in sports or in play.
sanguinity: The quality of being sanguine; sanguineness.
Solenogastra: An order of lowly organized Mollusca belonging to the Isopleura. A narrow groove takes the place of the foot of other gastropods.
Spurred: Wearing spurs; furnished with a spur or spurs; having shoots like spurs.
Studentship: The state of being a student.
Substruction: Underbuilding; the foundation, or any preliminary structure intended to raise the lower floor or basement of a building above the natural level of the ground.
Shakedown: A temporary substitute for a bed, as one made on the floor or on chairs; -- perhaps originally from the shaking down of straw for this purpose.
Sacellum: An unroofed space consecrated to a divinity.
Sublieutenant: An inferior or second lieutenant; in the British service, a commissioned officer of the lowest rank.
Sportal: Of or pertaining to sports; used in sports.
Sparpiece: The collar beam of a roof; the spanpiece.
&Verbar;Saccharum: A genus of tall tropical grasses including the sugar cane.
Surrejoin: To reply, as a plaintiff to a defendant's rejoinder.
Semipalmate: Having the anterior toes joined only part way down with a web; half-webbed; as, a semipalmate bird or foot. See Illust. k under Aves.
&Verbar;Scherzando: In a playful or sportive manner.
Snook: A large perchlike marine food fish (Centropomus undecimalis) found both on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of tropical America; -- called also ravallia, and robalo.
Sadden: To become, or be made, sad.
&Verbar;Sympodium: An axis or stem produced by dichotomous branching in which one of the branches is regularly developed at the expense of the other, as in the grapevine.
Stateroom: A magnificent room in a palace or great house.
Shriek: A sharp, shrill outcry or scream; a shrill wild cry such as is caused by sudden or extreme terror, pain, or the like.
Sonorous: Giving sound when struck; resonant; as, sonorous metals.
Snarler: One who makes use of a snarling iron.
Strap-shaped: Shaped like a strap; ligulate; as, a strap-shaped corolla.
Superstruction: The act of superstructing, or building upon.
Suffumigate: To apply fumes or smoke to the parts of, as to the body in medicine; to fumigate in part.
Sirup: A thick and viscid liquid made from the juice of fruits, herbs, etc., boiled with sugar.
Salep: The dried tubers of various species of Orchis, and Eulophia. It is used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powdered preparation with hot water.
Schwenkfelder: A member of a religious sect founded by Kaspar von Schwenkfeld, a Silesian reformer who disagreed with Luther, especially on the deification of the body of Christ.
Setterwort: The bear's-foot (Helleborus fœtidus); -- so called because the root was used in settering, or inserting setons into the dewlaps of cattle. Called also pegroots.
Subvariety: A subordinate variety, or a division of a variety.
Scaliness: The state of being scaly; roughness.
Sparger: A vessel with a perforated cover, for sprinkling with a liquid; a sprinkler.
&Verbar;Strategus: The leader or commander of an army; a general.
Scape-wheel: The wheel in an escapement (as of a clock or a watch) into the teeth of which the pallets play.
Semiannular: Having the figure of a half circle; forming a semicircle.
Stoneware: A species of coarse potter's ware, glazed and baked.
Self-glorious: Springing from vainglory or vanity; vain; boastful.
Self-knowing: Knowing one's self, or one's own character, powers, and limitations.
Spumous: Consisting of, containing, or covered with, froth, scum, or foam; frothy; foamy.
Scombroid: Like or pertaining to the Mackerel family.
Struse: A Russian river craft used for transporting freight.
Shend: To injure, mar, spoil, or harm.
&Verbar;Significavit: Formerly, a writ issuing out of chancery, upon certificate given by the ordinary, of a man's standing excommunicate by the space of forty days, for the laying him up in prison till he submit himself to the authority of the church.
Spurious: Not proceeding from the true source, or from the source pretended; not genuine; counterfeit; false; adulterate.
sliver: To cut or divide into long, thin pieces, or into very small pieces; to cut or rend lengthwise; to slit; as, to sliver wood.
Schismatize: To take part in schism; to make a breach of communion in the church.
Simper: A constrained, self-conscious smile; an affected, silly smile; a smirk.
Syringotomy: The operation of cutting for anal fistula.
Splenization: A morbid state of the lung produced by inflammation, in which its tissue resembles that of the spleen.
&Verbar;Steganophthalmata: The Discophora, or Phanerocarpæ. Called also Steganophthalmia.
Sober: To become sober; -- often with down.
Shelve: To incline gradually; to be slopping; as, the bottom shelves from the shore.
Semichorus: A half chorus; a passage to be sung by a selected portion of the voices, as the female voices only, in contrast with the full choir.
Syringotome: A small blunt-pointed bistoury, -- used in syringotomy.
Starchly: In a starched or starch manner.
Suffragist: One who possesses or exercises the political right of suffrage; a voter.
Sea trout: Any one of several species of true trouts which descend rivers and enter the sea after spawning, as the European bull trout and salmon trout, and the eastern American spotted trout.
Shipwright: One whose occupation is to construct ships; a builder of ships or other vessels.
Seizing: The act of taking or grasping suddenly.
Saury: A slender marine fish (Scomberesox saurus) of Europe and America. It has long, thin, beaklike jaws. Called also billfish, gowdnook, gawnook, skipper, skipjack, skopster, lizard fish, and Egypt herring.
Subdean: An under dean; the deputy or substitute of a dean.
Sarmentaceous: Bearing sarments, or runners, as the strawberry.
Spirometer: An instrument for measuring the vital capacity of the lungs, or the volume of air which can be expelled from the chest after the deepest possible inspiration.  Cf. Pneumatometer.
Spot stroke: The pocketing of the red ball in a top corner pocket from off its own spot so as to leave the cue ball in position for an easy winning hazard in either top corner pocket.
Scruze: To squeeze, compress, crush, or bruise.
Sanidine: A variety of orthoclase feldspar common in certain eruptive rocks, as trachyte; -- called also glassy feldspar.
Scapiform: Resembling a scape, or flower stem.
Suspicion: To view with suspicion; to suspect; to doubt.
Stalemate: To subject to a stalemate; hence, to bring to a stand.
Scripture: Anything written; a writing; a document; an inscription.
Satirist: One who satirizes; especially, one who writes satire.
Sixteenth: The quotient of a unit divided by sixteen; one of sixteen equal parts of one whole.
Saltpetrous: Pertaining to saltpeter, or partaking of its qualities; impregnated with saltpeter.
Schreibersite: A mineral occurring in steel-gray flexible folia. It contains iron, nickel, and phosphorus, and is found only in meteoric iron.
Shorer: One who, or that which, shores or props; a prop; a shore.
Stoup: A flagon; a vessel or measure for liquids.
Schismatic: One who creates or takes part in schism; one who separates from an established church or religious communion on account of a difference of opinion.
Sigillarid: One of an extinct family of cryptagamous trees, including the genus Sigillaria and its allies.
Serrature: A notching, like that between the teeth of a saw, in the edge of anything.
Suturated: Sewed or knit together; united by a suture; stitched.
Sect: Those following a particular leader or authority, or attached to a certain opinion; a company or set having a common belief or allegiance distinct from others; in religion, the believers in a particular creed, or upholders of a particular practice; especially, in modern times, a party dissenting from an established church; a denomination; in philosophy, the disciples of a particular master; a school; in society and the state, an order, rank, class, or party.
Surturbrand: A fibrous brown coal or bituminous wood.
Stupefy: To make stupid; to make dull; to blunt the faculty of perception or understanding in; to deprive of sensibility; to make torpid.
Stupeous: Resembling tow; having long, loose scales, or matted filaments, like tow; stupose.
Sweepstakes: A winning of all the stakes or prizes; a sweepstake.
Skeleton: Consisting of, or resembling, a skeleton; consisting merely of the framework or outlines; having only certain leading features of anything; as, a skeleton sermon; a skeleton crystal.
Self-abased: Humbled by consciousness of inferiority, unworthiness, guilt, or shame.
Sceneman: The man who manages the movable scenes in a theater.
&Verbar;Sarcoseptum: One of the mesenteries of an anthozoan.
Semisoun: A half sound; a low tone.
Symbiotic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, or living in, a state of symbiosis.
&Verbar;Springbok: A South African gazelle (Gazella euchore) noted for its graceful form and swiftness, and for its peculiar habit of springing lightly and suddenly into the air.  It has a white dorsal stripe, expanding into a broad patch of white on the rump and tail.  Called also springer.
Sepiostare: The bone or shell of cuttlefish. See Illust. under Cuttlefish.
&Verbar;Soupe-maigre: Soup made chiefly from vegetables or fish with a little butter and a few condiments.
Silvas: Vast woodland plains of South America.
&Verbar;Shizoku: The Japanese warrior gentry or middle class, formerly called samurai; also, any member of this class.
Stiver: A Dutch coin, and money of account, of the value of two cents, or about one penny sterling; hence, figuratively, anything of little worth.
Snatch: A hasty catching or seizing; a grab; a catching at, or attempt to seize, suddenly.
Sambuke: An ancient stringed instrument used by the Greeks, the particular construction of which is unknown.
Strappado: To punish or torture by the strappado.
Shamanism: The type of religion which once prevalied among all the Ural-Altaic peoples (Tungusic, Mongol, and Turkish), and which still survives in various parts of Northern Asia. The Shaman, or wizard priest, deals with good as well as with evil spirits, especially the good spirits of ancestors.
Sleepwaker: On in a state of magnetic or mesmeric sleep.
Subvertebral: Situated beneath, or on the ventral side of, the vertebral column; situated beneath, or inside of, the endoskeleton; hypaxial; hyposkeletal.
Substance: To furnish or endow with substance; to supply property to; to make rich.
Subpentangular: Nearly or approximately pentangular; almost pentangular.
Siding: Attaching one's self to a party.
Self-worship: The idolizing of one's self; immoderate self-conceit.
Signer: One who signs or subscribes his name; as, a memorial with a hundred signers.
Solicitous: Disposed to solicit; eager to obtain something desirable, or to avoid anything evil; concerned; anxious; careful.
Signet: A seal; especially, in England, the seal used by the sovereign in sealing private letters and grants that pass by bill under the sign manual; -- called also privy signet.
Singleton: In certain games at cards, as whist, a single card of any suit held at the deal by a player; as, to lead a singleton.
Square: To accord or agree exactly; to be consistent with; to conform or agree; to suit; to fit.
Sunbonnet: A bonnet, generally made of some thin or light fabric, projecting beyond the face, and commonly having a cape, -- worn by women as a protection against the sun.
Serrulation: The state of being notched minutely, like a fine saw.
Sinusoid: The curve whose ordinates are proportional to the sines of the abscissas, the equation of the curve being y = a sin x. It is also called the curve of sines.
&Verbar;Subah: A province; a government, as of a viceroy; also, a subahdar.
&Verbar;Sarcophaga: A genus of Diptera, including the flesh flies.
Sightfulness: The state of being sightful; perspicuity.
Strangely: As something foreign, or not one's own; in a manner adapted to something foreign and strange.
Seaware: Seaweed; esp., coarse seaweed. See Ware, and Sea girdles.
Stilliform: Having the form of a drop.
Signable: Suitable to be signed; requiring signature; as, a legal document signable by a particular person.
Skyscraper: A skysail of a triangular form.
Semimonthly: Coming or made twice in a month; as, semimonthly magazine; a semimonthly payment.
Starwort: Any plant of the genus Aster. See Aster.
Sumatran: Of or pertaining to Sumatra or its inhabitants.
self-explaining: Explaining itself; capable of being understood without explanation.
Strabotomy: The operation for the removal of squinting by the division of such muscles as distort the eyeball.
Spiritualize: To refine intellectiually or morally; to purify from the corrupting influence of the world; to give a spiritual character or tendency to; as, to spiritualize soul.
&Verbar;Sivan: The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposed to correspond nearly with our month of June.
Spoon-billed: Having the bill expanded and spatulate at the end.
Sum: To bring together into one whole; to collect into one amount; to cast up, as a column of figures; to ascertain the totality of; -- usually with up.
Sensational: Of or pertaining to sensation; as, sensational nerves.
Sandaliform: Shaped like a sandal or slipper.
Satchel: A little sack or bag for carrying papers, books, or small articles of wearing apparel; a hand bag.
Snowshoer: One who travels on snowshoes; an expert in using snowshoes.
Syn\u0153cious: Having stamens and pistil in the same head, or, in mosses, having antheridia and archegonia on the same receptacle.
Suppurate: To cause to generate pus; as, to suppurate a sore.
Sceneshifter: One who moves the scenes in a theater; a sceneman.
Sock in: to cause (an airport) to cease functioning, by severe weather conditions, such as fog or a snowstorm.  Used often in the passive; the airport was socked in for two days by a blizzard.
Surplusage: Surplus; excess; overplus; as, surplusage of grain or goods beyond what is wanted.
Slubberingly: In a slovenly, or hurried and imperfect, manner.
Sinful: Tainted with, or full of, sin; wicked; iniquitous; criminal; unholy; as, sinful men; sinful thoughts.
Staysail: Any sail extended on a stay.
Saxony: A kind of glossy woolen cloth formerly much used.
Syntactic: Of or pertaining to syntax; according to the rules of syntax, or construction.
Seigneurial: Of or pertaining to the lord of a manor; manorial.
Stridulate: To make a shrill, creaking noise
Singe: A burning of the surface; a slight burn.
Stringcourse: A horizontal band in a building, forming a part of the design, whether molded, projecting, or carved, or in any way distinguished from the rest of the work.
Sleepiness: The quality or state of being sleepy.
Subp\u0153na: To serve with a writ of subpœna; to command attendance in court by a legal writ, under a penalty in case of disobedience.
Self-hardening: Designating, or pert. to, any of various steels that harden when heated to above a red heat and cooled in air, usually in a blast of cold air with moderate rapidity, without quenching. Such steels are alloys of iron and carbon with manganese, tungsten and manganese, chromium, molybdenum and manganese, etc. They are chiefly used as high-speed steels.
&Verbar;Solfatara: A volcanic area or vent which yields only sulphur vapors, steam, and the like. It represents the stages of the volcanic activity.
&Verbar;Secale: A genus of cereal grasses including rye.
Sesquialteral: Once and a half times as great as another; having the ratio of one and a half to one.
Shower: To rain in showers; to fall, as in a hower or showers.
Suggestive: Containing a suggestion, hint, or intimation.
Squirarchy: The gentlemen, or gentry, of a country, collectively.
Superphysical: Above or beyond physics; not explainable by physical laws.
Seignior: A lord; the lord of a manor.
Sapan wood: A dyewood yielded by Cæsalpinia Sappan, a thorny leguminous tree of Southern Asia and the neighboring islands. It is the original Brazil wood.
Skunk: In games of chance and skill: To defeat (an opponent) (as in cards) so that he fails to gain a point, or (in checkers) to get a king.
Sassarara: A word used to emphasize a statement.
Smutch: To blacken with smoke, soot, or coal.
Supertemporal: That which is more than temporal; that which is eternal.
Sequence: to determine the sequence of; as, to sequence a protein or a DNA fragment.
Sway-bracing: The horizontal bracing of a bridge, which prevents its swaying.
Slanderer: One who slanders; a defamer; a calumniator.
Subreader: An under reader in the inns of court, who reads the texts of law the reader is to discourse upon.
Superabound: To be very abundant or exuberant; to be more than sufficient; as, the country superabounds with corn.
&Verbar;Sorus: One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on the back of the fronds of ferns.
Sorbite: A sugarlike substance, isomeric with mannite and dulcite, found with sorbin in the ripe berries of the sorb, and extracted as a sirup or a white crystalline substance.
Sea orange: A large American holothurian (Lophothuria Fabricii) having a bright orange convex body covered with finely granulated scales.  Its expanded tentacles are bright red.
Scythian: A native or inhabitant of Scythia; specifically (Ethnol.), one of a Slavonic race which in early times occupied Eastern Europe.
Splurge: To make a great display in any way, especially in oratory.
Stencil: To mark, paint, or color in figures with stencils; to form or print by means of a stencil.
Sternness: The quality or state of being stern.
Supernaturalist: One who holds to the principles of supernaturalism.
Sea letter: The customary certificate of national character which neutral merchant vessels are bound to carry in time of war; a passport for a vessel and cargo.
Surfy: Consisting of, abounding in, or resembling, surf; as, a surfy shore.
Supernaturalism: The quality or state of being supernatural; supernaturalness.
Sandnecker: A European flounder (Hippoglossoides limandoides); -- called also rough dab, long fluke, sand fluke, and sand sucker.
Superorder: A group intermediate in importance between an order and a subclass.
&Verbar;Scire facias: A judicial writ, founded upon some record, and requiring the party proceeded against to show cause why the party bringing it should not have advantage of such record, or (as in the case of scire facias to repeal letters patent) why the record should not be annulled or vacated.
Seether: A pot for boiling things; a boiler.
Solecism: An impropriety or incongruity of language in the combination of words or parts of a sentence; esp., deviation from the idiom of a language or from the rules of syntax.
Submammary: Situated under the mammæ; as, submammary inflammation.
Sulphuric: Of or pertaining to sulphur; as, a sulphuric smell.
Subtrihedral: Approaching the form of a three-sided pyramid; as, the subtrihedral crown of a tooth.
Stellate: Resembling a star; pointed or radiated, like the emblem of a star.
Suave: Sweet; pleasant; delightful; gracious or agreeable in manner; bland.
Sharewort: A composite plant (Aster Tripolium) growing along the seacoast of Europe.
Sodomy: Carnal copulation in a manner against nature; buggery.
Stagger: An unsteady movement of the body in walking or standing, as if one were about to fall; a reeling motion; vertigo; -- often in the plural; as, the stagger of a drunken man.
Subdecanal: Of or pertaining to a subdean or subdeanery.
Stifle: To die by reason of obstruction of the breath, or because some noxious substance prevents respiration.
Surnominal: Of or pertaining to a surname or surnames.
&Verbar;Samisen: A Japanese musical instrument with three strings, resembling a guitar or banjo.
Secret service: The detective service of a government. In the United States, in time of peace the bureau of secret service is under the treasury department, and in time of war it aids the war department in securing information concerning the movements of the enemy.
Stagworm: The larva of any species of botfly which is parasitic upon the stag, such as Œstrus actæon, or Hypoderma actæon, which burrows beneath the skin, and Cephalomyia auribarbis, which lives in the nostrils.
Sutteeism: The practice of self-immolation of widows in Hindostan.
State: A statement; also, a document containing a statement.
Seismometer: An instrument for measuring the direction, duration, and force of earthquakes and like concussions.
Stag-horned: Having the mandibles large and palmate, or branched somewhat like the antlers of a stag; -- said of certain beetles.
Suit: To agree; to accord; to be fitted; to correspond; -- usually followed by with or to.
Scaphocerite: A flattened plate or scale attached to the second joint of the antennæ of many Crustacea.
Sonifer: A kind of ear trumpet for the deaf, or the partially deaf.
Sminthurid: Any one of numerous small species of springtails, of the family Sminthuridæ, -- usually found on flowers. See Illust. under Collembola.
&Verbar;Serrifera: A division of Hymenoptera comprising the sawflies.
Stereoelectric: Of or pertaining to the generation of electricity by means of solid bodies alone; as, a stereoelectric current is one obtained by means of solids, without any liquid.
Septomaxillary: Of or pertaining to the nasal septum and the maxilla; situated in the region of these parts.
Saracenic: Of or pertaining to the Saracens; as, Saracenic architecture.
Swellfish: Any plectognath fish that dilates itself, as the bur fish, puffer, or diodon.
Sea-green: Of a beautiful bluish green color, like sea water on soundings.
Seton: A few silk threads or horsehairs, or a strip of linen or the like, introduced beneath the skin by a knife or needle, so as to form an issue; also, the issue so formed.
Steening: A lining made of brick, stone, or other hard material, as for a well.
Spicy: Flavored with, or containing, spice or spices; fragrant; aromatic; as, spicy breezes.
Secretiveness: The quality of being secretive; disposition or tendency to conceal.
Saintologist: One who writes the lives of saints.
Swaddle: To bind as with a bandage; to bind or warp tightly with clothes; to swathe; -- used esp. of infants; as, to swaddle a baby.
Sebacic: Of or pertaining to fat; derived from, or resembling, fat; specifically, designating an acid (formerly called also sebic, and pyroleic, acid), obtained by the distillation or saponification of certain oils (as castor oil) as a white crystalline substance.
Subbronchial: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the bronchi; as, the subbronchial air sacs of birds.
Selection: The act of selecting, or the state of being selected; choice, by preference.
Spangle: To show brilliant spots or points; to glisten; to glitter.
Standard-bred: Bred in conformity to a standard. Specif., applied to a registered trotting horse which comes up to the standard adopted by the National Association of Trotting-horse Breeders.
Sea colander: A large blackfish seaweed (Agarum Turneri), the frond of which is punctured with many little holes.
Swoop: A falling on and seizing, as the prey of a rapacious bird; the act of swooping.
Spade: To dig with a spade; to pare off the sward of, as land, with a spade.
Studding: Material for studs, or joists; studs, or joists, collectively; studs.
Stripper: One who, or that which, strips;
Surveyor: One placed to superintend others; an overseer; an inspector.
Sidewise: A heavy swinging blow from the side, which disables an adversary.
Stamina: The fixed, firm part of a body, which supports it or gives it strength and solidity; as, the bones are the stamina of animal bodies; the ligneous parts of trees are the stamina which constitute their strength.
Sinological: Relating to the Chinese language, literature or culture.
Safety: The condition or state of being safe; freedom from danger or hazard; exemption from hurt, injury, or loss.
Self-willed: Governed by one's own will; not yielding to the wishes of others; obstinate.
Submetallic: Imperfectly metallic; as, a submetallic luster.
Superintendent: One who has the oversight and charge of some place, institution, or organization, affairs, etc., with the power of direction; as, the superintendent of an almshouse; the superintendent of public works.
