Secrecy: The state or quality of being hidden; as, his movements were detected in spite of their secrecy.
&Verbar;Squamella: A diminutive scale or bractlet, such as those found on the receptacle in many composite plants; a palea.
Self-centration: The quality or state of being self-centered.
Subjugation: The act of subjugating, or the state of being subjugated.
Sighting: a. & n. from Sight, v. t.
Sedentary: Accustomed to sit much or long; as, a sedentary man.
Syllabicate: To form or divide into syllables; to syllabify.
Splenotomy: Dissection or anatomy of the spleen.
Synonymy: The quality of being synonymous; sameness of meaning.
Soliform: Like the sun in form, appearance, or nature; resembling the sun.
Spice: To season with spice, or as with spice; to mix aromatic or pungent substances with; to flavor; to season; as, to spice wine; to spice one's words with wit.
Showy: Making a show; attracting attention; presenting a marked appearance; ostentatious; gay; gaudy.
Stereopticon: An instrument, consisting essentially of a magic lantern in which photographic pictures are used, by which the image of a landscape, or any object, may be thrown upon a screen in such a manner as to seem to stand out in relief, so as to form a striking and accurate representation of the object itself; also, a pair of magic lanterns for producing the effect of dissolving views.
Spodomantic: Relating to spodomancy, or divination by means of ashes.
Scheme: To form a scheme or schemes.
Skullcap: A cap which fits the head closely; also, formerly, a headpiece of iron sewed inside of a cap for protection.
Sateen: A kind of dress goods made of cotton or woolen, with a glossy surface resembling satin.
&Verbar;Sternebra: One of the segments of the sternum.
Spray: To let fall in the form of spray.
Sandiver: A whitish substance which is cast up, as a scum, from the materials of glass in fusion, and, floating on the top, is skimmed off; -- called also glass gall.
Sprat: A small European herring (Clupea sprattus) closely allied to the common herring and the pilchard; -- called also garvie. The name is also applied to small herring of different kinds.
Startingly: By sudden fits or starts; spasmodically.
Solemnity: A rite or ceremony performed with religious reverence; religious or ritual ceremony; as, the solemnity of a funeral, a sacrament.
spaceport: a facility where vehicles are launched into space.
Supercrescence: That which grows upon another growing thing; a parasite.
Suppliant: One who supplicates; a humble petitioner; one who entreats submissively.
Silvering: The art or process of covering metals, wood, paper, glass, etc., with a thin film of metallic silver, or a substance resembling silver; also, the firm do laid on; as, the silvering of a glass speculum.
Stagecoach: A coach that runs regularly from one stage, station, or place to another, for the conveyance of passengers.
Smotheriness: The quality or state of being smothery.
Seeming: Appearance; show; semblance; fair appearance; speciousness.
Supracondylar: Situated above a condyle or condyles.
Sundial: An instrument to show the time of day by means of the shadow of a gnomon, or style, on a plate.
Sidepiece: The jamb, or cheek, of an opening in a wall, as of door or window.
&Verbar;Siphonia: A former name for a euphorbiaceous genus (Hevea) of South American trees, the principal source of caoutchouc.
Shieldtail: Any species of small burrowing snakes of the family Uropeltidæ, native of Ceylon and Southern Asia. They have a small mouth which can not be dilated.
Skinker: One who serves liquor; a tapster.
Soother: One who, or that which, soothes.
Scutcheoned: Emblazoned on or as a shield.
Scrambled eggs: Eggs of which the whites and yolks are stirred together while cooking, or eggs beaten slightly, often with a little milk, and stirred while cooking.
Sacking: Stout, coarse cloth of which sacks, bags, etc., are made.
Shell: To fall off, as a shell, crust, etc.
Shelf: A flat tablet or ledge of any material set horizontally at a distance from the floor, to hold objects of use or ornament.
Smooth-tongued: Having a smooth tongue; plausible; flattering.
Stern-wheeler: A steamboat having a stern wheel instead of side wheels.
Self-propagating: Propagating by one's self or by itself.
Subcaudal: Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the tail; as, the subcaudal, or chevron, bones.
Swaying: An injury caused by violent strains or by overloading; -- said of the backs of horses.
Sporophyte: In plants exhibiting alternation of generations, the generation which bears asexual spores; -- opposed to gametophyte. It is not clearly differentiated in the life cycle of the lower plants.
Salary: To pay, or agree to pay, a salary to; to attach salary to; as, to salary a clerk; to salary a position.
Scavenging: Act or process of expelling the exhaust gases from the cylinder by some special means, as, in many four-cycle engines, by utilizing the momentum of the exhaust gases in a long exhaust pipe.
Scarry: Like a scar, or rocky eminence; containing scars.
Supramaxillary: Situated over the lower jaw; as, the supramaxillary nerve.
Scenographic: Of or pertaining to scenography; drawn in perspective.
Summer: To keep or carry through the summer; to feed during the summer; as, to summer stock.
standoffish: Shy or distant in manner; cold; aloof; reserved; not friendly.
Somniloquy: A talking in sleep; the talking of one in a state of somnipathy.
&Verbar;Souffl\u00e9e: Filled with air by beating, and baked; as, an omelette soufflé.
Subject: To bring under control, power, or dominion; to make subject; to subordinate; to subdue.
Space cadet: a person who appears disconnected from reality, or living in his own world; -- sometimes used of people who are under the influence of mind-altering drugs.
Scorching: Burning; parching or shriveling with heat.
Structured: Having a definite organic structure; showing differentiation of parts.
Shuttle: To move backwards and forwards, like a shuttle.
Sclerenchyma: Vegetable tissue composed of short cells with thickened or hardened walls, as in nutshells and the gritty parts of a pear. See Sclerotic.
Subdominant: The fourth tone above, or fifth below, the tonic; -- so called as being under the dominant.
Sweeny: An atrophy of the muscles of the shoulder in horses; also, atrophy of any muscle in horses.
Sprigtail: The pintail duck; -- called also sprig, and spreet-tail.
Shipper: One who sends goods from one place to another not in the same city or town, esp. one who sends goods by water.
Shrapnel: Applied as an appellation to a kind of shell invented by Gen. H. Shrapnel of the British army.
Sheriffalty: The office or jurisdiction of sheriff. See Shrievalty.
Stagnation: The condition of being stagnant; cessation of flowing or circulation, as of a fluid; the state of being motionless; as, the stagnation of the blood; the stagnation of water or air; the stagnation of vapors.
Spotless: Without a spot; especially, free from reproach or impurity; pure; untainted; innocent; as, a spotless mind; spotless behavior.
Sailable: Capable of being sailed over; navigable; as, a sailable river.
Semitic: Of or pertaining to Shem or his descendants; belonging to that division of the Caucasian race which includes the Arabs, Jews, and related races.
spread-eagled: Being in a position with the arms and legs extended fully.
Shellbark: A species of hickory (Carya alba) whose outer bark is loose and peeling; a shagbark; also, its nut.
Subordinary: One of several heraldic bearings somewhat less common than an ordinary. See Ordinary.
Segmented: Divided into segments or joints; articulated.
Stigmatize: To mark with a stigma, or brand; as, the ancients stigmatized their slaves and soldiers.
Sketchy: Containing only an outline or rough form; being in the manner of a sketch; incomplete.
Surtax: To impose an additional tax on.
Sadiron: An iron for smoothing clothes; a flatiron.
Spasm: An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more muscles or muscular fibers.
Seigniory: The power or authority of a lord; dominion.
&Verbar;Schappe: A silk yarn or fabric made out of carded spun silk.
Syncope: An elision or retrenchment of one or more letters or syllables from the middle of a word; as, ne'er for never, ev'ry for every.
Synergetic: Working together; coöperating; as, synergetic muscles.
Screw-cutting: Adapted for forming a screw by cutting; as, a screw-cutting lathe.
Shoemaker: One whose occupation it is to make shoes and boots.
spitball: Paper chewed, and rolled into a ball, to be thrown as a missile; -- a childish prank.
Spirograph: An instrument for recording the respiratory movements, as the sphygmograph does those of the pulse.
Soda fountain: a counter at which people may sit and be served soda pop, ice cream, or light meals.  Such counters may be located for example in restaurants, ice cream shops, drugstores, departments stores.
Spirality: The quality or states of being spiral.
Spark coil: An induction coil used for producing sparks, esp. in an internal-combustion engine, wireless telegraph apparatus, etc.
Sclerogenous: Making or secreting a hard substance; becoming hard.
Stampede: To disperse by causing sudden fright, as a herd or drove of animals.
Scarmage: A slight contest; a skirmish. See Skirmish.
Systolic: Of or pertaining to systole, or contraction; contracting; esp., relating to the systole of the heart; as, systolic murmur.
Self-assertion: The act of asserting one's self, or one's own rights or claims; the quality of being self-asserting.
Squareness: The quality of being square; as, an instrument to try the squareness of work.
Schoolmistress: A woman who governs and teaches a school; a female school-teacher.
Shoebill: A large African wading bird (Balæniceps rex) allied to the storks and herons, and remarkable for its enormous broad swollen bill. It inhabits the valley of the White Nile. See Illust. (l.) of Beak.
Sire: To beget; to procreate; -- used of beasts, and especially of stallions.
Shim: A kind of shallow plow used in tillage to break the ground, and clear it of weeds.
Snaffle: To put a snaffle in the mouth of; to subject to the snaffle; to bridle.
Systemization: The act or process of systematizing; systematization.
Service entrance: an entrance for use of servants and those providing services, such as deliveries or repair work.
slip road: a short road giving access to an expressway
Sesquisalt: A salt derived from a sesquioxide base, or made up on the proportions of a sesqui compound.
Soapberry tree: Any tree of the genus Sapindus, esp. Sapindus saponaria, the fleshy part of whose fruit is used instead of soap in washing linen; -- also called soap tree.
Slough: To cast off; to discard as refuse.
Standpipe: A vertical pipe, open at the top, between a hydrant and a reservoir, to equalize the flow of water; also, a large vertical pipe, near a pumping engine, into which water is forced up, so as to give it sufficient head to rise to the required level at a distance.
Shire horse: One of an English breed of heavy draft horses believed to be descended largely from the horses used in war in the days of heavy armor. They are the  largest of the British draft breeds, and have long hair on the back of the cannons and fetlocks. Brown or bay with white on the face and legs is now the commonest color.
Short-spoken: Speaking in a quick or short manner; hence, gruff; curt.
Sarcode: A name applied by Dujardin in 1835 to the gelatinous material forming the bodies of the lowest animals; protoplasm.
Subtribe: A division of a tribe; a group of genera of a little lower rank than a tribe.
Sophist: One of a class of men who taught eloquence, philosophy, and politics in ancient Greece; especially, one of those who, by their fallacious but plausible reasoning, puzzled inquirers after truth, weakened the faith of the people, and drew upon themselves general hatred and contempt.
Sophism: The doctrine or mode of reasoning practiced by a sophist; hence, any fallacy designed to deceive.
Sublimable: Capable of being sublimed or sublimated.
Science: To cause to become versed in science; to make skilled; to instruct.
Schoolship: A vessel employed as a nautical training school, in which naval apprentices receive their education at the expense of the state, and are trained for service as sailors. Also, a vessel used as a reform school to which boys are committed by the courts to be disciplined, and instructed as mariners.
Strait-jacket: A dress of strong materials for restraining maniacs or those who are violently delirious. It has long sleeves, which are closed at the ends, confining the hands, and may be tied behind the back.
Shortness: The quality or state of being short; want of reach or extension; brevity; deficiency; as, the shortness of a journey; the shortness of the days in winter; the shortness of an essay; the shortness of the memory; a shortness of provisions; shortness of breath.
Shunt: A turning off to a side or short track, that the principal track may be left free.
Solacement: The act of solacing, or the state of being solaced; also, that which solaces.
Swanherd: One who tends or marks swans; as, the royal swanherd of England.
Solution: The act of separating the parts of any body, or the condition of undergoing a separation of parts; disruption; breach.
Sond: That which is sent; a message or messenger; hence, also, a visitation of providence; an affliction or trial.
Scepterless: Having no scepter; without authority; powerless; as, a scepterless king.
Sevenfold: Seven times as much or as often.
Snowcap: A very small humming bird (Microchæra albocoronata) native of New Grenada.
Slit: A long cut; a narrow opening; as, a slit in the ear.
Salter: One who makes, sells, or applies salt; one who salts meat or fish.
Sight-shot: Distance to which the sight can reach or be thrown.
Slip: The act of slipping; as, a slip on the ice.
Strychnine: A very poisonous alkaloid resembling brucine, obtained from various species of plants, especially from species of Loganiaceæ, as from the seeds of the St. Ignatius bean (Strychnos Ignatia) and from nux vomica. It is obtained as a white crystalline substance, having a very bitter acrid taste, and is employed in medicine (chiefly in the form of the sulphate) as a powerful neurotic stimulant. Called also strychnia, and formerly strychnina.
spanking: Moving with a quick, lively pace, or capable of so doing; dashing.
Sinew: To knit together, or make strong with, or as with, sinews.
Sporozoite: In certain Sporozoa, a small active, usually elongate, sickle-shaped or somewhat amœboid spore, esp. one of those produced by division of the passive spores into which the zygote divides. The sporozoites reproduce asexually.
Smectite: A hydrous silicate of alumina, of a greenish color, which, in certain states of humidity, appears transparent and almost gelatinous.
Sea trumpet: A great blackish seaweed of the Southern Ocean, having a hollow and expanding stem and a pinnate frond, sometimes twenty feet long.
Shut: The act or time of shutting; close; as, the shut of a door.
Sanation: The act of healing or curing.
Syncopal: Of or pertaining to syncope; resembling syncope.
Suitability: The quality or state of being suitable; suitableness.
Sharply: In a sharp manner,; keenly; acutely.
Shun: To avoid; to keep clear of; to get out of the way of; to escape from; to eschew; as, to shun rocks, shoals, vice.
Scops owl: Any one of numerous species of small owls of the genus Scops having ear tufts like those of the horned owls, especially the European scops owl (Scops giu), and the American screech owl (S. asio).
Sociable: A gathering of people for social purposes; an informal party or reception; as, a church sociable.
Slapjack: A flat batter cake cooked on a griddle; a flapjack; a griddlecake.
Savorless: Having no savor; destitute of smell or of taste; insipid.
Substantiate: To make to exist; to make real.
Slantwise: In an inclined direction; obliquely; slopingly.
Spiniferous: Producing spines; bearing thorns or spines; thorny; spiny.
Synecdochical: Expressed by synecdoche; implying a synecdoche.
Self-importance: An exaggerated estimate of one's own importance or merit, esp. as manifested by the conduct or manners; self-conceit.
Sentence: To pass or pronounce judgment upon; to doom; to condemn to punishment; to prescribe the punishment of.
Spriteful: See Sprightful, Sprightfully, Sprightliness, Sprightly, etc.
Shooty: Sprouting or coming up freely and regularly.
Suborner: One who suborns or procures another to take, a false oath; one who procures another to do a bad action.
Scrupulize: To perplex with scruples; to regard with scruples.
Serratirostral: Having a toothed bill, like that of a toucan.
Single-foot: To proceed by means of the single-foot, as a horse or other quadruped.
Synagogue: A congregation or assembly of Jews met for the purpose of worship, or the performance of religious rites.
&Verbar;Subbrachiales: A division of soft-finned fishes in which the ventral fins are situated beneath the pectorial fins, or nearly so.
Spathe: A special involucre formed of one leaf and inclosing a spadix, as in aroid plants and palms. See the Note under Bract, and Illust. of Spadix.
Soundness: The quality or state of being sound; as, the soundness of timber, of fruit, of the teeth, etc.; the soundness of reasoning or argument; soundness of faith.
Socinianize: To cause to conform to Socinianism; to regulate by, or imbue with, the principles of Socinianism.
Sustaltic: Mournful; -- said of a species of music among the ancient Greeks.
Sesquioxide: An oxide containing three atoms of oxygen with two atoms (or radicals) of some other substance; thus, alumina, Al2O3 is a sesquioxide.
&Verbar;Symphyla: An order of small apterous insects having an elongated body, with three pairs of thoracic and about nine pairs of abdominal legs. They are, in many respects, intermediate between myriapods and true insects.
Sulphocyanic: Of, pertaining to, derived from, or designating, a sulphacid, HSCN, analogous to cyanic acid, and obtained as a colorless deliquescent crystalline substance, having a bitter saline taste, and not poisonous.
Swiple: That part of a flail which strikes the grain in thrashing; a swingel.
Sloyd: Lit., skilled mechanical work, such as that required in wood carving; trade work; hence, a system (usually called the sloyd system) of manual training in the practical use of the tools and materials used in the trades, and of instruction in the making and use of the plans and specifications connected with trade work. The  sloyd system derives its name from the fact that it was adopted or largely developed from a similar Swedish system, in which wood carving was a chief feature. Its purpose is not only to afford practical skill in some trade, but also to develop the pupils mentally and physically.
Supersphenoidal: Situated above, or on the dorsal side of, the body of the sphenoid bone.
Smeller: One who smells, or perceives by the sense of smell; one who gives out smell.
Straddling: Applied to spokes when they are arranged alternately in two circles in the hub. See Straddle, v. i., and Straddle, v. t., 3.
Scrambler: One who scrambles; one who climbs on all fours.
Soybean oil: an oil obtained from the soybean (Glycine max), rich in protein, fats, sterols, and phospholipids, used as a food and in paints and varnishes and in various industrial applications; -- called also soya oil.  It is also used in preparing the sauce called soy or soy sauce.
&Verbar;Saltigrad\u00e6: A tribe of spiders including those which lie in wait and leap upon their prey; the leaping spiders; called also Salticidae.
Subway: An underground way or gallery; especially, a passage under a street, in which water mains, gas mains, telegraph wires, etc., are conducted.
Sympodial: Composed of superposed branches in such a way as to imitate a simple axis; as, a sympodial stem.
Senegin: A substance extracted from the rootstock of the Polygala Senega (Seneca root), and probably identical with polygalic acid.
Shunter: A person employed to shunt cars from one track to another.
Sewen: A British trout usually regarded as a variety (var. Cambricus) of the salmon trout.
&Verbar;Schisma: An interval equal to half a comma.
Solacious: Affording solace; as, a solacious voice.
Suborn: To procure or cause to take a false oath amounting to perjury, such oath being actually taken.
Strain: The act of straining, or the state of being strained.
Shoreless: Having no shore or coast; of indefinite or unlimited extent; as, a shoreless ocean.
Shopbook: A book in which a tradesman keeps his accounts.
Salting: The act of sprinkling, impregnating, or furnishing, with salt.
Sonification: The act of producing sound, as the stridulation of insects.
Sirenical: Like, or appropriate to, a siren; fascinating; deceptive.
Self-torture: The act of inflicting pain on one's self; pain inflicted on one's self.
Subsidy: Support; aid; coöperation; esp., extraordinary aid in money rendered to the sovereign or to a friendly power.
&Verbar;Samovar: A metal urn used in Russia for making tea. It is filled with water, which is heated by charcoal placed in a pipe, with chimney attached, which passes through the urn.
Solenoid: An electrodynamic spiral having the conjuctive wire turned back along its axis, so as to neutralize that component of the effect of the current which is due to the length of the spiral, and reduce the whole effect to that of a series of equal and parallel circular currents. When traversed by a current the solenoid exhibits polarity and attraction or repulsion, like a magnet.
Superfrontal: A cloth which is placed over the top of an altar, and often hangs down a few inches over the frontal.
&Verbar;Se\u00f1ora: A Spanish title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also, a lady.
Shoppish: Having the appearance or qualities of a shopkeeper, or shopman.
Sandre: A Russian fish (Lucioperca sandre) which yields a valuable oil, called sandre oil, used in the preparation of caviar.
Spectroscopist: One who investigates by means of a spectroscope; one skilled in the use of the spectroscope.
&Verbar;Serpula: Any one of numerous species of tubicolous annelids of the genus Serpula and allied genera of the family Serpulidæ. They secrete a calcareous tube, which is usually irregularly contorted, but is sometimes spirally coiled. The worm has a wreath of plumelike and often bright-colored gills around its head, and usually an operculum to close the aperture of its tube when it retracts.
Stomatoscope: An apparatus for examining the interior of the mouth.
Saloop: An aromatic drink prepared from sassafras bark and other ingredients, at one time much used in London.
Saloon: A spacious and elegant apartment for the reception of company or for works of art; a hall of reception, esp. a hall for public entertainments or amusements; a large room or parlor; as, the saloon of a steamboat.
&Verbar;Spaghetti: A variety or macaroni made in tubes of small diameter.
Split stitch: A stitch used in stem work to produce a fine line, much used in old church embroidery to work the hands and faces of figures.
space shuttle: a reusable vehicle that can carry people or objects into orbit around the earth and return to be used again for subsequent trips; -- distinguished from rockets that are used only once.  The present (1997) American space shuttle is a manned vehicle, having an external fuel tank that is expendable and not re-used.
Self-repellency: The quality or state of being self-repelling.
Syndesmology: That part of anatomy which treats of ligaments.
Sinter: Dross, as of iron; the scale which files from iron when hammered; -- applied as a name to various minerals.
Subtile: Thin; not dense or gross; rare; as, subtile air; subtile vapor; a subtile medium.
Starlight: Lighted by the stars, or by the stars only; as, a starlight night.
Saint-Simonianism: The principles, doctrines, or practice of the Saint-Simonians; -- called also Saint- Simonism.
Stoppage: The act of stopping, or arresting progress, motion, or action; also, the state of being stopped; as, the stoppage of the circulation of the blood; the stoppage of commerce.
Singultous: Relating to, or affected with, hiccough.
Southward: The southern regions or countries; the south.
Steatitic: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, steatite; containing or resembling steatite.
Styracin: A white crystalline tasteless substance extracted from gum storax, and consisting of a salt of cinnamic acid with cinnamic alcohol.
Sixfold: Six times repeated; six times as much or as many.
Strategic: Of or pertaining to strategy; effected by artifice.
Squeaker: One who, or that which, squeaks.
Sucker: To form suckers; as, corn suckers abundantly.
Summerliness: The quality or state of being like summer.
Snow: To scatter like snow; to cover with, or as with, snow.
Sucken: The jurisdiction of a mill, or that extent of ground astricted to it, the tenants of which are bound to bring their grain thither to be ground.
Scribble: Hasty or careless writing; a writing of little value; a scrawl; as, a hasty scribble.
Slimness: The quality or state of being slim.
Suchwise: In a such a manner; so.
Subquadrate: Nearly or approximately square; almost square.
Sufficiently: To a sufficient degree; to a degree that answers the purpose, or gives content; enough; as, we are sufficiently supplied with food; a man sufficiently qualified for the discharge of his official duties.
Sweet-sop: A kind of custard apple (Anona squamosa). See under Custard.
Sediment: The matter which subsides to the bottom, from water or any other liquid; settlings; lees; dregs.
&Verbar;Solifug\u00e6: A division of arachnids having large, powerful fangs and a segmented abdomen; -- called also Solpugidea, and Solpugides.
Succorable: Capable of being succored or assisted; admitting of relief.
Succinic: Pertaining to, or derived from, amber; specif., designating a dibasic acid, C&unr_;H&unr_;.(CO&unr_;H)&unr_;, first obtained by the dry distillation of amber. It is found in a number of plants, as in lettuce and wormwood, and is also produced artificially as a white crystalline substance having a slightly acid taste.
Salmonet: A salmon of small size; a samlet.
Siredon: The larval form of any salamander while it still has external gills; especially, one of those which, like the axolotl (Amblystoma Mexicanum), sometimes lay eggs while in this larval state, but which under more favorable conditions lose their gills and become normal salamanders. See also Axolotl.
Subindicate: To indicate by signs or hints; to indicate imperfectly.
Subliminal: Existing in the mind, but below the surface or threshold of consciousness; that is, existing as feeling rather than as clear ideas.
Sifilet: The six-shafted bird of paradise. See Paradise bird, under Paradise.
Seljuckian: A member of the family of Seljuk; an adherent of that family, or subject of its government;
Scoriaceous: Of or pertaining to scoria; like scoria or the recrement of metals; partaking of the nature of scoria.
Salad: A preparation of vegetables, as lettuce, celery, water cress, onions, etc., usually dressed with salt, vinegar, oil, and spice, and eaten for giving a relish to other food; as, lettuce salad; tomato salad, etc.
Sewerage: The construction of a sewer or sewers.
Sunshiny: Bright with the rays of the sun; clear, warm, or pleasant; as, a sunshiny day.
Sicken: To become sick; to fall into disease.
Saltcat: A mixture of salt, coarse meal, lime, etc., attractive to pigeons.
single-handed: Having but one hand, or one workman; also, alone; unassisted.
Sucrose: A common variety of sugar found in the juices of many plants, as the sugar cane, sorghum, sugar maple, beet root, etc. It is extracted as a sweet, white crystalline substance which is valuable as a food product, and, being antiputrescent, is largely used in the preservation of fruit. Called also saccharose, cane sugar, etc.  At one time the term was used by extension, for any one of the class of isomeric substances (as lactose, maltose, etc.) of which sucrose proper is the type; however this usage is now archaic.
Sustainable: Capable of being sustained or maintained; as, the action is not sustainable.
Sdeath: An exclamation expressive of impatience or anger.
Subminister: To be subservient; to be useful.
&Verbar;Synovia: A transparent, viscid, lubricating fluid which contains mucin and secreted by synovial membranes; synovial fluid.
Sug: A kind of worm or larva.
Sectator: A follower; a disciple; an adherent to a sect.
Sue: To seek by request; to make application; to petition; to entreat; to plead.
Sun: To expose to the sun's rays; to warm or dry in the sun; as, to sun cloth; to sun grain.
Section: The act of cutting, or separation by cutting; as, the section of bodies.
Saponification: The act, process, or result, of soap making; conversion into soap; specifically (Chem.), the decomposition of fats and other ethereal salts by alkalies; as, the saponification of ethyl acetate.
Sylvan: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained together with furfuran (tetrol) by the distillation of pine wood; -- called also methyl tetrol, or methyl furfuran.
Spoonbill: Any one of several species of wading birds of the genera Ajaja and Platalea, and allied genera, in which the long bill is broadly expanded and flattened at the tip.
Sanguinolent: Tinged or mingled with blood; bloody; as, sanguinolent sputa.
Self-determining: Capable of self-determination; as, the self-determining power of will.
Seerhand: A kind of muslin of a texture between nainsook and mull.
Sherd: A fragment; -- now used only in composition, as in potsherd. See Shard.
Sporosac: A hydrozoan reproductive zooid or gonophore which does not become medusoid in form or structure. See Illust. under Athecata.
Supposititious: Fraudulently substituted for something else; not being what is purports to be; not genuine; spurious; counterfeit; as, a supposititious child; a supposititious writing.
Submission: The act of submitting; the act of yielding to power or authority; surrender of the person and power to the control or government of another; obedience; compliance.
Sanctify: To make sacred or holy; to set apart to a holy or religious use; to consecrate by appropriate rites; to hallow.
Scabbiness: The quality or state of being scabby.
Scoop: to report a story first, before (a rival); to get a scoop, or a beat, on (a rival); -- used commonly in the passive; as, we were scooped.  Also used in certain situations in scientific research, when one scientist or team of scientists reports their results before another who is working on the same problem.
Simpai: A long-tailed monkey (Semnopitchecus melalophus) native of Sumatra. It has a crest of black hair. The forehead and cheeks are fawn color, the upper parts tawny and red, the under parts white. Called also black-crested monkey, and sinpæ.
Scoot: To walk fast; to go quickly; to run hastily away.
Stound: A vessel for holding small beer.
Supercilious: Lofty with pride; haughty; dictatorial; overbearing; arrogant; as, a supercilious officer; asupercilious air; supercilious behavior.
Saltmouth: A wide-mouthed bottle with glass stopper for holding chemicals, especially crystallized salts.
slip ring: a metal ring on a rotating part of a machine to provide a continuous electrical connection through brushes on stationary contacts
Stereoscopist: One skilled in the use or construction of stereoscopes.
Skid: To slide without rotating; -- said of a wheel held from turning while the vehicle moves onward.
Supra-auricular: Situated above the ear coverts, or auriculars; -- said of certain feathers of birds.
Semite: One belonging to the Semitic race. Also used adjectively.
Slabbery: Like, or covered with, slabber or slab; slippery; sloppy.
Stannoso-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting relation to stannous compounds, or connection with stannous compounds.
Shock-headed: Having a thick and bushy head of hair.
Shellfish: Any aquatic animal whose external covering consists of a shell, either testaceous, as in oysters, clams, and other mollusks, or crustaceous, as in lobsters and crabs.
Scorify: To reduce to scoria or slag; specifically, in assaying, to fuse so as to separate the gangue and earthy material, with borax, lead, soda, etc., thus leaving the gold and silver in a lead button; hence, to separate from, or by means of, a slag.
Spurtle: To spurt or shoot in a scattering manner.
Senatorial: Of or pertaining to a senator, or a senate; becoming to a senator, or a senate; as, senatorial duties; senatorial dignity.
Springhalt: A kind of lameness in a horse. See Stringhalt.
Sidle: To go or move with one side foremost; to move sidewise; as, to sidle through a crowd or narrow opening.
Spaniard: A native or inhabitant of Spain.
Scentful: Full of scent or odor; odorous.
Steppe: One of the vast plains in Southeastern Europe and in Asia, generally elevated, and free from wood, analogous to many of the prairies in Western North America. See Savanna.
Speary: Having the form of a spear.
Speakable: Capable of being spoken; fit to be spoken.
Self-fertilization: The fertilization of a flower by pollen from the same flower and without outer aid; autogamy.
Subvert: To overthrow anything from the foundation; to be subversive.
Semipellucidity: The quality or state of being imperfectly transparent.
Smally: In a small quantity or degree; with minuteness.
Scythe: To cut with a scythe; to cut off as with a scythe; to mow.
Stoic: Of or pertaining to the Stoics; resembling the Stoics or their doctrines.
Siphonostomatous: Having the front edge of the aperture of the shell prolonged in the shape of a channel for the protection of the siphon; -- said of certain gastropods.
Scaturient: Gushing forth; full to overflowing; effusive.
Stupor: Great diminution or suspension of sensibility; suppression of sense or feeling; lethargy.
Seabeard: A green seaweed (Cladophora rupestris) growing in dense tufts.
Stem-winding: Wound by mechanism connected with the stem; as, a stem-winding watch.
Suggestion: The act of suggesting; presentation of an idea.
&Verbar;Strobila: A form of the larva of certain Discophora in a state of development succeeding the scyphistoma. The body of the strobila becomes elongated, and subdivides transversely into a series of lobate segments which eventually become ephyræ, or young medusæ.
Substyle: A right line on which the style, or gnomon, of a dial is erected; being the common section of the face of the dial and a plane perpendicular to it passing through the style.
Soldanel: A plant of the genus Soldanella, low Alpine herbs of the Primrose family.
Self-distrust: Want of confidence in one' self; diffidence.
&Verbar;Scamillus: A sort of second plinth or block, below the bases of Ionic and Corinthian columns, generally without moldings, and of smaller size horizontally than the pedestal.
&Verbar;Stylommatophora: A division of Pulmonata in which the eyes are situated at the tips of the tentacles. It includes the common land snails and slugs. See Illust. under Snail.
Superposable: Capable of being superposed, as one figure upon another.
Subaction: The act of reducing to any state, as of mixing two bodies combletely.
Subordinate: To place in a lower order or class; to make or consider as of less value or importance; as, to subordinate one creature to another.
slip carriage: a railway car at the end of the train; it can be detached without stopping the train.
Swimmingness: Act or state of swimming; suffusion.
Sinistrality: The quality or state of being sinistral.
Scallion: A kind of small onion (Allium Ascalonicum), native of Palestine; the eschalot, or shallot.
Sinecure: To put or place in a sinecure.
Shiver: The act of shivering or trembling.
Sootiness: The quality or state of being sooty; fuliginousness.
Spartan: Of or pertaining to Sparta, especially to ancient Sparta; hence, hardy; undaunted; as, Spartan souls; Spartan bravey.
Socman: One who holds lands or tenements by socage; a socager.
Systemize: To reduce to system; to systematize.
Stellionate: Any fraud not distinguished by a more special name; -- chiefly applied to sales of the same property to two different persons, or selling that for one's own which belongs to another, etc.
Sticcado: An instrument consisting of small bars of wood, flat at the bottom and rounded at the top, and resting on the edges of a kind of open box. They are unequal in size, gradually increasing from the smallest to the largest, and are tuned to the diatonic scale. The tones are produced by striking the pieces of wood with hard balls attached to flexible sticks.
Soggy: Filled with water; soft with moisture; sodden; soaked; wet; as, soggy land or timber.
Spherule: A little sphere or spherical body; as, quicksilver, when poured upon a plane, divides itself into a great number of minute spherules.
Sparrow: One of many species of small singing birds of the family Fringilligæ, having conical bills, and feeding chiefly on seeds. Many sparrows are called also finches, and buntings. The common sparrow, or house sparrow, of Europe (Passer domesticus) is noted for its familiarity, its voracity, its attachment to its young, and its fecundity. See House sparrow, under House.
Self-condemnation: Condemnation of one's self by one's own judgment.
Site: The place where anything is fixed; situation; local position; as, the site of a city or of a house.
Shiftiness: The quality or state of being shifty.
Shooting: Of or pertaining to shooting; for shooting; darting.
Stereometer: An instrument for measuring the solid contents of a body, or the capacity of a vessel; a volumenometer.
Sunfish: A very large oceanic plectognath fish (Mola mola, Mola rotunda, or Orthagoriscus mola) having a broad body and a truncated tail.
